('63', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. MAY THE OLD MAN LIVE FOR A HUNDRED YEARS 1
('63', 0, 2, 3, 88) [January 18, 1934] 2
('63', 0, 3, 4, 109) You would add to the glory of Gujarat and its people by cele brating the eighty first birthday of Abbas Saheb.
('63', 0, 3, 5, 220) No one can compete with Abbas Saheb in zeal, self sacrifice and generosity.
('63', 0, 3, 6, 296) I came in contact with him during the inquiry regarding the Punjab Martial Law.
('63', 0, 3, 7, 376) Knowing that he belonged to the Tyabji family and had been a Congress worker for a long time, I suggested his name for the Committee.
('63', 0, 3, 8, 510) Though a staunch Mussalman, he can live with a staunch Hindu like his own bloodbrother.
('63', 0, 3, 9, 598) Among such Hindus I am as one of his family.
('63', 0, 3, 10, 643) His secrets are not unknown to me.
('63', 0, 3, 11, 678) Everyone in his family contributes to the national service according to his or her capacity.
('63', 0, 3, 12, 771) May the old man live for a hundred years!
('63', 0, 3, 13, 813) [From Gujarati] Gujarati, 28 1 1934
('63', 0, 4, 14, 849) 2. FRAGMENT OF LETTER TO JIVANJI D. DESAI
('63', 0, 5, 15, 891) January 18, 1934 PS.
('63', 0, 5, 16, 912) I was forgetting one thing completely.
('63', 0, 5, 17, 951) I cannot give the right decision on the question of closing of the Prakashan Mandir.
('63', 0, 5, 18, 1036) The matter was discussed in my presence.
('63', 0, 5, 19, 1077) I had expressed the view that, if some people took up the task of propagating Gandhi literature, we could leave it to them and let those who wished to court arrest do so.
('63', 0, 5, 20, 1248) We do not wish to stop anyone from courting arrest so that we can carry on the work of publication.
('63', 0, 5, 21, 1348) But the converse of this also may be worth considering.
('63', 0, 5, 22, 1404) We can decide about that only after taking into account all the relevant factors.
('63', 0, 5, 23, 1486) I cannot judge about them from this distance.
('63', 0, 5, 24, 1532) You should, therefore, pay no attention to my opinion but do what all of you think is best.
('63', 0, 5, 25, 1624) If there are strong differences of opinion among you, send me the views of all together with their reasons.
('63', 0, 5, 26, 1732) I shall then be able to give the final decision.

('63', 1, 4, 9, 2419) 3. SPEECH AT PALLURUTHY 1
('63', 1, 5, 10, 2445) January 18, 1934 I am thankful to the organizers for having taken me through the school building and the temple.
('63', 1, 5, 11, 2558) I am thankful also for the frankness with which your opinion is expressed in this address.
('63', 1, 5, 12, 2649) I am glad that this address is really more in the nature of advice to me than anything else.
('63', 1, 5, 13, 2742) The best way to reciprocate is to tell you frankly what views I hold.
('63', 1, 5, 14, 2812) You have advised me not to conduct this campaign in the name of Hindu religion.
('63', 1, 5, 15, 2892) I am very sorry I cannot endorse your advice.
('63', 1, 5, 16, 2938) It is wholly wrong to say or even think that this movement is conducted in order to consolidate Hindu religion or consolidate anything.
('63', 1, 5, 17, 3074) If I commit sin and want to do penance, I do it not to consolidate myself but to purify myself.
('63', 1, 5, 18, 3170) For me, this untouch ability is a sin that Hinduism commits against the untouchables.
('63', 1, 5, 19, 3256) It becomes and remains a sin inasmuch as the savarna Hindus consider the untouchables, whom I now call Harijans, as untouchable Hindus.
('63', 1, 5, 20, 3392) Therefore I can only call this a movement of reformation and purifi cation in Hinduism.
('63', 1, 5, 21, 3480) I become a debtor only to those who call them selves Hindus.
('63', 1, 5, 22, 3541) I do not become a debtor to those who have nothing to do with Hinduism.
('63', 1, 5, 23, 3613) You just now took me to the temple and there showed me everything including the worship that is done according to the Hindu traditions.
('63', 1, 5, 24, 3749) If your form of worship is the same as mine, my heart naturally goes out to you.
('63', 1, 5, 25, 3830) But if you say you are no longer Hindus and you have adopted some other faith, my obligation to you as Hindus ceases.
('63', 1, 5, 26, 3948) My obligation to you as fellow beings, of course,
('63', 1, 6, 27, 3998) 1 This was in reply to the address presented on behalf of Shri Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam.
('63', 1, 6, 28, 4095) The speech was also reported in brief in The Hindu, 20 1 1934.
('63', 2, 0, 1, 4158) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 3
('63', 2, 1, 2, 4200) does not cease.
('63', 2, 1, 3, 4216) There is that fine and necessary distinction which you cannot get over.
('63', 2, 1, 4, 4288) God has made Nature so that we are one in many.
('63', 2, 1, 5, 4336) There are different faiths in this world.
('63', 2, 1, 6, 4378) I believe them all to be true.
('63', 2, 1, 7, 4409) But so long as there are different faiths and we belong to one faith, there are special obligations attached to that faith.
('63', 2, 1, 8, 4533) That does not mean that I would not work for Mussalman fellow men or Christian fellow men or Parsis or Jews or any other.
('63', 2, 1, 9, 4655) But I can realize unity with no one if I loose my foot from the platform on which I am standing.
('63', 2, 1, 10, 4752) I believe in God much more than I believe in the fact that you and I are alive and that I am speaking to you.
('63', 2, 1, 11, 4862) I may give you an illustration of what I mean.
('63', 2, 1, 12, 4909) In appearance, I am speaking to you and you are listening to me.
('63', 2, 1, 13, 4974) In reality, your hearts and minds may be somewhere else.
('63', 2, 1, 14, 5031) My heart also may be somewhere else and my mind may be in something else.
('63', 2, 1, 15, 5105) Then my speaking or your listening would be a deception.
('63', 2, 1, 16, 5162) Therefore my speaking and your listening, though they are an appearance, may not be a reality.
('63', 2, 1, 17, 5257) But my heart, word and deed are pledged to the Being called God, Allah, Rama or Krishna.
('63', 2, 1, 18, 5346) You will now easily recognize that it is true when I say that my belief in God is far more a reality to me than this meeting which I am addressing.
('63', 2, 1, 19, 5494) But I must not take you into deeper waters.
('63', 2, 1, 20, 5538) The sum and substance of what I say is this.
('63', 2, 1, 21, 5583) If I appear to you as a Hindu, I do so in order to discharge an obligation I owe to you.
('63', 2, 1, 22, 5672) I am supposed to have been born in a savarna family.
('63', 2, 1, 23, 5725) As a savarna Hindu, when I see that there are some Hindus called avarnas, it offends my sense of justice and truth, and it cuts me to the quick.
('63', 2, 1, 24, 5870) It is an abhorrent thought to me that in the faith in which I was born and nurtured there should be a single human being considered lower than myself.
('63', 2, 1, 25, 6021) Therefore I have become an untouchable by choice, and if I discover that Hindu Shastras really countenance untouchability as it is seen today, I will renounce and denounce Hinduism.
('63', 2, 1, 26, 6203) As a student of Hindu religion and of comparative religions, I see no such warrant in Hindu Shastras.
('63', 2, 1, 27, 6305) But Hindus today practise untouchability.
('63', 2, 1, 28, 6347) Therefore it becomes my duty to warn them against that evil.
('63', 2, 1, 29, 6408) If, however, you embrace any other faith, or have no faith whatsoever, I can have no appeal for you.
('63', 2, 1, 30, 6509) You cease to be untouchable Hindus.
('63', 2, 1, 31, 6545) If you want to cut adrift from Hinduism, you are absolutely free to do so.
('63', 2, 1, 32, 6620) I cannot hold you to Hinduism by force.
('63', 2, 1, 33, 6660) I can only hold you by the force of love.
('63', 2, 1, 34, 6702) I may so endear myself to you by my service that you may feel that,
('63', 3, 0, 1, 6770) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 3, 1, 2, 6810) although you have been classed as untouchables by certain Hindus, there is no untouchability in Hinduism.
('63', 3, 1, 3, 6916) It may be in God’s dis pensation that I have come to you too late.
('63', 3, 1, 4, 6983) But God will not punish me for that, because He knows that for the last fifty years I have rebelled against untouchability.
('63', 3, 1, 5, 7107) Now, I think, you fairly understand what I stand for.
('63', 3, 1, 6, 7161) The movement is not anti Mussalman, anti Christian or anti Jew.
('63', 3, 1, 7, 7225) It is anti humbug.
('63', 3, 1, 8, 7244) That is what I stand for.
('63', 3, 1, 9, 7270) A concluding remark as to the use of the word ‘Harijan’.
('63', 3, 1, 10, 7327) It is not a word of my coinage.
('63', 3, 1, 11, 7359) It was suggested by an untouchable.
('63', 3, 1, 12, 7395) Untouchability is a hateful and detestable thing; but, so long as one has to talk of those who are considered today untouchables, it is surely better to use an unoffending name than an offending one.
('63', 3, 1, 13, 7595) I give you an illustration from life.
('63', 3, 1, 14, 7633) In South Africa, Indians were not called Indians but coolies.
('63', 3, 1, 15, 7695) I was called not an Indian lawyer but a coolie lawyer.
('63', 3, 1, 16, 7750) To the Whites, the words coolie and Indian were synonymous.
('63', 3, 1, 17, 7810) I protested against the word coolie, just as this untouchable brother protested against the word untouchable, and I suggested that the word Indians should be used to designate the inhabitants of India.
('63', 3, 1, 18, 8012) So long as men were known by their countries, some name was necessary to signify the inhabitants of India ‘Indians’ was an unoffending desig nation.
('63', 3, 1, 19, 8161) Precisely in the same manner the word ‘Harijan’ is used.
('63', 3, 1, 20, 8218) Lastly, let me in all humility tell you that I have not come to help those who feel their strength.
('63', 3, 1, 21, 8318) I know that no word of offence which you use against the savarna Hindus will be too strong.
('63', 3, 1, 22, 8410) I know also that, if your resentment expresses itself in acts, savarna Hindus will deserve those acts.
('63', 3, 1, 23, 8513) But I know infinitely more than you do what Harijans are, where they live, what their number is and to what con dition they have been reduced.
('63', 3, 1, 24, 8656) You can speak of this place, possibly of the whole of Cochin, possibly of Cochin and Travancore, still more possibly of Malabar.
('63', 3, 1, 25, 8785) But I claim to be able to speak of Harijans from the North to the South, the East and the West of India, and I know their abject position.
('63', 3, 1, 26, 8924) My only business is, if it is at all possible, to lift those who are in the mire.
('63', 3, 1, 27, 9006) I want to do it because I want to lift myself.
('63', 3, 1, 28, 9053) With their abjectness I feel myself also abject.
('63', 3, 1, 29, 9102) I know that, if Hindus were freed from the coil of untouchability, you would find that all the corroding distinctions, not between Hindus and Hindus only, but also between Hindus and non Hindus, will disappear as if by a magic touch.
('63', 3, 1, 30, 9336) I have delivered during the brief period at my disposal the whole of my message.
('63', 3, 1, 31, 9417) The choice is entirely yours.
('63', 3, 1, 32, 9447) You may accept
('63', 4, 0, 1, 9462) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 5
('63', 4, 1, 2, 9504) this reparation or it is perfectly open to you to reject it.
('63', 4, 1, 3, 9565) If you still fail to understand me, I can only pray in the lines of a celebrated English hymn:
('63', 4, 2, 4, 9660) We shall know each other better
('63', 4, 3, 5, 9692) When the mists have rolled away.
('63', 4, 3, 6, 9725) Harijan, 2 2 1934
('63', 4, 4, 7, 9743) 4. SPEECH AT THURAVUR 1
('63', 4, 5, 8, 9767) January 18, 1934
('63', 4, 6, 9, 9784) In the course of his reply, he asked the audience if they knew anything about the story of the purse presented to him then.
('63', 4, 6, 10, 9908) The real collection, he said, was Rs. 420, out of which a sum of Rs. 195 was reported to him to be expenses for the reception.
('63', 4, 6, 11, 10035) The purse was only the balance of the collection.
('63', 4, 6, 12, 10085) That meant that nearly 50 per cent of the collection was devoted to expenses in feeding him and entertaining him otherwise.
('63', 4, 6, 13, 10209) Neither they nor he could justify those expenses.
('63', 4, 6, 14, 10259) The Reception Committee should have spent the amount they collected as a miser.
('63', 4, 6, 15, 10339) They should render to him an account of their expenses.
('63', 4, 6, 16, 10395) Till recently, he was not able to go through the accounts of each of the districts on account of great pressure of work he was in.
('63', 4, 6, 17, 10526) But immediately he got the time, he began to enquire.
('63', 4, 6, 18, 10580) He had received a rough account of the expenses of this place.
('63', 4, 6, 19, 10643) They collected Rs. 420 and spent Rs. 159 out of it for his reception.
('63', 4, 6, 20, 10713) At this rate, he would have to tour with his food in his pocket as had been his wont some time ago.
('63', 4, 6, 21, 10813) The cost of that pandal came up to Rs. 80. Of course, a portion of that amount could be realized by the sale proceeds of the pandal after the function was over.
('63', 4, 6, 22, 10974) The pandal was an avoidable item.
('63', 4, 6, 23, 11008) There was no justification whatever to spend a single pie from the Harijan purse for the pandal and other reception luxuries.
('63', 4, 6, 24, 11134) Another item was Rs. 25 spent for volunteers.
('63', 4, 6, 25, 11180) Another item was Rs. 20 spent on printing.
('63', 4, 6, 26, 11223) The last two items of expenditure were Rs. 35 for conveyance and Rs. 35 for miscellaneous.
('63', 4, 6, 27, 11314) The last item was the last straw to break the camel’s back.
('63', 4, 6, 28, 11374) It may be that all these amounts were spent legitimately.
('63', 4, 6, 29, 11432) He meant no reflection at all on the integrity of the workers, but it reflected indeed on the want of forethought or want of consideration for the cause on their part.
('63', 4, 6, 30, 11600) They had not thought of the religious nature of the programme, they had not thought of the reparation to be made to the Harijans.
('63', 4, 6, 31, 11730) Reparation meant reparation and nothing else.
('63', 4, 6, 32, 11776) The savarna Hindus should consider themselves as the debtors of the Harijans; those who did not feel as debtors should be deemed to be not in sympathy with the cause.
('63', 4, 6, 33, 11943) He did not wish to receive anything from those who had no sympathy for this cause.
('63', 4, 7, 34, 12026) The Hindu, 21 1 1934
('63', 4, 8, 35, 12047) 1 This was in reply to addresses of welcome and a purse of Rs. 225.

('63', 5, 1, 2, 12155) 5. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ERNAKULAM
('63', 5, 2, 3, 12194) January 18, 1934
('63', 5, 3, 4, 12211) Mahatmaji, replying to the address 1, said that he saw the destruction of Hindu religion and Hindu dharma in the custom of untouchability.
('63', 5, 3, 5, 12350) The Hindus brought into being the untouchable Harijans and later proclaimed they were created by God.
('63', 5, 3, 6, 12452) The Shastras did not sanction caste or untouchability which was the root cause of all the evils the country was subject to.
('63', 5, 3, 7, 12576) He did not want to fight with the Christians or Muslims for greater rights for the Hindus.
('63', 5, 3, 8, 12667) It was a movement of self purification for the Hindus.
('63', 5, 3, 9, 12722) Cochin could be converted to a punyakshetra.
('63', 5, 3, 10, 12767) They had the seashore on one side and the rishis had proclaimed such tracts to be holy.
('63', 5, 3, 11, 12855) Suryanarayan was shedding his radiance from above, and that was the best time for them to take a vow that they would consider no one inferior to them.
('63', 5, 3, 12, 13006) He felt deeply grieved that in such States like Cochin and Travancore ruled by far seeing, enlightened and benevolent Hindu rulers, whose ideals and simplicity of life were remarkable, untouchability should have found a place.
('63', 5, 3, 13, 13233) It was not the duty of rulers alone to get rid of the evil.
('63', 5, 3, 14, 13293) As long as they had in their hearts the thought of untouchability, the rulers were helpless.
('63', 5, 3, 15, 13386) He did not care very much for their addresses and presents.
('63', 5, 3, 16, 13446) What was required was their wholehearted co operation in the removal of the curse of untouchability.
('63', 5, 4, 17, 13547) The Hindu, 20 1 1934
('63', 5, 5, 18, 13568) 6. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ALLEPPEY 2
('63', 5, 6, 19, 13608) January 18, 1934
('63', 5, 7, 20, 13625) In the course of his reply, Gandhiji thanked the temple authorities for placing the temple premises at the disposal of the Reception Committee and he was thankful that the temple premises being in the possession of the Thiyyas or the Ezhavas of the locality, there was no trouble on that score.
('63', 5, 7, 21, 13920) Then about the preference of a reply in English, Gandhiji opined that the Alleppey public was not singular in the choice of that language.
('63', 5, 7, 22, 14059) He added: You want to examine me and know how well or ill I speak in English.
('63', 5, 7, 23, 14137) I do not pretend to be a scholar of the English language.
('63', 5, 8, 24, 14195) 1 Presented by the Municipality 2 The meeting, according to The Hindu which also published a brief report, was held at the Kidangamparambu Maidan.
('63', 5, 8, 25, 14342) Addresses of welcome on behalf of the public of Alleppey, Hindi Premi Mandal and Kudumbi Association were presented to Gandhiji.
('63', 5, 8, 26, 14471) Gandhiji began the speech in Hindi but had to switch over to English on public demand.
('63', 6, 0, 1, 14558) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 7
('63', 6, 1, 2, 14600) spite of my great love for the English tongue and English people, I have failed to master that language up to now.
('63', 6, 1, 3, 14715) I commit mistakes in spelling the English words and my English idioms have often been inaccurate, the English words I use are not always appropriate.
('63', 6, 1, 4, 14865) How can I do otherwise?
('63', 6, 1, 5, 14889) I learnt the English language not to become a scholar but to convey my thoughts.
('63', 6, 1, 6, 14970) I consider myself to be a practical man and use the English language as occasion arises to serve my pur pose.
('63', 6, 1, 7, 15080) If I speak in Hindustani, the audience will appreciate my speeches more.
('63', 6, 1, 8, 15153) Anyhow, often I yield to the wishes of the English educated people since I want them to work for me.
('63', 6, 1, 9, 15254) If I were to take a referendum to know the mind of the audience, I know they would record a thumping majority for the Hindi language.
('63', 6, 1, 10, 15388) Hundreds of words are common to Malayalam and Hindi.
('63', 6, 1, 11, 15441) I follow my Malay alam translators rather closely and correct them, if they committed mistakes.
('63', 6, 1, 12, 15537) Even today, I had to do this correction business more than twice, because the translator did not get at the spirit of my speeches.
('63', 6, 1, 13, 15668) One point I have to bring home to you, i.e., please pick up at least an elementary knowledge of the Hindi language so that you may be enabled to get into the hearts of the twenty crores of your brethren in India.
('63', 6, 1, 14, 15881) Maybe, it is not a substitute for either English or Malayalam.
('63', 6, 1, 15, 15944) Malayalam is your mother tongue.
('63', 6, 1, 16, 15977) It is a sin not to know it and not to know it well.
('63', 6, 1, 17, 16029) Only, if you have an all India heart or an all India will, Hindi could be learnt.
('63', 6, 1, 18, 16111) English helps us to become internationalists for that is the language of the international commerce of the day.
('63', 6, 1, 19, 16223) Each is good in its own place and will serve its purpose accordingly.
('63', 6, 1, 20, 16293) May I illustrate this point ?
('63', 6, 1, 21, 16323) Malayalam in the Punjab is useless, so is English for a Punjabi farmer.
('63', 6, 1, 22, 16395) But if you speak to the Punjabi in Hindi, e.g., Salamalikum’, he will smile at you and he will say, ‘I know him’.
('63', 6, 2, 23, 16509) Instead of dealing with the several addresses presented here, I deal with the addresses or letters not presented here but showered on me from outside this audience.
('63', 6, 2, 24, 16674) I hold two letters in my hand.
('63', 6, 2, 25, 16705) One is a printed letter written from Shertalai, the other, a typewritten one, from Alleppey.
('63', 6, 2, 26, 16798) Now this is how the printed letter starts: “We beg to state that your present attempt to strengthen the Hindu religion by re moving the evil of untouchability will end in utter failure.” Then follows the advice after this introduction.
('63', 6, 2, 27, 17034) The second letter has this: “You are well aware of the fact that the greatest obstacle in the way of the creation of a united Indian nation is religion.” I am not a stranger
('63', 6, 3, 28, 17208) 1 This has been taken from the report published in The Hindu, 21 1 1934.
('63', 7, 0, 1, 17281) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 7, 1, 2, 17321) to this kind of advice.
('63', 7, 1, 3, 17345) I had had letters from Travancore and Cochin even when I was in Poona, ailing.
('63', 7, 1, 4, 17424) They were all nicely and courte ously worded, but strong in their emphasis on their belief that religion was the greatest obstacle in the way of the country’s progress.
('63', 7, 1, 5, 17593) Ever since I have set foot on the Cochin Travancore soil, I have been flooded with communications of this sort.
('63', 7, 1, 6, 17705) I cannot possibly disregard all these letters.
('63', 7, 1, 7, 17752) I know that for this belief, which is evidently growing upon some young men in Cochin and Travancore, the savarna Hindus are primarily responsible.
('63', 7, 1, 8, 17900) They have dignified irreligion in the name of religion.
('63', 7, 1, 9, 17956) They have defended sin as if it was virtue with divine sanction.
('63', 7, 1, 10, 18021) These young men have felt, in their impatience, that, if religion is as savarna Hindus describe it to be and practise it, religion is an evil.
('63', 7, 1, 11, 18164) Having become impatient and angered, they have not stopped to think out the question and have condemned religion wholesale.
('63', 7, 1, 12, 18288) If I have real religion in me, I have got to be patient and gentle to these brethren of mine.
('63', 7, 1, 13, 18382) I have reasoned with them by corres pondence, and reasoned with them today at Palluruthy.
('63', 7, 2, 14, 18472) I must tell these friends that my present attempt has nothing to do with the strengthening of Hinduism.
('63', 7, 2, 15, 18576) I ask you to take me at my word when I say that I am wholly indifferent whether Hindu religion is strengthened or weakened or perishes; that is to say, I have so much faith in the correctness of the position I have taken up that, if my taking up that position results in weakening Hinduism, I cannot help it and I must not care.
('63', 7, 2, 16, 18905) I tell you what I want to do with Hindu religion.
('63', 7, 2, 17, 18955) I want to purify it of the sin of untouchability.
('63', 7, 2, 18, 19005) I want to exorcize the devil of untouchability which has today distorted and disfigured Hinduism out of all recognition.
('63', 7, 2, 19, 19126) I know that, if this evil can be re moved root and branch, those very friends who say religion is the greatest obstacle to the progress of India will immediately change their minds.
('63', 7, 2, 20, 19308) But if it is any consolation to these friends, I tell them that, if I came to the conclusion that Hinduism sanctioned untouch ability, I should denounce it.
('63', 7, 2, 21, 19465) But even then I would not go so far with them as to say that religion itself is useless and that God is not God but devil.
('63', 7, 2, 22, 19588) For me the result will be that I shall lose faith in Hindus and Hinduism, but my faith in God will be strengthened.
('63', 7, 2, 23, 19704) And I want to tell you why it will be strengthened.
('63', 7, 2, 24, 19756) Faith is not a delicate flower which would wither under the slightest stormy weather.
('63', 7, 2, 25, 19842) Faith is like the Himalaya mountains which cannot possibly change.
('63', 7, 2, 26, 19909) No storm can possibly remove the Himalaya mountains from their foundations.
('63', 7, 2, 27, 19985) I am daily praying for strength from God to be able to say to God,
('63', 7, 3, 28, 20052) 1 Vide “Speech at Palluruthy”, 18 1 1934.
('63', 8, 0, 1, 20094) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 9
('63', 8, 1, 2, 20136) when Hindus disappoint me, ‘Although Thy own creation has dis appointed me, I still cling to Thee as a babe clings to the mother’s breast.’ And I want every one of you to cultivate that faith in God and religion.
('63', 8, 1, 3, 20349) It is my conviction that all the great faiths of the world are true, are God ordained and that they serve the purpose of God and of those who have been brought up in those surroundings and those faiths.
('63', 8, 1, 4, 20552) I do not believe that the time will ever come when we shall be able to say there is only one religion in the world.
('63', 8, 1, 5, 20668) In a sense, even today there is one fundamental religion in the world.
('63', 8, 1, 6, 20739) But there is no such thing as a straight line in Nature.
('63', 8, 1, 7, 20796) Religion is one tree with many branches.
('63', 8, 1, 8, 20837) As branches you may say religions are many; as tree Religion is one.
('63', 8, 1, 9, 20906) What is at the bottom of this movement for purification in Hinduism?
('63', 8, 1, 10, 20975) It is not designed as a movement hostile to any religion.
('63', 8, 1, 11, 21033) It is designed to bring all faiths nearer together.
('63', 8, 1, 12, 21085) Do you for one moment suppose that, if savarna Hindus make reparation in the terms that I have suggested and if they forget the distinctions of high and low, they will forget those distinctions only in regard to Harijans and not in regard to others?
('63', 8, 1, 13, 21335) Today this poison of untouchability has overtaken the whole of Indian society.
('63', 8, 1, 14, 21414) Harijans are not the only untouchables.
('63', 8, 1, 15, 21454) They are on the extreme fringe.
('63', 8, 1, 16, 21486) But all Hindus are untouchables to themselves, and all Hindus to non Hindus.
('63', 8, 1, 17, 21563) Non Hindus have noted this fact; and I suggest to you that our differences and quarrels today have their main root in this canker of untouch ability.
('63', 8, 1, 18, 21713) I ask you to believe me implicity when I say that, if untouch ability is removed, it must result in bringing all Indians together and, if I may say in all humility, all humanity nearer.
('63', 8, 1, 19, 21899) It is not a small movement, but a big movement fraught with great conse quences.
('63', 8, 1, 20, 21980) Can you imagine that, if it were otherwise, as a wise man, which I consider myself to be, I would ceaselessly wander from place to place in the evening of my life to deliver a message which has the consequence of strengthening Hindus for fighting against Mussal mans, Christians, Jews and Parsis, among whom I have friends as dear as blood bro thers?
('63', 8, 1, 21, 22331) I have that implicit faith in my mission that, if it succeeds—as it will succeed, it is bound to succeed—history will record it as a movement designed to knit all people in the world to gether, not as hostile to one another but as parts of one whole.
('63', 8, 1, 22, 22582) I think I have given sufficient answer to those who have sent me these letters.
('63', 8, 2, 23, 22662) Harijan, 26 1 1934, and The Hindu, 21 1 1934
('63', 9, 0, 1, 22707) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 9, 1, 2, 22748) 7. KAUMUDI’S RENUNCIATION
('63', 9, 2, 3, 22774) It has been my privilege to witness many touching and soulstirring scenes during a busy life packed with a variety of rich experiences.
('63', 9, 2, 4, 22910) But at the moment of writing this, I cannot recall a scene more touching than that of the Harijan cause.
('63', 9, 2, 5, 23015) I had just finished my speech at Badagara.
('63', 9, 2, 6, 23058) In it I had made a reasoned appeal to the women present for jewellery.
('63', 9, 2, 7, 23129) I had finished speaking and was selling the presents received when gently walked up to the platform Kaumudi, a girl 16 years old.
('63', 9, 2, 8, 23259) She took out one bangle and asked me if I would give my autograph.
('63', 9, 2, 9, 23326) I was preparing to give it, when off came the other bangle.
('63', 9, 2, 10, 23386) She had only one on each hand.
('63', 9, 2, 11, 23417) I said, “You need not give me both, I shall give you the autograph for one bangle only.” She replied by taking off her golden necklace.
('63', 9, 2, 12, 23553) This was no easy performance.
('63', 9, 2, 13, 23583) It had to be disengaged from her long plait of hair.
('63', 9, 2, 14, 23636) But the Malabar girl that she is, she had no false modesty about per forming the whole process before a wondering public counting several thousands of men and women.
('63', 9, 2, 15, 23802) “But have you the permission of your parents ?” I asked.
('63', 9, 2, 16, 23859) There was no answer.
('63', 9, 2, 17, 23880) She had not yet completed her renunciation.
('63', 9, 2, 18, 23924) Her hands automatically went to her ears and out came her jewelled ear rings amid the ringing cheers of the public, whose expression of joy was no longer to be suppressed.
('63', 9, 2, 19, 24096) I asked her again whether she had her parents’ consent to the sacrifice.
('63', 9, 2, 20, 24169) Before I could extract any answer from the shy girl, someone told me that her father was present at the meeting, that he was himself helping me by bidding for the addresses I was auctioning and that he was as generous as his daughter in giving to worthy causes.
('63', 9, 2, 21, 24431) I reminded Kau mudi that she was not to have the ornaments replaced.
('63', 9, 2, 22, 24500) She resolutely assented to the condition.
('63', 9, 2, 23, 24542) As I handed her the autograph, I could not help prefacing it with the remark,“Your renunciation is a truer orna ment than the jewellery you have discarded.” May her renunciation prove to have been an earnest of her being a true Harijan sevika.
('63', 9, 2, 24, 24786) Harijan, 19 1 1934
('63', 10, 0, 1, 24805) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 11

('63', 10, 6, 13, 25237) January 19, 1934
('63', 10, 7, 14, 25254) Gandhiji, in the course of his reply, said that the organizers should produce a certificate from the Harijans before he could believe whatever they had stated in the address.
('63', 10, 7, 15, 25429) The address attempted to show that the Harijans were perfectly all right.
('63', 10, 7, 16, 25503) But the case of Harijans was not really so.
('63', 10, 7, 17, 25547) He warned the savarnas against entertaining any false belief.
('63', 10, 7, 18, 25609) Things were not as rosy as had been depicted.
('63', 10, 7, 19, 25655) He had received bitter complaints from the Ezhavas and Thiyyas.
('63', 10, 7, 20, 25719) Some of them wanted to destroy God from their and others’ religion.
('63', 10, 7, 21, 25787) He did not blame them for entertaining such a misconcep tion.
('63', 10, 7, 22, 25849) Gandhiji emphasized the need for the economic uplift of the Harijans and pointed out that temple entry would not solve their problems.
('63', 10, 7, 23, 25984) Economic uplift alone would make the Harijans conscious of their degraded position.
('63', 10, 7, 24, 26068) He expressed his belief that the address was not a true expression of the feeling of the public that had assembled.
('63', 10, 8, 25, 26184) Continuing, Gandhiji said that the campaigning against untouchability was not an easy job.
('63', 10, 8, 26, 26275) Its virus had upset the whole society.
('63', 10, 8, 27, 26314) He had received piteous wails from Christian Harijans.
('63', 10, 8, 28, 26369) If Christians had grades of untouchability, even for that sin savarnas were responsible.
('63', 10, 8, 29, 26458) There was no use in reminding him that there was in Kottayam a church, a mosque, and a temple existing side by side.
('63', 10, 8, 30, 26575) They existed in many other parts of India and even outside India.
('63', 10, 8, 31, 26641) He made an earnest plea for the removal of untouchability from “this land of Dharma Rajya”.
('63', 10, 8, 32, 26733) He had heard with considerable strain that there was a Christian party and a Nayar party in the State that

('63', 11, 1, 2, 27049) did not work for the common end.
('63', 11, 1, 3, 27082) People had been repeatedly dinning into his ears that there were mutual jealousies and rivalries in their midst.
('63', 11, 1, 4, 27195) The Maharaja and the officials would be unable to remove those evils.
('63', 11, 1, 5, 27265) The people themselves had to remove them root and branch.
('63', 11, 1, 6, 27323) If untouchability was removed from the heart, all other ills would also be removed.
('63', 11, 1, 7, 27407) He would not go away satisfied if the opening of the roads and temples were not a token of the heart unity among them.
('63', 11, 2, 8, 27526) Gandhiji said that he had received from Travancore the most hair splitting letters on untouchability.
('63', 11, 2, 9, 27628) It was not a matter for surprise that religious faiths of the Ezhavas were being rudely shaken.

('63', 11, 2, 12, 27919) He asked them to pray to God to give them the strength to confess their guilt, purify their heart and discharge the duty they owed to the Harijans.

('63', 13, 0, 1, 31173) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 13, 1, 2, 31214) 13. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TRIVANDRUM 1
('63', 13, 2, 3, 31257) January 20, 1934
('63', 13, 3, 4, 31274) I am no stranger to Travancore or Trivandrum.
('63', 13, 3, 5, 31320) If you will permit me, I should say I am with you a fellow citizen of Travancore.
('63', 13, 3, 6, 31402) And I shall tell you why I would love to become a citizen of Travancore.
('63', 13, 3, 7, 31475) I have had the audacity, if you like to call it, or courage as I would call it, to say that Malabar, which includes Travancore and Cochin, was the blackest spot in the untouchability map of India.
('63', 13, 3, 8, 31672) The worst forms of untouchability are to be found in Malabar.
('63', 13, 3, 9, 31734) And Mala bar is the home of Shankaracharya, the teacher of the advaita doctrine.
('63', 13, 3, 10, 31815) How untouchability of the worst type can be consistent with the teaching of Shankara passes my comprehension.
('63', 13, 3, 11, 31925) But, since I have become a Harijan by choice, I should love to suffer with the Harijans who are supposed to occupy the lowest rung of the ladder even in the Harijan scale.
('63', 13, 3, 12, 32097) I cannot possibly do so unless I could take out a naturalization certificate and become a citizen of Travancore.
('63', 13, 3, 13, 32210) For, do you know what I saw this morning when I went to a Harijan school?
('63', 13, 3, 14, 32284) There I saw two Harijan boys, belonging to what are called the Vetas.
('63', 13, 3, 15, 32354) One lives and learns on this earth.
('63', 13, 3, 16, 32390) I learnt then and there that Vetas are invisible like the Nayadis—synonymous terms.
('63', 13, 3, 17, 32474) In the note that was passed to me, it was stated that Vetas had the greatest difficulty in finding pure drinking water.
('63', 13, 3, 18, 32594) Once during the Boer War, as a humble member of the Ambulance Corps that I was, I found myself in the position of the Vetas.
('63', 13, 3, 19, 32719) Not that there was any prohibition against the soldiers and ambulance men who were marching through that scorching country, but it happened to be a waterless desert; it was a decree of prohibition from Providence itself.
('63', 13, 3, 20, 32940) The midday sun shone scorching overhead.
('63', 13, 3, 21, 32981) We were all—white soldiers and brown ambu lance men—parched with thirst.
('63', 13, 3, 22, 33054) Suddenly we came upon a little pool filled with dirty water.
('63', 13, 3, 23, 33115) That was to serve as drinking water for us.
('63', 13, 3, 24, 33159) This morning I immediately recalled that scene and said to myself how infinitely worse the Vetas must feel when day in and day out they are consigned to dirty pools for drinking water, not in a waterless desert,
('63', 13, 4, 25, 33371) 1 Over ten thousand people were present at the meeting which was held at the Municipal Maidan.
('63', 13, 4, 26, 33466) Addresses of welcome on behalf of the public and the Hindi Prachar Sabha were presented to Gandhiji together with a purse of Rs. 1001. A report of the speech also appeared in The Hindu, 23 1 1934.
('63', 14, 0, 1, 33663) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 15
('63', 14, 1, 2, 33706) but in a place where ample fresh water is perennial.
('63', 14, 1, 3, 33759) Are you now surprised that I should love to identify myself with a Veta and feel with him by living with him and seeing what you feel when you see fresh water all around and are debarred from using it?
('63', 14, 1, 4, 33961) If God wills it, He will give me the strength and the will to go through the fire.
('63', 14, 1, 5, 34044) You now understand the nature of the message that I want to deliver to you this evening.
('63', 14, 1, 6, 34133) But there is always a ray of light even through apparently im penetrable darkness.
('63', 14, 1, 7, 34216) The communique of the Maharaja’s Government in connection with this untouchability business was this morning placed in my hands.
('63', 14, 1, 8, 34345) I was able, at the meeting, where I saw the order of His Highness the Maharaja’s Government, to tender my congrat lations.
('63', 14, 1, 9, 34468) As I then read this order, it seemed to me in short that there would be no State recognition for those public institutions which debarred untouch ables from their use.
('63', 14, 1, 10, 34636) Whilst it was possible for me to tender my congratulations, you must not run away with the belief that such relief of a very modified type can give me satisfaction.
('63', 14, 1, 11, 34801) This deep seated disease requires not a temporizing but a drastic remedy.
('63', 14, 1, 12, 34875) If the Hindu patient is to live, then this disease has to be removed root and branch.
('63', 14, 1, 13, 34961) I wish that the young Maharaja and his advisers may take courage into their hands and apply the only remedy that can undo this mischief.
('63', 14, 1, 14, 35098) The remedy is incredibly simple.
('63', 14, 1, 15, 35131) They have simply to say that there will be no State recognition in any shape or form of untouchability, unapproachability or invisibility.
('63', 14, 1, 16, 35270) As an ex lawyer, who still has some memory of legal lore, I make bold to say that such a legislation or such a proclamation will not amount to any interference with any single individual’s religious belief or practice.
('63', 14, 1, 17, 35489) It is the boun den duty of a State which has subjects entertaining different faiths to take an impartial and detached view in matters of religion.
('63', 14, 1, 18, 35636) By identifying itself with practices prevalent among a section of its subjects and by giving legal protection to those practices, the State interferes with the progress of reform and interferes with the free play of people’s conscience.
('63', 14, 1, 19, 35873) All that the State has got to do is to say to its subject, ‘The State has nothing to do with your religious beliefs and practices.
('63', 14, 1, 20, 36004) We will interfere when you, in prosecuting your religious practices, interfere with common law rights or with the peace of the State.’ But the existing State recognition of untouchability makes it a current coin.
('63', 14, 1, 21, 36217) I feel that an extremely heavy responsibility rests upon Hindu
('63', 15, 0, 1, 36280) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 15, 1, 2, 36321) princes when, as I feel, the very Hindu religion runs the risk of being utterly destroyed if this virus of untouchability is not expelled from the Hindu body.
('63', 15, 1, 3, 36480) Those who feel as deeply as I do about this matter cannot possibly rest until the socalled Harijans are clothed with pre cisely the same rights as nonHarijan Hindus possess today.
('63', 15, 1, 4, 36660) Now one or two words only with reference to the individual duty of everyone in this audience, man or woman.
('63', 15, 1, 5, 36768) This is a movement essentially of self purification, of savarna Hindus frankly acknowled ging the debt that they owe to Harijans, and rendering full reparation to them.
('63', 15, 1, 6, 36937) This can only be brought about by a complete change of heart on our part.
('63', 15, 1, 7, 37011) As I have already described to you, the State aid can only be of a negative character.
('63', 15, 1, 8, 37098) The State cannot possibly change the individual heart.
('63', 15, 1, 9, 37153) That can only be made by prayer to Almighty.
('63', 15, 1, 10, 37198) It is not possible for a single human being to change the heart of a fellow being.
('63', 15, 1, 11, 37281) I know that I cannot do it.
('63', 15, 1, 12, 37309) I can only make an appeal to your reason and to your heart.
('63', 15, 1, 13, 37369) But it is God alone who can arm the word that I speak to you with the power to shoot like an arrow and make a lodgment in your heart.
('63', 15, 1, 14, 37503) If you can believe the word of a man who is perpetually seeking after truth, believe me that throughout all my waking hours, and if I can say so, during my sleep also, my one constant prayer to God is that He may give that power to my words, so that the Hindu heart can be touched and it may be purged of the virus of untouchability and Hindus and Hinduism may be saved from this impending doom.
('63', 15, 1, 15, 37899) Please remember that your duty and my duty does not end with merely recognizing the Harijans as blood brothers and bloodsisters.
('63', 15, 1, 16, 38028) That is the beginning of the end.
('63', 15, 1, 17, 38062) The end is that we should rid ourselves of every form of untouchability that is eating into the vitals of Hindu society.
('63', 15, 1, 18, 38183) As an address reminded me only this morning, it was not enough to treat Pulayas, Nayadis and others as blood brothers; for, untouchability existed among savarna Hindus them selves, caste against caste.
('63', 15, 1, 19, 38385) It is true that the poison has gone so deep that it has corrupted the whole of our society.
('63', 15, 1, 20, 38477) It has even affected our fellow countrymen—Mussalmans, Christians, and others.
('63', 15, 1, 21, 38556) What, there fore, you and I have to do is to forget that there is anybody high or low on this earth.
('63', 15, 1, 22, 38657) Then, being the children of the same Creator, the same God, no matter to what faith we may belong, no matter what hue we may have, we are all equal in the eyes of our Maker.
('63', 15, 1, 23, 38831) Do you not see that, when we have been able to purge ourselves of this virus, not
('63', 16, 0, 1, 38913) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 17
('63', 16, 1, 2, 38956) only shall we, Hindus, be able to look the world in the face but we shall also be able to live in peace with our neighbours, be they Mussalmans, be they Christians, Jews, Parsis or others?
('63', 16, 1, 3, 39145) Now you will understand why I consider insignificant the purse you have been good enough to give me, considering that Trivandrum is the capital of a great State of India.
('63', 16, 1, 4, 39316) Do you know that both Bangalore and Calicut have given no less than six or seven thousand rupees to the Harijan purse?
('63', 16, 1, 5, 39435) If you were to tell me that poverty had hit Travancore harder than Calicut or Bangalore, I must refuse to believe it.
('63', 16, 1, 6, 39553) Bangalore at least is not a land flowing with milk and honey as Travancore is.
('63', 16, 1, 7, 39632) As somebody was saying, no man need die of positive hunger in Kerala.
('63', 16, 1, 8, 39702) You have got the richest milk that mother coconut can yield, and you can have all the sweetness you desire from the banana, which is very cheap here.
('63', 16, 1, 9, 39852) When I was travelling through the South in 1915, I lived for days together on bananas and coconuts; and as an expert diet reformer, I can tell you that you can well hold body and soul together for many days, indeed many years, on bananas and coconuts.
('63', 16, 1, 10, 40104) So if you were to advance the plea of poverty as against Harijans, you would be absolutely out of court.
('63', 16, 1, 11, 40209) While, therefore, I am in Trivandrum, I expect all of you, who are here and who have listened to me, to make up for this very serious defect in your purse.
('63', 16, 1, 12, 40365) Sisters can copy little Kaumudi, 1 who lives not very many miles from you, and discard all the jewellery that they wear.
('63', 16, 1, 13, 40486) And you, the citizens of Travancore, can put your heads together and decide that your purse should be the richest, because you represent the blackest spot, and you can undertake to make up for the defect I have shown to you.
('63', 16, 1, 14, 40711) But you will permit me to point out another serious defect.
('63', 16, 1, 15, 40771) Since I have been travelling in Travancore, I have discovered that the people have paid like misers, but the organizers have spent money like spendthrifts.
('63', 16, 1, 16, 40927) Therefore, as it has astounded me, it will astound you to learn that the feeding charges of my party, which certainly descends like locusts on a field, and such other expenses which should never be deducted from purses given for the Harijan cause, have been deducted.
('63', 16, 1, 17, 41195) You will be astonished to know that in many cases more than 50 per cent has been spent.
('63', 16, 1, 18, 41283) What would God tell me when I say to Him that in the name of Harijans so many thousand rupees were collected and 50 per cent were deducted for feeding and entertaining

('63', 17, 0, 1, 41495) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 17, 1, 2, 41536) I know that, if I did not protest against such expenses my claim to represent the Harijans would be summarily dismissed by Divinity.
('63', 17, 1, 3, 41669) The fact of the matter is that you have not treated this Harijan question as seriously as it should have been treated.
('63', 17, 1, 4, 41788) It is a deeply religious question.
('63', 17, 1, 5, 41823) It affects the well being of the poorest in the land.
('63', 17, 1, 6, 41877) It affects the well being of those who are despised by society.
('63', 17, 1, 7, 41941) I wish you and I and every one of us would hang down our heads in shame, if we were guilty of misusing or using improperly a single pie collected on behalf of the Harijans.
('63', 17, 1, 8, 42114) I assure you that I do not want a single convenience which cannot be cheaply supplied.
('63', 17, 1, 9, 42201) One little flickering light will suffice for my purpose.
('63', 17, 1, 10, 42258) I want no flags or buntings for me and my party.
('63', 17, 1, 11, 42307) If you gave me the open sky and the velvety sand of Travancore to lie upon, I should never utter a single word of reproach.
('63', 17, 1, 12, 42431) But I will reproach everyone connected with this cause who misspends a single pie when it might have been saved for the Harijan cause.
('63', 17, 1, 13, 42566) I want you all to understand the seriousness of this mission.
('63', 17, 1, 14, 42628) I want you then to bestir yourselves, put your shoulders to the wheel and make a Herculean effort, whilst there is yet time, to save ourselves and the ancient faith from the impending doom.
('63', 17, 1, 15, 42818) I do not wish to convey the meaning that only the Committees in Travancore have been guilty of useless expenditure.
('63', 17, 1, 16, 42934) God alone knows how many other Committees have been guilty of this.
('63', 17, 1, 17, 43002) But this I can tell you that, ever since this tour began, I have been cross questioning every Committee, and I have called for accounts of receipts and expenditure from every Committee and am awaiting accounts from them.
('63', 17, 1, 18, 43223) There is no reflection here on the honesty of a single person.
('63', 17, 1, 19, 43286) But those of you, who are studying law or who are lawyers, will at once understand when I say that neglect or carelessness on the part of a trustee, which everyone connected with this movement is, amounts to a crime.
('63', 17, 1, 20, 43503) A trustee is expected to give greater attention and care to the protection of his ward than he would bestow on his own protection.
('63', 17, 2, 21, 43634) Harijan, 2 2 1934
('63', 18, 0, 1, 43652) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 19
('63', 18, 1, 2, 43695) 14. INTERVIEW ON TRAVANCORE GOVERNMENT COMMUNIQUE 1
('63', 18, 2, 3, 43747) TRIVANDRUM, January 20, 1934
('63', 18, 3, 4, 43776) Interviewed on the communique of the Travancore Government, declaring public tanks and wells open to all castes, Gandhiji said: I have already tendered my congratulations to His Highness and Government on the communique but I have also said that it cannot possibly satisfy me, much less the Harijans.
('63', 18, 3, 5, 44077) There can be neither satis faction nor rest until the States refuse to recognize untouchability in any shape or form.
('63', 18, 3, 6, 44195) That will not interfere with anybody’s personal or religious freedom.
('63', 18, 3, 7, 44265) But today untouchability receives State protection.
('63', 18, 3, 8, 44317) I venture therefore to hope that H. H. the Maharaja and his advisers will at least take up an impartial attitude by withholding State recog nition of untouchability.
('63', 18, 4, 9, 44483) 1 The communique read: “In their report, the Temple entry Enquiry Committee have recommended, inter alia, prompt action on the following lines: ‘Distance pollution or theendal should be removed by appropriate legislative measures subject to reservations in the matter of entry into temples and into their adjuncts like temple tanks, temple wells, homapuras, anakottils, etc., and subject to the following provisoes: ‘(a) Public tanks used for bathing purposes should be thrown open, after separate cisterns are attached to them or portions of them are walled off, where people could wash their clothes, etc., before getting into the tanks for bath.
('63', 18, 4, 10, 45132) ‘(b) Public wells should be thrown open after they are provided with cisterns in which water should be stored from the wells by Municipal or Health Department employees and from which water should be drawn through taps.
('63', 18, 4, 11, 45352) ‘(c) Government satrams should be thrown open after they are provided with separate kitchens, as in the case of such as are already open to all classes.
('63', 18, 4, 12, 45505) ‘ “Government share the view of the Committee that distance pollution or theendal must cease and are of opinion that no general public funds should be spent by Government in the maintenance of public tanks, public wells, satrams, etc., admission to which is denied to any person by reason of his belonging to a theendal caste.
('63', 18, 4, 13, 45832) They have resolved, therefore, that all public roads, public tanks, public wells, satrams, etc., maintained by them out of their general public funds shall be thrown open to all classes of people irrespective of the caste to which they belong.
('63', 18, 4, 14, 46076) Measures to carry out these objects soon are being considered.
('63', 18, 4, 15, 46139) “ 2. The other recommendations of the Committee are under the consideration of Government.”
('63', 19, 0, 1, 46231) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 19, 1, 2, 46272) With regard to one of the recommendations of the Travancore Temple entry Enquiry Committee, relating to a reference to a parishad of learned men, Gandhiji said: In my opinion, this is not a question to be decided by a parishad merely of learned men.
('63', 19, 1, 3, 46522) Such parishad, if it is composed of men who are not merely learned but are also holy and wise, can guide the people but not the State, for in a composite society, such as ours is, a State has to adopt an attitude of perfect neutrality.
('63', 19, 1, 4, 46758) Supposing that parishad gave it as its opinion that untouchability, such as we know it, is a Hindu religious obligation, then the State cannot clothe it with legal protection.
('63', 19, 1, 5, 46934) Those who believe in it will observe it, but they shall not compel non believers to do so.
('63', 19, 1, 6, 47025) But the state of law today is such, that men who do not believe in untouchability are compelled to submit to it.
('63', 19, 2, 7, 47138) In reply to the question whether the temples in Travancore did not stand on a different footing from most in British India, and whether they were not really a trust property in the hands of Government, Gandhiji said: Trustees are bound, so long as they retain that office, to carry out faithfully the conditions of the trust.
('63', 19, 2, 8, 47464) All therefore that they can do is to resign their office, if they regard untouchability as a sinful practice.
('63', 19, 3, 9, 47574) Asked if Government in that case should give up the wardenship of temples, Mahatma Gandhiji said: Most decidedly, Government should certainly give up their custodianship of temples.
('63', 19, 4, 10, 47756) The Hindu, 22 1 1934
('63', 20, 0, 1, 47777) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 21

('63', 24, 8, 13, 53695) 22. LETTER TO SRI PRAKASA
('63', 24, 9, 14, 53721) Unrevised January 22, 1934
('63', 24, 10, 15, 53748) MY DEAR SRI PRAKASA, I am glad that you could not follow my article 2 on ornaments.
('63', 24, 10, 16, 53832) That has enabled me to get a letter from you and also to have a con fession from you that you do not read Harijan.
('63', 24, 10, 17, 53947) I had thought that you would insist on reading it as a general weekly letter from me.
('63', 24, 10, 18, 54033) It is never too late to mend.
('63', 24, 10, 19, 54063) I recommend your getting it regularly and reading it.
('63', 24, 10, 20, 54117) Now for your argument.
('63', 24, 10, 21, 54140) I never said that foreign cloth was in itself an evil.
('63', 24, 10, 22, 54195) I did say and say it even now that the use of foreign cloth in India by Indians is an evil.
('63', 24, 10, 23, 54287) I do not put the use of ornaments in the same category as foreign cloth.
('63', 24, 10, 24, 54360) But I do preach disuse of ornaments.
('63', 24, 10, 25, 54397) Not having funda mental objection to the use of ornaments as to the use of foreign cloth, I do not mind selling ornaments to those who would wear them.
('63', 24, 10, 26, 54549) It is enough for me if I get one woman to discard ornaments.
('63', 24, 10, 27, 54610) You may not know that one hundredth part of them are sold as ornaments, ninety nine parts are melted and turned into gold and sold as currency.
('63', 24, 10, 28, 54754) The other parts of your argument touch upon a wider field and involve a discussion of capital and labour, poverty and riches, etc.
('63', 24, 10, 29, 54885) These I omit for want of time.
('63', 24, 10, 30, 54916) May I take your letter to mean that you are now quite restored

('63', 27, 1, 24, 58982) The Bhagavad Gita says that the Lord’s bhakta should cultivate solitude.
('63', 27, 1, 25, 59055) This requires to be carefully grasped.
('63', 27, 1, 26, 59094) We came into the world alone and shall leave it alone; why, then, should we yearn for anybody’s companionship during the uncertain interval between birth and death?
('63', 27, 1, 27, 59259) However, though we come alone we also see that we are not altogether alone.
('63', 27, 1, 28, 59335) We have the company of our parents.
('63', 27, 1, 29, 59371) Were it not for that, we would not be able to live even for a moment.
('63', 27, 1, 30, 59441) When we grow up, we generally get married.
('63', 27, 1, 31, 59484) That also gives us similar com pany.
('63', 27, 1, 32, 59521) Then we get the company of friends too.
('63', 27, 1, 33, 59561) For spiritual pro gress also we require company to some extent.
('63', 27, 1, 34, 59625) Why, then, does the Gita advise cultivating solitude?
('63', 27, 1, 35, 59679) Let us try to understand this point.
('63', 27, 1, 36, 59716) Think of any companions and you will see that the bond is a sign of our dependence.
('63', 27, 1, 37, 59800) Father, mother, husband, wife, friend, everybody makes us dependent on him or her to some extent.
('63', 27, 1, 38, 59898) But one who is a bhakta of the Lord is full of compassion.
('63', 27, 1, 39, 59957) He is dependent on God alone.
('63', 27, 1, 40, 59987) He is the only true friend and, besides, He is our charioteer too....
('63', 27, 1, 41, 60057) What else can he want who has His company?
('63', 27, 1, 42, 60100) Mother Gita, therefore, advises us to seek solitude.
('63', 27, 1, 43, 60153) This does not mean that we should shun the company of fellow beings.
('63', 27, 1, 44, 60222) It only means that we should not desire it.
('63', 27, 1, 45, 60266) We should not lose heart when we do not have it and, on the other
('63', 27, 2, 46, 60332) 1 Premlila Thackersey 2 Brother of Kasturba Gandhi
('63', 28, 0, 1, 60383) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 29
('63', 28, 1, 2, 60426) hand, even in the midst of crores of people, should feel mental soli tude and nearness to God.
('63', 28, 1, 3, 60521) I hope you remember the bhajan: “Friends of the body are selfish, one and all; they will refuse to accompany one at the end.” One who cultivates solitude will never be unhappy anywhere, for he sees only Vishnu in all places.
('63', 28, 1, 4, 60746) Prahlad, the bhakta, saw Vishnu even in a red hot pillar.

('63', 28, 1, 6, 60870) All of you have got, un sought, an opportunity to do so.

('63', 35, 6, 13, 70917) 36. INTERVIEW WITH THE MEMBERS OF SELF RESPECT PARTY 1
('63', 35, 7, 14, 70972) [January 23, 1934] 2
('63', 35, 8, 15, 70993) Q. What is your programme with regard to the Harijan work?
('63', 35, 9, 16, 71052) A. My programme is to provide for them schools, hostels, medi cal aid, facilities for water—generally to do everything that would put them on a par with others.
('63', 35, 10, 17, 71213) Q. What of Christian and Mussalman untouchables?
('63', 35, 10, 18, 71262) We want a programme affecting them also.
('63', 35, 10, 19, 71303) A. I have no such grand programme applicable to all.
('63', 35, 10, 20, 71356) Not that I do not like it, but it is beyond my power to handle.
('63', 35, 10, 21, 71420) It comes under the movement of swaraj.
('63', 35, 10, 22, 71459) When swaraj comes, it will be applicable to all, to all the poor of India.
('63', 35, 10, 23, 71534) Swaraj means among other things a redress of their wrongs.
('63', 35, 11, 24, 71593) Q. In South India, we know they are paid wages in kind and there are no fixed hours of work.
('63', 35, 11, 25, 71686) Why do you not try to get for them more wages and fixed hours of work, instead of appealing for temple entry?
('63', 35, 12, 26, 71796) A. These things do not arise out of untouchability, but from
('63', 35, 13, 27, 71857) 1 Extracted from Chandrashankar Shukla’s “Weekly Letter” 2 The date is from Harijan, 2 2 1934.
('63', 36, 0, 1, 71952) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 37
('63', 36, 1, 2, 71995) other causes.
('63', 36, 2, 3, 72009) Q. The two questions are interwoven.
('63', 36, 3, 4, 72046) A. I know they overlap each other.
('63', 36, 3, 5, 72081) If I succeed in solving this question, I solve the rest.
('63', 36, 3, 6, 72138) As a physician I know what to do.
('63', 36, 3, 7, 72172) A physician finds the root of the disease and treats it.
('63', 36, 3, 8, 72229) Similarly I treat the seat of the disease.
('63', 36, 4, 9, 72272) Q. Of course you are more experienced than we are.
('63', 36, 4, 10, 72323) But we feel that the Harijans want food for their stomachs and a social status.
('63', 36, 4, 11, 72403) You merely harp upon temple entry.
('63', 36, 5, 12, 72438) A. Surely, you are wrong.
('63', 36, 5, 13, 72464) You will find only a passing reference to it in all my speeches during the tour.
('63', 36, 5, 14, 72545) But I cannot do without it.
('63', 36, 6, 15, 72573) Q. But do you not say this is a movement of self purification?
('63', 36, 7, 16, 72636) A. I do.
('63', 36, 7, 17, 72645) There is no question about that.
('63', 36, 7, 18, 72678) I said that at Palluruthy 1
('63', 36, 8, 19, 72706) in the plainest terms possible.
('63', 36, 8, 20, 72738) The Harijans there accused me of pleading for reform as a Hindu.
('63', 36, 8, 21, 72803) I pleaded guilty.
('63', 36, 8, 22, 72821) I do not hide my colours.
('63', 36, 8, 23, 72847) They said that, if they got all economic facilities, everything would follow; I said, it won’t.
('63', 36, 8, 24, 72943) And I can give you many instances in support of what I say.
('63', 36, 8, 25, 73003) You may revile temples if you like.
('63', 36, 8, 26, 73039) You may not go to them.
('63', 36, 8, 27, 73063) But you must have the right to go and worship there.
('63', 36, 8, 28, 73116) You may or may not use it.
('63', 36, 8, 29, 73143) Not all the Thiyyas feel as you do.
('63', 36, 8, 30, 73179) Those very Thiyyas at Palluruthy took me to a temple which was essentially a Hindu temple.
('63', 36, 8, 31, 73270) They were all young men.
('63', 36, 8, 32, 73295) And did not Narayana Guru Swami establish temples?
('63', 36, 8, 33, 73346) I know of thousands of Harijans who, when they hear of a temple being opened, have a new lustre in their eyes.
('63', 36, 8, 34, 73457) They do not know why, but they feel different men.
('63', 36, 8, 35, 73508) I have seen them transported with joy on entering a temple.
('63', 36, 8, 36, 73568) They felt themselves face to face with Deity.
('63', 36, 9, 37, 73614) Q. We respect you only as a revolutionary leader of a revolutionary people.
('63', 36, 10, 38, 73690) A. Then, say a Hindu revolutionary is appearing on the scene and revolutionizing Hinduism.
('63', 36, 10, 39, 73781) But if I have done wrong to somebody, who is to do reparation but me?
('63', 36, 10, 40, 73851) I say to Harijans, you may accept the reparation or reject it.

('63', 37, 2, 10, 74866) 37. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TINNEVELLY 1
('63', 37, 3, 11, 74909) January 24, 1934 Before I refer to the proceedings of this morning, I must take the very first opportunity that has occurred to me of making a refe rence to a great calamity that has descended upon India, I mean the great earthquake that has desolated fair Bihar.
('63', 37, 3, 12, 75173) I read yesterday the Viceregal communication.
('63', 37, 3, 13, 75219) I read also the reports of the Government of Bihar that were published in the papers; and I had a most heart rending telegram from Babu Rajendra Prasad as soon as he was discharged from his prison.
('63', 37, 3, 14, 75417) All these communications show what puny mortals we are.
('63', 37, 3, 15, 75473) We who have faith in God must cherish the belief that behind even this indescribable calamity there is a divine purpose that works for the good of humanity.
('63', 37, 3, 16, 75630) You may call me superstitious if you like; but a man like me cannot but believe that this earthquake is a divine chastisement sent by God for our sins.
('63', 37, 3, 17, 75782) Even to avowed scoffers it must be clear that nothing but divine will can explain such a calamity.
('63', 37, 3, 18, 75881) It is my unmistakable belief that not a blade of grass moves but by the divine will.
('63', 37, 3, 19, 75966) What are you and I to do in the face of a calamity of this magnitude?
('63', 37, 3, 20, 76036) I can only say to you that all of us should contribute our mite to lessen the misery to the best of our ability.
('63', 37, 3, 21, 76149) But I may not be deflected from the purpose to which, as I believe, by the direction of God, I have dedicated myself for the few months at my disposal; nor have I the authority to turn from their destination the funds that I am just now collecting from you.
('63', 37, 3, 22, 76407) But with all the earnestness that I can

('63', 39, 2, 4, 79484) 38. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TUTICORIN 1
('63', 39, 3, 5, 79526) January 24, 1934 I want you to remember that Province in the north east of India.
('63', 39, 3, 6, 79608) It is the place where Sita grew up and Janaka ruled.
('63', 39, 3, 7, 79661) It is the land where Gautam found divine knowledge.
('63', 39, 3, 8, 79713) It has many other sacred associations and it is known to you, to me and to every child in India as Bihar and Bihar means “fair land”.
('63', 39, 3, 9, 79847) Today that fair land has become desolate through earthquakes.
('63', 39, 3, 10, 79909) Several thousands are said to have died.
('63', 39, 3, 11, 79950) Many more thousands have suffered injuries from which they are even now suffering excruciating pain.
('63', 39, 3, 12, 80051) Many fair cities have become heaps of ruin.
('63', 39, 3, 13, 80095) Aid has been coming to them from all parts of the world.
('63', 39, 3, 14, 80152) The King has sent a message of sympathy.
('63', 39, 3, 15, 80193) This divine calamity has suddenly reminded us that all humanity is one; and as is but right and proper, in the face of this calamity the Government and the people have become one.
('63', 39, 3, 16, 80373) For the time being distinctions between Congressmen and non Congressmen have been abolished, and all parties are supplementing the efforts of one another.
('63', 39, 3, 17, 80528) I want you to be “superstitious” enough with me to believe that the earthquake is a divine chastisement for the great sin we have committed and are still committing against those whom we describe as untouchables, Panch amas, and whom I describe as Harijans.
('63', 39, 3, 18, 80786) Let us derive the lesson from this calamity that this earthly existence is no more permanent than that of the moths we see every night dancing round lights for a few minutes and then being destroyed.
('63', 39, 3, 19, 80986) This earthly existence of ours is more brittle than the glass bangles that ladies wear.
('63', 39, 3, 20, 81074) You can keep glass bangles for thousands of years if you treasure them in a chest and let them remain untouched.
('63', 39, 3, 21, 81187) But this earthly existence is so fickle that it may be wiped out in the twinkling of an eye.
('63', 39, 3, 22, 81280) Therefore, whilst we have yet breathing time, let us get rid of the distinctions of high and low, purify our hearts, and be ready to face our Maker when an earthquake or some natural calamity or death in the ordinary course overtakes us.

('63', 44, 1, 7, 89890) I know that you are all believers in God.
('63', 44, 1, 8, 89932) Our forefathers have taught us to think that when ever a calamity descends upon a people, that calamity comes because of our personal sins.
('63', 44, 1, 9, 90072) You know that when the rains do not come in time we perform sacrifices and ask gods to send us rains and forgive us our sins owing to which rains are detained.
('63', 44, 1, 10, 90232) And it is not only here—I have seen it in England and South Africa.
('63', 44, 1, 11, 90300) When there is a visitation of locusts or the rivers are in flood, they appoint days of humiliation and days of fasting and pray to God to remove the calamity from their midst.
('63', 44, 1, 12, 90476) And then I want you to believe with me that for this absolutely unthinkable affliction in Bihar your sins and my sins are responsible.
('63', 44, 1, 13, 90611) And then when I ask myself what can be that atrocious sin that we must have committed to deserve such a calamity which staggers us and which today probably has staggered the whole world,—within living memory there is no record of an earthquake of this magnitude in India— I tell you the conviction is growing on me that this affliction has come to us because of this atrocious sin of untouchability.
('63', 44, 1, 14, 91011) I beseech you not to laugh within yourself and think I want to appeal to your instinct of superstition.
('63', 44, 1, 15, 91115) I don’t.

('63', 44, 1, 17, 91198) I may be called superstitious, but I cannot help telling you what I feel deep down in me.
('63', 44, 1, 18, 91288) I do not propose to take up your time and my time by elaborating this.
('63', 44, 1, 19, 91359) You are free to believe it or to reject it.
('63', 44, 1, 20, 91403) If you believe with me, then you will be quick and think there is no such thing as untouchability as we practise it today in the Hindu Shastras.
('63', 44, 1, 21, 91548) You will think with me that it is a diabolical sin to think of any human being as an untouchable.
('63', 44, 1, 22, 91646) It is man’s insolence that tells him that he is higher than any other.
('63', 44, 1, 23, 91717) I tell you, the more I think of it the more I feel that there cannot be a greater sin than for a man to consider that he is higher than any single being.
('63', 44, 1, 24, 91871) All the good men of the world and all the wise men of the world whom I know anything of, and I know a great deal, have all said that they are the lowest of the low.
('63', 44, 1, 25, 92036) But here unfortunately with us our life is bound up with the idea of high and low.

('63', 45, 2, 5, 92661) 44. REPLY TO CIVIC ADDRESS, MADURA 1
('63', 45, 3, 6, 92698) January 26, 1934
('63', 45, 4, 7, 92715) MEMBERS OF THE MUNICIPAL COUNCIL AND FRIENDS, In the first instance I would like to tender my apologies to you for not keeping the appointments in connection with the receipt of your address.
('63', 45, 4, 8, 92907) But Nature allows no interference with her superior will.
('63', 45, 4, 9, 92965) So in spite of all the best efforts put forth yesterday, it was not possible to reach Madura before quarter past eleven last night.
('63', 45, 4, 10, 93097) I thank you for the address that you have given me.
('63', 45, 4, 11, 93149) I am glad to note that you have made reference to hand spinning, Hindi and such activities which are dear to me.
('63', 45, 4, 12, 93262) And since you believe in hand spinning as a cottage industry essential for the seven hundred thousand villages of India, I should expect that the councillors in their homes and in all manner open to them would insist on the use of hand spun and hand woven khaddar.
('63', 45, 4, 13, 93527) I am glad that you recognize the importance of Hindi as a national language.
('63', 45, 4, 14, 93604) I have no doubt in my mind that as English is the language highly important for the international and commercial purposes, so is Hindi important for the interprovincial purposes.
('63', 45, 4, 15, 93783) Yet I wish that it was possible for you to have enabled wanderers like me to speak to you in the national language.
('63', 45, 4, 16, 93899) I tender you my sincere congratulations on the absence of the Hindu Muslim problem here.
('63', 45, 4, 17, 93988) I wish that your example will prove contagious and infectious and that all over India we shall forget the Hindu Muslim differences.

('63', 47, 3, 5, 96834) Their presence in such large numbers showed not merely the love they had for him, but that they entirely approved of the cause for which he had purposely come there.
('63', 47, 3, 6, 97000) They must show their affection by removing untouchability.
('63', 47, 3, 7, 97059) Untouchability was the greatest of the sins.
('63', 47, 3, 8, 97104) No human being should ever say that he or she was superior to another person whether they be amongst caste Hindus or as between caste Hindus on the one hand and Harijans on the other.
('63', 47, 3, 9, 97288) He also asked them to show their love by giving monetary help which was the least they could do.

('63', 47, 6, 14, 97701) January 26, 1934 I am very much obliged to you for all these addresses, purses and gifts.
('63', 47, 6, 15, 97791) This is not my first visit to Madura, but I think that the crowd that I see now is mightier than what I saw last time.

('63', 48, 1, 2, 99026) only a physical reason, but they carry with them also spiritual conse quences; and if it is a superstition, it is a superstition which I share in common with practically all mankind.
('63', 48, 1, 3, 99209) You may, if you like, reject this belief of mine.
('63', 48, 1, 4, 99259) But if we would but rise from the inertia which has overtaken us and has paralysed our vision, we would at once see as clearly as daylight that untouchability as it is practised today cannot be defended on any ground whatsoever.

('63', 48, 2, 14, 100444) Continuing, Gandhiji referred to a subject which he said was assuming serious proportions in Madura.
('63', 48, 2, 15, 100545) It was one touching upon the wellbeing of the Harijans.
('63', 48, 2, 16, 100601) As he had already demonstrated with facts and figures, several thousands of women belonging to the Harijan class earned a few pice a day by the spinning wheel.
('63', 48, 2, 17, 100761) But the practice among some merchants in passing off mill cloth as hand spun khaddar was depriving even the few pice that went into the pockets of the Harijans.
('63', 48, 2, 18, 100922) By this he did not condemn mill cloth but only wanted that mill yarn should not be passed as khaddar.
('63', 48, 2, 19, 101024) And he at the same time asked the purchasers to make sure that the cloth they purchased was genuine khaddar.

('63', 49, 3, 5, 101339) congratulated the certificate holders and prize winners and proceeded to speak about the merits of the Hindi language.
('63', 49, 3, 6, 101458) He pointed out that being akin to all other Indian languages Hindi was the easiest medium for the intercourse of thought among the peoples of India.
('63', 49, 3, 7, 101607) Further, unlike the English language, it had an atmosphere about it which was thoroughly Indian.
('63', 49, 3, 8, 101704) In all walks of life in India, Hindi served as a common medium of communication of thoughts and ideas.
('63', 49, 3, 9, 101807) It was particularly useful for merchants and commercial people.
('63', 49, 3, 10, 101871) By devoting one hour a day one could get a working knowledge of Hindi in about six months, but more than that one should keep in touch with it so as not to forget what one had learnt.
('63', 49, 3, 11, 102055) To acquire literary proficiency one will have to devote more time.

('63', 49, 5, 13, 102143) 48. SPEECH AT MEETING OF LABOURERS, MADURA 2
('63', 49, 6, 14, 102188) January 26, 1934
('63', 49, 7, 15, 102205) FELLOW LABOURERS, It has given me very great pleasure to be in your midst.
('63', 49, 7, 16, 102280) I call you ‘fellow labourers’, by design.
('63', 49, 7, 17, 102322) When I was hardly 23 years old, or 24 it might be, I came in touch with Balasundaram 3. Balasundaram was an indentured labourer.
('63', 49, 7, 18, 102451) I had the good fortune to handle his case.
('63', 49, 7, 19, 102494) I then learnt a great deal about the hardships of labour.
('63', 49, 7, 20, 102552) The bond between the labourers and myself became closer and closer and I threw myself entirely into their hands.
('63', 49, 7, 21, 102665) If I did not become an inden tured labourer myself, they realized that I was one with them myself.
('63', 49, 7, 22, 102764) That is the reason why I call myself a labourer.
('63', 49, 7, 23, 102813) Now I want to tell you something of what this self purification movement is.
('63', 49, 7, 24, 102890) I have just heard that when I was fasting in the Yeravda jail you were the first to hold a meeting to show your sympathy.
('63', 49, 7, 25, 103012) You did then
('63', 49, 8, 26, 103025) 1 After the address of welcome, which was in Hindi, was presented, Gandhiji gave away prizes and certificates to the meritorious students.
('63', 49, 8, 27, 103164) At the end of the meeting Gandhiji auctioned the address and the other presents.
('63', 49, 8, 28, 103245) 2 The meeting, arranged by the Madura Mills Labour Union, was held at 7 p.m.
('63', 49, 8, 29, 103322) in the compound of the Mills school.
('63', 49, 8, 30, 103359) Over five thousand labourers attended.

('63', 50, 0, 1, 103496) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 51
('63', 50, 1, 2, 103539) a great deal of work.
('63', 50, 1, 3, 103561) But I am not sure that you understand what all that meant.
('63', 50, 1, 4, 103620) You know that even among the labourers there are vast divisions and one considers the other lower than oneself.
('63', 50, 1, 5, 103732) Now, so long as you believe that there are some who are lower than yourself or some who are higher than yourself, you have not got the spirit of the movement.
('63', 50, 1, 6, 103891) Therefore, you must feel in your heart that there is nothing in this difference and abolish it.
('63', 50, 1, 7, 103987) Among you also I know that there are many caste Hindu labourers and many Harijan labourers.
('63', 50, 1, 8, 104079) You must forget, if you have understood this movement, that there are any untouchables.
('63', 50, 1, 9, 104167) And, you must consider every labourer as equal as you and your blood brother are.
('63', 50, 1, 10, 104249) If you can rise to that stage, you would immediately understand what happiness there will be for your own good and for the good of the country.
('63', 50, 1, 11, 104393) Under the circumstances, I would like to tell you, friends, in this self purification movement you will be expected to discard the intoxicating drink altogether.
('63', 50, 1, 12, 104555) If there are any amongst you at all who are used to eating carrion and beef, you must leave it.
('63', 50, 1, 13, 104651) You will give up gambling.
('63', 50, 1, 14, 104678) Do not incur debts.
('63', 50, 1, 15, 104698) And, if you have in your midst any Muslim labourers also, you must deal with them and live with them on terms of affection.
('63', 50, 1, 16, 104822) You ought to take a personal interest in the work that they may be doing.
('63', 50, 1, 17, 104896) While you have perfect right to demand good treatment from the employers, adequate wages from them and proper quarters, it is expected of you that you will render proper and honest service for the wages that you get.
('63', 50, 1, 18, 105113) If you will only consider for a moment, you will find, by reason of your being employed as labourers of a particular concern, you become part proprietors of that concern, in the same way as those who had invested money.
('63', 50, 1, 19, 105333) Labour, as a matter of fact, is as much money as metallic coin.
('63', 50, 1, 20, 105397) In the same way as money, labour is also put in a particular concern.
('63', 50, 1, 21, 105467) Just as without money your labour will be useless, so all the money of the world will be useless if there is no labour.
('63', 50, 1, 22, 105587) Therefore, you must take a pride in the concern where you are labouring.
('63', 50, 1, 23, 105660) While on the one hand you will be after your rights as part proprietors, on the other hand, considering that concern as yours, render your honest service for that concern.
('63', 50, 1, 24, 105832) Last, I am glad that you have given me a small purse for the Harijan cause and I thank you also for the photo frames you have given.
('63', 50, 1, 25, 105965) They will also be sold for the Harijan cause.
