('63', 57, 1, 2, 116790) 57. SPEECH AT LAYING OF FOUNDATION STONE FOR HARIJAN SCHOOL, DEVACOTTAH
('63', 57, 2, 3, 116862) January 28, 1934 I am obliged to you for this address and for your determination to help the poor and give them all possible facilities and freedom.
('63', 57, 2, 4, 117011) I am glad to learn that you have opened a free library to all without caste distinction.
('63', 57, 2, 5, 117100) It has also given me very great pleasure to lay today the foundation stone for the school which is designed for the use of all people without distinction including Harijans.
('63', 57, 2, 6, 117274) I hope that the school will be a prosperous one in the sense that it will be attended by all classes and you will take care to engage such teachers as will give real education, to the boys and girls who enter here, both of the heart and the head.
('63', 57, 3, 7, 117521) The Hindu, 30 1 1934
('63', 57, 4, 8, 117542) 58. SPEECH AT HARIJAN CHERI, CHITHANUR January 28, 1934
('63', 57, 5, 9, 117598) Gandhiji complimented them on their having a progressive school, and referring to the Harijan Nattar problem, said: I had known about the trouble between the Harijans and Nattars.
('63', 57, 5, 10, 117778) It is undoubtedly unfortunate that among the Hindus themselves there should be any such trouble.
('63', 57, 5, 11, 117875) It is undoubtedly shameful that there should be interference even with your freedom to dress and to move how you like.
('63', 57, 5, 12, 117994) I have not the shadow of doubt that you have precisely the same rights to the use of temples and roads and to regulate your habits of dress as the so called savarna Hindus have, and I would like you to shed the fear you have of being molested in the exercise of your liberty.
('63', 57, 5, 13, 118270) I would like you to be brave and courageous and face the sufferings in the exercise of your freedom.
('63', 57, 5, 14, 118371) You should also remember and know that at the present moment there is a growing body of reformers who are your true friends and servants, and I have no doubt that they will stand by you in your sufferings.
('63', 57, 5, 15, 118577) But remember in your sufferings let there be no hate.
('63', 57, 6, 16, 118631) Continuing, Gandhiji made a forceful appeal for their abstaining from drink and eating carrion.
('63', 57, 6, 17, 118727) The Hindu, 30 1 1934
('63', 57, 7, 18, 118748) 1 At the conclusion of the meeting the presents were auctioned.
('63', 58, 0, 1, 118812) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 59
('63', 58, 1, 2, 118855) 59. INTERVIEW WITH THE NATTARS, DEVACOTTAH
('63', 58, 2, 3, 118898) January 28, 1934
('63', 58, 3, 4, 118915) Gandhiji spoke at first for fifteen minutes.
('63', 58, 3, 5, 118960) He said even while in Poona the Nattar Harijan question had been brought to his notice.
('63', 58, 3, 6, 119048) He knew what was happening here.
('63', 58, 3, 7, 119081) Nattars and Harijans had quarrelled and he knew of it.
('63', 58, 3, 8, 119136) But he wanted to tell them as a Hindu that the Harijans had not asked for anything to which they were not entitled as Hindus and as human beings.
('63', 58, 3, 9, 119282) The Harijans had every right to wear what dress they pleased or what ornaments.
('63', 58, 3, 10, 119362) Why should they not?
('63', 58, 3, 11, 119383) Why should the Nattars have a sense of offence at this?
('63', 58, 3, 12, 119439) He asked Nattars to understand what was happening in the world today.
('63', 58, 3, 13, 119509) They could not resist reforms.
('63', 58, 3, 14, 119540) They should be kind to the Harijans who were their blood brothers.
('63', 58, 3, 15, 119607) They were the children of the same great God, ‘whose mercy was full to all men alike’; the Nattars and Harijans were members of the same family.
('63', 58, 3, 16, 119752) Learned men might hold that untouchability had a sanction in the Hindu Shastras.
('63', 58, 3, 17, 119833) But he would assure them that he had looked into the question most carefully and would assure them that there were many learned men and many holy men who were Hindus who held that untouchability as practised today had absolutely no sanction in the Shastras.
('63', 58, 3, 18, 120091) Could untruths be in the Shastras?
('63', 58, 3, 19, 120126) Untouchability was an untruth.
('63', 58, 3, 20, 120157) Therefore, they should not debate this question but act in accordance with truth.
('63', 58, 3, 21, 120239) One elderly Nattar stood up and stated that they had no quarrel with the Harijans who kept the old order in Hindu society.
('63', 58, 3, 22, 120362) But now the Harijans were violating established traditions and customs.
('63', 58, 3, 23, 120434) The Nattars never objected to Harijan women wearing what dress they liked.
('63', 58, 3, 24, 120509) In regard to the Harijan men it was only on public occasions and in temple festivals that the Nattars insisted on the Harijans observing old customs.
('63', 58, 3, 25, 120659) Gandhiji replied that the Nattars should look into the question and decide whether any particular tradition was good or bad and act accordingly.
('63', 58, 3, 26, 120804) But the Nattar leader continued to insist that established tradition could not be violated.
('63', 58, 3, 27, 120896) Gandhiji answered that there were certain laws common to all human society and one of them was that no body of men could force on another body of men particular modes of dress and ornaments, etc.
('63', 58, 3, 28, 121092) If the Harijans wanted a change in regard to these matters, why should they be prevented?
('63', 58, 3, 29, 121182) If, on this account, the Nattars molested theHarijans and the matter went to a court of law the Nattars’ case would be rejected at once.
('63', 58, 3, 30, 121319) Religion, dharma and established law alike forbade such interference.
('63', 58, 4, 31, 121389) He then made a final appeal to the Nattars and said that they should not allow matters to drift but make up their minds to do justice to the Harijans and treat them kindly and affectionately as brothers.
('63', 58, 4, 32, 121593) Such a procedure would benefit both the Nattars and the Harijans alike.
('63', 58, 4, 33, 121665) If he had any doubt that his advice would benefit the Harijans
('63', 59, 0, 1, 121728) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 59, 1, 2, 121769) only and not the Nattars, he would have hesitated to tender this advice.
('63', 59, 1, 3, 121842) But he was absolutely convinced that his advice would be beneficial and bring lasting good not only to the Harijans but to the Nattars also.
('63', 59, 2, 4, 121983) After the Nattar leader garlanded Gandhiji, the function terminated at 5 minutes to 1.45 p.m.
('63', 59, 2, 5, 122077) The Hindu, 30 1 1934
('63', 59, 3, 6, 122098) 60. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU” 1
('63', 59, 4, 7, 122129) January 28, 1934 I had an hour’s conversation with a very large number of Nattars.
('63', 59, 4, 8, 122212) 2 Their leaders spoke frankly.
('63', 59, 4, 9, 122243) I put it to the Nattar represen tatives present that it was wrong for them to plead the usage of custom in favour of depriving fellow beings of liberty of action as to their mode of dress or use of ornaments.
('63', 59, 4, 10, 122452) I am hoping that my conversation will produce the desired effect.
('63', 59, 4, 11, 122518) The Nattars were very attentive to what I said to them.
('63', 59, 4, 12, 122574) What gives me hope however is the fact that there are some Nattars who are earnest about reforms.
('63', 59, 4, 13, 122672) Besides, there is also an increasing awakening among Harijans themselves regarding their elementary rights.
('63', 59, 4, 14, 122780) There is no mistaking the fact that the phenomenal awakening that has taken place over the untouchability question is slowly affecting the villagers who were hitherto untouched by anything happening outside their own respective villages.
('63', 59, 5, 15, 123018) Answering another question, whether there was any attempt on the part of H. H. Puri Shankarachariar to see him at Devacottah, Gandhiji replied: His representative did see me and I said I would gladly have friendly discussion with him by appointment, but there was no time left in Devacottah.
('63', 59, 5, 16, 123310) The letter reached me only a few minutes before 1 o’clock yesterday, when I was to have a conference with the Nattar representatives but as I have said, I would gladly set apart an hour at Coonoor, if that would suit His Holiness.
('63', 59, 5, 17, 123541) In fact, I have gone out of my way to hold friendly conversations with those who claimed to be sanatanists.
('63', 59, 5, 18, 123649) The Hindu, 29 1 1934

('63', 63, 0, 1, 128398) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 63, 1, 2, 128439) 66. APPEAL TO THE WORLD
('63', 63, 2, 3, 128463) [On or before January 30, 1934] 1
('63', 63, 3, 4, 128497) I have received the following wire from Babu Rajendra Prasad:
('63', 63, 4, 5, 128559) Please consider the propriety of appealing to foreign countries, particularly to Indians abroad.
('63', 63, 4, 6, 128656) The reconstruction of the province requires crores.
('63', 63, 4, 7, 128708) Several thousands have perished and many times more injured and rendered homeless and resourceless.
('63', 63, 5, 8, 128808) The flourishing towns of Monghyr, Muzaffarpur, Darbhanga, Motihari, Samastipur, Sitamarhi and Madhubani are heaps of bricks.
('63', 63, 5, 9, 128933) Others like Patna, Chhapra and Bhagalpur fared better, but even there, hundreds of houses were demolished and hundreds are standing seriously damaged.
('63', 63, 6, 10, 129084) Countryside crops in vast tracts were destroyed or damaged by the flood caused by the eruption of water and sand through fissures in the earth.
('63', 63, 6, 11, 129228) Extensive areas were rendered a desert by heavy deposits of sand and other extensive areas covered with spouted water.
('63', 63, 7, 12, 129347) Wells are choked up and are causing scarcity of drinking water.
('63', 63, 7, 13, 129411) Many sugarcane factories were disabled and endangering the crop of one lakh acres unless prompt steps are taken to save.
('63', 63, 7, 14, 129532) I heartily endorse it and hope that Indians living in different parts of the world will send the utmost they can.
('63', 63, 7, 15, 129646) I have in mind espe cially my old friends and fellow workers in Africa.
('63', 63, 7, 16, 129718) And merchants and others living in England and on the Continent, Japan and America are also requested to send liberal contributions.
('63', 63, 7, 17, 129851) In point of distress nothing perhaps has surpassed the Bihar calamity in India within living memory.
('63', 63, 7, 18, 129952) Reluctant though I have always been to appeal to non Indians for pecuniary help, not from any prudery, but out of delicate consideration, I gladly adopt Babu Rajendra Prasad’s suggestion and invite numerous non Indian friends in Europe, America and Africa and other parts of the world to render such help as they can.
('63', 63, 7, 19, 130270) Contributions may be sent direct to Babu Rajendra Prasad, Patna; or to my address, Wardha, Central Provinces.
('63', 63, 7, 20, 130380) The Hindu, 3 2 1934
('63', 63, 8, 21, 130400) 1 The Bombay Chronicle, 1 2 1934, published the appeal under the date January 30 and The Searchlight, 2 2 1934, under the date January 31.

('63', 68, 6, 15, 138172) BROTHER RAJENDRA PRASAD, What am I to write?

('63', 68, 6, 28, 138811) Will not my not coming there be preferable ?
('63', 68, 6, 29, 138856) I shall do as you advise.

('63', 71, 0, 1, 142006) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 71, 1, 2, 142047) rendered full co operation to the Government.
('63', 71, 1, 3, 142093) At this instance I have made an appeal to the non Indian friends all over the world.
('63', 71, 1, 4, 142178) You must have seen Reuter’s cable.
('63', 71, 1, 5, 142213) Chandrashankar will be sending you a copy.
('63', 71, 1, 6, 142256) The male members of the Ashram who have just come out of prison have suspended their civil resistance and gone to Bihar.
('63', 71, 1, 7, 142377) The calamity is of such magnitude that all the help that the whole world may give will be a drop in the ocean.
('63', 71, 1, 8, 142488) But I suppose there is a spiritual result seen and unseen of such material help.
('63', 71, 1, 9, 142569) The stricken people will derive comfort from the thought that the whole world is thinking of them and coming to their assistance.
('63', 71, 1, 10, 142699) I am presently writing to Andrews and Holmes 1 and Rolland.
('63', 71, 1, 11, 142759) Of the gradual but sure dissolution of untouchability you know all from the cuttings that Chandrashankar has been sending you in addition to the copies of Harijan.
('63', 71, 1, 12, 142923) The measures the Government have adopted to crush the spirit of the people defy description.
('63', 71, 1, 13, 143016) The gagging of the Press has made it well nigh impossible to know the news accurately and to publish what little oozes out in spite of the strictest censorship.
('63', 71, 1, 14, 143177) Copies I am sending you of original documents will give you an inkling of what is happ ening.
('63', 71, 1, 15, 143271) I do not want any public propaganda but you may make what use you like among friends and among the official world there.
('63', 71, 1, 16, 143392) As you are aware, the two attempts I made to gain the ear of the autho rities ended in failure.
('63', 71, 1, 17, 143488) True, I had courteous replies but no admission of error.
('63', 71, 1, 18, 143545) On the contrary both from Bengal and Bombay I received a blank denial of the charges made including repudiation of the evidence of what Mira had seen with her own eyes.
('63', 71, 1, 19, 143714) I am trying my best to find a way to honourable peace.
('63', 71, 1, 20, 143769) But there can be none so long as the Government persist in repression.
('63', 71, 1, 21, 143840) My fear is that it has been worse in the Frontier Province than in Bengal.
('63', 71, 1, 22, 143915) But news is more difficult to get from there even than from Bengal.
('63', 71, 1, 23, 143983) All this, however, does not mean that I have given up all hope.
('63', 71, 1, 24, 144047) For I can never lose faith in prayer which is the same thing as nonviolence whether it be through letter writing or civil resistance or mute prayer only.
('63', 71, 1, 25, 144201) I simply mention the difficulties in the way.
('63', 71, 1, 26, 144247) Friends in England should have as accurate news as I can gather or rather the news that comes to me unsought.
('63', 71, 1, 27, 144357) My one preoccupation is war against untouchability.
('63', 71, 1, 28, 144409) I wonder if you realize that I hardly have time to read the voluminous post that follows me during the tour.
('63', 71, 1, 29, 144518) I read only the portion that
('63', 71, 2, 30, 144547) 1 John Haynes Holmes

('63', 73, 5, 17, 147385) COONOOR, February 1, 1934
('63', 73, 6, 18, 147411) MY DEAR KAMALANI,
('63', 73, 7, 19, 147429) I am very much behindhand in my correspondence.
('63', 73, 7, 20, 147477) I reach your letter of 29th December only today.
('63', 73, 7, 21, 147526) I appreciate the committee’s suggestion.
('63', 73, 7, 22, 147567) It shows their anxiety to show better results.
('63', 73, 7, 23, 147614) Please assure them that I know they are doing all they can.
('63', 73, 7, 24, 147674) My own conviction is that a paid Indian mission cannot do better and cannot render them effective help.
('63', 73, 7, 25, 147778) It will be wrong to deduce necessity for a permanent Indian organization from some good work that a man like Bhulabhai Desai may do.
('63', 73, 7, 26, 147911) Such men may go to England more frequently than they do.
('63', 73, 7, 27, 147968) But a permanent orga nization can do no good and may do harm.
('63', 73, 7, 28, 148030) People have to work out their salvation here and no amount of misrepresentation or suppre ssion of news will be able to restrain them when mass realization of strength has come to people.
('63', 73, 7, 29, 148218) What will be effective there is equal mass
('63', 73, 8, 30, 148261) Secretary, “Friends of India”, London
('63', 74, 0, 1, 148299) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 75
('63', 74, 1, 2, 148342) realization there of the consciousness of wrong being done to India in every way.
('63', 74, 1, 3, 148424) That realization can only come through the persisent efforts of societies like yours, even as here it is our effort that must count.
('63', 74, 1, 4, 148557) The money that Vithalbhai sent to me was to be used for constructive work here.
('63', 74, 1, 5, 148637) I propose to publish the correspondence as soon as I can put together the papers.
('63', 74, 1, 6, 148719) I could not have accepted the purse for any other purpose.
('63', 74, 1, 7, 148778) I know that in holding the views I have expressed here, I belong to the minority.
('63', 74, 1, 8, 148860) But the conviction that came to me in 1920 has grown stronger.
('63', 74, 1, 9, 148923) Even in the heyday of the struggle I never felt the want of an Indian organization in foreign lands.
('63', 74, 1, 10, 149024) Had there been any, perhaps neither the band of true Englishmen and Englishwomen who are working there now nor the band of true Americans working in America would have come into being.

('63', 78, 1, 2, 154813) 86. INTERVIEW TO ADI DRAVIDA JAN SABHA, COONOOR 1
('63', 78, 2, 3, 154863) February 1, 1934
('63', 78, 3, 4, 154880) The first question discussed was that of Harijan unemployment, which is very acute in these parts.
('63', 78, 3, 5, 154979) The deputation suggested the opening of a leather factory to give employment to Harijans.
('63', 78, 3, 6, 155069) Mahatmaji replied that such a leather factory in Coonoor could give employment at best only to a few Harijans, and even that would go into the hands of the professional cobblers.
('63', 78, 3, 7, 155248) The Central Board was engaged in drawing up a comprehensive scheme of economic survey and relief.
('63', 78, 3, 8, 155346) The suggestions of the deputation should go to the Central Board.
('63', 78, 3, 9, 155412) He asked the deputationists for statistical information regarding Harijan unemployment in the various occupations.
('63', 78, 4, 10, 155527) The second point discussed was the necessity for a special paper for Harijans wherein all the grievances of the Harijans could be legitimately ventilated.
('63', 78, 4, 11, 155682) The deputation was anxious that the Central Board should assist in financing such a venture.
('63', 78, 4, 12, 155775) Mahatmaji did not think money should, at this stage, be spent on such a venture.
('63', 78, 4, 13, 155856) Money was needed for more urgent items of relief.
('63', 78, 4, 14, 155906) And then he pointed out that there were widely circulated Tamil and English papers which would not cut out representations from the Harijans.
('63', 78, 4, 15, 156048) The deputation should make the best use of such papers.
('63', 78, 5, 16, 156104) The next question discussed was how far Gandhiji felt the savarna Hindus were changing their mind in regard to untouchability.
('63', 78, 5, 17, 156231) Mr. Manickam asked: “So far as the tour has progressed, do you find adequate change of heart among the savarnas?” Gandhiji’s reply was characteristic.
('63', 78, 5, 18, 156382) I have no doubt whatever in my mind that the change of heart is taking place.
('63', 78, 5, 19, 156460) I do not want to issue a certificate of merit to the savarna workers, but the change was phenomenal and even beyond expectations.
('63', 78, 5, 20, 156590) The Hindus are now forming themselves into two groups—one that of the reformers who consider themselves to be Harijans and not merely patrons of the Harijans, and the other those who refuse to have anything to do with the Harijan movement.
('63', 78, 5, 21, 156830) I have no doubt whatever that the former will grow and soon absorb the latter.
('63', 78, 6, 22, 156909) Mr. Manickam then asked: “But Mahatmaji, we read in the papers that even after your persuasion the Nattars are adamant and swear by old tradition.” Mahatmaji
('63', 78, 7, 23, 157067) 1 The deputation consisted of 12 persons and was headed by R. T. Kesavalu and R. T. Manickam.
('63', 79, 0, 1, 157161) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 79, 1, 2, 157202) smiled at this and said: Ah, I do not know what the newspapers have published, but the old Nattar representative who spoke to me seemed as though he had been coached, but what matters is that over a hundred Nattars listened to my advice with goodwill and let me tell you there are important Nattars who agree with me and are helping our workers.
('63', 79, 2, 3, 157548) Gandhiji assured the deputationists that they need have no fear, and that the desired change would come soon.
('63', 79, 3, 4, 157658) The deputationists observed: “From the very beginning our Sabha has stood out for Joint Electorate with reservation of seats.
('63', 79, 3, 5, 157784) We are assuring our community that our future is safe in the hands of the reformers.
('63', 79, 3, 6, 157869) Unless we can carry this conviction to our community, joint effort would be impossible.
('63', 79, 3, 7, 157957) Hence our anxiety to get your assurance of the coming change.” Gandhiji replied: The proof of the pudding is in the eating, and what should convince you is the work going on before your eyes.
('63', 79, 3, 8, 158149) Even here in Coonoor in my rest eager crowds surround me and I ask them for money for the Harijan fund.
('63', 79, 3, 9, 158253) They give me their annas and sometimes their rupee.
('63', 79, 3, 10, 158305) This movement is a religious movement, and everywhere people are recognizing it now.
('63', 79, 3, 11, 158390) That is why even here the crowds daily increase in giving me more money.
('63', 79, 4, 12, 158463) The next question discussed was regarding the number of seats assigned to the Harijans in the Madras Legislative Council as per the Yeravda Pact.
('63', 79, 4, 13, 158609) He assured the deputationists that their thirty votes would always help them in turning the corner in regard to their problems as they arose in the Council.
('63', 79, 4, 14, 158766) If you realize as I do the value of thirty votes in the Council, you will have no fears.
('63', 79, 4, 15, 158855) In South Africa, the Indian community with very much less voting strength could turn the scales in their favour at critical junctures.
('63', 79, 4, 16, 158990) Here your position is absolutely strong unless everyone else in the Council is opposed to you which is impossible.
('63', 79, 4, 17, 159105) So my word to you is: Have no fear for the future.
('63', 79, 5, 18, 159156) The last question was regarding the sweeper Harijans in general.
('63', 79, 5, 19, 159221) “Because Harijans are sweepers and scavengers, savarnas refuse to treat them as social equals.” Gandhiji replied: Not at all.
('63', 79, 5, 20, 159347) Here it is a question of utter stupidity.
('63', 79, 5, 21, 159389) We must remove this ignorance.
('63', 79, 5, 22, 159420) In my Ashram, I myself and all the inmates are sweepers and scavengers.
('63', 79, 5, 23, 159492) This is no new question to me.
('63', 79, 5, 24, 159523) The sweeping and scavenging work is first class social service.
('63', 79, 5, 25, 159587) With knowledge coming, this superstition will die.
('63', 79, 6, 26, 159638) The deputationists fervently prayed that Gandhiji should come again to these
('63', 80, 0, 1, 159715) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 81
('63', 80, 1, 2, 159758) parts soon.
('63', 80, 1, 3, 159770) Oh, if you want me to come again, I shall.
('63', 80, 1, 4, 159813) Only promise me life till my 99th year.
('63', 80, 1, 5, 159853) I shall be in Coonoor in my 99th year.
('63', 80, 1, 6, 159892) The Hindu, 3 2 1934

('63', 80, 6, 15, 160188) 88. BIHAR AND UNTOUCHABILITY
('63', 80, 7, 16, 160217) A friendly wire says, “Will you not lay aside untouchability and go to Bihar?” An angry wire says, “Must Mahatma fiddle while Bihar is burning?” Both the wires pay me an undeserved compliment and exaggerate my capacity for service, as they assume that I can do more than my comrades.
('63', 80, 7, 17, 160501) I have no such hallucination about my capacity.
('63', 80, 7, 18, 160549) Rajendra Prasad is one of the best among my co workers.
('63', 80, 7, 19, 160605) He can command my services whenever he likes.
('63', 80, 7, 20, 160651) The Harijan cause is as much his as it is mine, even as the cause of Bihar is as much mine as it is his.
('63', 80, 7, 21, 160756) But God has summoned him to the Bihar relief as He has chosen the Harijan cause for me.
('63', 80, 7, 22, 160844) When the call comes from Bihar, I hope I shall not be found wanting.
('63', 80, 7, 23, 160913) Champaran discovered me when I was a mere wanderer.
('63', 80, 7, 24, 160965) Babu Braj Kishore Prasad and his band of workers gave me their complete allegiance when India was wondering what place I had in her public life.
('63', 80, 7, 25, 161110) I am tied to Bihar by sacred ties which are indissoluble.
('63', 80, 7, 26, 161168) Therefore I need no spur to send me to Bihar.
('63', 80, 7, 27, 161214) Perhaps I am serving her best by remaining at my post for the time being.
('63', 80, 7, 28, 161288) All the world is directing her attention to the catastrophe.
('63', 80, 7, 29, 161349) It would be presumption on my part to rush to Bihar when all are ready
('63', 80, 8, 30, 161420) 1 In the source the letter has been placed between letters of January 31 and February 2.
('63', 81, 0, 1, 161509) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 81, 1, 2, 161550) to assist her.
('63', 81, 1, 3, 161565) Those also help who know how and when to wait.
('63', 81, 1, 4, 161612) But another wire says I must use the Harijan collections for Bihar relief.
('63', 81, 1, 5, 161687) I think it would be a clear breach of trust on my part if I listened to the advice.
('63', 81, 1, 6, 161771) We may not afford to be unnerved in the face of great calamities.
('63', 81, 1, 7, 161837) Not all the riches of the world would restore Bihar to her original condition.
('63', 81, 1, 8, 161916) Time must elapse before reconstruction takes place and things become normal.
('63', 81, 1, 9, 161993) What is necessary is that those who have anything to give are induced to give the most, not the least, they can.
('63', 81, 1, 10, 162106) But I make bold to suggest that, in reconstructing life in Bihar, if the wisest use is to be made of the help that is being sent, the organizers would have resolutely to set their faces against reproducing evil customs and habits.
('63', 81, 1, 11, 162337) They may not encourage untouchability or caste divisions unperceivably based on untouchability.
('63', 81, 1, 12, 162433) Nature has been impartial in her destruction.
('63', 81, 1, 13, 162479) Shall we retain our partiality—caste against caste, Hindu, Muslim, Christian, Parsi, Jew, against one another—in reconstruction, or shall we learn from her the lesson that there is no such thing as untouchability as we practise it today?
('63', 81, 1, 14, 162717) Tremendous responsibility rests both upon the Government and the unofficial agency as to how reconstruction is to be undertaken.
('63', 81, 1, 15, 162846) And as both are working in co operation for this purpose, it ought not to be difficult to rebuild Bihar on human and sanitary lines.
('63', 81, 1, 16, 162979) I share the belief with the whole world—civilized and uncivi lized—that calamities such as the Bihar one come to mankind as chas tisement for their sins.
('63', 81, 1, 17, 163133) When that conviction comes from the heart, people pray, repent and purify themselves.
('63', 81, 1, 18, 163219) I regard untouchability as such a grave sin as to warrant divine chastisement.
('63', 81, 1, 19, 163298) I am not affected by posers such as ‘why punishment for an age old sin’ or ‘why pun ishment to Bihar and not to the South’ or ‘why an earthquake and not some other form of punishment’.
('63', 81, 1, 20, 163483) My answer is: I am not God.
('63', 81, 1, 21, 163511) Therefore I have but a limited knowledge of His purpose.
('63', 81, 1, 22, 163568) Such cala mities are not a mere caprice of the Deity or Nature.
('63', 81, 1, 23, 163632) They obey fixed laws as surely as the planets move in obedience to laws governing their movement.
('63', 81, 1, 24, 163730) Only we do not know the laws governing these events and, therefore, call them calamities or disturbances.
('63', 81, 1, 25, 163836) Whatever, therefore, may be said about them must be regarded as guess work.
('63', 81, 1, 26, 163912) But guessing has its definite place in man’s life.
('63', 81, 1, 27, 163963) It is an ennobling thing for me to guess that the Bihar disturbance is due to the sin of untouchability.
('63', 81, 1, 28, 164068) It makes me humble, it spurs me to greater effort towards its removal, it
('63', 82, 0, 1, 164142) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 83
('63', 82, 1, 2, 164185) encourages me to purify myself, it brings me nearer to my Maker.
('63', 82, 1, 3, 164250) That my guess may be wrong does not affect the results named by me.
('63', 82, 1, 4, 164318) For what is guess to the critic or the sceptic is a living belief with me, and I base my future actions on that belief.
('63', 82, 1, 5, 164438) Such guesses become superstitions when they lead to no purification and may even lead to feuds.
('63', 82, 1, 6, 164534) But such misuse of divine events cannot deter men of faith from interpreting them as a call to them for repentance for their sins.
('63', 82, 1, 7, 164665) I do not interpret this chastisement as an exclusive punishment for the sin of untouchability.
('63', 82, 1, 8, 164760) It is open to others to read in it divine wrath against many other sins.
('63', 82, 1, 9, 164833) Let anti untouchability reformers regard the earthquake as a Nemesis for the sin of untouchability.
('63', 82, 1, 10, 164933) They cannot go wrong, if they have the faith that I have.
('63', 82, 1, 11, 164991) They will help Bihar more and not less for that faith.
('63', 82, 1, 12, 165046) And they will try to create an atmosphere against reproduc tion of untouchability in any scheme of reconstruction.
('63', 82, 2, 13, 165161) Harijan, 2 2 1934
('63', 82, 3, 14, 165179) 89. SOME QUESTIONS ANSWERED 1
('63', 82, 4, 15, 165209) I have a collection of questions in front of me.
('63', 82, 4, 16, 165258) These I have answered during the Kerala tour.
('63', 82, 4, 17, 165304) Some of the questions being of general interest, I propose to give them below with their answers.
('63', 82, 5, 18, 165402) Q. The local support one gets for Harijan work is very poor.
('63', 82, 5, 19, 165463) People give readily when you come.
('63', 82, 5, 20, 165498) Will you make an appeal for help to my work?
('63', 82, 6, 21, 165543) A. It is no use blaming the people.
('63', 82, 6, 22, 165579) If they do not give, the fault must lie with you.
('63', 82, 6, 23, 165629) You have not inspired sufficient confidence in you or your work.
('63', 82, 6, 24, 165694) You have to be patient and concentrate on producing the best quality of work, and you will find the support coming without fail.
('63', 82, 6, 25, 165823) I know of no healthy activity failing for want of pecuniary support.
('63', 82, 6, 26, 165892) But people are like God.
('63', 82, 6, 27, 165917) They try the patience of workers and answer prayers only when they have proved their sincerity and worth.
('63', 82, 7, 28, 166023) Q. Does the pay of Harijan workers at Harijan centres run by the Harijan Sevak Sangh come under welfare work or overhead charges?
('63', 82, 8, 29, 166153) A. It depends upon the nature of the work done by the worker.
('63', 82, 8, 30, 166215) If he is doing constructive work, such as teaching in a Harijan school, it is welfare work.
('63', 82, 8, 31, 166307) If he is keeping accounts or the like at an office, his
('63', 82, 9, 32, 166363) 1 A Gujarati version of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 28 1 1934.
('63', 83, 0, 1, 166430) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 83, 1, 2, 166471) pay would be part of overhead charges.
('63', 83, 2, 3, 166510) Q. There is a suggestion made by you that a society which disregards its servants suffers.
('63', 83, 2, 4, 166601) Do you imply that Harijans are servants?
('63', 83, 3, 5, 166642) A. I do.
('63', 83, 3, 6, 166651) I have stated a fact.
('63', 83, 3, 7, 166673) Harijans today are as a body servants of the society, and as such they are treated in a disgraceful manner.
('63', 83, 3, 8, 166781) He who runs may see how the society suffers in a thousand ways for its criminal neglect of its most useful servants.
('63', 83, 3, 9, 166898) This neglect accounts for a tremendous economic, social, sanitary and moral waste.
('63', 83, 3, 10, 166981) My statement of fact does not imply that Harijans should be compelled to remain servants for ever.
('63', 83, 4, 11, 167080) Q. There is lack of sympathy on the part of khadi workers for the Harijan cause as shown by the absence of Harijan recruits in khadi service.
('63', 83, 5, 12, 167222) A. So far as I am aware, the charge is not true.
('63', 83, 5, 13, 167271) There are many Harijans in the khadi service.
('63', 83, 5, 14, 167317) Certainly there is no bar anywhere against the employment of Harijans in that service.
('63', 83, 6, 15, 167404) Q. A practice is growing up of Harijans adopting caste surnames, e.g., Nambudri, Nambiar, etc.
('63', 83, 6, 16, 167499) What do you say to this?
('63', 83, 7, 17, 167524) A. I know the practice.
('63', 83, 7, 18, 167548) It is not new.
('63', 83, 7, 19, 167563) I dislike it.
('63', 83, 7, 20, 167577) Harijans do not want to steal into the so called savarna society.
('63', 83, 7, 21, 167643) The latter has openly to admit them as blood brothers and sisters.
('63', 83, 7, 22, 167710) The present movement is one of self purification, penance and reparation by savarna Hindus.
('63', 83, 8, 23, 167802) Q. You desire ladies to sacrifice their jewels.
('63', 83, 8, 24, 167850) Why do you not ask the caste man to sacrifice his pride by giving up his thread?
('63', 83, 9, 25, 167931) A. There is no parallel between the two cases.
('63', 83, 9, 26, 167978) The thread is a symbol of consecration for those who believe in it.
('63', 83, 9, 27, 168046) I do not wear it, because it has no meaning for me and I know that millions go without it.
('63', 83, 9, 28, 168137) In so far as it is used as a mark of superiority, it is worse than jewellery and the mere discarding of the thread would be valueless if pride, of which it is a symbol, is also not discarded.
('63', 83, 9, 29, 168329) There is nothing to prevent Harijans from adopting it if they choose.
('63', 83, 9, 30, 168399) But I should strongly discountenance the practice, as it would be an imitation without the original meaning behind it.
('63', 83, 10, 31, 168518) Q. I represent a brotherhood which is out to break caste distinctions and to preach harmony between religions.
('63', 83, 10, 32, 168629) Sree Narayana Guru advocated one God, one religion, one caste.
('63', 83, 10, 33, 168692) What is your message for me?
('63', 83, 11, 34, 168721) A. I wish you all success.
('63', 83, 11, 35, 168748) I do believe in harmony between all religions.
('63', 83, 11, 36, 168795) I have myself worked at it in my humble way.
('63', 83, 11, 37, 168840) Caste distinctions, in so far as they imply superiority of one over another,
('63', 84, 0, 1, 168917) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 85
('63', 84, 1, 2, 168960) have to be abolished altogether.
('63', 84, 1, 3, 168993) That is merely a phase or a grade of untouchability.
('63', 84, 1, 4, 169046) But in so far as caste in the sense of varna fulfils Nature’s law of conservation of human energy and true economics, it is good to recognize and obey the law.
('63', 84, 1, 5, 169206) You may deny the existence of any such law.
('63', 84, 1, 6, 169250) I can then only refer you to the few proofs I have given in the columns of Harijan in support of it.
('63', 84, 1, 7, 169351) I had the honour of meeting Sree Narayana Guru when he was still in the flesh and had a discussion with him on the point.
('63', 84, 1, 8, 169473) Belief in one God is the corner stone of all religions.
('63', 84, 1, 9, 169529) But I do not foresee a time when there would be only one religion on earth in practice.
('63', 84, 1, 10, 169617) In theory, since there is one God, there can be only one religion.
('63', 84, 1, 11, 169684) But in practice, no two persons I have known have had the same and identical conception of God.
('63', 84, 1, 12, 169780) Therefore, there will, perhaps, always be different religions answering to different temperaments and climatic conditions.
('63', 84, 1, 13, 169903) But I can clearly see the time coming when people belonging to different faiths will have the same regard for other faiths that they have for their own.
('63', 84, 1, 14, 170056) I think that we have to find unity in diversity.
('63', 84, 1, 15, 170105) I need say no more about caste beyond this that, in so far as abolition of distinctions of high and low are concerned, there is but one caste.
('63', 84, 1, 16, 170248) We are all children of one and the same God and, therefore, absolutely equal.
('63', 84, 1, 17, 170326) Harijan, 2 2 1934
('63', 84, 2, 18, 170344) 90. NOTES
('63', 84, 3, 19, 170354) THE CHEAPEST PLATFORM
('63', 84, 4, 20, 170376) In discussing the economics of public tours, in which vast crowds have to be considered, workers have suggested that platforms alone cost Rs. 50 at the least computation.
('63', 84, 4, 21, 170547) This need not be so.
('63', 84, 4, 22, 170568) Provision for vast crowds presupposes that the cause is popular and that, therefore, there will be voluntary help forthcoming.
('63', 84, 4, 23, 170695) In such favourable atmosphere it should not be difficult to borrow bricks.
('63', 84, 4, 24, 170770) Labour should be voluntary.
('63', 84, 4, 25, 170798) Mud should be used in the place of mortar.
('63', 84, 4, 26, 170841) A solid platform can thus be made for a rupee or thereabouts.
('63', 84, 4, 27, 170903) No skilled labour is necessary for erecting such a platform.
('63', 84, 4, 28, 170964) The only expense to be incurred will be that of carting bricks to and fro.
('63', 84, 4, 29, 171039) But even such a platform can be dispensed with.
('63', 84, 4, 30, 171087) If a ring is kept in the middle of the audience, large enough for a motor to turn round comfortably, and a broad passage left for it to pass through to the ring, the motor can be used as a solid platform.
('63', 84, 4, 31, 171292) This was successfully
('63', 85, 0, 1, 171314) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 85, 1, 2, 171355) tried at Sivaganga and Manamadura.
('63', 85, 1, 3, 171390) If a higher platform is needed, the top of a motor lorry makes a platform high enough for the largest audience.
('63', 85, 1, 4, 171502) This, too, I have tried successfully in previous tours.
('63', 85, 1, 5, 171558) The fence of the ring should be fairly strong.
('63', 85, 1, 6, 171605) Strong wooden posts and stout cords can be borrowed for the purpose, and the ring can be erected inside of two hours if sufficient voluntary labour is available.
('63', 85, 1, 7, 171767) Volunteers worth the name should be able to prepare these things without fuss and without any strain.
('63', 85, 2, 8, 171869) “GITA” RECITERS
('63', 85, 3, 9, 171885) The readers of Harijan know what Gita means to me.
('63', 85, 3, 10, 171936) I have always regarded the learning by heart of such books as the Gita a very desirable thing.
('63', 85, 3, 11, 172031) But I was never able to learn all the chapters of the Gita by heart myself though I made several attempts at it.
('63', 85, 3, 12, 172144) I know I am very stupid at memorizing.
('63', 85, 3, 13, 172183) So whenever I meet anyone who knows the Gita by heart, he or she commands my respect.
('63', 85, 3, 14, 172269) I have already met two such during the Tamil Nad tour—a gentleman at Madura and a lady at Devacottah.
('63', 85, 3, 15, 172371) The gentleman at Madura is a merchant unknown to fame; and the lady is Parvatibai, a daughter of the late Justice Sadasiva Iyer, who during his lifetime instituted an annual prize for the person who could best recite the Gita from memory.
('63', 85, 3, 16, 172610) I would like, however, the reciters to realize that the mere recitation is not an end in itself.
('63', 85, 3, 17, 172707) It should be an aid to the contemplation and assimilation of the meaning and the message of the Gita.
('63', 85, 3, 18, 172809) By patience even a parrot can be taught to recite it by heart.
('63', 85, 3, 19, 172872) But he would be no wiser for the recitation.
('63', 85, 3, 20, 172917) The reciter of the Gita should be what its author expects him to be—a yogi in its broad sense.
('63', 85, 3, 21, 173012) It demands from its votaries balance in every thought, word and deed and a perfect correspon dence between the three.
('63', 85, 3, 22, 173130) He whose speech and action do not accord with his thoughts is a humbug or a hypocrite.
('63', 85, 3, 23, 173217) It is necessary to sound this warning, for, of the people who flock to my prayer meetings, many run away, I am afraid, with the thought that they acquire merit by mere attendance at these prayers.
('63', 85, 3, 24, 173414) And since the majority of them are undoubtedly sympathizers with the battle against untouchability, it is necessary to warn them that they are expected to act in accordance with their belief and show by their action that there is no untoucha bility in them and that there is no person lower than themselves.
('63', 85, 4, 25, 173722) FOR SANATANISTS
('63', 85, 5, 26, 173738) As attempts are being made during the tour to draw me to a
('63', 86, 0, 1, 173797) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 87
('63', 86, 1, 2, 173840) public debate with Shankaracharyas and other learned men and as there is much misrepresentation about my replies to proposals for such interviews, I should like to repeat through these columns what I have said in my letters and verbal messages.
('63', 86, 1, 3, 174085) I have no desire to engage in a public debate on the origin of untouchability.
('63', 86, 1, 4, 174164) I do not believe in such debates, nor do I lay any claim to Sanskrit scholarship.
('63', 86, 1, 5, 174246) But I am ready, nay eager, to hold friendly conversations with any sanatanist for the sake solely of arriving at a mutual understanding, discovering points of contact, and, generally, elucidating truth.
('63', 86, 1, 6, 174449) For instance, a challenge is often sent to me with reference to my oft repeated statement that there is no warrant in the Shastras for untouchability as it is practised today and that in the matter of the use of public temples there is no prohibition in the Shastras against those who are today regarded as untouchables.
('63', 86, 1, 7, 174770) I have explained in these pages more than once what I mean by Shastras and what interpretation I put upon the verses that are commonly cited in support of untouchability in general and temple entry prohibition in particular.
('63', 86, 1, 8, 174995) I do not expect all my critics to read the Harijan.
('63', 86, 1, 9, 175047) I would, therefore, gladly explain my meaning to sanatanist friends and in my turn try to understand their objections.
('63', 86, 1, 10, 175166) Surely it is possible to have much common action, even though there may be differences on some matters.
('63', 86, 1, 11, 175270) The reader may also know that such friendly discussions have taken place often enough during the tour.
('63', 86, 1, 12, 175373) But some persons have made it their mission to discredit me anyhow.
('63', 86, 1, 13, 175441) So they make sugges tions for open debates which they know I have refused to adopt, or seek appointments which it is physically impossible for me to make unless I would cancel a whole day’s programme and disappoint thousands of men and women.
('63', 86, 1, 14, 175684) They are not to be placated by any thing I may say or do.
('63', 86, 1, 15, 175742) Time will do what no action of mine can.
('63', 86, 2, 16, 175783) Harijan, 2 2 1934

('63', 94, 1, 2, 186313) 103. LETTER TO HEMPRABHA DAS GUPTA
('63', 94, 2, 3, 186348) February 2, 1934
('63', 94, 3, 4, 186365) HEMPRABHA, I get your letters regularly.
('63', 94, 3, 5, 186406) The earthquake has given me a jolt.
('63', 94, 3, 6, 186442) But I have learnt that it is madness on our part to regard ourselves as different from others.
('63', 94, 3, 7, 186537) If we regard all as one, no one dies or lives.
('63', 94, 3, 8, 186584) “As in the body so in the universe.” The body ever dies, yet lives.
('63', 94, 3, 9, 186652) Similarly the Cosmos as expressed in the creation ever dies yet re mains alive.
('63', 94, 3, 10, 186732) As we are but a mere drop in that scheme, our death is no death.
('63', 94, 3, 11, 186797) Transformation of the body will go on, so what shall we mourn for?
('63', 94, 3, 12, 186864) Shall we then become hard hearted?
('63', 94, 3, 13, 186899) No, but if all of us living beings are one in spite of the seeming difference, we should die for one another, in other words make sacrifices to our utmost.
('63', 94, 3, 14, 187055) This same idea has been expressed wonderfully in the first mantra of the Isho panishad.
('63', 94, 3, 15, 187143) If you are not familiar with it tell me and I shall send it to you.
('63', 94, 4, 16, 187211) Blessings from BAPU
('63', 94, 5, 17, 187231) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 1708
('63', 94, 6, 18, 187272) 104. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KOTAGIRI 1
('63', 94, 7, 19, 187314) February 2, 1934
('63', 94, 8, 20, 187331) FRIENDS, It is a matter of great joy to me to be able to see you this afternoon.
('63', 94, 8, 21, 187412) I was looking forward to coming to this beautiful hill.
('63', 94, 8, 22, 187468) I know that some of my co workers have been zealously working in the midst of hillmen.
('63', 94, 8, 23, 187555) I know, too, that you have not that vicious kind of untouchability amongst you that we have on the plains.
('63', 94, 8, 24, 187662) Nevertheless, no one, in India, can be absolutely free from that virus.
('63', 94, 8, 25, 187734) Even you have distinctions of high and low.
('63', 94, 8, 26, 187778) And so long as we have got that habit of considering ourselves higher than somebody else, we have not got rid of untouchability, and so long as we have got that distinction in our midst, remember we have not got rid of untouchability.
('63', 94, 8, 27, 188013) Therefore, I
('63', 94, 9, 28, 188026) 1 This was attended by about 6,000 people, mostly Badagas, a hill tribe.
('63', 94, 9, 29, 188099) They presented to Gandhiji a purse and an address of welcome.
('63', 94, 9, 30, 188161) A part of the speech was also published in Harijan, 9 2 1934.
('63', 95, 0, 1, 188223) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 95, 1, 2, 188264) would like all to consider and to know and realize that we are all children of the same God, and that therefore among us, His children, there can be nothing like some being high and some being low, and that all should have the same rights as everyone else.
('63', 95, 1, 3, 188521) And then, I want to draw your attention to one thing, of which I have just heard, that hillmen are very much given to the habit of drin king intoxicating liquors.
('63', 95, 1, 4, 188684) Those who are given to that habit should realize that it is drink which makes man thoroughly mad.
('63', 95, 1, 5, 188782) In toxicating liquors are in no way necessary for retaining ourselves.
('63', 95, 1, 6, 188853) Not only so, a man who drinks, very often, more often than not, forgets the distinction between his own wife and his own mother.
('63', 95, 1, 7, 188982) Drunken men and drunken women also have been known all the world over to do things of which they would be ashamed if they were sober.
('63', 95, 1, 8, 189116) Only yesterday, I heard as I was driving that two drunken men were quarrelling amongst themselves, with the result that one died on the spot, and the other is now lying in the hospital.
('63', 95, 1, 9, 189302) As this is a movement of self purification, I would like every one of those who are given to this vicious habit to come to a firm resolution never more to touch fiery liquors.
('63', 95, 1, 10, 189478) It will be a matter of very great joy to me if my fellow workers are able to report to me that many of you have given up drink altogether.
('63', 95, 1, 11, 189617) Now, whilst I thank you for these coppers and silver pieces that you have given me for the Harijan cause, I have to ask you to give some more coppers and some more silver for another cause which is as sacred as the Harijan cause.
('63', 95, 1, 12, 189847) In the north of India, there is one of our fairest provinces.
('63', 95, 1, 13, 189909) The name of that province is Bihar, the birth place of Sita.
('63', 95, 1, 14, 189970) It was there that only a few days ago, a terrible earthquake took place.
('63', 95, 1, 15, 190043) Several thousands of men died.
('63', 95, 1, 16, 190074) Many more thousands of men and women are lying in hospitals.
('63', 95, 1, 17, 190135) The whole world is directing its atten tion to the afflicted people of Bihar.
('63', 95, 1, 18, 190213) Thousands upon thousands of men and women are homeless, shelterless and clothless.
('63', 95, 1, 19, 190296) Many palace like buildings are now simply heaps of broken bricks.
('63', 95, 1, 20, 190362) It is for these that I would like you to give the most, and not the least, that you can.
('63', 95, 1, 21, 190451) If you have not got sufficient money on your persons, make collections after I am gone; you can make them tomorrow and send them either to Patna to Babu Rajendra Prasad, who is in charge of the relief work, or you can bring them to me whilst I am still in Coonoor.
('63', 95, 1, 22, 190716) In many places, remember, men and women have denied themselves their food, their clothes, and shared them with those
('63', 96, 0, 1, 190833) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 97
('63', 96, 1, 2, 190876) who are suffering that terrible affliction.
('63', 96, 1, 3, 190920) For me, personally, this earthquake has a much deeper lesson than that it has brought physical ruin to thousands of homes.
('63', 96, 1, 4, 191043) It is my firm conviction that such calamities descend upon mankind from time to time as a fit punishment for its sins.
('63', 96, 1, 5, 191162) I love to think that it is a punishment awarded to us for the great sin of untouchability.
('63', 96, 1, 6, 191253) If you cherish that belief with me, you will take care to remove the least taint of untouchability from your midst.
('63', 96, 1, 7, 191369) May God help you and me to realize this dream that India should be free once more from all kinds of impurities.
('63', 96, 1, 8, 191481) The Hindu, 4 2 1934

('63', 99, 8, 17, 195935) MITHUBEHN, I could take up your letter only today.
('63', 99, 8, 18, 195986) Just now I stay so far out of the way that the post takes some time to reach me.
('63', 99, 8, 19, 196067) Moreover, I can not attend to letters immediately they are received.
('63', 99, 8, 20, 196136) My replies, there fore, are very much delayed.
('63', 99, 8, 21, 196183) I can’t judge about the question which you have asked.
('63', 99, 8, 22, 196238) I am frightened by the very description that you have given.
('63', 99, 8, 23, 196299) How will you be able to do justice to your present work in Bombay and to this additional responsibility?
('63', 99, 8, 24, 196404) All the same, if you can see your way and are confident, how can I discourage you?

('63', 99, 8, 26, 196522) Do what you think right and may God pros per you in your undertaking.
('63', 99, 8, 27, 196592) Chunilal had put to me the very same question that you have.
('63', 99, 8, 28, 196653) I told him that I could not guide him, that he should do what he thought right and that I would not blame him whatever decision he took.
('63', 99, 8, 29, 196790) I say the same thing to you.
('63', 99, 8, 30, 196819) You should not expect from me a categorical opinion in such matters.
('63', 99, 8, 31, 196888) Are you all right now?

('63', 100, 1, 2, 197019) 112. LETTER TO MANSHANKAR J. TRIVEDI
('63', 100, 2, 3, 197056) February 3, 1934
('63', 100, 3, 4, 197073) MANU, I got your letter.
('63', 100, 3, 5, 197098) Since you remain as straightforward as you used to be I have no fear on your account.
('63', 100, 3, 6, 197184) Your assurance that you will not marry without my blessings will protect you.
('63', 100, 3, 7, 197262) I have written to Father not to hurt your feelings in any way.
('63', 100, 3, 8, 197325) In your letters to him, see that you never forsake civility.
('63', 100, 3, 9, 197386) If he appears to you to use harsh language just now, there is nothing behind it but love for you and concern for your future born of that love.
('63', 100, 3, 10, 197530) There is an error in your belief concerning one matter.
('63', 100, 3, 11, 197586) I do not have with me a copy of the letter to the Princess.
('63', 100, 3, 12, 197646) I don’t think there will be any in the office either.
('63', 100, 3, 13, 197700) You say in your letter that it is your belief that, provided the children remain Hindu by culture, I wouldn’t mind in what faith they were brought up.
('63', 100, 3, 14, 197851) I am not likely to have written anything to that effect, since for a Hindu, culture and religion are one and the same thing.
('63', 100, 3, 15, 197976) Is there any Hindu culture apart from the Upanishads, the Gita, the Mahabharata and the Ramayana?
('63', 100, 3, 16, 198074) I must have said in my letter that, if Elizabeth could adopt Hindu culture in her life, I wouldn’t mind her remaining a Roman Catholic in religion.
('63', 100, 3, 17, 198222) This is very different from saying that the children may be brought up as Roman Catholics.
('63', 100, 3, 18, 198313) I want you to understand this difference.
('63', 100, 3, 19, 198355) I have no quarrel with you.
('63', 100, 3, 20, 198383) I do not distrust you or Elizabeth in the least.
('63', 100, 3, 21, 198432) But I want to correct a misunderstanding under which you seem to be labouring.
('63', 100, 3, 22, 198511) To me all religions are alike.
('63', 100, 3, 23, 198542) But since religions are many, there is diversity even in their oneness.
('63', 100, 3, 24, 198614) All living beings are one in essence, but as embodied creatures they are infinite in number and diverse.
('63', 100, 3, 25, 198719) To realize the unity of all life in spite of our having different bodies is the supreme end of human endeavour.
('63', 100, 3, 26, 198831) If the bodies were not different, there would have been no need to realize the unity of life.
('63', 100, 3, 27, 198925) The fact that you are a Hindu and other people are Muslims or Christians does have some meaning.
('63', 100, 3, 28, 199022) That meaning must be respected in the case of your children.
('63', 100, 3, 29, 199083) I am convinced that if you two wish to live happily and in peace after marriage, your children ought to be brought up as Hindus, and Elizabeth, or rather Vimala—I had forgotten her new name— should adopt Hindu culture.
('63', 100, 3, 30, 199302) If she cannot forget Europe, you must live in Europe.
('63', 100, 3, 31, 199356) If she wishes to serve India,
('63', 101, 0, 1, 199386) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 101, 1, 2, 199428) she must become an Indian at heart.
('63', 101, 1, 3, 199464) Without doing that, she may certainly be able to serve the country although with a superior attitude, but you believe her to be a true servant at heart.
('63', 101, 1, 4, 199617) As she has changed her name, she must change her heart too.
('63', 101, 1, 5, 199677) But she cannot do that by force.
('63', 101, 1, 6, 199710) She will succeed in being an Indian at heart only if she is born with such a predisposition.
('63', 101, 1, 7, 199803) You also must have in your mind a clear picture of the future.
('63', 101, 1, 8, 199866) If you wish to dedicate yourself to the service of Mother India, you will have to imbibe in your life what I have explained to you in my letters.
('63', 101, 1, 9, 200012) If, therefore, you have any doubts on that, you should ask me to explain again and again till you are satisfied.
('63', 101, 1, 10, 200125) Don’t hesitate to write to me.
('63', 101, 1, 11, 200156) I don’t know whether I shall be able to write to you after July.
('63', 101, 1, 12, 200221) You should, therefore, put to me during the months which remain whatever questions you wish to and have your doubts cleared and get from me whatever help you want.

('63', 102, 6, 15, 201739) 115. SPEECH AT OTTUPATRAI 1
('63', 102, 7, 16, 201767) February 3, 1934
('63', 102, 8, 17, 201784) FRIENDS, I am very much pleased to have come here and to have met you.
('63', 102, 8, 18, 201855) You know that this movement that is now going on is a movement for self purification.
('63', 102, 8, 19, 201941) Those who call themselves savarna Hindus have to purify themselves by fraternizing with Harijans and ceasing to con sider them as untouchables, or lower than themselves.
('63', 102, 8, 20, 202111) Harijans have to do certain things, not by way of exchange but because they also have to purify themselves; they should conform to the laws of clean life and cleanliness, both internally and externally, giving up carrion, beef, liquor and drugs.
('63', 102, 8, 21, 202357) I understand that here you offer as sacrifice to your God buffaloes or other animals in order to appease Kali.
('63', 102, 8, 22, 202468) You must not, for one moment, imagine that God can ever be pleased by sacrifice of animals.
('63', 102, 8, 23, 202560) There are savarna Hindus, so called, who also resort to this barbarous practice.
('63', 102, 8, 24, 202641) But, all the world over, it is now recognized that there can be no religion in sacrificing animals.
('63', 102, 8, 25, 202741) I should like you, therefore, to think that there can be no virtue in offering animals as sacrifices to appease Kali, or any other goddess or
('63', 102, 9, 26, 202883) 1 This was one of the Harijan cheries Gandhiji visited during the day.
('63', 102, 9, 27, 202954) About 200 inhabitants accorded him a warm welcome.
('63', 103, 0, 1, 203005) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 103, 1, 2, 203047) After all, there is but one God, whether you worship Him as Kali or whether you worship Him as Vishnu or Shiva or Brahma, no matter by what name, but, there is only one God, and that God is the God of Truth and Love, not of vengeance.
('63', 103, 1, 3, 203282) Therefore, I hope that, henceforth, there will be no two parties amongst you, but that you will all unite in order to stop this animal sacrifice in the name of God.

('63', 103, 2, 5, 203467) 116. SPEECH AT THANDAKARANCHERI 1
('63', 103, 3, 6, 203501) February 3, 1934
('63', 103, 4, 7, 203518) FRIENDS, It gives me much pleasure to be in your midst.
('63', 103, 4, 8, 203574) You should know that I am a scavenger myself by choice, and you must take me literally when I tell you that I have cleaned hundreds of commodes in my life.
('63', 103, 4, 9, 203730) Everyone in the Ashram which I was conducting—and I have over one hundred men and women there— had to do this work every day.
('63', 103, 4, 10, 203856) I call scavenging one of the most honourable among the occu pations to which mankind is called.
('63', 103, 4, 11, 203952) I do not consider it an unclean occupation by any means.
('63', 103, 4, 12, 204009) That in performing the cleaning operation you have to handle dirt is true.
('63', 103, 4, 13, 204084) But, that every mother has to do, every doctor does.
('63', 103, 4, 14, 204137) But, nobody says that a mother’s occupation when she cleans her children, or a doctor’s occupation when he cleans his patients, is an unclean occupation.
('63', 103, 4, 15, 204291) And therefore I consider that those who call themselves superior class of Hindus commit a grave sin when they consider scavengers as untouchables.
('63', 103, 4, 16, 204438) I am travelling up and down in order to convince these so called superior Hindus that it is a sin to consider any human being as untouchable.
('63', 103, 4, 17, 204580) But, I am travelling also to tell fellow scavengers that whilst we may handle dirt, we must ourselves be clean inwardly and outwardly.
('63', 103, 4, 18, 204715) After we have done the work of cleaning, we must clean ourselves and wear clean clothes.
('63', 103, 4, 19, 204804) I know that many scavengers eat carrion or beef.
('63', 103, 4, 20, 204853) Those who are doing this should abstain from that, and then I know that many of them are given to the evil habit of drink.
('63', 103, 4, 21, 204976) Drink is a bad, filthy, unclean, degrading habit.
('63', 103, 4, 22, 205026) The Hindu, 7 2 1934
('63', 103, 5, 23, 205046) 1 This was another cheri which Gandhiji visited.
('63', 103, 5, 24, 205095) Here the inhabitants were mostly municipal scavengers and about 300 of them had gathered to hear Gandhiji.

('63', 104, 1, 2, 205246) 117. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, COONOOR 1
('63', 104, 2, 3, 205287) February 3, 1934
('63', 104, 3, 4, 205304) FRIENDS, It is a matter of keen pleasure to me that I have been able to live in your beautiful climate all these few days, and this meeting this afternoon adds to that pleasure.
('63', 104, 3, 5, 205482) The address, presented on behalf of Harijans, tells me that I am rendering a great service by awakening the conscience of the so called savarna Hindus.
('63', 104, 3, 6, 205634) I do not believe that I am rendering any service to anybody but myself.
('63', 104, 3, 7, 205706) I called this a move ment of self purification and penance, which it undoubtedly is, and what I am trying to do, from day to day, is nothing but going through a process of self purification myself.
('63', 104, 3, 8, 205904) I could not live at peace with myself if I did not declare the truth as I see it in connection with un touchability.
('63', 104, 3, 9, 206021) I have no doubt whatsoever that, if the so called savarna Hindus do not cleanse themselves of the sin of untouchability Hindu ism and Hindus must perish.
('63', 104, 3, 10, 206175) We proudly call overselves children of God, and yet, in the name of God and religion, deny to our own brethren, the children of God, those rights and privileges which we enjoy.
('63', 104, 3, 11, 206352) I have not a shadow of doubt in my mind that such belief constitutes a great sin.
('63', 104, 3, 12, 206434) This sin of untouchability does not confine itself merely to those who are called Harijans or Adi Dravidas or untouchables, but it has taken in its snaky coil all the communities of India.
('63', 104, 3, 13, 206623) And so, in a way Christians, Mussalmans, Parsis, Jews and Hindus have all become untouchables to one another.
('63', 104, 3, 14, 206733) My great hope therefore is that when we have cleansed ourselves of untouchability all these offshoots of untouchability will be demolished.
('63', 104, 4, 15, 206873) Gandhiji then made a fervent appeal on behalf of Bihar earthquake victims.
('63', 104, 5, 16, 206948) The Hindu, 7 2 1934
('63', 104, 6, 17, 206968) 1 At this meeting Gandhiji was presented with a purse and three addresses of welcome which included one from the Adi Dravida Jana Sabha and a Tamil verse specially composed in his honour.
('63', 104, 6, 18, 207156) A brief report of the meeting was also published in Harijan, 16 2 1934.

('63', 106, 1, 2, 208824) 120. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, OOTACAMUND 1
('63', 106, 2, 3, 208868) February 4, 1934
('63', 106, 3, 4, 208885) FRIENDS, It is a matter of great pleasure to me to be able to visit this beau tiful place.
('63', 106, 3, 5, 208976) I thank you for the addresses you have presented and the purses that you have given on behalf of Harijans.
('63', 106, 3, 6, 209083) You have in your general address apologized for the leanness of your purse, although this place is inhabited by very rich people.
('63', 106, 3, 7, 209213) You need not have ren dered any apology whatsoever, because this is essentially a move ment in which the co operation, not of the few rich but of the millions of poor people, is asked for and invited.
('63', 106, 3, 8, 209414) As I have claimed, this is a movement of self purification.
('63', 106, 3, 9, 209474) It is not an article of commerce which can be bought and sold on the market.
('63', 106, 3, 10, 209551) Whilst therefore I welcome the coppers of even thousands of rich men, I welcome still more the coppers of millions.
('63', 106, 3, 11, 209667) Even these offerings would be valueless unless they were a token of the change of heart on the part of the giver.
('63', 106, 3, 12, 209781) The evil of untouchability cannot be driven out from our midst even if some persons were to offer one crore of rupees or more.
('63', 106, 3, 13, 209908) It can only be brought about by individual efforts on the part of millions of self styled savarna Hindus.
('63', 106, 3, 14, 210014) It is they who have to exorcize the devil of untouchability from their hearts.
('63', 106, 3, 15, 210093) It is they who have to do reparation to Harijans, untouchables, whom they have systematically suppressed for centuries in the name of religion.
('63', 106, 3, 16, 210237) What is required is not a superficial makeshift but a fixed determination to rid ourselves of untouchability in every shape and form.
('63', 106, 3, 17, 210371) This great change can only be brought about by an effective appeal to the hearts of the millions of savarna Hindus.
('63', 106, 3, 18, 210487) Conviction has to be brought home to them that hitherto, in considering a portion of Hindu society as untouchables, we have committed a great sin against God and humanity inasmuch as this taint of untouchability has travelled far beyond the limits that were prescribed by Hindus.
('63', 106, 3, 19, 210767) So far as untouchables are concerned, we have to put our house in order so that we may forget all distinction of high and low among mankind.
('63', 106, 3, 20, 210908) It is a matter therefore of great joy and
('63', 106, 4, 21, 210950) 1 More than 10,000 people attended the meeting, which was held in the Municipal Maidan.
('63', 106, 4, 22, 211038) At the end of the meeting Gandhiji auctioned the presents received from the public.

('63', 107, 1, 3, 211405) The Harijan address rightly lays stress upon the desirability that the Harijan purses collected in different parts of Tamil Nad and elsewhere should be utilized for Harijan uplift and that alone.
('63', 107, 1, 4, 211601) A statement has already been made from more than one platform that not only will the bulk of money collected in districts or provinces be utilized in those provinces or districts, but that the bulk of that money will be utilized only for constructive purposes.

('63', 107, 1, 7, 212188) I accept the compliment in all humility.
('63', 107, 1, 8, 212229) I believe in the truth of all religions of the world.
('63', 107, 1, 9, 212283) And since my youth upward, it has been a humble but persistent effort on my part to understand the truth of all the religions of the world, and adopt and assimilate in my own thought, word and deed all that I have found to be best in those religions.
('63', 107, 1, 10, 212534) The faith that I profess not only permits me to do so, but it renders it obligatory for me to take the best from whatsoever source I may find it.
('63', 107, 1, 11, 212680) It is in that spirit that this movement or campaign against untouchability is conceived.
('63', 107, 1, 12, 212769) For this “touch me notism” has not been confined to Harijans, but it has affected caste against caste and religion against religion.
('63', 107, 1, 13, 212902) I for one shall not be satisfied until, as the result of this movement, we have arrived at heart unity amongst all the different races and communities inhabiting this land, and it is for that reason that I have invited the co operation of all the people living in India and even outside.

('63', 116, 1, 2, 229818) There have been no letters from Radha recently.
('63', 116, 1, 3, 229866) Brijkrishna is fairly well.

('63', 116, 2, 9, 230104) She is still in Patna.
('63', 116, 2, 10, 230127) I hope you and the other women are in good health.
('63', 116, 2, 11, 230178) I will start from here tomorrow morning and go to see Raja.
('63', 116, 2, 12, 230238) And now the discourse.
('63', 116, 2, 13, 230261) There is a saying among us: “One road, two purposes.” What road is that following which will always serve “two purposes”?
('63', 116, 2, 14, 230383) “Two purposes” should not, either, be understood to mean only two.
('63', 116, 2, 15, 230450) Here “two” means more than one.
('63', 116, 2, 16, 230482) One may, therefore, also say: “One road and a hundred purposes.” In Bihar thousands of people were buried alive in the matter of a minute.
('63', 116, 2, 17, 230621) This cannot but make us think that one should not waste a single moment.
('63', 116, 2, 18, 230694) “Make the best of today, for who has seen tomorrow?” —sang Mira.
('63', 116, 2, 19, 230759) We don’t know what will happen even after a minute or a second.
('63', 116, 2, 20, 230823) One may pass away even in the act of yawning.
('63', 116, 2, 21, 230869) What, then, is that golden road following which would serve all purposes?
('63', 116, 2, 22, 230943) There is only one, viz., helping others.
('63', 116, 2, 23, 230984) That means service of the neighbour.
('63', 116, 2, 24, 231021) Another name for it is paramartha.
('63', 116, 2, 25, 231056) The word means ‘supreme purpose’.
('63', 116, 2, 26, 231090) A third name for it is Hari bhakti 2. We sing in the prabhatiyan 3 of Narasinh Mehta that such bhakti is not practised by telling beads or putting marks on the forehead or bathing in the Ganga.
('63', 116, 2, 27, 231284) Bhaktas tell us that it means pledging one’s head.
('63', 116, 2, 28, 231335) We should, therefore, always wish the world’s good all the hours of the day whether in jail or outside, and do what ever service may fall to our lot in order to advance it.
('63', 116, 2, 29, 231508) I hope this will be enough for today’s discourse.
('63', 116, 3, 30, 231558) Blessings to all from BAPU [From Gujarati] Bapuna Bane Patro, pp.

('63', 119, 2, 6, 234908) 133. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TIRUPUR 1
('63', 119, 3, 7, 234949) February 6, 1934
('63', 119, 4, 8, 234966) FRIENDS, I am very much obliged to you all for the addresses and the different purses.
('63', 119, 4, 9, 235053) I have already gone through a fairly long program me and I have once more to tax my mind in this assembly and I know that you have been waiting patiently for some time.
('63', 119, 4, 10, 235222) I shall therefore be very brief.
('63', 119, 4, 11, 235255) I have gone through the English translation of the addresses you have presented to me.
('63', 119, 4, 12, 235342) I tender my congratulations to the Municipal Council for all that has been done by it for the Harijan cause.
('63', 119, 4, 13, 235451) But neither the Councillors nor the people can rest satisfied until untouchability in every shape and form is removed.
('63', 119, 4, 14, 235570) I know that it is not within the province of the Municipal Council to throw open the temples.
('63', 119, 4, 15, 235664) But it is up to the so called savarna Hindus to formulate public opinion to such an extent that every temple in Tirupur is opened to the Harijans.
('63', 119, 4, 16, 235811) I am quite convinced in my own mind that until all the public temples are open to the Harijans precisely on the same terms as to the other caste Hindus, we shall not have got rid of untouchability.
('63', 119, 4, 17, 236009) The so called untouchables must have absolutely the same rights and facilities that are enjoyed by the so called savarna Hindus.
('63', 119, 4, 18, 236138) I have gone through the address presented by the khadi merchants.
('63', 119, 4, 19, 236204) I know what khadi means for the Harijans.
('63', 119, 4, 20, 236246) Throughout the length and breadth of India, tens of thousands of men and women who belong to the Harijan class and who have no other employment are getting a few pies now.
('63', 119, 4, 21, 236418) It is therefore a matter for shame that spurious khadi should have sprung up in our midst and since we have no legal protection for khadi the only thing that we can do is to take care to strengthen the public opinion.
('63', 119, 4, 22, 236636) The same complaint was
('63', 119, 5, 23, 236659) 1 At the meeting, purses and addresses of welcome were presented on behalf of the Tirupur Municipal Council and the khadi workers.

('63', 120, 1, 2, 236957) brought to me in Madura and the only thing for the time being that I was able to suggest was that the public should be warned against taking any khadi that was not certified by the All India Spinners’ Association.
('63', 120, 1, 3, 237171) I also heard a rumour that I have changed my opinion about the absolute necessity of khadi.
('63', 120, 1, 4, 237263) I can give my assurance that my opinion has not undergone any changes whatsoever.

('63', 121, 1, 2, 238850) 134. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, COIMBATORE 1
('63', 121, 2, 3, 238894) February 6, 1934
('63', 121, 3, 4, 238911) I am glad to visit your city a second time.
('63', 121, 3, 5, 238955) You have prepared for me a very heavy programme tonight.
('63', 121, 3, 6, 239012) You have presented so many addresses and given me so many purses that it will take some time before I can dispose of them all.
('63', 121, 3, 7, 239139) I must therefore ask you kindly to be patient with me for some time.
('63', 121, 3, 8, 239208) And those who have got tired should retire without making any noise.
('63', 121, 3, 9, 239277) I would like those who have already become restless kindly to be still so that I may follow the proceedings.
('63', 121, 3, 10, 239386) You have presented so many addresses that you do not expect me to give a detailed reply to all of them.
('63', 121, 3, 11, 239490) You will please accept my consolidated thanks for all those addresses and the purses presented.
('63', 121, 3, 12, 239586) You know from your addresses the purpose of my mission.
('63', 121, 3, 13, 239642) We must, if we are to live, get rid of this virus of untouchability.
('63', 121, 3, 14, 239711) I have not the least doubt that if savarna Hindus will not purify their hearts of this taint of untouchability, Hinduism and Hindus must perish.
('63', 121, 3, 15, 239856) That there is a ferment in Hindu society is evidenced by the meetings of this character wherever I had come.
('63', 121, 3, 16, 239965) All these crowds have been there before whenever I have toured throughout India.
('63', 121, 3, 17, 240046) So far as I am aware, invariably this time crowds have been larger still.
('63', 121, 3, 18, 240120) Every attempt that was humanly possible has been made to make clear the purpose of my mission to the crowds.
('63', 121, 3, 19, 240229) Their presence coupled with their copper and silver pieces are to my mind an unmistakable sign that they are ready for the great reform that I have placed before them.
('63', 121, 3, 20, 240397) And if untoucha bility is not removed root and branch I have no doubt that it would not be the fault of the masses but that it would be entirely due to the fault of the workers and the leaders who are today leading the movement.
('63', 121, 3, 21, 240626) I would, therefore, like all the co workers and the leaders to realize the significance of this movement.
('63', 121, 3, 22, 240732) I would like them clearly to see that this is a movement of self purification, self sacrifice and reparation to those whom the so called savarna Hindus have supp ressed for centuries.
('63', 121, 3, 23, 240916) I was therefore considerably disturbed this after noon when on my coming to Coimbatore I saw a few Harijan friends
('63', 121, 4, 24, 241031) 1 The meeting, held in the Gandhi Irwin Stadium, was attended by about thirty to forty thousand people.
('63', 121, 4, 25, 241135) Besides the municipal address, several other addresses were presented to Gandhiji which at the end of the meeting were auctioned.

('63', 122, 1, 4, 241536) They tell me that even their labour is boycotted.
('63', 122, 1, 5, 241586) I have assured them that so far as it is possible for me during the brief hours that I am here I shall try to understand the situation.

('63', 122, 1, 9, 242352) If we were not being eaten up by this canker of superiority and inferiority there never would be any occasion for such quarrels and disturbances.

('63', 122, 1, 13, 243052) The columns of The Hindu have shown what wide sympathy he had for the suffering Bihar and how his appeal was supported by the many subscribers to The Hindu.
('63', 122, 1, 14, 243209) I have no doubt that his place whether as a journalist or as a servant of the nation is not easy to fill.
('63', 122, 1, 15, 243315) He had, as I know, an amazing industry and wisdom which stood well for the Congress at critical times.
('63', 122, 1, 16, 243418) I would like you to associate yourselves with me in tendering our sympathy and respect for the bereaved family and in doing so I would ask you to respond to the appeal that he made on behalf of the sufferers of Bihar.

('63', 124, 2, 3, 245101) February 7, 1934 I wish you would all keep perfect silence.

('63', 124, 2, 6, 245322) The train has come late and I know you were all waiting for a very long time.

('63', 124, 2, 8, 245439) You all know for what purpose I have come.

('63', 124, 2, 10, 245598) Those whom you consider untouchables are your brothers and sisters.

('63', 124, 2, 15, 246082) The charkha before me is a very attractive one and the workmanship deserves much praise.
