('63', 126, 7, 20, 250623) 141. TO SUBSCRIBERS
('63', 126, 8, 21, 250643) The Harijan finishes one year of its existence with this issue.
('63', 126, 8, 22, 250707) The subscribers and readers know the limits within which it is work ing.
('63', 126, 8, 23, 250780) It devotes itself solely to the Harijan cause.
('63', 126, 8, 24, 250827) Even so it eschews all matters which may be calculated to bring it in conflict with the Government.
('63', 126, 8, 25, 250927) It eschews politics altogether.
('63', 126, 8, 26, 250959) These limitations were essential, if it was to be a paper controlled by a prisoner.
('63', 126, 8, 27, 251043) For reasons
('63', 127, 0, 1, 251055) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 127, 1, 2, 251097) which I need not repeat here, though I am not a prisoner in law, I am conducting the paper as if I was one in fact.
('63', 127, 1, 3, 251213) It can, therefore, naturally draw only those men and women who are interested in the campaign against untouchability and who would help the cause even if it is only to the extent of subscribing to the paper and thus helping the only paper that is solely devoted to the cause of anti untouchability and is the mouthpiece of the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('63', 127, 1, 4, 251561) The subscribers know that it will not be continued at a loss.
('63', 127, 1, 5, 251623) I believe that the paper, in order to justify its existence, must be a felt want, and it must, therefore, have the minimum number of subscribers to pay its way.
('63', 127, 1, 6, 251784) The readers know also that, as it avoids all advertisements, it has no other source of income.
('63', 127, 1, 7, 251879) Therefore, subscribers whose subscriptions are due are requested to send their subscriptions promptly to the Manager, Harijan, Triplicane, Madras.
('63', 127, 1, 8, 252026) The despatch of the paper will be auto matically discontinued for those inland subscribers who fail to send their subscriptions after the receipt of two issues after this.
('63', 127, 1, 9, 252198) Those who had constituted themselves as voluntary agents will kindly perform that office for the next year, if they are satisfied that the paper has justified its existence.
('63', 127, 1, 10, 252372) The rates of subscription are: Inland Rs. 4, Foreign Rs. 5/8. Harijan, 9 2 1934
('63', 127, 2, 11, 252452) 142. IS IT CRIMINAL?
('63', 127, 3, 12, 252473) Nowhere have the reception committees been so extravagant as in Travancore in the matter of reception expenses.
('63', 127, 3, 13, 252585) In some places, it seems the expenses have been almost half of the purses collected.
('63', 127, 3, 14, 252670) I had a memo of expenses already from two places.
('63', 127, 3, 15, 252720) The former inclu ded motor hire, printing and feeding charges.
('63', 127, 3, 16, 252783) As usual I have asked for detailed and audited account of expenses.
('63', 127, 3, 17, 252851) I have the fear that even the cost of printing addresses has been set against the purses.
('63', 127, 3, 18, 252941) If so, it amounts in my opinion to criminal misappropriation of purse funds.
('63', 127, 3, 19, 253018) The purses belong to Harijans.
('63', 127, 3, 20, 253049) The cost of collection may be a proper charge against them where the committees are composed of poor people.
('63', 127, 3, 21, 253158) In every case the purses should be handed intact.
('63', 127, 3, 22, 253208) The ex penses that may be passed will be refunded to the committees con cerned.
('63', 127, 3, 23, 253288) This was the practice followed in Andhra.
('63', 127, 3, 24, 253330) In C.P., so far as I am aware, entertainment expenses were in every case borne by private persons.
('63', 127, 3, 25, 253429) The following rules should be borne in mind by the commit 
('63', 128, 0, 1, 253488) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 129
('63', 128, 1, 2, 253532) tees in future.
('63', 128, 1, 3, 253548) 1. The fewest number of volunteers should be employed.
('63', 128, 1, 4, 253603) 2. Motor hire for local purposes should be minimized.
('63', 128, 1, 5, 253657) 3. Motor hire for the party should be separately shown, so as to enable one to collect from those who are travelling at their own ex pense.
('63', 128, 1, 6, 253797) 4. Printing charges should be incurred only when absolutely necessary.
('63', 128, 1, 7, 253868) 5. No decoration charges can be allowed to be debited against the purse.
('63', 128, 1, 8, 253941) 6. On no account can address expenses be paid out of the purse fund.
('63', 128, 1, 9, 254010) I have repeatedly said that addresses need not be presented at all.
('63', 128, 1, 10, 254078) I know that they have, when they are spontaneous, a propaganda value of the right sort.
('63', 128, 1, 11, 254166) But if addresses continue to be presented thoughtlessly, the sacrifice of propaganda value may have to be made.
('63', 128, 1, 12, 254278) The burden, therefore, rests upon reception committees of permitting only those addresses that are spontaneous and have a value in terms of the Harijan cause.
('63', 128, 1, 13, 254437) 7. Accounts for feeding the party should be separately rendered when they are meant to be a charge against the purse.
('63', 128, 1, 14, 254555) I must say in fairness to the committees that outside Travancore I have not known committees having to defray the feeding expenses.
('63', 128, 1, 15, 254687) And seeing that my party is very big, consisting of 15 persons, even providing one meal is no light task in a poor country like India.
('63', 128, 1, 16, 254822) Travancore is still a comparatively new field and, being the home of orthodoxy, I and my party naturally became untouchables among orthodox people, who were before good enough to have me in their homes.
('63', 128, 1, 17, 255025) Add to this the fact that the Government circulars, warning their servants against their countenancing me or the movement, and possibly similar instructions from the Travancore authorities, frightened even moneyed laymen from having any dealings with me.
('63', 128, 1, 18, 255280) The wonder to me is that, in spite of the vague or justified fear of the high placed, the common people flocked to the meetings even in Travancore, as never before.
('63', 128, 1, 19, 255445) I am not, therefore, surprised that the poor members of reception committees in some places in Travancore had to find feeding expenses from the purse.
('63', 128, 1, 20, 255596) But, in every such case I must scrutinize the bill of fare as I would if it was rendered by a hotel keeper.
('63', 128, 1, 21, 255704) The committees know by this time that the simplest food only is expected.
('63', 128, 1, 22, 255778) No sweets, no elaborate dishes, no spices are required.
('63', 128, 1, 23, 255834) The largest item, I fear, is
('63', 129, 0, 1, 255863) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 129, 1, 2, 255905) goat’s milk and fruit.
('63', 129, 1, 3, 255928) These ought not to be provided at every place.
('63', 129, 1, 4, 255975) As usually the three meals are taken at three different places, milk and fruit may be provided once for all at the morning meal.
('63', 129, 1, 5, 256104) Fruit should be only local season’s fruit and oranges.
('63', 129, 1, 6, 256159) Fruit is unfortunately a medical necessity for several members of the party.
('63', 129, 1, 7, 256236) Reception committees are not to be expected to provide these through private individuals, nor may they be allowed to spend what they like from the purses.
('63', 129, 1, 8, 256391) Thakkar Bapa, who is in charge of the party, should be left to decide what the bill of fare should be.
('63', 129, 1, 9, 256494) Local committees would be expected to see that honest dealers provide the necessaries at market prices.
('63', 129, 1, 10, 256598) The thing to remember is that all of us working for the cause are trustees for the moneys collected and, therefore, have to spend like misers, taking greater care of the trust funds than we would of our own.
('63', 129, 1, 11, 256806) If, as against this, it is said that without spectacular displays and demonstrations no money is to be got, my answer without hesitation would be that we must do without it.
('63', 129, 1, 12, 256980) Either the moneys given are an earnest of reparation or they are not.
('63', 129, 1, 13, 257050) If they are such an earnest, they will come spontaneously after conviction is brought home to the would be donor.
('63', 129, 1, 14, 257164) My experience of begging for public causes covers a period of now over 40 years.
('63', 129, 1, 15, 257245) I cannot recall a single occasion when I have had to resort to spectacular displays.
('63', 129, 1, 16, 257330) It was done by hard work, con centrated, patient and gentle arguments and unshaken faith in the cause.
('63', 129, 1, 17, 257433) And of all the causes for which I had the privilege of collecting, the Harijan cause undoubtedly is the noblest, because it affects the most suppressed part of humanity on the face of this globe.
('63', 129, 1, 18, 257629) It will prosper if it had true men and women behind it.
('63', 129, 1, 19, 257685) The needed money will come without much effort.
('63', 129, 1, 20, 257733) Honest and selfless work is the truest prayer.
('63', 129, 1, 21, 257780) And no such prayer has ever gone unanswered.
('63', 129, 1, 22, 257825) Harijan, 9 2 1934
('63', 129, 2, 23, 257843) 143. KHADI AND HARIJANS
('63', 129, 3, 24, 257867) Those who, apart from the whole programme of anti untouchability, are interested in the economic betterment of Harijans should know that khadi gives employment to thousands of Harijan men, women and children who otherwise had no employment.
('63', 129, 3, 25, 258108) It entirely supports some families and supplements the slender resources of many more and keeps the wolf from the door.
('63', 129, 3, 26, 258228) Its capacity to be the only universal source of employment to the starving millions is not
('63', 130, 0, 1, 258319) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 131
('63', 130, 1, 2, 258363) now seriously questioned.
('63', 130, 1, 3, 258389) It is this poor man’s stay which is being undermined by unscrupulous methods.
('63', 130, 1, 4, 258467) I learnt in Madura that some dealers in cloth were palming off khadi cloth woven from mill spun yarn as hand spun and handwoven.
('63', 130, 1, 5, 258596) I was shown specimens which were exact copies of special khadi varieties.
('63', 130, 1, 6, 258670) Lovers of khadi and Harijan servants who believe in the potency of khadi to serve Harijans are requested not to buy khadi which does not bear the hallmark of the All lndia Spinners’ Association.
('63', 130, 1, 7, 258865) I heard also that mill cloth, too, both foreign and indigenous, is largely sold in the market as khadi.
('63', 130, 1, 8, 258969) And to fill my cup of woe, I am being represented as having changed my views on khadi and having put indigenous mill cloth on a par with khadi.
('63', 130, 1, 9, 259113) This is a misrepresentation of my view of khadi.
('63', 130, 1, 10, 259162) My faith in khadi is, if possible, stronger than ever from the moral, economic and national (in its widest sense) standpoint; there is no comparison between khadi and mill cloth, even indigenous.
('63', 130, 1, 11, 259358) Exploitation of the poor through mill cloth or mill yarn is an impossibility in the case of khadi.
('63', 130, 1, 12, 259457) Exploitation of the poor through mill cloth and mill yarn is inevitable in some shape or form, be it ever so mild.
('63', 130, 1, 13, 259572) The use of genuine khadi constitutes some (be it ever so small) automatic return to the poor for their continuous exploitation by the comparatively rich and can in the aggregate become a mighty return, though never adequate, to the masses living in the villages.
('63', 130, 1, 14, 259835) None of these functions can ever be performed by mill cloth even if every mill was nationalized.
('63', 130, 1, 15, 259932) In the mill industry, even if it was conducted purely as a trust for the nation and ably managed, there could never be automatic distribution and there must be displacement of a vast amount of labour, In khadi, with the spinning wheel in every cottage, there can be no displacement of labour and there is always automatic distri bution of the product of labour.
('63', 130, 1, 16, 260294) Hence for me there can be no comparison between khadi and mill cloth, there can be no juxta position.
('63', 130, 1, 17, 260396) For, the two are not of the same kind.
('63', 130, 1, 18, 260435) Khadi may never reach the finish of the mill cloth, nor its variety nor yet its cheapness in terms of the market.
('63', 130, 1, 19, 260549) The measurement for each is different.
('63', 130, 1, 20, 260588) Khadi represents human values, mill cloth represents mere metallic value.
('63', 130, 1, 21, 260662) A yard of khadi is cheap for me at 4 annas per yard.
('63', 130, 1, 22, 260715) Mill cloth of the same count and texture is too dear for me at 2 annas per yard.
('63', 130, 1, 23, 260796) My plea, therefore, is for discrimination and avoidance of confusion of thought.
('63', 130, 1, 24, 260877) Let each stand on its own platform.
('63', 130, 1, 25, 260913) Let mill managers not grudge khadi the place it occupies.
('63', 130, 1, 26, 260971) It ill becomes them to produce cloth that looks like khadi and thus cheat the buyers into the belief that it is khadi.
('63', 130, 1, 27, 261090) Harijan, 9 2 1 934
('63', 131, 0, 1, 261109) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 131, 1, 2, 261151) 144. AMONG THE NATTARS
('63', 131, 2, 3, 261174) Two events in Chettinad deserve special notice.
('63', 131, 2, 4, 261222) One was a visit to a Harijan village, Chittannoor, near Devacottah.
('63', 131, 2, 5, 261290) It has a caste Hindu as a teacher living in it with his family.
('63', 131, 2, 6, 261354) Both are devoted workers attached to Harijans.
('63', 131, 2, 7, 261401) They are conducting a little school and are giving the Harijans medical and such other aid as is within their power to give.
('63', 131, 2, 8, 261526) The school is being conducted on behalf of the local Sangh.
('63', 131, 2, 9, 261586) I had a long chat with the Harijans.
('63', 131, 2, 10, 261623) Their spokesman read to me a statement of the hardships inflicted on them by Nattars.
('63', 131, 2, 11, 261709) The readers of Harijan are familiar with them.
('63', 131, 2, 12, 261756) On my way back, I saw a deputation of Nattars who waylaid me with garlands and coconut.
('63', 131, 2, 13, 261844) I told the leader about the Harijan complaints.
('63', 131, 2, 14, 261892) He gave clever and evasive answers.
('63', 131, 2, 15, 261928) This was a foretaste of what was in store for me at Devacottah, where I was to meet a party of Nattars by appointment.
('63', 131, 2, 16, 262047) They were over one hundred.
('63', 131, 2, 17, 262075) I gave them an hour and had an ex haustive, interesting and illuminating conversation.“Custom” was the only justification for the inhuman treatment that is being meted out to the Harijans, though in a less cruel form than before.
('63', 131, 2, 18, 262305) “Nowa days we don’t interfere with their manner of dressing, except for certain festival days”, replied the old leader of the party quite courte ously but equally firmly.
('63', 131, 2, 19, 262476) “But what right you have to dictate their dress for any day at all?” “It is the custom handed down by our forefathers”, the old man replied.
('63', 131, 2, 20, 262617) “Supposing someone regulated your dress?” I interposed, “Why not?
('63', 131, 2, 21, 262683) We have to submit to many things that the higher castes prescribe for us, and the Harijans have to submit to us.” “You need not submit to anybody’s dictation.
('63', 131, 2, 22, 262842) There is no higher and no lower”, I replied.
('63', 131, 2, 23, 262887) “How can that be?
('63', 131, 2, 24, 262905) The Harijans cannot be allowed to cross the limits prescribed by custom”, the old man persisted.
('63', 131, 2, 25, 263002) “But, surely, you won’t adhere to a custom which is manifestly bad”, I gently remonstrated.
('63', 131, 2, 26, 263094) Prompt came the reply, “Who is to judge what is bad for me?
('63', 131, 2, 27, 263154) All custom must be good, because it comes from our forefathers.”
('63', 132, 0, 1, 263219) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 133
('63', 132, 1, 2, 263263) I had no argument against this.
('63', 132, 1, 3, 263295) I accepted my defeat.
('63', 132, 1, 4, 263317) But I warned the old man and my other hearers that many customs had gone and what they refused to do now voluntarily and gracefully they would be obliged reluctantly to do later by pressure of circumstances.
('63', 132, 1, 5, 263525) In spite of the persistence of the old leader, the conversation was carried on with good humour and ended with a collection for the sufferers of Bihar.
('63', 132, 1, 6, 263677) There is much and glorious work for the young worker to do.
('63', 132, 1, 7, 263737) The old man knew that he had no case.
('63', 132, 1, 8, 263775) But he evidently thought that he must defend the indefensible.
('63', 132, 2, 9, 263838) Harijan, 9 2 1934

('63', 137, 1, 2, 272709) 150. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, THEVARAM
('63', 137, 2, 3, 272749) February 9, 1934
('63', 137, 3, 4, 272766) Gandhiji, addressing the gathering, said that it was not without difficulty that Thevaram was included in the programme of his visit.
('63', 137, 3, 5, 272900) At one time, it seemed as if he would not go over there, but the workers who invited him to Madura would not take ‘no’ for an answer.
('63', 137, 3, 6, 273034) I am glad indeed that I have come here to see your beautiful place which is at the foot of the hills and it did my heart good to see so many enthusiastic volunteers from Combai to Thevaram which seemed to be like an unbroken line of volunteers on either side.
('63', 137, 3, 7, 273294) I wish that all that man power and all that energy was utilized for at least retaining if not adding to the beauty of this valley.
('63', 137, 3, 8, 273425) Let it not be said that what nature had so lavishly beautified man had dirtied.
('63', 137, 3, 9, 273505) I could see that, all along the broken road, volunteers had worked somewhat to make it passable for the cars.

('63', 140, 1, 6, 280603) Whilst I deplore that this great temple of Srirangam is not open to Harijans precisely in the same manner that it is open to caste Hindus, I have absolutely no desire that that temple should be opened to Harijans until the caste Hindu opinion in general is ripe for such opening.
('63', 140, 1, 7, 280883) It is not a question of Harijans asserting their right of temple entry or claiming it.

('63', 140, 1, 10, 281221) It can only be opened when there is a consensus of opinion on the part of caste Hindus.
('63', 140, 1, 11, 281309) The difficulty therefore comes in only when a single Hindu says, ‘so long as I am opposed to it, Srirangam temple should not be opened.’ If such an impossible doctrine were to be accepted, we can never think of any progress in Hindu religion.
('63', 140, 1, 12, 281552) We should never be able to deal with so many social abuses on these terms, and I do not know the history of a single Hindu temple, or for that matter any mosque or church, which has remained prohibited to a class of people because of the opposition of one single solitary worshipper.

('63', 144, 1, 2, 288898) Christians, but also of us, Mohammedans, in a word, the public cause, i.e., of our people getting their rights of citizenship and of their being saved from their economic bondage.
('63', 144, 1, 3, 289078) I may, in answer, give this absolute assurance not only to these Mussalman friends, but through them to all whom it may concern, that in the evening of my life I am not likely to take up a sectional cause to the injury of the public cause.
('63', 144, 1, 4, 289318) And if at the present moment I appear to be advocating a sectional cause, you may depend upon it that behind that sectional cause lies deep down the desire that the whole of the public may benefit by it.
('63', 144, 1, 5, 289522) For I do not believe that life is divided into separate air tight compartments.
('63', 144, 1, 6, 289602) On the contrary it is an undivided and indivisible whole; and, therefore, what is or may be good for one must be good for all.
('63', 144, 1, 7, 289729) Whatever activity fails to stand that unmistakable test is an activity that must be abjured by all who have the public weal at heart.
('63', 144, 1, 8, 289863) Having throughout my life believed in this doctrine of universal good, never have I taken up any activity—be it sectional or national— which would be detrimental to the good of humanity as a whole.
('63', 144, 1, 9, 290061) And in pursuing that universal goal, I discovered years ago that untoucha bility, as it is practised today among Hindus, is a hindrance not only to the march of Hindus towards their own good, but also a hindrance to the general good of all.
('63', 144, 1, 10, 290302) He who runs may discover for himself how this untouchability has taken in its snaky coil not merely caste Hindus but all other communities representing different faiths in India, that is to say, Mussalmans, Christians and others.
('63', 144, 1, 11, 290532) In dealing with the monster of untouchability my own innermost desire is not that the brother hood of Hindus only may be achieved, but it essentially is that the brotherhood of man—be he Hindu, Mussalman, Christian, Parsi or Jew—may be realized.
('63', 144, 1, 12, 290778) For I believe in the fundamental truth of all great religions of the world.
('63', 144, 1, 13, 290854) I believe that they are all God given, and I believe that they were necessary for the people to whom these religions were revealed.
('63', 144, 1, 14, 290986) And I believe that, if only we could all of us read the scriptures of the different faiths from the standpoint of the followers of those faiths we should find that they were at bottom all one and were all helpful to one another.
('63', 144, 1, 15, 291215) Hence it is that I have not hesitated to ask all non Hindus to help me with their prayer in this mission, and it is because I have a living faith in my mission and because that faith is based on an extensive experience that I have not hesitated to say with the greatest delibera 
('63', 145, 0, 1, 291495) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 145, 1, 2, 291537) tion that, if we, Hindus, do not destroy this monster of untouchability, it will devour both Hindus and Hinduism.
('63', 145, 1, 3, 291651) And when I ask you to purify your hearts of untouchability, I ask of you nothing less than this—that you should believe in the fundamental unity and equality of man.
('63', 145, 1, 4, 291817) I invite you all to forget that there are any distinctions of high and low among the children of one and the same God.
('63', 145, 1, 5, 291936) And therefore it is that I have not hesitated to plead on bended knees before those caste Hindus who call themselves sanatanists that they should join hands with me in this movement of self purification.
('63', 145, 1, 6, 292140) If they would only patiently study it and its implications, they would discover that there are more points of contact than of difference between them and the reformers.
('63', 145, 1, 7, 292309) They cannot possibly, if they will study the movement, justify themselves in subjecting to indignities all those who are considered untouchables.
('63', 145, 1, 8, 292455) Not far from Trichinopoly there is a place called Mel Arasur.

('63', 146, 3, 5, 293581) You cannot be comfortably sitting in the sun as you must have been for a few hours, and I have yet to cover a distance of 76 miles, nor is it necessary for me to say much, for your purses and addresses show that you are alive to the object of the mission.
('63', 146, 3, 6, 293837) I appreciate the message that some sanatanists have sent through the members of the Reception Committee.
('63', 146, 3, 7, 293942) Some of them, I understand from your address, have been good enough to give their own mite towards Harijan uplift, but they have sent me their advice that I ought to drop the claim that I am putting forth for temple entry on behalf of Harijans.
('63', 146, 3, 8, 294187) Claiming as I do to be a sanatanist as they themselves are, I cannot give up the claim on behalf of Hari jans to enter our temples precisely on the same terms as sanatanist Hindus do, but I can give them this absolute assurance that so far as I am concerned, and so far as Harijan Sevak Sangh is concerned, there never shall be a single Harijan entering a single Hindu temple unless there is a clear or rather clearest possible consensus of opinion of temple goers to that particular temple that Harijans should enter.
('63', 146, 3, 9, 294706) My prosecution of the claim therefore ought not to affect a single opponent of temple entry, for temple entry will surely depend upon their being converted to my view.
('63', 146, 3, 10, 294874) So long as they remain opposed to temple entry, it is quite clear, from what I have told you, that there can be no temple entry by Harijans, but I do want to give this warning that, so far as I can judge, public opinion is daily veering round to the fact that savarna Hindus will fail in their elementary duty to Harijans if they prevent them from making use of public temples precisely on the same terms as caste Hindus do.
('63', 146, 3, 11, 295299) Remember please, that the refor mer and the sanatanist base their interpretation of the duty of caste Hindus upon identical Shastras.
('63', 146, 3, 12, 295433) Their interpretations differ undou btedly.
('63', 146, 3, 13, 295476) Society can only gain by both parties courteously, gently and honourably putting their own interpretations before the public.

('63', 147, 3, 4, 295901) Gandhiji thanked them for the addresses and purses and said that they would not expect him to speak for long at that time of the evening, knowing that he left Trichinopoly that day very early in the morning and that he had to go another 42 miles by motor to the place of his night halt.

('63', 147, 3, 6, 296302) He was glad to know of the Harijan work done by the local Municipal Council and he asked them not to be satisfied with the work already done but to continue their work till untouchability was rooted out from their hearts.
('63', 147, 3, 7, 296524) In the eyes of God there was no difference between man and man and it was a sin to hold any difference.
('63', 147, 3, 8, 296628) The Hindu religion was in danger and removal of untouchability would certainly avert it.
('63', 147, 3, 9, 296717) He knew that sanatanists did not agree with him.
('63', 147, 3, 10, 296766) But if they had rightly understood the Harijan movement, its principles and work, they would have no grievance against him.
('63', 147, 3, 11, 296890) He was trying to meet sanatanists wherever possible in his tour, and to convince them to have a change of heart.

('63', 149, 6, 22, 300605) 162. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, PUDUPALAYAM
('63', 149, 7, 23, 300648) February 12, 1934
('63', 149, 8, 24, 300666) FRIENDS, You know that here I am not supposed to have come to visit the village really but to visit the Ashram.
('63', 149, 8, 25, 300778) 1 It is highly unlikely that I would have come to Pudupalayam but for the Ashram.
('63', 149, 8, 26, 300860) That does not mean that I do not want the change of heart here also that I am asking for from all caste Hindus.
('63', 149, 8, 27, 300972) But it means this, that I have come to see what service the Ashram has been rendering to you.
('63', 149, 8, 28, 301066) The Ashram being in your midst, my visit to you should be considered as superfluous.
('63', 149, 8, 29, 301151) If I discovered that in spite of the Ashram being in your midst for so many years, you have not yet got rid of the taint of untouchability, I should very nearly despair.
('63', 149, 8, 30, 301321) As a matter of fact, places like Pudupal ayam ought to serve as a proper test in order to know how far the caste Hindu mind has been touched on the matter of untouchability.
('63', 149, 9, 31, 301495) 1 The Ashram was started by C. Rajagopalachari in 1926 for constructive work among the villagers.
('63', 149, 9, 32, 301593) Removal of untouchability was one of its aims.
('63', 150, 0, 1, 301640) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 151
('63', 150, 1, 2, 301684) For you have in your midst a body of the servants of the people who in their own life have no taint of untouchability about them at all.
('63', 150, 1, 3, 301821) They are all pledged to regard Harijans as their own blood brothers and sisters.
('63', 150, 1, 4, 301902) I would certainly like to think that you are also treating the Harijans in the same manner.
('63', 150, 1, 5, 301994) But I know that it is not your position today.
('63', 150, 1, 6, 302041) Though you have made considerable headway in that direction you have still your doubts about the necessity of removing untouchability altogether.
('63', 150, 1, 7, 302187) You still like the distinction of high and low.
('63', 150, 1, 8, 302235) You still feel, some of you at any rate, that if Harijans came into their own they will not give you the same service that they are giving today.
('63', 150, 1, 9, 302381) I think that it is wrong; it is sinful to keep persons under suppression simply because, if their suppression was removed, they might not render us the service that they have been rendering hitherto.
('63', 150, 1, 10, 302581) We have no right whatsoever to force service from fellow human beings.
('63', 150, 1, 11, 302652) I can therefore only hope and pray that you will get rid of whatever untouchability there is still left in you.
('63', 150, 1, 12, 302764) Believe with me that untouchability has no divine sanction, but that it is a positive sin.
('63', 150, 1, 13, 302855) I did not expect the purse you have given me.
('63', 150, 1, 14, 302901) Your purse I consider to be a handsome purse.
('63', 150, 1, 15, 302947) I have no doubt that you have heard of the province of Bihar and you must have heard about the earthquake that has desolated many of its fair and rich cities.
('63', 150, 1, 16, 303106) I understand that the purse you have presented is just now collected and it is absolutely a spontaneous offering.
('63', 150, 1, 17, 303220) Therefore I dare not suggest that you should make collections for Bihar at this very moment; but I would like you to think of your suffering countrymen in Bihar and put together whatever money you can and send that money to Rajendrababu.
('63', 150, 1, 18, 303458) You should know that nearly 25,000 people have died and many more thousands are today homeless and without clothing and living on doles supplied to them.

('63', 154, 2, 3, 309033) February 14, 1934
('63', 154, 3, 4, 309051) FRIENDS, You have brought me to one of the most picturesque sights in all India and an ideal place for holding a meeting such as this.
('63', 154, 3, 5, 309186) You have pre sented me with a number of addresses and purses and made different other gifts.
('63', 154, 3, 6, 309279) The movement which is now going on is one of religious self purification.
('63', 154, 3, 7, 309353) Through this we must endeavour to attain a status of absolute equality for Harijans, whom caste Hindus have suppressed for centuries.
('63', 154, 3, 8, 309487) I regard your monetary offering as a token of whole hearted support for this movement.
('63', 154, 3, 9, 309574) I see from the Taluk Board address that you have been endeavouring, in whatever way you can, to help the Harijan cause.
('63', 154, 3, 10, 309694) I hope, however, that you will not cease your efforts until Harijans attain perfect equality with the caste Hindus to which I have just now adverted.
('63', 154, 3, 11, 309844) I have here an address from the Harijans.
('63', 154, 3, 12, 309886) They say that they have built a temple by the public subscription of philanthropic men.
('63', 154, 3, 13, 309974) But, evidently, it is unfinished and they need financial help to complete it.
('63', 154, 3, 14, 310052) I hope that leaders here will go into the matter and do whatever is necessary.
('63', 154, 3, 15, 310131) The Harijans would like me to visit the cheries and the temple site.
('63', 154, 3, 16, 310200) I wish I could go and see them.
('63', 154, 3, 17, 310232) But it is hardly possible now, seeing that I have a heavy programme in front of me for the day.
('63', 154, 3, 18, 310328) Now I must proceed to the disposing of these addresses and these articles you have given me.
('63', 154, 3, 19, 310421) I see you have not yet made any collections for the stricken people of Bihar.
('63', 154, 3, 20, 310499) I would, therefore, like volunteers to spread them selves among the crowd and collect what they can.
('63', 154, 3, 21, 310600) I take it that you know 25,000 people have been swallowed up by mother earth in a second.

('63', 154, 3, 23, 310828) I would, therefore, like you to subscribe liberally for the Bihar Relief Fund.

('63', 157, 5, 17, 314735) NAGAPATTAM, [February 15, 1934] 1
('63', 157, 6, 18, 314769) BHAISHRI MUNSHI, I have your letter.
('63', 157, 6, 19, 314806) I have read Dinshaw’s letter and your note.
('63', 157, 6, 20, 314850) It seems to me that now there is no point in my giving my opinion in the matter.
('63', 157, 6, 21, 314931) Those mill owners who hold independent views with regard to artificial silk can follow their own course.

('63', 157, 6, 23, 315080) Actually, there is no effective organization of the mills.
('63', 157, 6, 24, 315139) I do not find that they are bound by any moral obligations.
('63', 157, 6, 25, 315199) Hence, we should be content with whatever work can be got out of them through entreaty.
('63', 157, 6, 26, 315287) I do not approve of everybody rushing to Britain, though occasionally I may be of assistance in that.
('63', 157, 6, 27, 315389) But that even people like you should go there in search of peace and physical comfort is too much.
('63', 157, 6, 28, 315488) Are there not enough number of places in India?

('63', 157, 6, 31, 315607) Go to Darjeeling.

('63', 157, 6, 33, 315704) There is one at Ooty too.
('63', 157, 6, 34, 315730) It is a beautiful place.
('63', 157, 7, 35, 315755) 1 From the contents and from ‘Nagapattam’ in the date line where Gandhiji had been on February 15, 1934.

('63', 158, 1, 5, 316050) But if you find comfort only in Britain, what is wrong with the British rule?

('63', 159, 1, 2, 318026) but repeatedly that our sanatanist friends would associate with all other reforms with reference to untouchability, if only I would surrender the claim of temple entry on behalf of the Harijans.
('63', 159, 1, 3, 318221) They little know that that advice is tantamount to asking me to surrender the force which sustains me.
('63', 159, 1, 4, 318324) I looked at the Tanjore temple and then within probably a few seconds or a few minutes of passing by the temple, I saw the sun rising above the horizon.
('63', 159, 1, 5, 318477) I asked myself whether he rose only for caste Hindus or whether he rose for Harijans as well.
('63', 159, 1, 6, 318571) I discovered at once that he was absolutely impartial and had probably to rise more for the Harijans than for the caste Hindus, who had plenty of wealth and who had shut themselves in their palaces, shutting out light even beyond the rise of the sun.
('63', 159, 1, 7, 318822) Poor Harijans, they do not sleep after sunrise; on the contrary, being a labourer the Harijan has to get up even before sunrise.
('63', 159, 1, 8, 318951) And therefore whilst many of us may be still sleeping on our cots and on our mattresses, the Harijans get a proper sun bath.
('63', 159, 1, 9, 319076) If that temple designed by God opens out to the whole world, shall a man built temple open less for Harijans?
('63', 159, 1, 10, 319186) Not one of these temples can be opened without the free consent of those who are in the habit of going to these temples or who believe in these temples.
('63', 159, 1, 11, 319339) Why should therefore the sanatanists or any other person worry about my conviction about temple entry, when the matter was purely a voluntary thing?
('63', 159, 1, 12, 319488) But what grieves me is this, that under the excuse of this temple entry question, in many other things where the sanatanists say there is a perfect agreement they are not moving their little finger.
('63', 159, 1, 13, 319687) Let them treat Harijans on terms of absolute equality in all other matters.
('63', 159, 1, 14, 319763) They will then have done something to retrieve the great blunder.
('63', 159, 1, 15, 319829) There I must leave my message.
('63', 159, 1, 16, 319860) I can only hope and pray that all of you will recognize the simple truth and you will have sufficient strength to act according to it.

('63', 160, 3, 6, 320317) I must say that one expression that you have used is enough warrant for me to continue my mission.

('63', 160, 3, 8, 320495) I am doing absolutely nothing more than cultivating public opinion in favour of justice being done to Harijans.
('63', 160, 3, 9, 320607) I know the difference on the question of temple entry.
('63', 160, 3, 10, 320662) That is my only point of difference with sanatanist opinion.
('63', 160, 3, 11, 320723) Nothing is going to be done, so far as I can prevent it, or so far as the Central Board of the Harijan Sevak Sangh can prevent it, to force temple entry.
('63', 160, 3, 12, 320877) Temple entry is a question purely for the caste Hindus to solve.
('63', 160, 3, 13, 320942) If caste Hindus say as a body that Harijans shall not enter the temples, I shall say it will be unfortunate, it will be marching against the spirit of the times; but, so long as that opinion persists, no Harijan will enter any temple.
('63', 160, 3, 14, 321177) My duty is merely to confine myself to the cultivation of public opinion in the direction.
('63', 160, 3, 15, 321268) I come to the parting of the ways when I am told that I should not whisper a word about the subject.
('63', 160, 3, 16, 321369) I cannot do that.
('63', 160, 3, 17, 321387) For I feel, as a lover of my faith, to say that caste Hindus will not be doing their elementary duty so long as they prohibit temple entry to Harijans.
('63', 160, 3, 18, 321539) I hold it to be impossible for a man who has studied Hindu Shastras with an unbiased mind to feel other wise.
('63', 160, 3, 19, 321649) When an overwhelming majority favours the entry of Harijans into a particular temple, it should be opened.
('63', 160, 3, 20, 321756) Wherever I have gone and opened temples to Harijans, I have done so in the presence of thousands of caste Hindus and with their consent: the thousands of caste Hindus who were most concerned about the temple said, “We want the temples to be opened.” But if you say that no temples should be opened so long as there is one caste Hindu who says, ‘No, the temple should not be opened,’ then, I would say that that is coercion with a vengeance.

('63', 163, 0, 1, 327212) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 163, 1, 2, 327254) addressed to all mankind.
('63', 163, 1, 3, 327280) If I can but succeed in persuading the caste Hindus to wipe out this curse of untouchability, I believe that Hindus would have taken a long step towards the realization of brotherhood for which the whole world knowingly or unknowingly is aspiring.
('63', 163, 1, 4, 327528) I would have you believe me when I say that there is absolutely no warrant for untouchability, as we practise it, in the Shastras and I want to suggest to all who would study the Shastras the golden rule of inter pretation.
('63', 163, 1, 5, 327752) If you take an isolated text from the Shastras it is possible to prove in them anything that you may wish to prove.
('63', 163, 1, 6, 327868) Therefore in order to save ourselves from falling into death traps it is necessary to understand the drift of the Shastras and I make bold to say that the drift of the Shastras can only point to brotherhood and not to distinction between man and man.
('63', 163, 2, 7, 328119) The Hindu, 17 2 1934
('63', 163, 3, 8, 328140) 175. SUPERSTITION v.
('63', 163, 4, 9, 328161) The Bard of Santiniketan is Gurudev for me as he is for the inmates of that great institution.
('63', 163, 4, 10, 328256) I and mine had found our shelter there when we returned from our long self imposed exile in South Africa.
('63', 163, 4, 11, 328362) But Gurudev and I early discovered certain differences of outlook between us.
('63', 163, 4, 12, 328440) Our mutual affection has, however, never suffered by reason of our differences, and it cannot suffer by Gurudev’s latest utterance on my linking the Bihar calamity with the sin of untou chability.
('63', 163, 4, 13, 328637) He had a perfect right to utter his protest when he believed that I was in error.
('63', 163, 4, 14, 328719) My profound regard for him would make me listen to him more readily than to any other critic.
('63', 163, 4, 15, 328813) But in spite of my having read the statement three times, I adhere to what I have written in these columns.
('63', 163, 4, 16, 328921) When at Tinnevelly I first linked the event with untouchability, 1 I spoke with the greatest deliberation and out of the fulness of my heart.
('63', 163, 4, 17, 329063) I spoke as I believed.
('63', 163, 4, 18, 329086) I have long believed that physical pheno mena produce results both physical and spiritual.
('63', 163, 4, 19, 329177) The converse I hold to be equally true.
('63', 163, 4, 20, 329217) To me the earthquake was no caprice of God nor a result of a meeting of mere blind forces.
('63', 163, 4, 21, 329308) We do not know all the laws of God nor their working.
('63', 163, 4, 22, 329362) Knowledge of the tallest scientist or the greatest
('63', 163, 5, 23, 329413) 1 Vide “Speech at Public Meeting, Tinnevelly”, 24 1 1934.
('63', 164, 0, 1, 329471) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 165
('63', 164, 1, 2, 329515) spiritualist is like a particle of dust.
('63', 164, 1, 3, 329556) If God is not a personal being for me like my earthly father, He is infinitely more.
('63', 164, 1, 4, 329641) He rules me in the tiniest detail of my life.
('63', 164, 1, 5, 329687) I believe literally that not a leaf moves but by His will.
('63', 164, 1, 6, 329746) Every breath I take depends upon His sufferance.
('63', 164, 1, 7, 329795) He and His Law are one.
('63', 164, 1, 8, 329819) The Law is God.
('63', 164, 1, 9, 329835) Anything attributed to Him is not a mere attribute.
('63', 164, 1, 10, 329887) He is the Attribute.
('63', 164, 1, 11, 329908) He is Truth, Love, Law, and a million things that human ingenuity can name.
('63', 164, 1, 12, 329984) I do believe with Gurudev in “the inexorableness of the universal law in the working of which God Himself never interferes”.
('63', 164, 1, 13, 330109) For God is the Law.
('63', 164, 1, 14, 330129) But I submit that we do not know the Law or the laws fully, and what appear to us as catastrophes are so only because we do not know the universal laws sufficiently.
('63', 164, 1, 15, 330295) Visitations like droughts, floods, earthquakes and the like, though they seem to have only physical origins, are, for me, somehow connected with man’s morals.
('63', 164, 1, 16, 330454) Therefore, I instinctively felt that the earthquake was a visitation for the sin of untouchability.
('63', 164, 1, 17, 330554) Of course, sanatanists have a perfect right to say that it was due to my crime of preaching against untouchability.
('63', 164, 1, 18, 330670) My belief is a call to repentance and self purification.
('63', 164, 1, 19, 330727) I admit my utter ignorance of the working of the laws of Nature.
('63', 164, 1, 20, 330792) But, even as I cannot help believing in God though I am unable to prove His existence to the sceptics, in like manner I cannot prove the connection of the sin of untouchability with the Bihar visitation even though the connection is instinctively felt by me.
('63', 164, 1, 21, 331051) If my belief turns out to be ill founded, it will still have done good to me and those who believe with me.
('63', 164, 1, 22, 331159) For we shall have been spurred to more vigorous efforts towards self purification, assuming, of course, that untouchability is a deadly sin.
('63', 164, 1, 23, 331300) I know fully well the danger of such speculation.
('63', 164, 1, 24, 331350) But I would be untruthful and cowardly if, for fear of ridicule, when those that are nearest and dearest to me are suffering, I did not proclaim my belief from the house top.
('63', 164, 1, 25, 331525) The physical effect of the earthquake will be soon forgotten and even partially repaired.
('63', 164, 1, 26, 331615) But it would be terrible if it is an expression of the Divine wrath for the sin of untouchability and we did not learn the moral lesson from the event and repent of that sin.
('63', 164, 1, 27, 331790) I have not the faith which Gurudev has that “our own sins and errors, however enormous, have not got enough force to drag down the structure of creation to ruins”.
('63', 164, 1, 28, 331954) On the contrary, I have the faith that our own sins have more force to ruin that structure than any mere physical phenomenon.
('63', 164, 1, 29, 332080) There is an indissoluble marriage between matter and spirit.
('63', 164, 1, 30, 332141) Our ignorance of the results of the union makes it a profound mystery and inspires awe in us, but it cannot undo them.
('63', 164, 1, 31, 332260) But a living recognition of the union has enabled many to use every physical catastrophe for their own moral
('63', 165, 0, 1, 332369) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 165, 1, 2, 332411) uplifting.
('63', 165, 1, 3, 332422) With me the connection between cosmic phenomena and human behaviour is a living faith that draws me nearer to my God, humbles me and makes me readier for facing Him.
('63', 165, 1, 4, 332588) Such a belief would be a degrading superstition, if out of the depth of my ignorance I used it for castigating my opponents.

('63', 166, 7, 18, 335385) But it is not given to all to enforce the three things in practice and I am ashamed that Hindus have been the worst criminals in this respect.
('63', 166, 7, 19, 335528) It was reserved for them to invoke the name of God for untouchability.
('63', 166, 7, 20, 335599) But after having studied the Hindu Shastras for a number of years to the extent that a layman could do, I have come to the definite conclusion that there is no warrant for untouchability in the Hindu Shastras.
('63', 166, 7, 21, 335809) Historians have testified from the dawn of human wisdom to the unity of God; and the unity of all life in God was taught in the earliest hymns that the world first knew—the Rigveda.
('63', 166, 7, 22, 335991) They first taught that God was one and all; life was created by Him and born in Him.

('63', 170, 2, 8, 344661) Every pice or every rupee that we may pay for the Harijan cause, is merely part payment of an obligation that we have owed to them for centuries past and yet no financial compensation that we may make to our Harijan brothers and sisters can possibly undo the wrong that we have done to them and are still doing, unless we raise the bar sinister.
('63', 170, 2, 9, 345007) Every pice or every rupee that I therefore get for the Harijan cause, I interpret it to mean the determination on the part of the givers that they have abolished from their own hearts distinctions of high and low.
('63', 170, 2, 10, 345221) I hope therefore that, in your present life, each man and woman in this audience is showing to Harijan brothers and sisters that they are, so far as they are concerned, in every way their equals and in no way their inferiors.

('63', 171, 1, 2, 345710) 182. APPEAL TO ORGANIZERS AND CO WORKERS, CUDDALORE
('63', 171, 2, 3, 345762) [February 16, 1934] 1
('63', 171, 3, 4, 345784) You should understand my limitations.
('63', 171, 3, 5, 345822) You should also under stand the object of my mission.
('63', 171, 3, 6, 345876) My limitations are prescribed by my physical capacity or incapacity.
('63', 171, 3, 7, 345945) They are also prescribed by Father Time.
('63', 171, 3, 8, 345986) Everywhere, organizers draw up for me a programme which taxes all my energy and resources to go through from day to day.
('63', 171, 3, 9, 346107) My mission today is primarily to appeal to the savarna Hindus and call upon them to repent for the injustice that has been done for centuries past to Harijans, to tell them in language as precise as I can command that, so far as my study of Hindu Shastras goes, Harijans are entitled to the same rights and privileges as non Harijan Hindus enjoy, to tell them with all the emphasis at my command that, if this elementary justice is not rendered to Harijans, Hinduism must perish.
('63', 171, 3, 10, 346587) Co workers, therefore, should not put a strain upon me to do work which is their primary duty to perform.
('63', 171, 3, 11, 346693) They may, when I have time, take me to cheries to admire the work they have done, but it is their business to sweep them clean; it is their business to open schools and conduct them.
('63', 171, 3, 12, 346876) It is their business to take a ray of hope to Harijan cottages from day to day.
('63', 171, 3, 13, 346956) In my present intensive hurricane tour, my energy and my time should be reserved for the chief object of my mission.
('63', 171, 3, 14, 347073) Harijan, 23 2 1934

('63', 174, 1, 2, 351974) 185. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, VELLORE 1
('63', 174, 2, 3, 352015) February 18, 1934
('63', 174, 3, 4, 352033) FRIENDS, Time is short, and you have given me much work to do.
('63', 174, 3, 5, 352096) Therefore, I would like you to help me to shorten the proceedings.
('63', 174, 3, 6, 352163) There are two things that I want to say.
('63', 174, 3, 7, 352204) Whilst I am deeply grateful to the Municipal Council and the District Board for their addresses, and to individual members for the purses that they have given me, I would like to utter a word of request through these two bodies, to other bodies, that they will conserve my energies and time, just now, when I am going through a hurricane tour, by presenting me addresses, if they mean presenting them, on the common platform.
('63', 174, 3, 8, 352630) Most bodies have very kindly and generously presented addresses on the common platform.
('63', 174, 3, 9, 352718) I have no difficulty in understanding, and even appreciating the natural desire of local bodies to present their addresses in their own offices.
('63', 174, 3, 10, 352863) But when they are concerned with a person like me, a humble servant of the nation, trying to utilize every moment of his life for the service of the nation, they might waive their undoubted right of taking me to their own offices and make common cause with others who might present their addresses.
('63', 174, 3, 11, 353162) In the midst of this noise, 2 I do not propose to mention the second thing that happened at the station last night.
('63', 174, 3, 12, 353278) So far as the immediate objective of the mission is concerned, I deeply appreciate all these addresses, purses and gifts, as, to me, they are a token of your desire to help the Harijan cause and to get rid of the evil of untouchability.
('63', 174, 3, 13, 353515) I hope that you will not be satisfied until the disease of untouchability is rooted out from our midst in its entirety, for, at the bottom of this movement, there is no less a desire than the realization of the Brotherhood of Man.
('63', 174, 3, 14, 353746) Now I must ask you to take these things from me and give fat prices.
('63', 174, 3, 15, 353815) The Hindu, 19 2 1934
('63', 174, 4, 16, 353836) 1 The meeting, held in the Gandhi Maidan, was largely attended.

('63', 175, 0, 1, 354030) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 175, 1, 2, 354072) 186. SPEECH AT CHRISTKULA ASHRAM 1, TIRUPPATTUR
('63', 175, 2, 3, 354120) February 18, 1934
('63', 175, 3, 4, 354138) FRIENDS, It seems that I have come to one of my homes in coming here.
('63', 175, 3, 5, 354208) I have been wanting to come to this place for—I might also say— several years, and when the tour programme in the Southern Presi dency was being arranged by Dr. Rajan, I had told him that if it was at all possible, he ought to include this Ashram in the programme.
('63', 175, 3, 6, 354473) But I do not want to waste many words this evening.
('63', 175, 3, 7, 354525) The whole of my party are absolutely tired out.
('63', 175, 3, 8, 354573) I will therefore just give you the gist of my message, and it is this: Untouchability is the greatest sin that Hindus, the so called caste Hindus, have committed against God and man, and I have felt the enormity of the crime so deeply that I have stated from many a platform that either untouchability goes, or Hindus and Hinduism go.
('63', 175, 3, 9, 354908) And let me say what I mean by it.
('63', 175, 3, 10, 354942) It is not enough that caste Hindus begin to touch Harijans.
('63', 175, 3, 11, 355002) Mere touch can give me no satisfaction whatsoever.
('63', 175, 3, 12, 355053) Their hearts must be touched and they must necessarily believe that it is an affront to their own dignity to consider a single human being as lower than themselves.
('63', 175, 3, 13, 355218) And in that sense, you could easily understand that it is an attempt to realize the Brotherhood of Man, not merely Hindu man but man in general, no matter to what part of the world he belongs or to what race he belongs, or to what faith he belongs.
('63', 175, 3, 14, 355467) And, for the caste Hindus to change their hearts, in connection with those who are regarded by them as untouchables by birth, it is merely a stepping stone to this grand realization.
('63', 175, 3, 15, 355650) Therefore, all those who are caste Hindus naturally can take part in this movement.
('63', 175, 3, 16, 355734) It is their duty to do so.
('63', 175, 3, 17, 355761) They have tomake the beginning.
('63', 175, 3, 18, 355793) But I have invited the whole world to take part in this movement and the whole world can take part in this movement by sympathizing with and understanding the movement and by prayer to God.
('63', 175, 3, 19, 355983) Repentance and reparation have naturally to be done only by the caste Hindus.
('63', 175, 3, 20, 356061) What are the Harijans to do?
('63', 175, 3, 21, 356090) Since this is a movement of self purification, they also have to play their part.
('63', 175, 3, 22, 356172) And that is to examine themselves and get rid of the vices, the bad habits, for which,
('63', 175, 4, 23, 356259) 1 A summary of the speech was also published in Harijan, 2 3 1934.
('63', 176, 0, 1, 356326) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 177
('63', 176, 1, 2, 356370) undoubtedly, originally they probably were not responsible.
('63', 176, 1, 3, 356430) Whoever was responsible, is just now irrelevant to consider.
('63', 176, 1, 4, 356491) Somehow or other, these bad habits, or vices, have got to be got rid of.
('63', 176, 1, 5, 356564) For instance, the laws of hygiene, personal cleanliness, they should understand and they should conform to them.
('63', 176, 1, 6, 356677) If they are given to carrion eating, they should give it up.
('63', 176, 1, 7, 356738) In no part of the civilized world is carrion ever eaten, and so far as my knowledge of all the other races of the earth is concerned, there are very few races outside India who are given to carrion eating.
('63', 176, 1, 8, 356944) And since Harijans consider themselves to be Hindus, it is necessary for them to give up beef eating, if they are given to beef eating.
('63', 176, 1, 9, 357080) Personally, I am of opinion that in a country like India, where there are millions of human beings who have to depend upon cow’s milk, where they can at all get that, it is a proper thing for anybody to abstain from eating beef.
('63', 176, 1, 10, 357309) The third thing is to give up drink.
('63', 176, 1, 11, 357346) I know that many Harijans are addicted to drink.
('63', 176, 1, 12, 357395) Some of them have told me that they should not be asked to give up the habit before the caste Hindus, who also, many of them, are given to the habit of drinking, are asked to give it up.
('63', 176, 1, 13, 357582) The logic of this argument may be admitted.
('63', 176, 1, 14, 357626) But there is no moral justification for saying that if one man commits a vice, others also should do likewise, or may do likewise.
('63', 176, 1, 15, 357757) Why should I tell a lie because tens of thousands of my neighbours may be telling lies?
('63', 176, 1, 16, 357845) If thousands commit suicide, why should I commit suicide?
('63', 176, 1, 17, 357903) And I want to say that taking intoxicating liquors is almost like committing suicide, because a man or a woman who takes intoxicating liquors and gets mad, kills his or her soul, for the time being.
('63', 176, 1, 18, 358102) Surely, death of the soul is far worse than death of the body.
('63', 176, 1, 19, 358165) I will ask all those Harijans who are given to the drink habit to give it up.
('63', 176, 1, 20, 358243) Lastly, I do not know whether you have been told anything about the sufferers of Bihar.
('63', 176, 1, 21, 358331) Bihar is the land where Sitadevi was born, and it is one of the fairest provinces of India.
('63', 176, 1, 22, 358423) In the twinkling of an eye, almost twenty thousand people have been swallowed by mother earth.
('63', 176, 1, 23, 358518) Tens of thousands of people are homeless, and for them not only all over India but also all over the world subscriptions are being collected.
('63', 176, 1, 24, 358660) I do not care how poor you may be, I want you to give your coppers, or your silver pieces, or whatever you can, for the sufferers in Bihar.
('63', 176, 1, 25, 358800) The Hindu, 20 2 1934

('63', 177, 11, 21, 359818) 189. LETTER TO VITHALDAS JERAJANI
('63', 177, 12, 22, 359852) MADRAS, Monday, February 19, 1934 I understand everything.
('63', 177, 12, 23, 359911) Keep up your effort.
('63', 177, 12, 24, 359932) You are bound to succeed soon.
('63', 177, 12, 25, 359963) But as a result of independent thinking, I have come to the following conclusions.
('63', 177, 12, 26, 360046) They may be modified with further expe rience.
('63', 177, 12, 27, 360093) For the present think over them.
('63', 178, 0, 1, 360126) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 179
('63', 178, 1, 2, 360170) 1. We must sell unbleached khadi, though we may get it blea ched on special request from anybody.
('63', 178, 1, 3, 360268) 2. We must now try to spread khadi in villages.
('63', 178, 1, 4, 360316) We should assume that the age of cities for this work is over.
('63', 178, 1, 5, 360379) 3. We must refuse to be satisfied that khadi has spread till all khadi produced in an area can be sold locally.
('63', 178, 1, 6, 360491) 4. Concentrating our efforts in cities has done untold harm to our aim of making khadi a permanent feature.
('63', 178, 1, 7, 360599) 5. It clearly follows from this that there should be no need to send the khadi produced in one province to other provinces.
('63', 178, 1, 8, 360723) If we create several Manchesters in India, we shall kill khadi with our own hands.
('63', 178, 1, 9, 360806) 6. We should apply this rule to Bihar right now and decide that it should consume all the khadi which it produces.
('63', 178, 1, 10, 360921) This will be the best way of using the fund.
('63', 178, 1, 11, 360966) 7. If this line of reasoning is correct, we should pay more or all our attention to the strength, evenness of texture and appearance of khadi at the production stage itself.
('63', 178, 1, 12, 361140) Please don’t use all this as a reason for slackening your own effort.
('63', 178, 1, 13, 361210) Sale, and that in cities, is your special field of work.
('63', 178, 1, 14, 361267) If, however, you remember our original aim, it is desirable that you should plan your efforts in keeping with that aim.
('63', 178, 1, 15, 361387) (Send a copy of this to Shankerlal and get it translated into English for Rajaji.

('63', 178, 2, 18, 361527) How can I expect her to write to me now?

('63', 179, 6, 10, 362121) 191. LETTER TO TARABEHN R .
('63', 179, 7, 11, 362149) February 19, 1934
('63', 179, 8, 12, 362167) TARA, I got your letter.
('63', 179, 8, 13, 362192) I often wonder why people fall ill so often.
('63', 179, 8, 14, 362237) I have finally come to the conclusion that illness is a kind of death.
('63', 179, 8, 15, 362308) Death is the result of violation of Nature’s laws by us, and, therefore, is a blessing.
('63', 179, 8, 16, 362396) Similarly, illness also is the result of violation of Nature’s laws and should be regarded as a blessing.
('63', 179, 8, 17, 362502) Death and illness both give us pain because we don’t look upon them as Nature’s kindness to us.
('63', 179, 8, 18, 362598) If we understand this truth, we would spare ourselves all the trouble which we take now to cure illness.
('63', 179, 8, 19, 362703) May be we succeed in our efforts, but they seem to make our minds more sensitive and even weaker.
('63', 179, 8, 20, 362801) Please do not understand from this that you should stop the treatment which you are taking.
('63', 179, 8, 21, 362893) But it certainly means that you should take it with a detached mind and remain unconcerned whether the disease is cured or not.
('63', 179, 8, 22, 363021) I am trying here to explain the teaching of the Gita in a new way.
('63', 179, 8, 23, 363088) You may convey the foregoing to Ramniklal 1 and add this: I have read your letter.
('63', 179, 8, 24, 363171) You have been making good use of your time.
('63', 179, 8, 25, 363215) If you didn’t do that, who else may be expected to do so?
('63', 179, 8, 26, 363273) When you are released, you will see many changes.
('63', 179, 8, 27, 363323) But the original determi nation remains unchanged behind them all.
('63', 179, 8, 28, 363390) If we understand it, we

('63', 187, 11, 25, 375591) 202. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('63', 187, 12, 26, 375621) February 20, 1934 Two achievements stand out prominently in my Tamil Nad tour.
('63', 187, 12, 27, 375700) In spite of the hard times, people have given freely; and in spite of prognostication to the contrary, tens of thousands of people, including a very large number of women flocked to our meetings, although they knew for what purpose the meetings were held.
('63', 187, 13, 28, 375956) Q. How is it proposed to harness such enthusiasm as you have aroused in the
('63', 188, 0, 1, 376032) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 189
('63', 188, 1, 2, 376076) present tour for constructive effort?
('63', 188, 2, 3, 376114) A. In order to make sure that the work will be continued, the Central Board is allowing 75 per cent of the collections to each province to be used for constructive schemes, to be produced by them.
('63', 188, 2, 4, 376311) If they succeed in doing so, naturally the work done now will be all properly garnered.
('63', 188, 2, 5, 376399) Constructive work will consist of conducting schools, hostels and, wherever necessary, digging wells and doing work that would tend towards the social, moral and economic uplift of the suppressed classes.
('63', 188, 3, 6, 376604) Gandhiji gave the information that total collections, including value of jewellery presented up to Sunday last, amounted to Rs. 1,06,491 1 5 in Tamil Nad.
('63', 188, 4, 7, 376759) A couple of questions were then put regarding the temple entry movement.
('63', 188, 4, 8, 376832) Gandhiji said: While I have purposely kept the temple entry question in the background, the sanatanists have always been keeping it before the public.
('63', 188, 4, 9, 376983) My own impression is that the public mind is overwhelmingly in favour of entry of Harijans into temples on the same terms as other Hindus.
('63', 188, 4, 10, 377122) But I have no desire whatsoever to force the issue.
('63', 188, 4, 11, 377174) For me the acid test is of a change of heart on the part of the caste Hindus; and temple entry unaccompanied by that change of heart is to me of no consequence.
('63', 188, 4, 12, 377335) I am, therefore, concentrating my efforts on educating public opinion on the question.
('63', 188, 5, 13, 377422) Q. Have you been able to effect any change in the attitude of the sanatanists?
('63', 188, 6, 14, 377501) A. I am sure that the rank and file of sanatanists have been visibly affected by the manifestation of the mass mind.
('63', 188, 6, 15, 377618) After all those who flocked to our meetings were the sanatanists of yesterday.
('63', 188, 6, 16, 377697) So far as sanatanists are concerned, I cannot say that their attitude has changed, although I have noticed that they have begun to realize that the public are not with them.
('63', 188, 7, 17, 377871) Q. Are you satisfied with the provisions of the Temple entry Bill in the Assembly?
('63', 188, 7, 18, 377954) Opinion, even among those friendly to the cause, does not seem to be quite favourable to the Bill in its present form, owing to legal difficulties.
('63', 188, 8, 19, 378102) A. The Bill in the Assembly is certainly capable of improvement.
('63', 188, 8, 20, 378167) When the proper time comes, I would be prepared to offer suggestions.
('63', 188, 8, 21, 378237) Those who oppose the Bill are so prejudiced against it that they are not disposed even to consider improvements.
('63', 188, 9, 22, 378350) Q. Opinion among sanatanists being favourable to the uplift of Harijans, it is suggested that you can enlist their support for social uplift and leave the temple entry
('63', 189, 0, 1, 378518) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 189, 1, 2, 378560) question, which is only one aspect of the big problem, to solve itself?
('63', 189, 2, 3, 378632) A. I have never been able to understand the attitude of those sanatanists who propose in a bargaining spirit that on my abandoning the temple entry movement, they would co operate with me on the social, moral and economic uplift of Harijans.
('63', 189, 2, 4, 378874) They must respect the conscience of reformers who believe that temple entry is an integral part of the Yeravda Pact.
('63', 189, 3, 5, 378991) When next the interviewer sought for an expression of his views on one or
('63', 189, 4, 6, 379065) two political questions, Gandhiji’s curt reply was that he could not answer them.
('63', 189, 5, 7, 379147) Asked about his further programme, Gandhiji said that as soon as he finished
('63', 189, 6, 8, 379224) the Karnataka tour, he proposed to go to Bihar in response to Babu Rajendra Prasad’s
('63', 189, 7, 9, 379309) invitation.
('63', 189, 8, 10, 379321) The Hindu, 21 2 1934

('63', 191, 4, 7, 381440) 206. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, CONJEEVARAM
('63', 191, 5, 8, 381483) February 21, 1934
('63', 191, 6, 9, 381501) FRIENDS, This is about the last city that I shall have visited in Tamil Nad during this tour.
('63', 191, 6, 10, 381595) It is true that on my way to Arkonam, in order to catch the train, I have to pass through Arni and one or two other places.
('63', 191, 6, 11, 381719) But this is the most important place of the day.
('63', 191, 6, 12, 381768) This is the peak of Sanskrit learning.
('63', 191, 6, 13, 381807) There is a great temple in your midst, and therefore I should imagine that this place should be prepared to come forward to do reparation to Harijans.
('63', 191, 6, 14, 381958) But such good luck is not in store for us.
('63', 191, 6, 15, 382001) Sanskrit learning is still being used by some who know Sanskrit against Harijans.
('63', 191, 6, 16, 382083) Your great temple still bars its gates in the face of Harijans, and I am convinced that the God of Truth and Justice cannot preside in a temple where access is denied to Harijans, and the sin of this denial falls not only on those who are versed in Sanskrit, but on you and me, and all those who call themselves caste Hindus.
('63', 191, 6, 17, 382409) But I know that public opinion is rising fast in favour of opening temples to Harijans, and I would like you to persevere in formulating public opinion till it becomes so irresistible that pandits and trustees of temples notwithstanding, temples will be opened to Harijans.
('63', 191, 6, 18, 382683) In one of your addresses mention is made that in this place not much work for Harijans has been done for want of workers.
('63', 191, 6, 19, 382805) Surely, out of this vast assemblage there must be sufficient number of workers forthcoming who will work for Harijans.
('63', 191, 6, 20, 382924) There must be students enough in Conjee varam who would give their leisure hours to this precious service.
('63', 191, 6, 21, 383031) I do hope you will make every effort to establish in this city a centre of activity for Harijans, and please remember that this is a penance of self purification and that every one of you can purify himself by eradicating untouchability from his heart.
('63', 191, 6, 22, 383284) You can, if you feel the
('63', 192, 0, 1, 383309) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 193
('63', 192, 1, 2, 383353) inward urge, demolish all distinctions of high and low, and I hope that God will inspire you to work in this great cause of humanity.
('63', 192, 1, 3, 383487) Lastly, I would like you to remember the sufferers of Bihar, and while I am disposing of these addresses and other things you have given me, I will like volunteers to collect for the Bihar sufferers.
('63', 192, 1, 4, 383687) The Hindu, 23 2 1934
('63', 192, 2, 5, 383708) 207. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ARNI 1
('63', 192, 3, 6, 383746) February 21, 1934 I thank you for your addresses and the purse.
('63', 192, 3, 7, 383810) The message on the eve of leaving Tamil Nadu is that every one of us should cleanse our hearts of the sin of untouchability.
('63', 192, 3, 8, 383935) We must regard all Harijans as our own blood brothers and sisters.
('63', 192, 3, 9, 384002) That means that we must forget all distinctions of high and low.
('63', 192, 3, 10, 384067) We are all children of one and the same God, and, as such there can be no distinctions of high and low amongst us.
('63', 192, 3, 11, 384182) Harijans should have the same rights and privileges that other Hindus have.
('63', 192, 3, 12, 384258) Their children must have access to public schools.
('63', 192, 3, 13, 384309) They must have access to all public wells, tanks and such other places of utility.
('63', 192, 3, 14, 384392) All public temples should be flung open to them precisely on the same terms that they are open for Hindus, and if we succeed in doing these things, the natural result will be that we shall realize the essential brotherhood of man.
('63', 192, 3, 15, 384623) For, removal of untouchability does not merely mean restoration of the privileges and rights of Harijans, but it means the removal of distinctions between man and man, no matter where they exist.
('63', 192, 3, 16, 384819) I would like you to justify the spirit of brotherliness towards the sufferings of Bihar.
('63', 192, 3, 17, 384908) I know that collections have been made amongst you, but they were only for Harijans.
('63', 192, 3, 18, 384993) I hope that you will, all of you, do whatever you can towards the relief of the distress of tens of thousands of people who are homeless and foodless.
('63', 192, 3, 19, 385144) The Hindu, 23 2 1934
('63', 192, 4, 20, 385165) 1 About 15,000 people had gathered to attend the meeting.
('63', 192, 4, 21, 385223) Three addresses of welcome and a purse of Rs. 801 on behalf of the general public were presented to Gandhiji.
('63', 193, 0, 1, 385333) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 193, 1, 2, 385375) 208. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ARKONAM 1
('63', 193, 2, 3, 385416) [February 21, 1934] 2
('63', 193, 3, 4, 385438) FRIENDS, Tonight, and at this meeting, finishes the long Tamil Nad tour.
('63', 193, 3, 5, 385511) At the outset I would like to say, as I would be leaving this province presently, how thankful I feel to the police and the railway adminis tration in the South for the help rendered to me on all the occasions throughout the province.
('63', 193, 3, 6, 385746) It is a great pleasure to me to say that they were acting, the police I mean, as if they were, as they undoubtedly are, or should be, servants of the people.
('63', 193, 3, 7, 385904) As I am saying this, I am reminded of a conversation I had with two gentlemanly detectives who were appointed in London to look after me.
('63', 193, 3, 8, 386042) They told me that the constables in London, as the police there are called, before being detailed off for duty for the day, had to go through a rehearsal every morning, at which they had to declare, “We are the servants ofthe people and we shall act as such.” Whatever my difference with the English official world, I claim to understand the virtues of my oppo nents.
('63', 193, 3, 9, 386410) And so, I have ever recognized in the London constable an ideal policeman.
('63', 193, 3, 10, 386485) I dare say as a human being he also has his limita tions.
('63', 193, 3, 11, 386543) But knowing, as I do, the police at close quarters in several parts of the world, I can say truthfully that my recollections of con duct of the London constables are altogether pleasant.
('63', 193, 3, 12, 386730) Therefore, it is no mean compliment that I am paying to the police from my expe rience of them throughout the tour, when I recall the London constable.
('63', 193, 3, 13, 386882) I must not omit to mention also the volunteers, who have done duty in all parts of the South.
('63', 193, 3, 14, 386976) Many of them are often untrained.
('63', 193, 3, 15, 387010) In spite of their embarrassing fussiness, I would be ungrateful if I did not mention that they were, in every case, indispensable for the success of the tour.
('63', 193, 3, 16, 387169) They were obliged to work under most trying circumstances, because nobody expected the unprecedented crowds which were witnessed at every place.
('63', 193, 3, 17, 387314) My thanks are, therefore, due to all these parties who have enabled the tour to become the success which in my humble opinion it has been.
('63', 193, 3, 18, 387453) I can only hope that my co workers and others who are identified with the Harijan cause will reap the fullest benefit out of the tremendous awakening that one has seen through 
('63', 193, 4, 19, 387630) 1 The report of the speech in Chandrashankar Shukla’s “Weekly Letter” in Harijan has been collated with the report published in The Hindu.
('63', 193, 4, 20, 387769) 2 From the report of the speech in The Hindu
('63', 194, 0, 1, 387814) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 195
('63', 194, 1, 2, 387858) out the province.
('63', 194, 1, 3, 387876) Unless the workers set themselves to their tasks immediately, there is every danger of this awakening, or the energy created by it, being frittered away.
('63', 194, 1, 4, 388030) It would be a great tragedy if such a thing happened in a movement of self purification, which this is.
('63', 194, 1, 5, 388134) I hope, therefore, that all those who are connected with the Harijan cause will ever remain on the watch tower and not only watch themselves, but watch also what the public is doing in connection with the cause.
('63', 194, 1, 6, 388346) And remember, too, the magnificent result that we intend, or we expect, to achieve from this removal of untouchability—it is no less than the realization of the Brotherhood of Man.
('63', 194, 1, 7, 388527) You cannot—millions of caste Hindus cannot—do reparation to several million Harijans, whom they have suppressed for centuries, without setting free a power, a force, that will envelop the whole of the human family and knit all its members together into one.
('63', 194, 1, 8, 388785) And it is because I have never lost sight of this goal that I have called this movement a deeply spiritual and exclusively religious movement.
('63', 194, 1, 9, 388928) And it is because I realize to the fullest extent how untouchability, as we practise it today in the name of religion, is a stumblingblock in the realization of this brotherhood that I have not hesitated to say that, if we do not cleanse ourselves of this cursed untouchability, Hinduism and Hindus are bound to perish.
('63', 194, 1, 10, 389248) As I, therefore, leave you tonight, I should like to leave you with the full hope that you will endeavour to realize to the fullest extent the ideal that I have sketched before you.
('63', 194, 1, 11, 389430) It is easy enough to do so, if we will but change our hearts.
('63', 194, 1, 12, 389492) May God help you to do so!
('63', 194, 1, 13, 389519) I know that there are people among us who still cling to the belief that untouchability is not only not a sin, but is an obligation imposed upon us by the Shastras.
('63', 194, 1, 14, 389684) As against that, I can but give you my own personal experience based upon uniform conduct for the past fifty years, and that experience is backed by a study of our Shastras such as is possible for a layman, and at that, a busy man like myself.
('63', 194, 1, 15, 389928) After that prayerful study, after discussion with learned shastris who believe in untouchability, I have come to the deliberate conclusion that untouchability has no warrant whatsoever in the Hindu Shastras.
('63', 194, 1, 16, 390136) It is a sin before God and man.
('63', 194, 1, 17, 390168) The sooner we get rid of this sin, the better it is for us, for the whole world.
('63', 194, 1, 18, 390249) Now I must commence business.
('63', 194, 1, 19, 390279) Whilst I am conducting auction sales, I would like volunteers to be in your midst and collect for the sufferers of Bihar.
