('63', 198, 1, 2, 396377) 212. SPEECH AT HUDEKERI 1
('63', 198, 2, 3, 396403) [February 22, 1934] 2
('63', 198, 3, 4, 396425) It is a matter of very great joy to me that God has enabled me to come to this beautiful land of Coorg.
('63', 198, 3, 5, 396529) Ever since I have come here, I have been simply drinking in the natural beauty of the place; and I presume your hearts are as beautiful as your scenery.
('63', 198, 3, 6, 396682) And yet there is lurking in my mind a doubt as to the beauty of your hearts; for I see that, though there is not that poisonous untouchability here that is found in the plains, there is still some of it in your midst.
('63', 198, 3, 7, 396900) For, in your address you have said that temples are not open to Harijans.
('63', 198, 3, 8, 396974) It is just like a father saying to some of his children, ‘I give you food, clothing, housing but I won’t let you come to the sanctuary of my heart.’ Imagine what those children would feel.
('63', 198, 3, 9, 397163) So long as you do not allow Harijans to enter temples on the same terms as you do, I cannot say your hearts are beautiful.
('63', 198, 3, 10, 397286) I wish, therefore, that you will take a lesson from Nature and wash out that black spot on your hearts.
('63', 198, 3, 11, 397390) Harijan, 2 3 1934
('63', 198, 4, 12, 397408) 213. SPEECH AT PANAMPET 3
('63', 198, 5, 13, 397434) [February 22, 1934] 4
('63', 198, 6, 14, 397456) A moment’s reflection will show you that it cannot but be a religious question, because we have been told by those who claim to understand Shastras that untouchability is a divine institution.
('63', 198, 6, 15, 397649) When it comes to me in the garb of religion, I can only meet it by showing that religion has nothing to do with it as we practise it today.
('63', 198, 6, 16, 397789) Then, take the temple entry question.
('63', 198, 6, 17, 397827) What is it if it is not a religious question?
('63', 198, 6, 18, 397873) In order to have temples opened, I have got to touch your hearts; and anything that touches one’s heart, touches one’s faith, immediately becomes a religious thing.
('63', 198, 6, 19, 398038) Indeed, those sanatanists who claim that un touchability is of divine origin fling the taunt in my face that I know nothing of religion.
('63', 198, 6, 20, 398175) Of course, I cannot endorse that taunt, for the simple reason that the whole of my life is saturated with the
('63', 198, 7, 21, 398285) 1 This has been taken from Chandrashankar Shukla’s “Weekly Letter”.
('63', 198, 7, 22, 398353) 2 From Gandhiji’s itinerary 3 Extracted from Chandrashankar Shukla’s “Weekly Letter” 4 From Gandhiji’s itinerary
('63', 199, 0, 1, 398466) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 199, 1, 2, 398508) religious spirit.
('63', 199, 1, 3, 398526) I could not live for a single second without religion.
('63', 199, 1, 4, 398581) Many of my political friends despair of me because they say that even my politics are derived from my religion.
('63', 199, 1, 5, 398693) And they are right.
('63', 199, 1, 6, 398713) My politics and all other activities of mine are derived from my religion.
('63', 199, 1, 7, 398788) I go further and say that every activity of a man of religion must be derived from his religion, because religion means being bound to God, that is to say, God rules your every breath.
('63', 199, 1, 8, 398973) If you recognize that truth, naturally God regulates every activity of yours.
('63', 199, 1, 9, 399051) But, then, it is as a man of religion who is trying to live up to it every moment that I am here to tell you that untouchability is not of divine origin.
('63', 199, 1, 10, 399205) I am here to tell you, after having searched the Shastras in the manner in which a layman like myself can do, that untouchability is a sin against God and man.
('63', 199, 1, 11, 399365) I am here to tell you that there is no warrant in the Shastras for untouchability as we practise it today and that, therefore, it is sinful to deny entrance into our temples to Harijans.

('63', 199, 2, 13, 399570) 214. NOTES
('63', 199, 3, 14, 399581) FOR BIHAR’S SAKE
('63', 199, 4, 15, 399598) Hardly a meeting has been addressed by me since the calamity of Bihar without reference to it.
('63', 199, 4, 16, 399693) It must gladden Babu Rajendra Prasad’s and every Bihari’s heart to know that I have had the most generous response even from the poorest in the most distant villages.
('63', 199, 4, 17, 399860) Harijans have vied with non Harijans in giving their coppers.
('63', 199, 4, 18, 399922) Where they have not given anything at the meetings, they have been able to say, ‘I have already sent my mite to Rajendrababu.’ At these meetings women have given their bracelets and men their rings, young students their fountain pens because they had nothing else to give.
('63', 199, 4, 19, 400195) All together, up to now, the Bihar collections made at the meetings have amounted to Rs. 5135 4 1. Of course, this is nothing compared to the amount required for the relief.
('63', 199, 4, 20, 400369) But the value of the gifts of the poor lies not in their metallic content, but in their being evidence of genuine sympathy.
('63', 199, 4, 21, 400493) Man does not live by bread alone.
('63', 199, 4, 22, 400527) Fellow feeling is often more precious than bread.
('63', 199, 4, 23, 400577) And whilst I am writing about the villagers’ contributions, I am glad to be able to announce the receipt of a cable remittance of Rs.1,969 3 2 from the Yokohama Indian merchants.
('63', 199, 4, 24, 400756) The amount has been duly forwarded to Babu Rajendra Prasad at Patna.
('63', 199, 4, 25, 400825) There is no
('63', 200, 0, 1, 400837) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 201
('63', 200, 1, 2, 400881) doubt that the Bihar calamity has stirred the hearts of men and women all over the world.
('63', 200, 2, 3, 400971) GOKHALE AND HARIJANS
('63', 200, 3, 4, 400992) Several young men have, during the tour in the South, written to me attributing to Brahmins untouchability and other evils from which Hindu society is suffering.
('63', 200, 3, 5, 401154) I am writing this note the day after the 19th anniversary of Gokhale’s death.
('63', 200, 3, 6, 401232) I am, therefore, naturally re minded of his love of Harijans.
('63', 200, 3, 7, 401294) It is not possible to imagine a man freer from the taint of untouchability than he.
('63', 200, 3, 8, 401378) With him there was no inequality between man and man.
('63', 200, 3, 9, 401432) Once, in South Africa, a man had come to him, asking him to attend a meeting of a sectional character.
('63', 200, 3, 10, 401535) He was disinclined.
('63', 200, 3, 11, 401555) An appeal was made to his Hinduism.
('63', 200, 3, 12, 401591) He was indi gnant over what he felt to be a reproach and said with a warmth which astonished the hearers, “If that is Hinduism, I am not a Hindu.” He could not stand the assumption of superiority by any person or community.
('63', 200, 3, 13, 401815) In his dealings with fellow men, he exemplified in his own life the spirit of universal brotherhood.
('63', 200, 3, 14, 401916) He mixed with the greatest freedom with the so called Pariahs.
('63', 200, 3, 15, 401979) There was no patronizing air about him.
('63', 200, 3, 16, 402019) He evolved the ideal of service.
('63', 200, 3, 17, 402052) Public men and women were not leaders but servants.
('63', 200, 3, 18, 402104) For him the greatest leader was the greatest servant.
('63', 200, 3, 19, 402158) And Gokhale was a born Brahmin in every sense of the term.
('63', 200, 3, 20, 402217) He was a born teacher.
('63', 200, 3, 21, 402240) He loved to be called Professor.
('63', 200, 3, 22, 402273) He was humility personified.
('63', 200, 3, 23, 402302) He surrendered his all to the nation.
('63', 200, 3, 24, 402340) He might have amassed a fortune, but he deliberately chose a life of poverty.
('63', 200, 3, 25, 402418) Will not the haters of Brahmins be proud of a servant like Gokhale?
('63', 200, 3, 26, 402486) And Gokhale was not the only one of his kind.
('63', 200, 3, 27, 402532) It is possible to make out a long list of Brahmins who have stood up for equality between man and man.
('63', 200, 3, 28, 402635) To decry the Brahmins as a class is to deny ourselves the benefit of the selfless service for which many of them have specially fitted themselves.
('63', 200, 3, 29, 402782) They stand in no need of certificates.
('63', 200, 3, 30, 402821) Their service is its own reward.
('63', 200, 3, 31, 402854) In the words of Gokhale written on a momentous occasion in his life, “Service undertaken at the bidding of no one cannot be given up at the bidding of anyone.” The safest rule, therefore, is to take a man at his present worth, irrespective of his birth, or race or colour.
('63', 200, 3, 32, 403127) In the campaign against untouchability, we may despise no service, be it ever so small, so long as it is service and and not patronage.
('63', 201, 0, 1, 403263) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 201, 1, 2, 403305) A WORTHY EXAMPLE
('63', 201, 2, 3, 403322) In response to my speech to the students of the Trichy National College, I got the following letter, signed by thirteen students, on the day of my departure from Trichy: We, the following students of the National College, paying our respects to you, Sir, express our desire to work for the cause of the Harijans and other schemes like child welfare scheme.
('63', 201, 2, 4, 403679) But students as we are, our time is not wholly ours.
('63', 201, 2, 5, 403732) We are willingly prepared to devote our leisure hours for such holy duties.
('63', 201, 2, 6, 403808) We humbly request you, Revered Mahatmaji, to be kind enough to give us instructions for our future guidance and bestow on us your sacred blessings.
('63', 201, 2, 7, 403956) The signatories are to be congratulated on their decision.
('63', 201, 2, 8, 404015) Let us hope that they will carry it out with unflagging zeal.
('63', 201, 2, 9, 404077) The signatories want guidance.
('63', 201, 2, 10, 404108) The only guidance I can give is to ask them to do to the Harijans as they would have the Harijans do to them if they were untouchables.
('63', 201, 2, 11, 404244) In other words, they should regard Harijans as their blood brothers and sisters.
('63', 201, 2, 12, 404325) If they will visit Harijan quarters in that spirit, they will always find the right word and the right action.
('63', 201, 3, 13, 404436) Harijan, 23 2 1934
('63', 201, 4, 14, 404455) 215. ‘AN APPEAL FOR PEACE’
('63', 201, 5, 15, 404482) A correspondent from Bengal writes: The present quarrel between the reformers and the sanatanists is causing much bitterness on both sides.
('63', 201, 5, 16, 404622) It is desirable that the quarrel should be stopped at an early date.
('63', 201, 5, 17, 404691) I would, therefore, appeal to both the parties to show mutual tolerance.
('63', 201, 5, 18, 404764) India is a country of many races and creeds, and it is essential for the peace and progress of the country that there should be tolerance between different creeds and races.
('63', 201, 5, 19, 404938) Tolerance has been one of the most beautiful features in the history of India.
('63', 201, 5, 20, 405017) There is no reason why there should be quarrel and bitterness when Gandhiji carries on a reform movement against untou chability.
('63', 201, 5, 21, 405147) But it is necessary for Gandhiji and his followers to show some tolerance while carrying on their movement.
('63', 201, 5, 22, 405255) The reformers might think that untouchability is bad.
('63', 201, 5, 23, 405309) But they should not try to deprive orthodox people of the right to worship as they like in their own temples.
('63', 202, 0, 1, 405419) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 203
('63', 202, 1, 2, 405463) If the Anti untouchability Bill and the Temple entry Bill are passed, will not orthodox Hindus be deprived of this right?
('63', 202, 1, 3, 405585) Suppose an orthodox Hindu builds and endows a temple and allows all savarna Hindus to enter the temple and worship the deity, but excludes Hari jans whom he considers untouchable.
('63', 202, 1, 4, 405765) According to the Anti unto uchability Bill, his desire to exclude the Harijans will not be respected, because the law will not recognize any person as untouchable.
('63', 202, 1, 5, 405929) According to the Temple entry Bill, if the majority of the upper caste Hindus desire to admit the Harijans, they will be able to override the desire of the donor.
('63', 202, 1, 6, 406092) That would be obviously unfair.
('63', 202, 1, 7, 406124) I believe that among the reformers there would be many who would not like to deprive orthodox Hindus of reasonable facilities in the matter of conducting religious ceremonies.
('63', 202, 1, 8, 406300) Such liberal reformers should not support these Bills which would deprive the orthodox people of their legitimate rights as explained above.
('63', 202, 1, 9, 406441) Difference of opinion should not cause bitterness, if there is no attempt on the part of either party to deprive the other of its reasonable privileges.
('63', 202, 1, 10, 406594) As regards existing temples, it is necessary to consider the interests of three parties: (I) reformers, (2) sanatanists and (3) Harijans.
('63', 202, 1, 11, 406732) At present Harijans do not enjoy the right to worship in the temples.
('63', 202, 1, 12, 406802) It is proposed that they should be allowed to worship in the temples.
('63', 202, 1, 13, 406872) The sanatanists believe that they cannot worship properly if Harijans are admitted.
('63', 202, 1, 14, 406956) The sanatanists may be wrong in thinking so, but there is no doubt that they do think so.
('63', 202, 1, 15, 407046) Is it not natural that they should feel sorely aggrieved, if a privilege which they have enjoyed long is taken away?
('63', 202, 1, 16, 407163) Will it not be the most peaceful way of intro ducing the reforms to build new temples where reformers and Hari jans may worship together?
('63', 202, 1, 17, 407301) The reformers may, of course, boycott orthodox temples.
('63', 202, 1, 18, 407357) If (as the reformers claim) a great majority of the countrymen are against untouchability, the orthodox temples will be deserted and the reformers will be able to demonstrate that un touchability has left the country.
('63', 202, 1, 19, 407575) Gandhiji is collecting lakhs of rupees in his tour and should have no difficulty in building new temples for reformers and Harijans if he likes.
('63', 202, 1, 20, 407720) The money is worth spending, if it can save a split among the Hindus.
('63', 202, 1, 21, 407790) At Trichy, the other day, a pleader, describing himself as a liberal sanatanist brought a written statement from which I extract the following: We believe that the item relating to temple entry may be
('63', 203, 0, 1, 407991) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 203, 1, 2, 408033) dropped for the present and the resources of all Hindus including the sanatanists may be pooled together for promoting the material, moral, educational and spiritual welfare of Harijans in consonance with the tradition of Hindu religion, so that the Harijans may become the equals of savarnas in every respect and there will not be any curse of untouchability, if they are treated as our kith and kin.
('63', 203, 1, 3, 408435) No impartial observer will fail to recognize that the removal of the customary social disabilities effecting the Harijans is absolutely necessary.
('63', 203, 1, 4, 408582) The reform must proceed gradually step by step.
('63', 203, 1, 5, 408630) Our Harijans should be admitted to our homes just as Europeans and Muslims are admitted.
('63', 203, 1, 6, 408719) Our Hari jans should be admitted to the several callings or professions open to savarnas and ought not to be segregated, and they should be taught to assert their rights of elementary citizenship.
('63', 203, 1, 7, 408916) It is likely that, in the course of fifty years, our Harijans will be admitted into the temples.
('63', 203, 2, 8, 409013) These are two typical statements.
('63', 203, 2, 9, 409047) Both want the temple entry question to be dropped.
('63', 203, 2, 10, 409098) The first letter makes an “appeal to both parties to show mutual tolerance” but in effect insists on even one sanatanist excluding Harijans from temples, even though all the rest may be prepared to admit them.
('63', 203, 2, 11, 409308) In naked terms, this is coercion of the worst type—a minority of one bending the will of the majority to its will.
('63', 203, 2, 12, 409423) None but tyrants are reported by history to have succeeded in enforcing their will against all others, and that they did to their own utter destruction.
('63', 203, 2, 13, 409576) So far as I can speak for the reformers, their position is plain.
('63', 203, 2, 14, 409642) They do not wish to see a single temple opened to Harijans until there is an overwhelming majority of existing temple goers in favour of such entry.
('63', 203, 2, 15, 409791) There is, therefore, no question of compulsion or coercion, unless the enforcement of the will of an overwhelming majority may be so called.
('63', 203, 2, 16, 409932) The majority may be, ought to be, expected to be forbearing and accommodating towards a minority.
('63', 203, 2, 17, 410030) How that can be done I have already shown in these columns.
('63', 203, 2, 18, 410090) But the minority wants no accommodation, it insists on the present position remaining intact.
('63', 203, 2, 19, 410184) This would mean stagnation and ultimate death.
('63', 203, 2, 20, 410231) Hence it is that I have been saying: either we kill untouchability or it will kill us as surely as the rising of the sun on the morrow.
('63', 203, 2, 21, 410367) There is no question of mutual bitterness or quarrel.
('63', 203, 2, 22, 410421) Reformers have no bitterness on account of the sanatanists’ opposition, for they give to them the same credit for honesty of purpose as they claim for themselves.
('63', 203, 2, 23, 410584) The reformers are showing exemplary toleration in that they refrain from opening temples where there is a fair division of
('63', 204, 0, 1, 410707) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 205
('63', 204, 1, 2, 410751) opinion, even though a clear majority may be in favour of reform.
('63', 204, 1, 3, 410817) The reformers’ task is, therefore, confined to the conversion of popular opinion to their side.
('63', 204, 1, 4, 410913) And if the sanatanists will but recognize this undoubted right, there need be no friction whatsoever.
('63', 204, 1, 5, 411015) Whilst the first writer asks nothing from the sanatanists and wants everything from the reformers, the second recognizes that the temples will have to be opened some day to Harijans.
('63', 204, 1, 6, 411198) But he pleads for time and recommends common work in all other matters.
('63', 204, 1, 7, 411270) The only amendment I would suggest is that, whilst the temple entry ques tion may not be given up altogether, the agitation should be carried on with the greatest consideration for the orthodox sentiment.
('63', 204, 1, 8, 411475) If the sanatanists would respect this very moderate position, instead of stag ing opposi tion, sometimes not quite wisely, and would make common cause in all other matters, the whole movement could be carried on with the greatest decorum and without wounding any body’s suscep tibilities.
('63', 204, 1, 9, 411764) As for the proposed legislation, it is necessary for the sake of removing the obstacle that is said to exist at present in the way of reform.
('63', 204, 1, 10, 411906) There is no compulsion in it, unless the prevalence of the will of one person against any number, be it ever so large, is insisted on.
('63', 204, 1, 11, 412041) And in no case have I any desire to see the Bills passed in the teeth of the opposition of a majority of Hindu members.
('63', 204, 1, 12, 412161) I should wait till the majority of Hindus of the existing or any future legislature or legislatures are ready for the long overdue reform.
('63', 204, 1, 13, 412300) Harijan, 23 2 1934

('63', 205, 4, 16, 413730) 217. SPEECH AT VIRAJPET 1
('63', 205, 5, 17, 413756) February 23, 1934 It was an agreeable surprise to me to receive an address in very choice, correct Hindustani.
('63', 205, 5, 18, 413867) I am a lover of Urdu and Urdu literature.
('63', 205, 5, 19, 413909) But I have noticed that down South it is rare to find an Urdu scholar; and I was not prepared to find good Urdu writing and speaking in Coorg.This address asks me to do whatever is possible in order to unite Hindus and Mussalmans throughout India as you are united here.
('63', 205, 5, 20, 414180) Of certain things which I hold as dear as life itself, Hindu Mus lim unity, i.e., unity among all the races in India, is one; and as I did some years ago in Delhi, I should be prepared, given the occasion and the inspiration, to stake my life again for the same cause.
('63', 205, 5, 21, 414449) My life is one indivisible whole, and all my activities run into one another; and they all have their rise in my insatiable love of mankind.
('63', 205, 5, 22, 414590) Seeking to realize oneness of life in practice, I cannot be happy if I see commu nities quarrelling with one another or men suppressing fellowmen.
('63', 205, 5, 23, 414737) I am, therefore, glad that this address admits that this Harijan movement is one for realizing the substantial oneness of man.
('63', 205, 5, 24, 414864) And if I have thrown myself heart and soul in the campaign against untouchability, it is because I know that untouchability is the greatest stumbling block in this realization.

('63', 206, 1, 2, 415179) 218. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING MERCARA 1
('63', 206, 2, 3, 415219) February 23, 1934 I finish this evening this all too short visit to your beautiful province.
('63', 206, 2, 4, 415312) Though the two days, or almost two days, have been strenu ous, they have been most agreeable to me—agreeable not merely because of the magnificent scenery that surrounds you, but also because untouchability has such a slight hold on you.
('63', 206, 2, 5, 415550) In your address, you have confined yourselves to facts and figures in connection with Harijans.
('63', 206, 2, 6, 415646) I appreciate the manner in which you have prepared your address, which in fact is a report.
('63', 206, 2, 7, 415738) It gives me illuminating and exhaustive information about Harijans.
('63', 206, 2, 8, 415806) It is a matter of regret that Harijans here are daily becoming landless.
('63', 206, 2, 9, 415879) I see that what little land they still possess is lying fallow.
('63', 206, 2, 10, 415943) It is up to the local Harijan Sevak Sangh to examine critically this situation and see what it is possible to do to prevent the Harijans from losing their lands.
('63', 206, 2, 11, 416105) It may be that there are economic causes applicable to all which it is not in your power to prevent.
('63', 206, 2, 12, 416206) It, therefore, becomes necessary for the Harijan Sevak Sangh to understand the economic condition of Harijans who have become landless.
('63', 206, 2, 13, 416342) It may be that as a result of the investigation it will be found that, though they have lost their land they are not the poorer.
('63', 206, 2, 14, 416471) But, should it be otherwise—as I fear it is—it will be up to the Harijan Sevak Sangh to apply the necessary remedy in order to improve their economic condition.
('63', 206, 2, 15, 416632) But, in my opinion, the greatest question with you, so far as Harijans are concerned, is the temple entry question.
('63', 206, 2, 16, 416748) It seems to be monstrous that public opinion here should not be able to open temples to Harijans.
('63', 206, 2, 17, 416846) I see that you have no fixed prejudices such as are to be seen on the plains.
('63', 206, 2, 18, 416924) I would, therefore, ask all workers who have the Harijan cause at heart to apply themselves to the solution of this problem; and I would like you to cherish the ambition that you may give the lead to India in this respect.
('63', 206, 2, 19, 417147) I would like also to mention to you the sufferers of Bihar.
('63', 206, 2, 20, 417207) You are living somewhat in isolation from the rest of India.
('63', 206, 2, 21, 417268) You seem also to be mostly self contained.
('63', 206, 2, 22, 417311) I hope that has not hardened your hearts.
('63', 206, 3, 23, 417353) 1 According to The Hindu, 25 2 1934, the meeting was held at Raja’s Seat Maidan at 6.30 in the evening.
('63', 206, 3, 24, 417457) About 15,000 attended.
('63', 206, 3, 25, 417480) At the end of the meeting a collection was made for Bihar relief.
('63', 207, 0, 1, 417546) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 207, 1, 2, 417588) After all, you are but a part of the whole of India; and the sufferings of Indians in the extreme North should be shared by you as by others.
('63', 207, 1, 3, 417730) You may know that Bihar is a sacred land because of the birth of both Sita and Gautama Buddha.
('63', 207, 1, 4, 417825) Our countrymen in Bihar believe that every particle of the soil in that land is sacred.
('63', 207, 1, 5, 417913) And to a man like me, it would almost appear that God has selected that sacred land for castigation for the sin of untouchability.
('63', 207, 1, 6, 418044) It does not matter to me in the least degree that my imagination may be wrong.
('63', 207, 1, 7, 418123) But let us cherish the thought and make greater effort to purify ourselves.
('63', 207, 1, 8, 418199) After all, if we will feel that all mankind is one, the distress of one single man on any part of the earth should be shared by us.
('63', 207, 1, 9, 418331) How much more so, then, when it is in connection with those whom we consider as our kith and kin!
('63', 207, 1, 10, 418429) And after all, that to me is one of the implications of the removal of untouchability.
('63', 207, 1, 11, 418516) If we believe that all mankind are touch able, it necessarily follows that we should share the sufferings of all mankind.
('63', 207, 1, 12, 418638) Therefore, whilst I conduct the auction, volunteers will go amongst you, and you will give to them whatever you can.
('63', 207, 1, 13, 418755) It is not that you will thereby give much material help to the sufferers.
('63', 207, 1, 14, 418829) But in the face of a calamity so great as has befallen Bihar, every copper given is a token of tangible sympathy with the sufferers.
('63', 207, 1, 15, 418962) And do we not all know that sympathy in distress often goes much further than material help brought to us?

('63', 210, 2, 13, 424905) Therefore you must find out a variety of ways whereby you may occupy their attention, their minds, their hands and their feet.

('63', 219, 1, 12, 441766) Well, that is like an oasis in the desert of Sahara, very pleasant and very nice when you are walking through a desert.

('63', 219, 1, 17, 442318) When I compare it with the palace of the old Maharani of Travancore, I tell you, there is not much distinction between this house and the palace which I had the pleasure of seeing in Travancore.

('63', 220, 2, 17, 444491) 232. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MULKI 1
('63', 220, 3, 18, 444530) February 25, 1934 I am obliged to you for this address and the purse.
('63', 220, 3, 19, 444600) I must congratulate you on your being able to recite the many things you have done in connection with the removal of untouchability and I hope that your belief that sanatanists’ opposition against temple entry is dying down is well based.
('63', 220, 3, 20, 444839) There is the last sentence in your address which requires explanation.
('63', 220, 3, 21, 444910) You have prayed to God Almighty that by the power of Harijans, the Hindu society may be strengthened.
('63', 220, 3, 22, 445012) If thereby you mean that justice having been rendered to Harijans and reparation having been made to them by caste Hindus, Hindu society will be purified and therefore by reason of this purity it will gain moral height, I can join in that prayer whole heartedly.
('63', 220, 3, 23, 445275) Whereas if this prayer means that because caste Hindus who by reason of their being pampered and degraded have become infirm in bodies will receive
('63', 220, 4, 24, 445423) 1 A brief report of this was also published in Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter”, Harijan, 9 3 1934.
('63', 221, 0, 1, 445520) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 221, 1, 2, 445562) access to physical strength from the able bodied Harijans, it is impossible to join in that prayer.
('63', 221, 1, 3, 445662) I must tell you that thought has never crossed my mind.
('63', 221, 1, 4, 445718) And I shall never allow myself to be associated with a movement which is based upon physical strength.
('63', 221, 1, 5, 445821) It is my conviction that no religion on earth can be sustained by brute strength.
('63', 221, 1, 6, 445903) On the contrary, “those who rely on the sword shall perish by the sword” is an eternal truth.
('63', 221, 1, 7, 445997) Religion is a mighty tree which derives all its sap from the moral height of those who profess that religion.
('63', 221, 1, 8, 446107) Hence I have repeated from a thousand meetings that this is essentially a movement of self purification and repentance.
('63', 221, 1, 9, 446227) You will be glad to know that this purse of Rs. 501 contains Rs. 200 given by the fishermen.
('63', 221, 1, 10, 446320) I congratulate them on their handsome donation.
('63', 221, 1, 11, 446368) I know that they are a flourishing community.
('63', 221, 1, 12, 446414) And I know also that if they got rid of the drink habit and if they had the free supply of salt they could do much better.
('63', 221, 1, 13, 446537) Free supply of salt depends upon circumstances over which we have no control.
('63', 221, 1, 14, 446615) But upon the liquor habit, we have full control.
('63', 221, 1, 15, 446664) And I would like my fishermen friends to carry on this reform which they have well begun in Mangalore.
('63', 221, 1, 16, 446767) It is a habit that destroys the soul.
('63', 221, 2, 17, 446805) The Hindu, 28 2 1934

('63', 223, 1, 2, 450007) community, till at last there is absolutely no caste, no section, which does not consider itself superior to some other section or caste.
('63', 223, 1, 3, 450145) There may be and there are many other causes but I am convinced that this superiority and inferiority complex is at the bottom of many of our communal troubles.
('63', 223, 1, 4, 450306) Therefore the implication of this cam paign against untouchability is that we want to achieve brotherhood of man.
('63', 223, 1, 5, 450420) And that essential brotherhood of man is unattainable so long as we believe that untouchability has Divine sanction.

('63', 223, 1, 17, 451482) It is an incredibly simple language to learn and you ought to take sufficient trouble to master the elements of that language.

('63', 229, 1, 2, 461556) Last week I wrote about the power of the Name.
('63', 229, 1, 3, 461603) But the question arises: how should one repeat the Name?
('63', 229, 1, 4, 461660) What good does it do to keep repeating it when thousands of idle thoughts distract the mind?
('63', 229, 1, 5, 461753) Either one should repeat the Name from the heart, or not at all.
('63', 229, 1, 6, 461818) This is partly right and partly not.
('63', 229, 1, 7, 461855) If one repeats the Name for outward show, it has no meaning.
('63', 229, 1, 8, 461916) On the contrary it is a sin to do so since it amounts to deception.
('63', 229, 1, 9, 461984) But a person may wish sincerely to repeat the Name, and yet his mind may be continually distracted by other thoughts when he is repeating it.
('63', 229, 1, 10, 462126) He should not lose heart, however.
('63', 229, 1, 11, 462161) He should go on repeating the Name in spite of the distraction of thoughts.
('63', 229, 1, 12, 462237) If he keeps up the practice, some day the Name will get inscribed in his heart.
('63', 229, 1, 13, 462317) This is the reason why the power of the Name has been glorified.
('63', 229, 1, 14, 462382) Even an illiterate or dull person can repeat the Lord’s name.
('63', 229, 1, 15, 462444) One can learn to do so in one second.
('63', 229, 1, 16, 462482) After that one has merely to keep repeating it.
('63', 229, 1, 17, 462530) By and by this becomes so much a habit that one does not feel happy unless one is going on with it.
('63', 229, 1, 18, 462630) When the habit becomes so strong that one goes on repeating the Name at all hours of the day, whether eating or drinking or working or resting, then it may be said that the Name has sunk in one’s heart.
('63', 229, 1, 19, 462833) Such persons are rare, but they rise above all suffering.
('63', 229, 1, 20, 462891) An interesting story about Hanuman illustrating this was told in the Ashram once by Panditji’s guru.
('63', 229, 1, 21, 462992) I will narrate it next week.
('63', 229, 2, 22, 463021) Blessings to all from BAPU [From Gujarati]

('63', 236, 8, 20, 475521) 250. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, SIRSI 1
('63', 236, 9, 21, 475560) February 28, 1934
('63', 236, 10, 22, 475578) Gandhiji said the name Sirsi was not unfamiliar to him.
('63', 236, 10, 23, 475634) When his Karnataka programme was arranged, Sirsi was bound to be included, as so many of his comrades lived in it, and if he could not exact Harijan service from comrades, he had little right to expect it of others.
('63', 236, 10, 24, 475850) It was his constant experience that untouchability was vanishing from places where his comrades were to be found in large numbers.
('63', 236, 10, 25, 475981) And who were his comrades?
('63', 236, 10, 26, 476008) They only were his comrades who looked upon the entire people of India, Muslims, Christians, Jews, etc., no less than Hindus, as brothers and sisters, who, while holding India dearer than life itself, did not wish ill to any other country on earth, who did not despise or hate anyone even in a dream, who were ready to lay down their lives in the quest of truth.
('63', 236, 10, 27, 476371) Such comrades could never consider
('63', 236, 11, 28, 476406) 1 Extracted from Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('63', 237, 0, 1, 476453) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 237, 1, 2, 476495) anybody as untouchable or inferior to themselves.
('63', 237, 1, 3, 476545) He was, therefore, confident that in Sirsi at any rate he would not meet anyone capable of upholding untouchability, and he was, therefore, not surprised to hear that its Municipality had accorded assistance to the local sangh and given free studentships to Harijan boys.
('63', 237, 1, 4, 476817) Indeed, it would have been a painful surprise to him if it had been otherwise.
('63', 237, 1, 5, 476896) The Municipal address admitted that they had “not yet been able entirely to throw off notions of superiority”.
('63', 237, 1, 6, 477007) That admission was creditable to them, for consciousness of imperfection is the first step in the march towards perfection.
('63', 237, 1, 7, 477131) However, he hoped they would surmount the superiority complex, which was at the root, not only of untouchability, but also of communal bitterness.
('63', 237, 1, 8, 477278) Removal of untouchability would go a long way in bringing about universal brotherhood.
('63', 237, 2, 9, 477365) Gandhiji congratulated the trustees of the temple 1 for flinging it open to Harijans, but he was deeply pained to hear that animals were offered at that shrine.
('63', 237, 2, 10, 477526) He would not consider any place holy where animals were slaughtered for sacrifice.
('63', 237, 2, 11, 477609) Millions killed animals in other countries for food, but did not pretend that they did so to propitiate God.
('63', 237, 2, 12, 477718) It was an insult to human intelligence and an outrage on the human heart to imagine that one could propitiate the deity by sacrificing animals.
('63', 237, 2, 13, 477862) One can please God only by self sacrifice and self denial.
('63', 237, 2, 14, 477921) He, therefore, hoped that the trustees of the temple would take a strong line and put an end to the evil practice in question.
('63', 237, 2, 15, 478048) He would go so far as to say that Harijans ought not to be encouraged to visit any temple where animal sacrifice was offered.
('63', 237, 3, 16, 478174) Harijan, 9 3 1934

('63', 239, 6, 12, 480411) 254. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, SIDDAPUR 1
('63', 239, 7, 13, 480453) March 1, 1934
('63', 239, 8, 14, 480467) Gandhiji said that the complaint 2 was perhaps rather exaggerated, but he had no doubt that it was substantially true.
('63', 239, 8, 15, 480586) He, therefore, hoped that the savarna Hindus of Siddapur would remove the disabilities of Harijans.
('63', 239, 8, 16, 480686) Or else it was no use their contributing to the Harijan fund.
('63', 239, 8, 17, 480748) No one should regard such donations as a licence for the sins for the removal of which they were made.
('63', 239, 8, 18, 480851) Donations intended as atonement for sin should be a token of future abstinence from it.
('63', 239, 8, 19, 480939) In future, therefore, they should treat Harijans as blood brothers and sisters.
('63', 239, 8, 20, 481019) Oppression of Harijans was a potent factor in our present degradation and India could never expect to be happy so long as Harijans were in chains.
('63', 239, 8, 21, 481166) A peasant presented Gandhiji with samples of arecanuts, cardamoms and pepper, on which he had marked the comparative prices of these products in 1929 and 1933.
('63', 239, 9, 22, 481326) Adverting to this, Gandhiji said he would point out a remedy which they might apply if they chose.
('63', 239, 9, 23, 481425) That remedy was spinning.
('63', 239, 9, 24, 481451) They must grow profitable crops and utilize their leisure fully.
('63', 239, 9, 25, 481516) They must not sit idle because spinning did not promise any large returns.
('63', 239, 9, 26, 481591) Something was better than nothing.
('63', 239, 9, 27, 481626) They must produce strong and uniform yarn, get it woven and wear the cloth themselves, or sell it if not required for personal use.
('63', 239, 10, 28, 481758) Gandhiji did not wish to suggest that there were not many other measures necessary for a radical cure of the depressions, but that was a larger question to be
('63', 239, 11, 29, 481917) 1 Extracted from Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 2 Of the local Harijans that they were treated as slaves
('63', 240, 0, 1, 482021) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 241
('63', 240, 1, 2, 482065) dealt with by statesmen and politicians.
('63', 240, 1, 3, 482106) His appeal was directly to the men in distress, and he was trying to show what each individual could do for himself to alleviate the distress.
('63', 240, 1, 4, 482249) And that was obviously to make use of enforced idleness further intensified by the distress.
('63', 240, 1, 5, 482342) It was open to others o suggest more remunerative occupations.
('63', 240, 1, 6, 482405) He could find no other that would apply to millions of men and women.
('63', 240, 2, 7, 482475) Harijan, 9 3 1934
('63', 240, 3, 8, 482493) 255. OPINION INVITED
('63', 240, 4, 9, 482514) DRAFT RULES FOR THE DISBURSEMENT OF GANDHIJI’S HARIJAN PURSE TOUR FUND 1
('63', 240, 5, 10, 482587) (1) About a month or two after the collections of the purse fund of each province, the existing financial relations between the Central Office and the Provincial Office may cease in favour of the new financial relations arising out of the new Purse Fund, which are described below.
('63', 240, 5, 11, 482869) The fund is called the Gandhi Harijan Purse Fund.
('63', 240, 6, 12, 482919) (2) The money for all welfare work expenses incurred after the passing of the welfare schemes should be charged to the Purse Fund, that is, it will come out of the 75 per cent quota of the Purse Fund, or out of the 50 per cent in the case of principal cities.
('63', 240, 6, 13, 483179) Grants for administrative and propaganda expenses will be continued to be paid according to the existing system, that is, one half or two thirds, or whatever the ratio may be, of such expenditure, out of the central fund, from which the Purse Fund will be kept separate.
('63', 240, 7, 14, 483450) (3) Except for Bombay, Calcutta, Karachi and similarly circumstanced cities, at least 75 per cent of the money collected in each town, district or province will be spent in that place, or area or province, if the following two conditions are satisfied:
('63', 240, 8, 15, 483703) (a) A scheme, including all the old commitments, of welfare work for utilizing the quota of the Purse Fund money is proposed, submitted and approved by the Central Office.
('63', 240, 9, 16, 483875) (b) Whole time, honorary or part time workers are forthcoming for working out the approved scheme or schemes, and their names approved.
('63', 240, 9, 17, 484011) In appointing permanent workers, care should be taken to see that they have had at least 2 years’ continued service.
('63', 240, 10, 18, 484128) (4) The Purse Fund should be spread out over a period of not less than two years, according to circumstances, at the discretion of the workers of the locality concerned, with the approval of the provincial workers.
('63', 240, 11, 19, 484343) 1 These were framed by Harijan Sevak Sangh, Delhi.
('63', 241, 0, 1, 484394) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 241, 1, 2, 484436) (5) The money will be forthcoming by instalments, as may be required, on presentation of monthly bills of expenditure incurred on welfare schemes.
('63', 241, 1, 3, 484583) Reasonable advances, however, will be made to keep the work going.
('63', 241, 2, 4, 484650) It is the special desire of Mahatma Gandhi that out of the Purse Fund not a single rupee should be spent for administration and propaganda of the provincial, district or other offices and that the purse money cash should be utilized for no other purpose than the execution of schemes for Harijan welfare work.
('63', 241, 3, 5, 484960) (6) The earmarking of donations should be done at the time of the donation and not after.
('63', 241, 3, 6, 485050) And in each case, when earmarking is done, it will be accepted only if Gandhiji approves.
('63', 241, 4, 7, 485140) (7) Special cases of districts requiring extra help over 75 per cent would be considered only on the grounds of the poverty of the district, or the extraordinary scope for work in the district or the unusually large number of Harijans in the district.
('63', 241, 5, 8, 485392) (8) In regard to taluk organizations and their finances, schemes from the taluks which have paid money to the Fund will receive due consideration in relation to such schemes.
('63', 241, 5, 9, 485567) There need be no paid secretary or office in the taluks.
('63', 241, 6, 10, 485624) (9) The Provincial Secretary as also District Secretaries, should cease to be office men, but should become necessary parts of the welfare schemes.
('63', 241, 6, 11, 485772) The charges of the provincial staff needed for supervising schemes in the districts will thus be met from the 75 per cent quota and taken from the districts in proportion to their budgets.
('63', 241, 6, 12, 485961) Workers necessary for supervising welfare schemes may be treated as part of the constructive expenses.
('63', 241, 6, 13, 486064) All those who belong to various Harijan Sevak organizations or are otherwise interested in the cause are invited to send to the Secretary, Central Board, as early as possible their suggestions on the foregoing draft rules.
('63', 241, 6, 14, 486287) The object is to incorporate in the final rules the wisdom of those who have helpful suggestions to make.
('63', 241, 6, 15, 486393) Perhaps it is more difficult to spend the money wisely than it was to collect it.
('63', 241, 6, 16, 486475) The chief difficulty will be to find whole time, trustworthy and otherwise competent workers.
('63', 241, 6, 17, 486569) In making their recommendations, therefore, local sanghs and individuals will bear in mind the difficulty about workers.
('63', 241, 6, 18, 486690) Schemes, moreover, which would admit of employing Harijans by preference must be more acceptable than those in which such special qualifications may be required as to make it impossible to employ Harijans.
('63', 241, 6, 19, 486896) Suffice it to say that the aim of every scheme should be the greatest and the quickest amelioration of the educational and the economic condition of Harijans with the funds available.
('63', 241, 6, 20, 487080) Thus the general rules can only be indicative and elastic, so as to cover as wide a range of schemes as might be formulated by the provincial and district sanghs.
('63', 241, 6, 21, 487243) Harijan, 2 3 1934

('63', 242, 4, 7, 487493) 257. A WAIL FROM MELA ARASUR
('63', 242, 5, 8, 487522) I cannot recall a place where I have not received addresses from Harijans.
('63', 242, 5, 9, 487597) Most of them have dealt with general grievances, but in two or three cases I can recall having had instances of specific complaints against the tyranny of caste Hindus.
('63', 242, 5, 10, 487766) Mela Arasur is a village in Lal gudi taluk, not far from Trichinopoly.
('63', 242, 5, 11, 487837) After the usual complimentary paragraph, the appeal proceeds: 1
('63', 242, 6, 12, 487901) We, the inhabitants of the village of Mela Arasur, have got two tanks of drinking water, one of which is big and the other small, but both of which are being utilized by the savarnas to our exclusion.
('63', 242, 6, 13, 488102) We are debarred from touching the waters of the tanks.
('63', 242, 6, 14, 488157) We are about eighty families.
('63', 242, 6, 15, 488187) Our petition to the Government to remove this ostracism .
('63', 242, 6, 16, 488245) resulted in the putting up of notification that nobody should be obstructed from using the waters of the tank, but did not succeed in removing the ban, for the savarnas would take our attempts to heart and would not employ us in their fields.
('63', 242, 6, 17, 488488) Thus, in this poor condition, we are undergoing a lot of inexpressible difficulties for the past nine months.
('63', 242, 7, 18, 488598) We take this opportunity of presenting to you .
('63', 242, 7, 19, 488646) knowing that you alone will be able to relieve us of it.
('63', 242, 7, 20, 488703) Furthermore, we request you to be kind enough to relieve us from poverty and suffering by giving to each family some donation at least for sustaining three months, in such manner as you think it best.
('63', 242, 7, 21, 488904) This was received at Trichy and I made public reference to it in my speech.
('63', 242, 7, 22, 488980) 2 If the statements made are true, the position reflects no credit on the savarna Hindus of Mela Arasur.
('63', 242, 7, 23, 489085) It is to be hoped that the provincial Harijan sevak sangh will use all its efforts to secure justice for the helpless Harijans who are so dependent upon the caste Hindus.
('63', 242, 7, 24, 489256) It is relevant to know whether the Harijans have facilities for
('63', 242, 8, 25, 489320) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('63', 242, 8, 26, 489357) 2 Vide “Speech at Public Meeting, Trichinopoly”, 10 2 1934.
('63', 243, 0, 1, 489417) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 243, 1, 2, 489459) getting pure water apart from the tanks in question.
('63', 243, 1, 3, 489512) If they have not, humanity demands that the supply of pure water is guaranteed to them by those who deny the use of public tanks to which the Harijans are entitled in law.
('63', 243, 1, 4, 489684) The boycott of Harijans for their having dared to enforce their right to the use of the tanks is adding insult to injury.
('63', 243, 1, 5, 489806) I hope, however, that the good offices of the local Harijan sevak sangh will result in justice being done to the Harijans and in the restoration of good relations between the two divisions of the same family.
('63', 243, 1, 6, 490015) The last sentence of the appeal demands an answer.
('63', 243, 1, 7, 490066) Even if I had the ability, I would not have the wish to satisfy the signatories in their appeal for a “donation” that would sustain them for at least three months.
('63', 243, 1, 8, 490230) Such donations are a waste of public money.
('63', 243, 1, 9, 490274) They degrade those who receive them and put a premium on laziness.
('63', 243, 1, 10, 490341) The able bodied should ask for work, never charity.
('63', 243, 1, 11, 490393) I know that in these days of scarcity even work is difficult to find in the case of the general body and more so in that of Harijans.
('63', 243, 1, 12, 490527) But I believe that a person who is ready for any honourable labour will not have much difficulty in finding some work.
('63', 243, 1, 13, 490646) I would, therefore, urge all friends of Harijans to discourage appeals for doles and endeavour to find employment for the unemployed who would not refuse to do any honourable labour.
('63', 243, 2, 14, 490829) Harijan, 2 3 1934
('63', 243, 3, 15, 490847) 258. TO THE SUBSCRIBERS OF “HARIJAN SEVAK”
('63', 243, 4, 16, 490890) Harijan Sevak has completed its first year.
('63', 243, 4, 17, 490934) Subscribers know the policy of this journal.
('63', 243, 4, 18, 490979) Political questions are not even touched upon.
('63', 243, 4, 19, 491026) It exists solely for the service of Harijans, and the attempt is as far as possible to make it self supporting, which it is in a way, since any deficit that occurs is not made up by the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('63', 243, 4, 20, 491233) But looked at from another angle, it is far from self supporting for the number of subscribers so far is far below the mark.
('63', 243, 4, 21, 491358) There are at present roughly 1,600 subscribers.
('63', 243, 4, 22, 491406) To make the journal self suppo rting we need at least another 800. But if even the present number is further reduced, then there would be no justification left for continuing the paper.
('63', 243, 4, 23, 491592) Subscribers are therefore requested to send in their subscriptions as soon as they get this issue.
('63', 243, 4, 24, 491691) Readers who fail to send the subscription will not be sentcopies of Harijan Sevak.
('63', 243, 4, 25, 491774) The annual subscription of the paper is Rs. 3 8 0 and half yearly Rs. 2. Friends who have helped the paper by finding subscribers or in any
('63', 244, 0, 1, 491914) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 245
('63', 244, 1, 2, 491958) other way are requested to continue their help in the current year also.
('63', 244, 1, 3, 492031) Let everyone remember that news items of a general interest are not published in Harijan Sevak and also that it is the sole organ of the Harijan Sevak Sangh brought out in Hindi.
('63', 244, 2, 4, 492210) M. K. GANDHI [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 2 3 1934

('63', 245, 1, 2, 493095) 260. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BELLARY 1
('63', 245, 2, 3, 493136) March 3, 1934
('63', 245, 3, 4, 493150) Gandhiji congratulated the Chairman on his frankness and said that it was for the first time that he had heard of such dissociation.
('63', 245, 3, 5, 493283) He had also learnt that the sanatanists resented his attempt to procure legislation on temple entry.
('63', 245, 3, 6, 493384) He assured them that there was no question of compulsion in the proposed Bill.
('63', 245, 3, 7, 493463) On the other hand, it was designed to remove the legal compulsion that was then existing.
('63', 245, 3, 8, 493553) He, therefore, appealed to the Bellary sanatanists to help where there was no difference of opinion.
('63', 245, 3, 9, 493654) He pleaded for mutual toleration.
('63', 245, 3, 10, 493688) Surely they could have no ground for complaint if they accepted the assurance that no temple would be opened without the express consent of an overwhelming majority of bona fide temple goers.
('63', 245, 3, 11, 493880) The Bill therefore, even if it was passed, would not be sufficient automatically to open a single temple.
('63', 245, 3, 12, 493986) It was designed to authorize the opening of temples to Harijans when a clear majority desired it.
('63', 245, 3, 13, 494084) This was not possible under the existing law.
('63', 245, 3, 14, 494130) Apart from this question, surely they could have no objection to the education of Harijan children, the opening to Harijans of public wells or tanks, or their general economic betterment.
('63', 245, 3, 15, 494318) He could say without hesitation that the moneys that were being collected were not to be used for building temples.
('63', 245, 3, 16, 494434) They were to be used soley for constructive work of the kind mentioned above.
('63', 245, 3, 17, 494512) Whilst, therefore, he made this appeal to the sanatanists, he said, he would like to test the feelings of the vast gathering in front of him.
('63', 245, 3, 18, 494654) He, therefore, asked the volunteers to go amidst the men and women present and collect whatever they might give for the Harijan cause, knowing what it was to be used for.
('63', 245, 4, 19, 494825) Harijan, 23 3 1934

('63', 246, 4, 22, 496586) 262. LETTER TO W. H. BROWN
('63', 246, 5, 23, 496613) DHARWAR, March 4, 1934
('63', 246, 6, 24, 496636) DEAR FRIEND, Sjt.
('63', 246, 6, 25, 496654) A. V. Thakkar has shown me your letter of even date in connection with the flying of the national flag on the bonnet of the car that drove me from Hubli to Dharwar.
('63', 246, 6, 26, 496819) You are right in surmising that the flag could not have been put up with my consent.

('63', 247, 4, 11, 498585) 263. SPEECH AT RAILWAYMEN’S MEETING, HUBLI 1
('63', 247, 5, 12, 498630) March 4, 1934
('63', 247, 6, 13, 498644) Gandhiji claimed to be a fellow labourer, as he had lived in the midst of labour from his youth upwards.
('63', 247, 6, 14, 498749) He asked the workmen not to be disheartened or lose faith in themselves or feel helpless before those whom they called capitalists.
('63', 247, 6, 15, 498881) Labour itself was a form of capital.
('63', 247, 6, 16, 498918) It was not necessary that a man’s capital should be measured in coins.
('63', 247, 6, 17, 498989) In ancient times it was described in terms of the cattle possessed by him.
('63', 247, 6, 18, 499064) Capital owned by a working man was his labour.
('63', 247, 6, 19, 499111) The difference, therefore, was not in kind or quality, but it was purely in quantity.
('63', 247, 6, 20, 499197) Capitalists might possess thousands of rupees, whereas a labourer or a working man possessed labour which might represent only 8 annas per day.
('63', 247, 6, 21, 499341) But the combined labour of 50,000 working men would represent capital earned in one day of Rs. 25,000. Instances could be given to show that under certain circumstances the golden coins of the capitalists had proved valueless when they could not command labour, whereas the labour of one single labourer had proved invaluable.
('63', 247, 6, 22, 499668) If, therefore, the labourers acted as one man they could be as good capitalists as their employers.
('63', 247, 6, 23, 499768) Employers and employed were, therefore, interdependent.
('63', 247, 6, 24, 499824) And no cause for complaint need ever arise if each party recognized its limitations.
('63', 247, 6, 25, 499909) What he had said, Gandhiji proceeded, applied to Harijans
('63', 247, 7, 26, 499967) 1 Extracted from Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('63', 248, 0, 1, 500014) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 249
('63', 248, 1, 2, 500058) with double force.
('63', 248, 1, 3, 500077) When they had become conscious of their own strength, no power on earth would be able to check their economic progress.

('63', 252, 7, 9, 507014) 271. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('63', 252, 8, 10, 507042) BELGAUM, March 5, 1934
('63', 252, 9, 11, 507065) There was a meeting of Harijan workers at Belgaum, when Gandhiji had his
('63', 252, 10, 12, 507138) silence and Harijan editing days there.
('63', 252, 10, 13, 507178) One of the workers had brought typed
('63', 252, 11, 14, 507215) questions from which the most useful may be culled.
('63', 252, 12, 15, 507267) Q. Is your Harijan work based purely on religious or political grounds?
('63', 252, 13, 16, 507339) A. Purely on religious grounds.
('63', 252, 14, 17, 507371) Q. When you know that there are pandits and sanatanists who derive
('63', 252, 15, 18, 507438) untouchability from Shastras, why do you take the opinion from those who hold the
('63', 252, 16, 19, 507520) contrary view?
('63', 252, 17, 20, 507535) A. I have taken my opinion from nobody.
('63', 252, 17, 21, 507575) My opinion on untouchability was formed many years before I had discussed the question with a single pandit.
('63', 252, 17, 22, 507684) But when I began to preach against untouchability, and more especially when, owing to my first fast, the question attracted world wide attention, I had to study the position of those who defended untouchability as having its origin in the Shastras.
('63', 252, 17, 23, 507933) And in doing so, if I found pandits who defended untouchability, I
('63', 252, 18, 24, 508000) 1 Extracted from Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('63', 252, 18, 25, 508048) The questions were put to Gandhiji at a meeting of Harijan workers.
('63', 252, 18, 26, 508116) Since it was a silence day the questions had been typed out.
('63', 253, 0, 1, 508177) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 253, 1, 2, 508219) also found men who held strongly that the Shastras did not warrant any untouchability as it was practised today, and I found also that they were just as learned as the others.
('63', 253, 1, 3, 508395) Surely, I was entitled to use in support of my opinion the authority of these pandits.
('63', 253, 1, 4, 508482) But supposing these pandits came to hold a different view, I believe that my convic tion is strong enough to stand without the support of any pandit.
('63', 253, 2, 5, 508632) Q. You have said times without number that you have committed Himalayan
('63', 253, 3, 6, 508704) blunders.
('63', 253, 3, 7, 508714) Are you quite sure that you are not committing another such blunder again?
('63', 253, 4, 8, 508789) A. I am not sure at all, for I do not profess to be omniscient.
('63', 253, 4, 9, 508853) But if I discover that I have made a mistake, I should have no hesitation in retracing my step.
('63', 253, 4, 10, 508949) And I know that God will forgive all errors committed unconsciously, as He has done in the past.
('63', 253, 5, 11, 509046) Q. Some say that there should be no separate schools for Harijans at all,
('63', 253, 6, 12, 509120) whereas others say that separate schools are absolutely necessary.
('63', 253, 7, 13, 509187) A. My opinion is that, whilst every facility should be provided for the admission of Harijans to public schools, for some time to come preparatory schools will be absolutely necessary for preparing Harijan children for the primary schools.
('63', 253, 7, 14, 509427) It is futile to expect Harijan children all at once to flood public primary schools.
('63', 253, 7, 15, 509512) There is also a possibility of opposition to wholesale admission.
('63', 253, 7, 16, 509578) Hence preparatory schools are necessary if we honestly want to foster the education of Harijan chil dren.
('63', 253, 8, 17, 509684) Harijan, 23 3 1934
('63', 254, 0, 1, 509703) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 255
('63', 254, 1, 2, 509747) 272. LETTER TO SIR SAMUEL HOARE
('63', 254, 2, 3, 509779) AS AT WARDHA, (C.P.), INDIA, March 6, 1934
('63', 254, 3, 4, 509822) DEAR SIR SAMUEL, You will recollect that whilst I was returning to India in Decem ber of 1931 you had a cable caused to be sent to me in regard to an interview alleged to have been given by me to a journalist in Rome and that I had sent a categorical denial.
('63', 254, 3, 5, 510081) 1 To this there was a coun ter denial which I had not seen till recently, being in jail within less than one week of my landing in Bombay.
('63', 254, 3, 6, 510220) After my discharge from the last imprisonment in August last, I was told by Mirabai Slade that an English friend—Prof.
('63', 254, 3, 7, 510339) Maclean of Wilson College, Bombay—had thought that although the matter was stale, it was worth while my clearing it up, as the denial by the Rome journalist had created a profound impression at the time of its publi cation and had probably precipitated the Viceregal action against me in 1932. Agreeing with Prof.
('63', 254, 3, 8, 510653) Maclean, I at once asked Mirabai to write to Miss Agatha Harrison to procure the relevant newspaper cuttings.
('63', 254, 3, 9, 510763) After much search she was able to get them.
('63', 254, 3, 10, 510807) The last and the most important I received from her last month in the midst of my hurricane tour in the cause of the anti untouchability campaign.
('63', 254, 3, 11, 510954) For ready reference, I send you copies of the three cuttings marked ‘A’, ‘B’ and ‘C’ respectively.
('63', 254, 3, 12, 511053) It should be noted that these cuttings were for the first time seen by me on their being received from Miss Harrison.
('63', 254, 3, 13, 511171) I have now read and reread them several times, and I have no hesitation in saying that ‘A’ and ‘C’ are a caricature of what took place.
('63', 254, 3, 14, 511307) ‘A’ professes to be a summary of a long statement said to have been made by me to an Italian journalist.
('63', 254, 3, 15, 511412) In ‘C’ The Times correspondent, on seeing my denial regarding the alleged interview, makes a halting admission that I might be correct in so far as Signor Gayda did not “request any formal interview and no such interview was granted,” but insists that the statements attributed to me were substantially correct.
('63', 254, 3, 16, 511724) But truth will perhaps be better served by my simply stating what I do know than by analysing ‘A’ and ‘C’.
('63', 254, 3, 17, 511831) 1. I never made any statement, much less a long one, to Signor
('63', 254, 4, 18, 511894) 1 Vide “Cable to Croft”, 17 12 1931.
('63', 255, 0, 1, 511931) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 255, 1, 2, 511973) Gayda as suggested in ‘A’.
('63', 255, 1, 3, 512000) 2. I was never invited to meet Signor Gayda at any place.
('63', 255, 1, 4, 512058) But I was invited by an Italian friend to meet some Italian citizens at an informal drawing room meeting at a private house.
('63', 255, 1, 5, 512183) At this meeting I was introduced to several friends whose names I cannot now recall and could not have recalled even the day after the meeting.
('63', 255, 1, 6, 512327) The introduc tions were merely formal.
('63', 255, 1, 7, 512366) 3. At this meeting the conversation was general, and not addressed to any particular individual.
('63', 255, 1, 8, 512463) Questions were put by several friends and there was a random conversation as at all drawing room meetings.
('63', 255, 1, 9, 512570) 4. It was therefore wrong for Signor Gayda or The Times correspondent to reproduce my remarks as if they were one conn ected statement to one particular person.
('63', 255, 1, 10, 512731) 5. Signor Gayda never showed to me for verification anything he might have taken down.
('63', 255, 1, 11, 512818) 6. The conversation, among other things, referred to the Round Table Conference, my impression of it and my possible future action.
('63', 255, 1, 12, 512950) Many of the things that have been put into my mouth in ‘A’ I had never said.
('63', 255, 1, 13, 513027) All my hopes, fears and future intentions were expressed in as precise a language as it was possible for me to command and use in my speech at the close of the Round Table Conference.
('63', 255, 1, 14, 513211) Whatever I said in private conversation was but a paraphrase of the sentiments expressed in that speech.
('63', 255, 1, 15, 513316) I am not given to saying one thing in public and another in private, or to saying one thing to one friend and some thing else to another.
('63', 255, 1, 16, 513454) I could not have said that there was a definite rupture between the Indian nation and the British Government, for I had said to several friends about the same time that I was determined to strain every nerve to prevent a rupture and to continue the peaceful relations established by the Irwin Gandhi Pact.
('63', 255, 1, 17, 513760) Being an optimist, I do not believe in a final rupture between human beings.
('63', 255, 1, 18, 513837) 7. I never said that I was returning to India in order to restart the struggle against England.
('63', 255, 1, 19, 513933) Certain possibilities about which I was questioned at the informal meeting have been so described in ‘A’ as if I was actually going to India to bring them about if I could.
('63', 255, 1, 20, 514106) I would add that the public had neither the original notes sup posed to have been made by Signor Gayda nor the latter’s own ver sion wherever published.
('63', 255, 1, 21, 514259) In ‘A’ and ‘C’ they had only the impres sions of The Times correspondent about what Signor Gayda wrote or said.
('63', 255, 1, 22, 514371) I do not know how you were affected by ‘C’.
('63', 255, 1, 23, 514415) If your faith in my denial was shaken, perhaps in any case I should have been
('63', 256, 0, 1, 514493) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 257
('63', 256, 1, 2, 514537) acquainted with the rejoinder to my denial as you had kindly brought to my notice the first report.
('63', 256, 1, 3, 514637) I do not know how you will take this letter.

('63', 257, 5, 32, 518248) 275. SPEECH AT MERCANTILE ASSOCIATION, NIPANI 3
('63', 257, 6, 33, 518296) March 7, 1934 I speak as a merchant to fellow merchants.
('63', 257, 6, 34, 518353) The difference is that you are doing business for your respective families, perhaps not ex 
('63', 257, 7, 35, 518445) 1 Vide “Letter to Sir Samuel Hoare”, 6 3 1934. 2 Sarojini Naidu 3 Extracted from Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('63', 258, 0, 1, 518556) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 259
('63', 258, 1, 2, 518600) ceeding more than 100 members in each case at the outside, whereas I do business on behalf of a family consisting of several crores of people, called Harijans.
('63', 258, 1, 3, 518760) I have found that mercantile credit does not depend upon the cash that merchants can produce, but upon the prestige they have for redemption of their promises.
('63', 258, 1, 4, 518920) A bank having hoards of gold in its coffers would lose credit in a moment if it dishonoured a cheque drawn upon it, that is to say, if it did not redeem the promise underlying the cheque that it would be honoured on presentation, if there was a credit balance in favour of the drawer.
('63', 258, 1, 5, 519205) I, therefore, hope that you will not fail to redeem the promise which you are reported to have made in respect of crores of Harijans.
('63', 258, 2, 6, 519339) Harijan, 23 3 1934

('63', 259, 4, 12, 521238) 277. LETTER TO TARABEHN R. MODI
('63', 259, 5, 13, 521270) March 8, 1934
('63', 259, 6, 14, 521284) TARA, It is 3.30 a.m.
('63', 259, 6, 15, 521306) just now.
('63', 259, 6, 16, 521316) This is a small village.
('63', 259, 6, 17, 521341) We reached the place at 9 last night after travelling the whole day.
('63', 259, 6, 18, 521410) I was given your letter immediately on arrival and am writing this reply now.
('63', 259, 6, 19, 521488) Five systems of treatment are current in India at present: (1) allopathy, (2) ayurveda, (3) unani, (4) homoeopathy and (5) nature cure.
('63', 259, 6, 20, 521624) I leave out the use of mantras and magic.
('63', 259, 6, 21, 521666) Of these, allopathy is the most widely in use.
('63', 259, 6, 22, 521713) I am inclined towards nature cure and, if further help is needed, I would have recourse to allopathy, but within limits.
('63', 259, 6, 23, 521834) In certain cases surgery is indispensable and some of the drugs, like quinine, are very effective.
('63', 259, 6, 24, 521933) I would put you under nature cure treatment and, for the trouble you are having with your teeth, etc., I would advise you to take help from allopathy.
('63', 259, 6, 25, 522084) But I am not with you just now and don’t wish to offer guidance from this distance.
('63', 259, 6, 26, 522168) I, therefore, feel inclined to let things go on as at present.
('63', 259, 6, 27, 522231) Allopathic practitioners are comparatively more honest.
('63', 259, 6, 28, 522287) In the West, they are continually experimenting.
('63', 259, 6, 29, 522336) Their treatments, therefore, are often found to succeed.
('63', 259, 6, 30, 522393) But I would say this even from here.
('63', 259, 6, 31, 522430) After com mencing a treatment, one should think no more about it and watch the effect patiently.
('63', 259, 6, 32, 522527) One should not feel impatient for the result.
('63', 259, 6, 33, 522573) Let it be what it will, good or bad.
('63', 259, 6, 34, 522610) After all, how do we know what result is good and what bad?
('63', 259, 6, 35, 522670) “What we regard as misery is not misery, nor what we regard as happiness happiness.
('63', 259, 6, 36, 522754) The only misery is forgetful ness of Narayana’s name and the only happiness is constant memory of Him.” Let the attachment to the body fall away slowly.
('63', 259, 6, 37, 522907) Keep on writing to me.
('63', 259, 6, 38, 522930) I will then write if I have any suggestion to make.
('63', 259, 6, 39, 522982) Don’t think about anything till the body is completely restored

('63', 262, 9, 21, 527745) 282 OUR SHAME
('63', 262, 10, 22, 527759) Reference has already been made in these columns to a memo randum which was received by me at Coonoor on behalf of ‘Adi Hin dus of Tamil Districts’.
('63', 262, 10, 23, 527908) It is signed by thirty six representatives some of whom are members of municipal councils or taluq boards.
('63', 262, 10, 24, 528015) From this, I condense below the catalogue of their disabilities.
('63', 262, 10, 25, 528080) In conden sing it I have not materially changed their language.
('63', 262, 10, 26, 528144) Criticism inters persed with the recital has been removed as being superfluous.
('63', 262, 10, 27, 528224) The list is otherwise untouched.
('63', 262, 11, 28, 528257) 1 This letter was written before Gandhiji reached Hyderabad on March 9.
('63', 263, 0, 1, 528329) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 263, 1, 2, 528371) 1. We have no access to eating houses, laundries, shaving saloons, coffee and tea clubs, restaurants, choultries, schools, agraharams, wells, tanks, water taps, springs, post offices (located in villages) and other places of public resort, not to speak of temples in several places.
('63', 263, 2, 3, 528654) 2. In some places, holding umbrellas, wearing sandals, wearing dhotis below the knees are considered as a great crime.
('63', 263, 2, 4, 528773) Wearing jewels made of gold by our women folk and using clean cloth over their body would be regarded as an ill omen by some caste Hindus.
('63', 263, 3, 5, 528912) 3. We are not allowed to carry our dead within particular union board areas alongside the highway, simply because there is a temple of a deity on the road side.
('63', 263, 3, 6, 529073) We are compelled it carry the dead body through a paddy field even when there is knee deep mire during rainy season.
('63', 263, 4, 7, 529190) 4. The Headman of the so called untouchables within a particular union board area is not allowed by the caste Hindus to get on horseback and pass along the highway during his investiture ceremony as Headman of the said classes.
('63', 263, 5, 8, 529418) 5. In some village bazaars, bleached cloth cannot be touched by us when we are desirous of buying it for festivals.
('63', 263, 6, 9, 529534) 6. If cooked bread or other eatables are touched in bazaars knowingly or unknowingly, the whole cost of the food stuff will be extracted from our people for the sin of touching them.
('63', 263, 7, 10, 529717) 7. Since a very high percentage of our people living in rural areas have no habitation of their own in most of the districts of the presidency, but are allowed by sufferance to live on the lands of the land owning classes, any demand for wages for work contributed by our people in their lands is highly resented by their masters.
('63', 263, 7, 11, 530048) They do not get living wages and the hours of work are unlimited.
('63', 263, 7, 12, 530114) These are often paid in unwholesome grain in short measures.
('63', 263, 8, 13, 530175) 8. For marriage occasions or processions of our deity, we cannot get the services of caste Hindu musicians when we cannot find some among us.
('63', 263, 9, 14, 530317) 9. Young men of our community riding on bicycles are being regarded with severe displeasure.
('63', 263, 9, 15, 530410) In remotest villages, jutkas (horse cabs) cannot ply for us, as the caste Hindu owners refuse to take us.
('63', 263, 9, 16, 530516) The same is the case with motor buses.
('63', 263, 10, 17, 530555) 10. In public latrines, built out of public funds in a particular municipal area, the so called untouchables are actively prevented from using them.
('63', 263, 10, 18, 530704) After a good deal of assertion, they were provided with separate latrines.
('63', 263, 11, 19, 530779) 11. In some of the dispensaries run under the control of particular local bodies, our people do not get proper treatment at the hands of caste Hindus employed there.
('63', 263, 12, 20, 530945) 12. In the temporary water sheds erected by caste Hindus during the hot season, the distinction made by them in pouring water to the Adi Hindus for drinking purpose is highly intolerable and offensive.
('63', 263, 13, 21, 531147) 13. When our people get into local bodies and panchayats the orthodox caste Hindus resign their seats by way of protest, and in some cases our people are given
('63', 264, 0, 1, 531307) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 265
('63', 264, 1, 2, 531351) separate seats.
('63', 264, 2, 3, 531367) 14. When an Adi Hindu rests on the pial in front of his house, he should get up and bow his head before a caste Hindu and worship him with due veneration when the caste Hindu happens to pass that way.
('63', 264, 2, 4, 531568) If this custom is neglected by the Adi Hindus, they will be taken to task severely by the caste Hindus.
('63', 264, 3, 5, 531672) We are often asked to set our own house in order.
('63', 264, 3, 6, 531722) This is simply begging the question.
('63', 264, 3, 7, 531759) Where the Hindu society is one vast system of gradations and degradations based on caste and birth, there is no use in accusing the so called untouchables of being divided among themselves.
('63', 264, 3, 8, 531949) After all, the so called untouchables are themselves victims of circumstances.
('63', 264, 4, 9, 532028) 15. In municipal areas, separate water taps are maintained wherever caste Hindus object.
('63', 264, 5, 10, 532117) 16. To rural elementary schools maintained out of public funds our children have no free access.
('63', 264, 5, 11, 532214) When they are admitted, they are given separate seats, or they are asked to sit on the floor.
('63', 264, 5, 12, 532308) If the pupils approach the caste Hindu orthodox teachers employed there, knowingly or unknowingly, to clear some doubts, they are pushed back by the teachers with the help of slates or sticks for fear of pollution.
('63', 264, 5, 13, 532523) In some cases, our children are made to stand outside the main school premises in all seasons, in order to receive instruction through the window, and hence our children cannot even see the blackboard.
('63', 264, 5, 14, 532725) When the lower elementary course is completed in the separate schools established for our children, we are not admitted in the higher elementary schools run under the public management in the same village.
('63', 264, 5, 15, 532931) Even trained teachers belonging to Adi Hindu community are not appointed in such higher elementary schools.
('63', 264, 5, 16, 533039) Our children cannot use the common latrine.
('63', 264, 5, 17, 533083) It is a great pity that even our representatives serving on different local bodies do not pay surprise visits to such schools, where caste Hindus predominate, for fear of molestation and endless trouble.
('63', 264, 5, 18, 533287) Singanallore and Irugur villages near Coimbatore have become famous in this respect.
('63', 264, 5, 19, 533372) The elementary schools in urban areas are not free from such defects.
('63', 264, 6, 20, 533442) In high schools our students cannot take drinking water from the pots used there during hot season; but they must depend upon some caste Hindu students to pour water for our young men and girls.
('63', 264, 6, 21, 533637) Even vessels are not given to our students, but the students have to use only their hands as vessels for drinking.
('63', 264, 6, 22, 533752) To the common tiffin rooms our students have no free access.
('63', 264, 7, 23, 533813) 17. In post offices located in inaccessible places, we cannot post letters straightaway or transact any other business.
('63', 264, 7, 24, 533933) Even for buying post cards, covers or stamps, we will have to stand at a great distance from such post offices and beg some caste Hindu passers by to comply with our request.
('63', 264, 7, 25, 534108) There are two things involved in this.
('63', 264, 7, 26, 534147) Firstly, we cannot pass through the public pathway.
('63', 264, 7, 27, 534199) Secondly, we are prevented from transacting business straightaway in the post office.
('63', 264, 8, 28, 534285) 18. We feel sorry that your august person has not taken birth in the Adi Hindu community to realize our practical difficulties.
('63', 265, 0, 1, 534413) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 265, 1, 2, 534455) This is a formidable catalogue.
('63', 265, 1, 3, 534487) There is no exaggeration in it, if one or two mental reservations are understood.
('63', 265, 1, 4, 534569) Every statement is true of some place.
('63', 265, 1, 5, 534608) No disability is universal.
('63', 265, 1, 6, 534636) Some are rare.

('63', 266, 3, 9, 537256) 285. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, HYDERABAD 1
('63', 266, 4, 10, 537299) March 9, 1934
('63', 266, 5, 11, 537313) He thanked the public for their addresses and purses.
('63', 266, 5, 12, 537367) He was speaking to them in a language which was partly Urdu and partly Hindi because he considered both the languages to be one and the same.
('63', 266, 5, 13, 537509) The distinctions between higher and lower classes should not be perpetuated, for all were one in the service of the country.
('63', 266, 5, 14, 537634) He had given his thought to the question for the last 50 years and he felt that there should be no distinctions drawn between the Harijans and the other classes.
('63', 266, 5, 15, 537796) In fact, there should also be no distinctions between Hindus and others like Muslims, Christians and Parsis; they should all be united, like the five fingers on one hand.
('63', 266, 5, 16, 537967) Hindus owed a special responsibility for removing the blot of untouchability.
('63', 266, 5, 17, 538045) Friends from America, Japan and other countries were writing to him, saying that there was no untouchability in those countries.
('63', 266, 6, 18, 538174) Replying to orthodox opposition, Gandhiji said that his critics alleged that he was out to destroy Hinduism.
('63', 266, 6, 19, 538283) The charge was not at all true; he was only trying to remove a stigma from it.
('63', 266, 6, 20, 538362) In conclusion, Gandhiji made a fervent appeal to all to help him in the work of ameliorating the condition of Harijans.
('63', 266, 6, 21, 538482) The Hindu, 13 3 1934
