('63', 267, 2, 11, 539865) 287. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 1
('63', 267, 3, 12, 539911) HYDERABAD, March 9, 1934 I have not the faculty of others for looking ahead, much less across three months.
('63', 267, 3, 13, 540019) 1 When the period of my self imposed inactivity for the moment ends on 31st July there will be time enough to consider the position.
('63', 267, 3, 14, 540152) Till then, I have my hands full with anti untou chability work and the Bihar programme.
('63', 267, 4, 15, 540240) Questioned about the duration of his stay in Bihar, he said he was entirely in the hands of Babu Rajendra Prasad in that regard but hoped to take advantage of his present visit to tour Orissa and Assam in connection with anti untouchability work.
('63', 267, 4, 16, 540487) Gandhiji emphatically denied the report that his visit to Hyderabad marked the end of his tours for the uplift of Harijans.
('63', 267, 4, 17, 540611) He said he was only suspending his programme on account of the emergency in Bihar.
('63', 267, 4, 18, 540694) He added while much had been achieved in the past few months a great deal still remained to be accomplished.
('63', 267, 5, 19, 540803) Asked about the results of his recent tour in South India, Gandhiji said it was an unqualified success.
('63', 267, 5, 20, 540907) He found nothing throughout his visits in those parts to support the suggestion that South Indians were less disposed than people in other parts of India to help in the eradication of untouchability.
('63', 267, 5, 21, 541107) On the contrary, he declared, everywhere he observed as much enthusiasm over his campaign as elsewhere while in throwing open the temples and contributing to anti untouchability fund South Indians were second to none.
('63', 267, 5, 22, 541325) Guruvayur was an exception which bore out his experience in South India.
('63', 267, 5, 23, 541398) Even here he was confident that popular opinion would prevail.

('63', 268, 1, 2, 541604) 288. A WAIL FROM UDUMALPET 1
('63', 268, 2, 3, 541633) Udumalpet is a township between Podanur and Dindigul.
('63', 268, 2, 4, 541687) Among the addresses received there was one from its Harijans.
('63', 268, 2, 5, 541749) I ex tract the following from their long and bitter address.
('63', 268, 3, 6, 541810) In this town we are not allowed to draw water from any of the common fresh water wells.
('63', 268, 3, 7, 541898) Our females and children have to depend upon the mercy of caste Hindus for a pot of drinking water.
('63', 268, 3, 8, 541998) We have to be waiting for hours and hours together and put up with all abuses the caste Hindu showers upon us before we can get a pot of water.
('63', 268, 4, 9, 542142) Owing to extreme poverty many of us are homeless and shelterless.
('63', 268, 4, 10, 542208) We are exposed to the sun and rain and are suffering from innumerable difficulties.
('63', 268, 4, 11, 542292) In our cheries the huts are so closely situated that very often we meet with fire accidents which cause loss of life and property.
('63', 268, 4, 12, 542423) The town municipality is not attending to the sanitation of our cheries.
('63', 268, 4, 13, 542496) They never clean our cheries.
('63', 268, 5, 14, 542526) There is no proper drainage, no regular cleaning of night soil, no facilities for the hygienic living of our men.
('63', 268, 5, 15, 542640) No street light is found in our cheries and there is no regular street for us to walk on.
('63', 268, 5, 16, 542730) The town municipality confers so much benefit on all other portions of the town, but won’t attend to our cheries.
('63', 268, 5, 17, 542844) If the complaints are true, they require immediate attention from the Municipal Council, the public and the Local and Provincial Harijan Sevak Sanghs.
('63', 268, 5, 18, 542995) I shall be glad to publish a refutation, if there is any exaggeration in the complaints.
('63', 268, 5, 19, 543084) Meanwhile I defer further criticism.
('63', 268, 6, 20, 543121) Harijan, 16 3 1934

('63', 274, 3, 48, 555021) And now the discourse: As I wrote in my last letter, I will narrate the story told by Vishnu Digambar Shastri.
('63', 274, 3, 49, 555132) It has been devised to explain the meaning of bhakti.
('63', 274, 3, 50, 555186) When Rama returned with Sita to Ayodhya in the flying chariot Pushpak, he was accompanied by Hanuman and others.
('63', 274, 3, 51, 555299) It was time now to bid them farewell, and so a durbar was held.
('63', 274, 3, 52, 555363) Rama embraced all and Sita blessed them by putting her hands on their heads.
('63', 274, 3, 53, 555440) The eyes of all were moist with tears.
('63', 274, 3, 54, 555479) Rewards were distributed to all.
('63', 274, 3, 55, 555512) It was Hanuman’s turn to receive his.
('63', 274, 3, 56, 555550) Sita took off the necklace of precious jewels which she was wearing, put it round Hanuman’s neck and embraced him.
('63', 274, 3, 57, 555665) But what could Hanuman have to do with a necklace of jewels?
('63', 274, 3, 58, 555726) He snapped it into two and started opening up
('63', 275, 0, 1, 555772) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 275, 1, 2, 555814) each bead with his teeth and, not seeing Ramanama inside, would throw it away.
('63', 275, 1, 3, 555893) Everybody was stunned.
('63', 275, 1, 4, 555916) The necklace which Sita had given from off her neck to be thus treated!
('63', 275, 1, 5, 555988) Sita asked Hanuman why he was acting in that manner.
('63', 275, 1, 6, 556041) Hanuman replied: “Mother, what shall I do wearing a necklace consisting of jewels which do not contain Ramanama?
('63', 275, 1, 7, 556154) I want to have nothing but that.” The reply increased their amazement.
('63', 275, 1, 8, 556225) Somebody said: “If that is so, Ramanama cannot be seen in your body either; what about it?” Hanuman burst out laughing and said: “All right.
('63', 275, 1, 9, 556366) Look.” He then tore open his chest and there flowed out a stream of blood in every drop of which they saw Ramanama.
('63', 275, 1, 10, 556482) They all shouted: “Enough, enough.
('63', 275, 1, 11, 556517) We have seen it.
('63', 275, 1, 12, 556534) Please forgive us.” Hanuman closed the cut and the court was filled with shouts of victory to him.
('63', 275, 1, 13, 556633) Sita embraced him and bathed him in tears of joy.
('63', 275, 1, 14, 556683) This is an invented story.
('63', 275, 1, 15, 556710) It is not found even in the Ramayana.
('63', 275, 1, 16, 556748) There was no need for Hanuman to tear open his chest in order to show his bhakti.
('63', 275, 1, 17, 556830) But we have to learn something from this story.
('63', 275, 1, 18, 556878) Hanuman did not care for a reward.
('63', 275, 1, 19, 556913) To him his service was its own reward.
('63', 275, 1, 20, 556952) His bhakti was not for show.
('63', 275, 1, 21, 556981) Nor did it require expression in words.
('63', 275, 1, 22, 557021) Service itself constituted bhakti for him.
('63', 275, 1, 23, 557064) Rama filled his whole being and accompanied every breath of his.
('63', 275, 1, 24, 557129) He thought of nothing but Rama whether working or resting, eating or drinking, waking or asleep.
('63', 275, 1, 25, 557226) He had put himself, mind, speech and body, in the hands of Rama.
('63', 275, 1, 26, 557291) His heroism was dependent on his bhakti.
('63', 275, 1, 27, 557332) It sprang from it.
('63', 275, 1, 28, 557351) If we try, we can attain to bhakti like Hanuman’s.
('63', 275, 1, 29, 557402) If Ramanama is on our lips all the hours of the day, some day it will sink into our heart; and once it has sunk into the heart it is bound to fill the whole being.

('63', 284, 3, 11, 572088) 315. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MOTIHARI [March 15, 1934] 1
('63', 284, 4, 12, 572147) This is no time for talking.
('63', 284, 4, 13, 572176) I have come to see and help you, and not to talk.
('63', 284, 4, 14, 572226) But there are just two things I want to say to you.
('63', 284, 4, 15, 572278) The first is this.
('63', 284, 4, 16, 572297) The relief committees have the money, and either beggars or workers will take it.
('63', 284, 4, 17, 572379) And I want no beggars.
('63', 284, 4, 18, 572402) It would be deplorable if this earthquake turned us into mendicants.
('63', 284, 4, 19, 572471) Only those without eyes, or hands, or feet, or otherwise unfit for work, may ask for alms.
('63', 284, 4, 20, 572562) For the able bodied to beg is, in the language of the Gita, to become thieves.
('63', 284, 4, 21, 572641) The second thing is this, that God had Himself sent us this gift.
('63', 284, 4, 22, 572707) We must accept it as a gift from Him, and then we shall understand its meaning.
('63', 284, 4, 23, 572787) What is the meaning?
('63', 284, 4, 24, 572808) It is this, that untouchability must go, that is to say, nobody must consider himself higher than another.
('63', 284, 4, 25, 572915) If we can understand these two things, this earthquake will be turned into a blessing.
('63', 284, 4, 26, 573002) At present we count it as a sorrow, and no wonder when we see these fair fields and lands devastated.
('63', 284, 4, 27, 573104) But I pray to God that He may give us strength to make a blessing out of this destruction.

('63', 285, 0, 1, 573276) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 285, 1, 2, 573318) 316. INTERVIEW TO MIDDLE CLASS DEPUTATION, MOTIHARI
('63', 285, 2, 3, 573370) March 15, 1934
('63', 285, 3, 4, 573385) Mahatmaji told the deputationists that it was no use calling the help solicited by the name of loans.
('63', 285, 3, 5, 573487) 1 His experience of Gujarat famine was that such loans were never returned.
('63', 285, 3, 6, 573563) To call any help given by the relief organizations by the name of loans served only one purpose.
('63', 285, 3, 7, 573660) It saved the face of the middle class people and it also gave the relief committees the consolation that the money given would be returned, but as a matter of fact this money was never returned.
('63', 285, 3, 8, 573855) Mahatmaji saw no difficulty in giving gifts to the middle class people on a higher scale according to their needs, though, at the same time, he said while considering the cases of the middle class people the cases of those who were dying of starvation could never be ignored.
('63', 285, 3, 9, 574131) He enquired from the representatives what would be the minimum and maximum requirement of a middle class man, upon which one of the deputationists said that it was no use fixing a figure when no help was to be given.
('63', 285, 3, 10, 574348) Mahatmaji thereupon told him that that was not the correct attitude to adopt.
('63', 285, 3, 11, 574426) The committee of the middle classes should be prepared with their case to be placed before any organization— private or Government—and it would be for the relief organization to decide what help and in what form they could give to the middle class people whose sufferings were certainly great and needed redress.
('63', 285, 3, 12, 574739) The Searchlight, 18 3 1934
('63', 285, 4, 13, 574766) 317. INTERVIEW TO RELIEF WORKERS OF CHAMPARAN
('63', 285, 5, 14, 574812) MOTIHARI, March 15, 1934
('63', 285, 6, 15, 574837) Mahatma Gandhi tendered some valuable advice to the relief workers of Champaran District who met him on the eve of his departure from Motihari.
('63', 285, 6, 16, 574981) Regarding the problem of reclamation of land Gandhiji said that it was a difficult problem for the Central Relief Committee.
('63', 285, 6, 17, 575106) He thought that the Central Com mittee should take up only such programme of work as they could do full justice to.
('63', 285, 6, 18, 575222) It was true, further stated Gandhiji, that the people looked up to them for redress of all difficulties due to land problem, but he thought that beyond representing their case to the authorities concerned the Relief Committee should not take upon themselves any responsibility.
('63', 285, 6, 19, 575500) Neither the Government nor the zamindars, further said he, could be unmindful to this question for they were vitally interested in the reclamation of lands or else it would affect their revenue and rent.
('63', 285, 6, 20, 575704) Asked how he liked the idea of loans being advanced by the Bihar Central Relief Committee to the affected cultivators for reclamation of their lands, Gandhiji
('63', 285, 7, 21, 575863) 1 The deputationists had told Gandhiji that they badly needed loans and not gifts for rebuilding their fallen houses and restarting their businesses.
('63', 286, 0, 1, 576013) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 287
('63', 286, 1, 2, 576057) said that the question of granting loans to the cultivators was the question of granting loans to the middle class people also in the towns and loans in neither case could be realized by a private agency like the Central Relief Committee.
('63', 286, 1, 3, 576296) Any monetary help in this direction, said he, could only be in the nature of free gifts.
('63', 286, 1, 4, 576385) But he was doubtful if the Central Relief Committee had ample means at their disposal to meet the requirements of a large number of people who stood in need of such help.
('63', 286, 1, 5, 576556) Concluding, Gandhiji said that they should not court popularity, but conserve all energies in order to utilize them when other agencies had failed and need of rendering help became very acute.
('63', 286, 1, 6, 576749) The Bombay Chronicle, 19 3 1934
('63', 286, 2, 7, 576781) 318. TEMPLE ENTRY V. ECONOMIC UPLIFT
('63', 286, 3, 8, 576818) One sees sometimes in the public Press criticism on the temple entry question.
('63', 286, 3, 9, 576897) It is double barrelled, being directed on the one hand by Harijans and on the other by sanatanists.
('63', 286, 3, 10, 576997) Some of the Harijans say, “We do not want temple entry; do not build temples, but use all you receive for economic uplift.” Some sanatanists say, “Give up the temple entry question altogether.
('63', 286, 3, 11, 577190) You are hurting our feelings by forcing Harijans into temples.” Both are wrong in substance.
('63', 286, 3, 12, 577283) Not one single pice out of the purse has been or will be spent for building temples.
('63', 286, 3, 13, 577368) Attempt is being made only to have public temples opened to Harijans on the same terms on which they are open to the other Hindus.
('63', 286, 3, 14, 577499) It is a matter of choice for the Harijans to visit or not to visit them; savarna Hindus have to lift the bar against Harijans.
('63', 286, 3, 15, 577626) For those millions who regard temples as treasure chests of spiritual wealth, they are living realities which they hold dear as life itself.
('63', 286, 3, 16, 577767) If they are truly repentant towards Harijans, they must share these treasures with the latter.
('63', 286, 3, 17, 577862) I know what the opening of temples means to Harijans.
('63', 286, 3, 18, 577916) Only last week, between Dharwar and Belgaum, I opened three temples to Harijans in the presence of crowds of savarna Hindus and Harijans.
('63', 286, 3, 19, 578054) If critics had been present at the opening and noticed the pleasure on the countenances of the Harijans present as they bowed before the image and received the prasad, their criticism would have been silenced.
('63', 286, 3, 20, 578264) Harijan critics would have realized that, apart from themselves, Harijans at large did desire temple entry.
('63', 286, 3, 21, 578372) Sanatanist critics would have realized that temples, wherever they were opened, were being opened with the fullest concurrence of the temple goers concerned and in the presence of crowds of them.
('63', 286, 3, 22, 578568) No hole and corner opening can do any good whatsoever to Hinduism.
('63', 286, 3, 23, 578635) To be of spiritual or any value at all, the opening has to be performed with due publicity, solemnity and the willing consent of the existing temple goers, and not of such
('63', 287, 0, 1, 578807) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 287, 1, 2, 578849) self styled reformers as have no faith or interest in temples and for whom temples may even be a superstition.
('63', 287, 1, 3, 578960) Temple entry agitation requires no financial outlay, it does not lend itself to agitation except by a few workers who have faith in temples and whose word would command attention from the mass savarna mind.
('63', 287, 1, 4, 579167) It is, therefore, a question that can only be and is being gently and cautiously handled.
('63', 287, 1, 5, 579257) The only insistence is on the right and the duty of the believing reformer advocating temple entry and showing that without it the reformation will not only be incomplete but fruitless.
('63', 287, 1, 6, 579443) For, without temples being freely open to Harijans, untouchability could not be said to have been removed root and branch.
('63', 287, 1, 7, 579566) As for the economic uplift, it is altogether wrong to put it in opposition to temple entry.
('63', 287, 1, 8, 579658) Temple entry can only help such uplift.
('63', 287, 1, 9, 579698) For, when Harijans are freely admitted to temples, all the avenues to economic betterment must be automatically open to Harijans as to others.
('63', 287, 1, 10, 579841) So far as the moneys received are concerned, they will all be used only for economic uplift, if it is admitted that educational uplift also means economic, in that it makes the educated Harijan fitter for running life’s race.
('63', 287, 1, 11, 580067) I am aware that education among the savarnas has often rendered them less fit for the race.
('63', 287, 1, 12, 580159) But that has been so, because their education has meant contempt for labour.
('63', 287, 1, 13, 580236) There is not much danger of such a mishap with the general body of Harijans for some time to come at least.
('63', 287, 1, 14, 580344) And the danger can be averted altogether, if those who are in charge of the movement will take care to purge Harijan education of the evils of the current method, which ignores the technical side for the most part, if not altogether.
('63', 287, 2, 15, 580578) Harijan, 16 3 1934
('63', 287, 3, 16, 580597) 319. HARIJAN FINANCE Correspondents sometimes ask why the public do not know what moneys are being received during the tour and how they are being spent.
('63', 287, 3, 17, 580751) Those who thus ask or write in the columns of the Press evidently do not care to look at the Harijan.
('63', 287, 3, 18, 580853) Accounts have been and are being published from time to time in these columns giving as full details as possible of the receipts.
('63', 287, 3, 19, 580983) The reader will find therein all the purses, individual donations and prices realized for jewellery.
('63', 287, 3, 20, 581084) Three account keepers travel with the party and work day and night under the direct control of Thakkar Bapa, the ever vigilant secretary of the Central Board.
('63', 287, 3, 21, 581243) More often than not, they have to burn midnight oil in order to cope with thousands of copper and silver pieces and to tally cash from day to day.
('63', 287, 3, 22, 581390) These moneys are all sent to the Central Board at Delhi and there safely banked.
('63', 287, 3, 23, 581471) Of course, an accurate system of
('63', 288, 0, 1, 581504) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 289
('63', 288, 1, 2, 581548) account keeping has been devised at Delhi and every pice received or spent is to be found in the account books.
('63', 288, 1, 3, 581660) Accounts are audited and produced before the Board meetings from time to time.
('63', 288, 1, 4, 581739) All the trans actions of the Board are public and duly recorded.
('63', 288, 1, 5, 581804) In other words, the Board follows the accurate methods of banks and regards itself as a public institution responsible to the public regarding its financial and other management.
('63', 288, 1, 6, 581983) The public will be interested to know that up to 2nd March Rs. 3,52,130 9 7 had been received during the tour.
('63', 288, 1, 7, 582094) As to expenses, they will be largely regulated by the provinces which have produced the moneys, subject to sanction by the Central Board.
('63', 288, 1, 8, 582232) The draft rules 1 for the disposal of the funds were published the week before last and criticism has been invited.
('63', 288, 1, 9, 582348) More than this it is humanly impossible, and even unnecessary, to do.
('63', 288, 2, 10, 582418) Harijan, 16 3 1934
('63', 288, 3, 11, 582437) 320. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MUZAFFARPUR 2
('63', 288, 4, 12, 582482) March 16, 1934
('63', 288, 5, 13, 582497) Gandhiji said that was not the time to speak to them at any length.
('63', 288, 5, 14, 582565) It might be possible to do so next time, if he found time and if Rajendrababu thought it desirable to bring him to Muzaffarpur.
('63', 288, 5, 15, 582693) But at the present moment he would like to tell them that it was not at all desirable for any able bodied man or woman to take advantage of the present situation and benefit himself or herself by begging.
('63', 288, 5, 16, 582898) Begging was against one’s self respect and according to the Gita, an able bodied man or woman, capable of earning his or her living, if he or she begged, committed the sin of thieving.
('63', 288, 5, 17, 583083) Gandhiji desired that none of them should be held guilty of having committed that sin.
('63', 288, 5, 18, 583170) Secondly, they must bow to the will of God and see to it that even out of this calamity came some good by their doing away once for all with the curse of untouchability.
('63', 288, 5, 19, 583340) They must realize that the distinction of high and low between one man and another, or between one woman and another—who were all equally the creatures of one God—which this curse of untouchability involved was a great sin and could never be enjoined by the Vedas, for nothing that was not based on truth could be a vedavakya.
('63', 288, 5, 20, 583667) He, therefore, wanted all of them to realize the true significance of the great calamity that providence had chosen to inflict on them and profit by it.
('63', 288, 5, 21, 583820) The Searchlight, 18 3 1934
('63', 288, 6, 22, 583847) 1 Vide “Opinion Invited”, 2 3 1934. 2 The meeting was held in the Darbhanga Raj compound and was largely atten ded.
('63', 289, 0, 1, 583963) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 289, 1, 2, 584005) 321. INTERVIEW TO “THE SEARCHLIGHT”
('63', 289, 2, 3, 584041) PATNA, [March 16, 1934] 1
('63', 289, 3, 4, 584067) My impressions are that what used to be for me a fair land I witnessed as a land of desolation.
('63', 289, 3, 5, 584163) Motihari, Haripore, Lalganj and Muzaffarpore are places which I had visited before.
('63', 289, 3, 6, 584247) Other places, which I visited this time I have no recollection of having visited before.
('63', 289, 3, 7, 584336) In Motihari I lived for several months, that being my head quarters during my stay in Champaran in 1917. To see in these places house after house, some of which I knew so well, in a dilapidated con dition or a heap of ruins was a heart rending sight to me.
('63', 289, 3, 8, 584593) Field after field covered with sand showed how difficult life must have become for the peasantry of several thousand acres of land.
('63', 289, 3, 9, 584725) The problem of restoring conditions to anything like pre earthquake days is calculated to baffle the combined efforts of the best workers in the land.
('63', 289, 3, 10, 584876) In the midst, however, of this desert, it was a matter of joy to me to meet representatives of different relief societies, including those represent ing the Government Relief Department, and to find that they were working more or less in consultation with one another, all having one end in view, namely, relief to the distressed people to the best of their ability.
('63', 289, 4, 11, 585243) The Searchlight, 18 3 1934
('63', 289, 5, 12, 585270) 322. SPEECH AT BIHAR CENTRAL RELIEF COMMITTEE, PATNA 2
('63', 289, 6, 13, 585325) March 18, 1934 I must tell you that this resolution 3 has been drafted by me.
('63', 289, 6, 14, 585403) The author of non co operation as I am, I have recommended cooperation in the task before us without the slightest hesitation.
('63', 289, 6, 15, 585530) On the very first occasion when I spoke on the earthquake disaster in Tinnevelly, 4 I said that such a catastrophe imperatively demanded the co operation of India as a whole and that we must offer our co opera tion to Government.
('63', 289, 6, 16, 585760) The whole country has evinced its sympathy with
('63', 289, 7, 17, 585808) 1 The date is taken from The Hindu report.

('63', 290, 1, 2, 586230) Bihar in its unforeseen affliction, and it would be highly improper to make any distinction between the various agencies that are out to assist Bihar to stand on its legs again.
('63', 290, 1, 3, 586408) When a death occurs, we forget all dissensions for the moment, apply ourselves to the reverential performance of the last rites and follow the bier as a mark of respect.
('63', 290, 1, 4, 586578) But thousands have died in Bihar and many cities and villages have been razed to the ground.
('63', 290, 1, 5, 586671) The earthquake has taken a toll of about 25,000 lives according to our records, while the Government figure is about 10,000. Whatever may be the correct figure, the need of the hour undoubtedly is that we should try our utmost to succour the distressed people of Bihar, and while doing so put all distinctions out of the account.
('63', 290, 1, 6, 587001) The disaster is so tremendous that the wounds it has inflicted cannot be healed by the mere collection and distribution of funds; it is only the consciousness of the world’s sympathy that can carry comfort to the lacerated hearts of the sufferers.
('63', 290, 1, 7, 587249) Let us, in the face of this calamity, forget the distinction between Hindus and Mussalmans as well as between Indians and Englishmen.
('63', 290, 1, 8, 587383) And the same principle should impel us to cooperation between the Government and the people and, therefore, it is our duty to offer our respectful co operation to Government in the prosecution of the common object.
('63', 290, 1, 9, 587598) The Government has a number of experts and has control over lands and other facilities; while our resources are insigni ficant in these respects.
('63', 290, 1, 10, 587744) In such circumstances it would be impossible to make the best use of the funds at our disposal in the absence of co operation between Government and ourselves and I am certain that Government would equally fail to render full assistance to the sufferers without the whole hearted co operation of the people.
('63', 290, 1, 11, 588052) Let us not be afraid of the bogey that we would be strengthening the hands of the Government by our co operation.
('63', 290, 1, 12, 588166) If the Government has an accession of strength through the common attempt to succour the distressed, it is entitled to it.
('63', 290, 1, 13, 588289) We are offering to co operate with a view to the protection and relief of the people, and not to their injury.
('63', 290, 1, 14, 588400) I have been to Motihari, where I met and learnt a good deal from the representatives of a number of relief organizations as well as two Government officers.
('63', 290, 1, 15, 588557) The latter showed me the plans of new houses in contemplation and explained to me how Government was going to help, with the result that I had a clearer idea of the scope of our activities.
('63', 290, 1, 16, 588747) I also met some members of the middle classes whose problem is so much more difficult of solution and who could not receive the assistance they require without co operation between the
('63', 291, 0, 1, 588932) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 291, 1, 2, 588974) Government and the people.
('63', 291, 2, 3, 589001) If the Congressmen fear that the prestige of the Congress will suffer through such co operation, I submit that the fear is purely imaginary.
('63', 291, 2, 4, 589142) The thing is that we are going to work not as Congressmen but as humanitarians.
('63', 291, 2, 5, 589222) The question, therefore, of Congress prestige being enhanced or diminished does not arise.
('63', 291, 2, 6, 589313) The prestige of the Con gress must depend upon the Congressmen’s purity and capacity for service.
('63', 291, 2, 7, 589411) We do not cease to be Congressmen because we co operate with the Government in a humane task.
('63', 291, 2, 8, 589505) Has Rajendrababu ceased to be a Congressman?
('63', 291, 2, 9, 589550) Or have I ceased to be one because I am sponsoring this resolution?
('63', 291, 2, 10, 589618) It would be sinful on our part to import any other extraneous considerations into the all important question of alleviating human suffering.
('63', 291, 2, 11, 589759) When in Champaran I did not need to name and did not name the Congress even once.
('63', 291, 2, 12, 589841) The country has contributed over 20 lakhs of rupees today at Rajendrababu’s call.
('63', 291, 2, 13, 589923) The people know Rajendrababu alone and rely upon his sincerity.
('63', 291, 2, 14, 589987) They remember the great sacrifices he has made for the country.
('63', 291, 2, 15, 590051) It is now our duty to ensure that these funds are utilized in the purest possible way.
('63', 291, 2, 16, 590138) It was with this end in view that Rajendrababu constituted a mixed committee, and wrote to the Government offering his co operation.
('63', 291, 2, 17, 590271) I would therefore adjure Congressmen to decide in the first instance whether or not we should take up this task of reconstructing Bihar.
('63', 291, 2, 18, 590408) If yes, we ought to sincerely co operate with all workers in the field, including the Government.
('63', 291, 2, 19, 590506) And we should do so whole heartedly.
('63', 291, 2, 20, 590543) In prosecuting the common object, we must forget non co operation, or else leave Bihar relief severely alone.
('63', 291, 2, 21, 590653) Therefore, if you adopt this resolution you must adopt it in all sincerity on its merits, not for my sake but certainly for the sake of the millions who are in distress and expect your help.
('63', 291, 2, 22, 590844) The servant must think only of his master, and the millions of afflicted people are our masters today.
('63', 291, 2, 23, 590947) Of course the resolution must not be supposed to imply that we may not criticize the Government where, in our opinion, its policy is wrong or measures inadequate.
('63', 291, 2, 24, 591110) Finally, not as president 2 but as an old fellow worker and servant, I would request you, if possible, not to raise discussion on this resolution.

('63', 292, 6, 10, 591842) 324. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, PATNA 2
('63', 292, 7, 11, 591881) March 20, 1934
('63', 292, 8, 12, 591896) Gandhiji said he had no doubt in his mind that they must regard the calamity as in the nature of a gift from God and as punishment for their sins.
('63', 292, 8, 13, 592043) It would be true to say that these cataclysms visited as a result of their own actions and they would be wise if they took the right lessons to be drawn from the disaster to their heart.
('63', 292, 8, 14, 592230) Which action of theirs had brought on their heads the dire calamity he would not specify but he wished them to remember that the people in this country constituted one large human family so that the evil acts of any section profoundly acted and reacted on the whole.
('63', 292, 8, 15, 592497) The eyes not only of India but of the world were for the moment focussed on Bihar and contribution to the relief funds had poured in from far and near.
('63', 292, 8, 16, 592649) Many people had sent small sums and he had received from a sympathizer a shilling but it was of far greater value as it represented all that the sender had.
('63', 292, 8, 17, 592806) It was not unlikely, he felt, that the collections might reach a crore of rupees.
('63', 292, 9, 18, 592888) This response, however, made their responsibility greater and more onerous.
('63', 292, 9, 19, 592964) The more support they had from the country and outside, the greater became their responsibility and the greater the challenge to their own sense of duty.
('63', 292, 9, 20, 593118) He therefore wished them to consider what their duty was in the crisis they were in.
('63', 292, 9, 21, 593203) Their first duty was to see to it that proper account was kept of every cowrie contributed to their funds and, what is more, they should see to it that every cowrie so contributed reached the
('63', 292, 10, 22, 593395) 1 A word here is illegible.
('63', 292, 10, 23, 593423) 2 Newspaper reports stated that this was the largest meeting ever seen in Patna.
('63', 292, 10, 24, 593504) About thirty to fifty thousand people attended the meeting.
('63', 292, 10, 25, 593564) Other speakers were M. M. Malaviya and Maulana Azad.
('63', 293, 0, 1, 593617) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 293, 1, 2, 593659) hands of the suffering people for whom it was meant.
('63', 293, 1, 3, 593712) It was their duty to work in a spirit of service and to beware lest a single pie was wasted.
('63', 293, 1, 4, 593805) Secondly, proceeded Mahatmaji, those who had escaped damage or had suffered less must do their duty by those who had suffered more.
('63', 293, 1, 5, 593937) Bihar must not depend entirely on outside help.
('63', 293, 1, 6, 593985) Those who had suffered must have all the aid they were entitled to but large parts of the province had either not suffered at all or very partially.
('63', 293, 1, 7, 594134) Those present that evening could not pretend that they had all suffered so badly as not to be able to contribute their mite to the relief of the suffering people.
('63', 293, 1, 8, 594297) It was incumbent on each one of them to consider their duty and their means in that light before God as witness.
('63', 293, 1, 9, 594410) He appealed to them not as a stranger hailing from Bombay.
('63', 293, 1, 10, 594469) He was of Bihar or, more correctly speaking, of Champaran.
('63', 293, 1, 11, 594528) Champaran was the first to recognize him on his return to his country from South Africa.
('63', 293, 1, 12, 594617) He owed the same duty to Bihar as to Gujarat.
('63', 293, 1, 13, 594663) For him there were no geographical demarcations in India.
('63', 293, 1, 14, 594721) In appealing to them to do their duty he addressed them as one of them.
('63', 293, 1, 15, 594793) He was aware that Patna had suffered severely.
('63', 293, 1, 16, 594840) Eighty four men had lost their lives and many times more had been injured.
('63', 293, 1, 17, 594915) Yet they had on the whole escaped lightly as compared to the other devastated parts and it behoved all of them to search their hearts and consider what was obligatory on them to do for their suffering brethren.
('63', 293, 2, 18, 595126) In the third place Gandhiji asked them to consider if untouchability should not go even now.
('63', 293, 2, 19, 595219) God had made no distinctions between the savarna or the avarna, between the Hindu and the Mussalman, in respect of the sweep of the havoc.
('63', 293, 2, 20, 595358) For Hindus there was no crime more hideous than that of untouchability.
('63', 293, 2, 21, 595430) If they did not give up this age old sin, blot out all distinctions between the high and the low, and thereby purify themselves, he for one had no doubt that worse disaster was in store for them in the future.
('63', 293, 2, 22, 595640) The sin of untouchability had corroded their entire social system.
('63', 293, 2, 23, 595707) It was the spirit and the mentality behind this curse of untouchability that was responsible for the countless divisions that divided them and separated them into so many warring groups.
('63', 293, 2, 24, 595894) To root out this sense of high and low and universalize the principle of human brotherhood was their solemn duty in the crisis that confronted them.
('63', 293, 2, 25, 596043) If they did that they would have truly learnt from the earthquake.
('63', 293, 3, 26, 596110) Lastly, Gandhiji warned the suffering people against demoralizing themselves by begging in this hour of their destitution.
('63', 293, 3, 27, 596233) Those who were helpless could not but depend on gratuitous relief.
('63', 293, 3, 28, 596300) In their case it would not be begging just as a true sannyasi did not beg in the real sense of the term, for he gave back in other ways what he took by asking.
('63', 293, 3, 29, 596460) But those who were able to work must earn the relief they sought by working for it.
('63', 293, 3, 30, 596544) Let each suffering individual earn his relief by working for it.
('63', 293, 3, 31, 596609) In proportion to the work they put forth in lieu of what they received, they would vindicate the dignity of human labour and enhance their reputation in the eyes of the country and the world.

('63', 294, 2, 3, 596903) PATNA, March 20/21, 1934
('63', 294, 3, 4, 596928) BA, I have still not received your letter this time.
('63', 294, 3, 5, 596981) I am writing this on Tuesday after morning prayer.
('63', 294, 3, 6, 597032) I am in Patna.
('63', 294, 3, 7, 597047) By my side is Satisbabu, spinning on the takli.

('63', 294, 3, 9, 597127) Prabhavati too.
('63', 294, 3, 10, 597143) Om and Kisan are preparing to go to bed.

('63', 294, 3, 13, 597256) Malaviyaji, Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, Dr. Mahmud, etc., are here just now.
('63', 294, 3, 14, 597330) There was a meeting of all of them on Sunday.
('63', 294, 3, 15, 597376) At that meeting a new committee was appointed for relief work in Bihar.
('63', 294, 3, 16, 597448) Jamnalalji also is a member of it.
('63', 294, 3, 17, 597483) The work is progressing well.
('63', 294, 3, 18, 597513) I visited Motihari and other places.
('63', 294, 3, 19, 597550) Even big mansions have been reduced to heaps of brick and mortar.
('63', 294, 3, 20, 597616) Everywhere in the streets we saw heaps of bricks and ruins of buildings.
('63', 294, 3, 21, 597689) The fields are covered with sand ejected with water from the bowels of the earth.
('63', 294, 3, 22, 597771) Till this sand is removed, no crops can grow, and removing it is no easy work.
('63', 294, 3, 23, 597850) For it is not only one or two bighas that are so covered.
('63', 294, 3, 24, 597908) Thousands of bighas have been covered and in some places the layers are six inches thick or even thicker.
('63', 294, 3, 25, 598014) The people’s misery, therefore, is beyond measure.
('63', 294, 3, 26, 598065) But even then life is so dear that people, dizzy with the thought of having escaped death, can forget their hardships and keep smiling faces.
('63', 294, 3, 27, 598207) They have no food in their homes and no clothes to wear, but they do not seem to worry much about that.
('63', 294, 3, 28, 598311) Such is the scene here.
('63', 294, 3, 29, 598335) What can we do to help them?
('63', 294, 3, 30, 598364) Those who are working in the midst of the people may serve them humbly and unostentatiously.
('63', 294, 3, 31, 598457) They may plead with the idle to start working, and teach sensualists self control by their own example.
('63', 294, 3, 32, 598561) They may teach people Ramadhun and turn them Godward.
('63', 294, 3, 33, 598615) There are such silent workers, too, at many places.
('63', 294, 3, 34, 598667) God’s ways are beyond our understanding.
('63', 294, 3, 35, 598708) He erased the difference between birth and death in a matter of two minutes.
('63', 294, 3, 36, 598785) Who was born and who is dead?
('63', 294, 3, 37, 598815) Whether human beings are born or die, His play goes on.
('63', 294, 3, 38, 598871) Why then rejoice and grieve?
('63', 294, 3, 39, 598900) The Lord’s name is the only truth.
('63', 294, 3, 40, 598935) He who is aware of Him and serves Him, that is, His creation, as well as he may, lives.
('63', 294, 3, 41, 599023) Those who do not do this are as good as dead, though living.
('63', 294, 3, 42, 599084) Well, having started to write a letter I have given you this week’s discourse.
('63', 294, 3, 43, 599163) There may be a few words which you may not understand.
('63', 294, 3, 44, 599218) But Dahibehn or Shanta or Lalita, one of them will surely be able to understand them.

('63', 297, 1, 2, 602682) 329. SPEECH AT THE MEETING OF THE REPRESENTA TIVES OF THE RELIEF SOCIETIES, PATNA
('63', 297, 2, 3, 602764) March 21, 1934
('63', 297, 3, 4, 602779) Gandhiji addressed them at length, emphasizing at the outset the absolute necessity of all societies working in co operation in deciding upon a plan of action, in consultation with the Central Relief Committee.
('63', 297, 3, 5, 602990) He deprecated strongly any dis tinction of class, sect or religion being introduced or maintained in the matter of relief.
('63', 297, 3, 6, 603113) Gandhiji insisted that the construction of huts and semi permanent houses should not be undertaken on any haphazard plan.
('63', 297, 3, 7, 603235) They should be prepared to accept the advice of Government experts and should refrain from building houses on condemned lands.
('63', 297, 3, 8, 603362) It was really a very difficult question and the advice of experts must be scrupulously followed.
('63', 297, 3, 9, 603459) In Motihari and Muzaffarpur, he would advise people not to build on those sites which had been declared unsafe and would ask them to wait until the monsoon was over.
('63', 297, 3, 10, 603625) He appealed to them to alleviate suffering, even where the sufferer was unwilling to ask for help.
('63', 297, 3, 11, 603724) Relief should reach the old, the destitute and the lame at their places and the ant and elephant should not be judged by the same measure of relief.
('63', 297, 3, 12, 603873) Workers should not be guided by any other test but that of pure sufferings.
('63', 297, 4, 13, 603949) The Hindu, 24 3 1934

('63', 298, 3, 4, 604496) BHAI THAKKAR BAPA, I got your letters.
('63', 298, 3, 5, 604535) I sent a wire to you yesterday.
('63', 298, 3, 6, 604567) I started work ing at 2 this morning, and that is why I am able to take up this letter at 3. There was no other way.
('63', 298, 3, 7, 604684) I wanted to write to you yesterday but could not find the time for it.
('63', 298, 3, 8, 604755) I will give you the 5th and 6th.
('63', 298, 3, 9, 604788) I hope Ghanshyamdas will be able to come.

('63', 298, 3, 11, 604885) Rajen drababu has fixed a programme according to which the visit to Purnea would be postponed for the present and I would spend one day there on my way to Assam.
('63', 298, 3, 12, 605047) You can go to Assam a day earlier.
('63', 298, 3, 13, 605082) We may start together from here and I would get down at Purnea, spend Monday there and, leaving the place on Tuesday, reach Gauhati on Wednesday.
('63', 298, 3, 14, 605228) My plan is that after finishing the Assam trip we should return to Bihar, spend a week here, during which we should complete the Harijan tour in Chhota Nagpur, and then go to Orissa.
('63', 298, 3, 15, 605411) From there we should return to Bihar again.
('63', 298, 3, 16, 605455) After spending a few days here, we should draw up another programme.
('63', 298, 3, 17, 605524) This is how my mind is working.
('63', 298, 3, 18, 605556) We should give some time to every province.
('63', 298, 3, 19, 605600) By doing so we shall be able to do something at least, if not much.
('63', 298, 3, 20, 605668) We shall be able to meet the local workers.
('63', 298, 3, 21, 605712) But we can plan all this only when we meet.
('63', 298, 3, 22, 605756) I will start from here on the 27th to go to the North, and return on the 4th.
('63', 298, 3, 23, 605834) You can come here on the 4th if you wish.

('63', 298, 3, 28, 606062) We shall discuss the matter when you come here.
('63', 298, 3, 29, 606110) Please note down all such points in your diary.
('63', 298, 3, 30, 606158) Otherwise we might forget about them.

('63', 305, 2, 8, 622432) From Gujarati: C.W. 9130
('63', 305, 3, 9, 622457) 334. HARIJAN TOUR AND BIHAR It was a matter of sorrow to me to interrupt the Harijan tour.
('63', 305, 3, 10, 622548) It had to be, because it was a clear duty to answer the call from Shri Rajendra Prasad, who had postponed it as long as he could.
('63', 305, 3, 11, 622678) Whilst anti untouchability work is undoubtedly greater and its message of a permanent character, like all chronic diseases it can dispense with personal attention in the face of an acute case, which that of Bihar is.
('63', 305, 3, 12, 622895) He who is called by Rajendrababu, the physician in charge, has to answer the call when made or not at all.
('63', 305, 3, 13, 623002) When, therefore, the call came, I had to suspend the tour.
('63', 305, 3, 14, 623061) But I want to assure anti untouchability workers in the provinces not visited that I hope to resume the tour as soon as circumstances will permit and that Rajendrababu feels about untouchability no less keenly than I do.
('63', 305, 3, 15, 623282) He will disengage me at the earliest possible moment.
('63', 305, 3, 16, 623336) I hope to take Utkal and Assam first, and of these two that will have preference which for climatic reasons demands it.
('63', 305, 3, 17, 623456) Let the workers beware!
('63', 305, 4, 18, 623480) Harijan, 23 3 1 934
('63', 305, 5, 19, 623500) 335. IMPLICATIONS OF ANTI UNTOUCHABILITY
('63', 305, 6, 20, 623541) A Hubli correspondent asks the following questions:
('63', 305, 7, 21, 623593) Is untouchability natural or artificial?
('63', 305, 7, 22, 623634) Does it not depend upon the moral and intellectual development, mode of life, etc., of the people composing the society?
('63', 305, 7, 23, 623755) Can you give a picture of a society where untouchability is completely removed?
('63', 305, 7, 24, 623835) In my opinion, untouchability is a wholly artificial product.
('63', 305, 7, 25, 623897) It has no connection with moral or intellectual development of people, for the simple reason that in Hindu society there are to be seen men described as untouchable who are in every way equal in moral and intellectual development to the highest among caste Hindus and yet who are treated as untouchables.
('63', 305, 7, 26, 624202) My picture of a society free from untouchability is one in which no one will consider himself superior to another.
('63', 305, 7, 27, 624317) It is obvious that in a society so composed there will be no
('63', 306, 0, 1, 624378) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 307
('63', 306, 1, 2, 624422) unseemly rivalry or quarrelling.
('63', 306, 1, 3, 624455) The correspondent next asks:
('63', 306, 2, 4, 624484) Are inter dining and intermarriage necessary for the removal of untouchabi lity?
('63', 306, 2, 5, 624565) My answer is no and yes.
('63', 306, 2, 6, 624590) No, because it is no part of the progra mme of the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('63', 306, 2, 7, 624662) Generally, too, marrying and dining are matters of individual concern.
('63', 306, 2, 8, 624733) No one has a right to ask another to choose a girl for wife or to dine with anybody against his will.
('63', 306, 2, 9, 624835) But my answer is at the same time yes, because if a person refuses to take food touched by another person on the ground of untouchability or infe riority, he is observing untouchability.
('63', 306, 2, 10, 625022) In other words, untouch ability cannot constitute any ground for restraint on inter dining or inter marriage.
('63', 306, 2, 11, 625132) The correspondent next asks:
('63', 306, 3, 12, 625161) Can an imperfect person be a competent authority for introducing changes in the religious observances or customs?
('63', 306, 3, 13, 625275) Imperfection is a relative term.
('63', 306, 3, 14, 625308) All mortals are more or less imperfect.
('63', 306, 3, 15, 625348) But an imperfect person may not be so imperfect regarding a particular change as to be incompetent to make it.
('63', 306, 3, 16, 625459) A person, how ever imperfect otherwise, may have fairly fixed notions about the use of intoxicating drugs and liquors.
('63', 306, 3, 17, 625578) He has then every right to pro pose and bring about changes in the drink habits of people, although they may be based on religious grounds.
('63', 306, 4, 18, 625718) Harijan, 23 3 1934

('63', 308, 4, 12, 627826) 340. LETTER TO BHAGWANJI A. MEHTA March 23, 1934
('63', 308, 5, 13, 627875) BHAISHRI BHAGWANJI, I have always welcomed your letter.
('63', 308, 5, 14, 627931) Your frank words always please me.
('63', 308, 5, 15, 627966) You have mixed up two or three issues.
('63', 308, 5, 16, 628005) My own experience of Prabhashankar has been different from yours.
('63', 308, 5, 17, 628071) But I needn’t dwell on that, since my experience doesn’t count.
('63', 308, 5, 18, 628135) I agree with your views about Wills.
('63', 308, 5, 19, 628172) According to the rule that one can be certain only of that which is in one’s hands, I think it best for parents to make in their own lifetime any arrangements that they wish.
('63', 308, 5, 20, 628347) But in this case I must consider the situation as it exists.
('63', 308, 5, 21, 628408) From a moral point of view, I look upon the document drawn up by Doctor as a Will.
('63', 308, 5, 22, 628491) Everybody who wants to accept a legacy should also observe its conditions.
('63', 308, 5, 23, 628566) One of the two sisters is in such a condition that it would have been the duty of the brothers to support her even if there had been no Will.
('63', 308, 5, 24, 628708) Ratilal himself is not capable of looking after himself.
('63', 308, 5, 25, 628765) Hence, if my voice could have any effect, I would see that his sister, who is more incapable of looking after herself than Ratilal is of looking after himself, got some share.
('63', 308, 5, 26, 628941) Who knows, such a noble act may bring greater benefit to Ratilal.
('63', 308, 5, 27, 629007) In any case it cannot harm his interests.
('63', 308, 5, 28, 629049) Whether or not the sister gets a regular share, my sense of duty to the departed friend and to his family, and especially to Ratilal and Champa with whom I have maintained a special relation, will urge me to insist that the sisters should get a proportionate share each from Ratilal’s share, even if he pays it in instalments.
('63', 308, 5, 29, 629376) You are not right when you generalize from Narbheram’s case.
('63', 308, 5, 30, 629437) I am sure you know the
('63', 309, 0, 1, 629460) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 309, 1, 2, 629502) saying in English “Hard cases make bad law.” I hope you also know that Narbheram does not accept your charge as true.
('63', 309, 1, 3, 629620) The resort to civil marriage in the case of Devdas and Lakshmi was to satisfy Rajaji.
('63', 309, 1, 4, 629706) All of us wanted a religious ceremony.
('63', 309, 1, 5, 629745) But there was no difference between civil marriage and religious ceremony as we understood its significance.
('63', 309, 1, 6, 629854) According to the meaning which we attach to religious ceremony, its purpose was served by civil marriage.
('63', 309, 1, 7, 629960) According to me the Hindu law requires many reforms.
('63', 309, 1, 8, 630013) I think I have now replied to all your questions.
('63', 309, 1, 9, 630063) I am doing what I can about Bihar.
('63', 309, 1, 10, 630098) I think you have sent a handsome amount.
('63', 309, 2, 11, 630139) MOHANDAS From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 5821. Also C.W. 3044. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi
('63', 309, 3, 12, 630235) 341. MESSAGE TO THE PRESS
('63', 309, 4, 13, 630261) PATNA, March 23, 1934
('63', 309, 5, 14, 630283) In the course of a special message to Amrita Bazar Patrika, 1 Gandhiji lays down the following rules for the guidance of the relief workers:
('63', 309, 6, 15, 630424) (1) Overlapping should be scrupulously avoided.
('63', 309, 7, 16, 630472) (2) Not an anna should be spent for advertisement or to produce any spectacular effect.
('63', 309, 8, 17, 630560) (3) There should be no unseemly rivalry between relief organizations, whether Government or popular.
('63', 309, 8, 18, 630661) There should be rivalry in doing silent timely service.
('63', 309, 9, 19, 630717) (4) Every organization should know what others are doing.
('63', 309, 10, 20, 630775) (5) Expenses of management should be minimized as much as possible, consistently with efficiency and accurate account keeping.
('63', 309, 11, 21, 630902) (6) All distinctions of high and low should be altogether abolished.
('63', 309, 12, 22, 630971) (7) Those in receipt of relief should be induced to do some productive work.
('63', 309, 13, 23, 631048) (8) Relief centres should be kept in perfect sanitary condition.
('63', 309, 14, 24, 631113) (9) All volunteers should know how to render first aid and teach the villagers the rules of elementary sanitation.
('63', 309, 15, 25, 631228) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 24 3 1934
('63', 309, 16, 26, 631260) 1 The Hindu says that it was a special message for The Searchlight.

('63', 310, 10, 14, 631943) It is good that you think that way.
('63', 310, 10, 15, 631979) But the article is not worth publishing.
('63', 310, 10, 16, 632020) You should go still deeper.
('63', 310, 10, 17, 632048) Non violence is not such a simple thing as it would appear.
('63', 310, 10, 18, 632108) Instead of writing an article about it, it would be better to note down the thoughts that come to you and the difficulties you face while practising it.
('63', 310, 10, 19, 632261) Your statement that non violence is universally accepted as a religious principle is not quite correct either.
('63', 310, 10, 20, 632372) It has been so accepted only to a certain extent.
('63', 310, 10, 21, 632422) Some people consider it right to kill wild animals.
('63', 310, 10, 22, 632474) Others consider it right to kill evil doers.
('63', 310, 10, 23, 632519) Of course there can be no harm in writing such articles again and again in order to clarify your own thoughts.

('63', 311, 4, 7, 633178) 345. SPEECH AT DANAPORE
('63', 311, 5, 8, 633202) [March 24, 1934] 1
('63', 311, 6, 9, 633221) This is my second visit to Danapore.
('63', 311, 6, 10, 633258) In your address you have remarked that on account of the havoc caused by the recent earth quake the Harijan uplift movement has been thrown into the back ground.
('63', 311, 6, 11, 633420) This is all right.
('63', 311, 6, 12, 633439) Whatever I told you during the course of my speech at Patna, I will again say that almost everybody in this world has suffered and even then the public will soon forget this great disaster caused by it.
('63', 311, 6, 13, 633642) As we have completely forgotten the previous earthquakes in the history of this old world and consider them as historical incidents, we will hold the same view about this earthquake also after due course of time.
('63', 311, 6, 14, 633855) But so long as untouch ability exists, we are reminded of our miseries.
('63', 311, 6, 15, 633927) Some people consider untouchability as their religion and if it disappears it would be some sort of calamity to them.
('63', 311, 6, 16, 634045) But if you look at it dispassionately it cannot be defended.
('63', 311, 6, 17, 634106) Those also who call themselves sanatanists understand that untou chability is indefensible, and I think it is the staunchest class among sanatanists who hold this view.
('63', 311, 6, 18, 634275) After this earthquake we ought to be more humble, as death is inevitable.
('63', 311, 6, 19, 634349) Therefore those who feel sorry for this disaster may become humbler.
('63', 311, 6, 20, 634418) God has warned us in this manner and if we do not pay heed to this warning some greater disaster is in store for us.
('63', 311, 6, 21, 634535) Shastras lay down that complete destruction will overtake the whole creation some time.
('63', 311, 6, 22, 634623) In the light of all these divine lessons we ought to become more humble and do away with this sin of untouchability.
('63', 311, 6, 23, 634740) Those affected by the earthquake are more than a crore but there are others in this province who have escaped this disaster, and who have lost nothing.
('63', 311, 6, 24, 634892) Therefore they should subscribe as generously as people from outside the province have done.
('63', 311, 6, 25, 634985) In fact it is your duty as neighbours to subscribe to the relief funds.
('63', 311, 7, 26, 635057) 1 From Chandulal Dalal’s Gandhijini Dinwari
('63', 312, 0, 1, 635101) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 313
('63', 312, 1, 2, 635145) Yesterday we were discussing the budget of the Relief Committee.
('63', 312, 1, 3, 635210) The whole sum amounted to forty lakhs and yet certain things were left out.
('63', 312, 1, 4, 635286) The total collection up to date is just about 20 lakhs.

('63', 312, 2, 11, 635813) They have not come forward as they ought to do.

('63', 312, 2, 21, 636518) It is our determination to help those who have been struck hard but you may remember that we are not out to make beggars of them.
('63', 312, 2, 22, 636648) Those who will work will get help in return.
('63', 312, 2, 23, 636693) This is all that I have to say.
('63', 312, 2, 24, 636725) The purse which has been given to me I think does not contain subscription from all those who are present here.
('63', 312, 2, 25, 636837) Therefore I would appeal to them to pay their share also.
('63', 312, 2, 26, 636895) I may make it clear that half of the entire money collected on the spot and given to me in the shape of a purse will go to the Harijan movement and half of it for Bihar Relief.

('63', 314, 4, 8, 639512) 349. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI PATNA, March 26, 1934 CHI.
('63', 314, 4, 9, 639581) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I got the letters from you both.
('63', 314, 4, 10, 639635) Give up all hopes about Shanti.
('63', 314, 4, 11, 639667) If Sushila steadily improves her efficiency, she will be able to shoulder more responsibility.
('63', 314, 4, 12, 639762) Satisbabu’s wife does not know English, but she shoulders the whole burden of Khadi Pratishthan and its Prakashan Mandir and has released Satisbabu for Harijan work.
('63', 314, 4, 13, 639928) The truth of the matter is that both of them think only of service.
('63', 314, 4, 14, 639996) I understand what you say regarding West 1. I think his services have been so valuable that, even if he has come to feel aversion now towards us, we should not forget all that he has done in the past.
('63', 314, 4, 15, 640197) However, you may act as you like.

('63', 317, 6, 16, 645283) 354. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, CHAPRA 2
('63', 317, 7, 17, 645323) March 27, 1934 Today a terrible calamity has overwhelmed us all alike Hindus, Mussalmans, Christians and the rest, the so called highborn and the low born, without favour or distinction.
('63', 317, 7, 18, 645510) If even this terrible blow does not enable us to purge ourselves of ‘pride of place and blood’, to obliterate all arbitrary, man made distinctions between man and man, then I would only say that there is none so ill fated as we.
('63', 317, 7, 19, 645739) The conviction is growing upon me day after day that human intellect is incapable of fully understanding God’s ways.
('63', 317, 7, 20, 645856) God in His wisdom has circumscribed man’s vision, and rightly too, for, otherwise man’s conceit would know no bounds.
('63', 317, 7, 21, 645974) But whilst I believe that God’s ways cannot be comprehended fully by man, I have firm faith that not a leaf falls without His will, and not a leaf falls but it subserves His purpose.
('63', 317, 7, 22, 646157) If only we had enough humility, we would have no hesitation in accepting the recent earthquake as a just retribution for our sins.
('63', 317, 7, 23, 646288) This is not to say that we can with certainty attribute a particular calamity to a particular human action.
('63', 317, 7, 24, 646396) Very often we are unconscious of our worst sins.
('63', 317, 7, 25, 646445) All that I mean to say is that every visitation of
('63', 317, 8, 26, 646496) 1 This sentence is in Gujarati.

('63', 318, 3, 5, 647044) 355. SPEECH AT MEETING OF RELIEF WORKERS, CHAPRA 1
('63', 318, 4, 6, 647095) March 27, 1934
('63', 318, 5, 7, 647110) Gandhiji said he had offered his respectful co operation to the authorities on the present occasion.
('63', 318, 5, 8, 647211) He explained that there was no other way of saving the masses from the overwhelming calamity that had befallen them.
('63', 318, 5, 9, 647328) The issue before them was not of co operation versus non co operation or Congress versus Government, but simply of how best to serve the suffering masses in the face of an unparalleled calamity.
('63', 318, 5, 10, 647523) What was really needed was food, clothing, shelter and above all water.
('63', 318, 5, 11, 647595) Mr. Gandhi warned the residents against feeling sore because they found that adequate relief was not forthcoming or justice was not done in individual cases.
('63', 318, 5, 12, 647753) They should cease to think in personal terms and learn to think impersonally in terms of collective good.
('63', 318, 5, 13, 647859) They should not forget that the extent of the calamity was so great that Government or any other agency, however well inclined, could not afford complete relief.
('63', 318, 5, 14, 648021) He would therefore reiterate to them what he had previously said that the healing balm that could cure Nature’s wound like the present one must come not from without but from within themselves.
('63', 318, 5, 15, 648215) That saving sovereign balm was human sympathy and human love, which would enable them to forget their misfortune in a glow of mutual co operation and service.
('63', 318, 6, 16, 648374) The Hindu, 29 3 1934
('63', 318, 7, 17, 648395) 1 Almost identical versions were also published in The Indian Nation, 30 3 1934, and The Bombay Chronicle, 30 3 1934.

('63', 326, 1, 2, 664812) 364. WANTED A MANIFESTATION OF CHRIST IN DAILY LIFE
('63', 326, 2, 3, 664864) I have no hesitation whatsoever in publishing this talk 1 by Miss Lester with missionaries.
('63', 326, 2, 4, 664956) She handed it to me apologetically, asking me whether I would publish it as a supplement to Harijan, so that she could have a few copies for distribution among her friends, and, I suppose, at the same time give a few coppers in an enterprise devoted solely to the Harijan cause.
('63', 326, 2, 5, 665235) When she put this talk among my papers with the introductory remark I have referred to, I had decided that I would either print it in the body of the paper or not at all.
('63', 326, 2, 6, 665406) Let not the non Christian readers be afraid of “a manifestation of Christ” in daily life.
('63', 326, 2, 7, 665496) Whatever it may mean to Miss Lester, the word Christ is a common name, an attribute not to be attached merely to one single historical person.
('63', 326, 2, 8, 665639) Each one, therefore, according to his taste may think of his own beloved teacher and guide, or, better, of the only infallible teacher and guide—Truth—and call it Christ.
('63', 326, 2, 9, 665810) Let him read the conversation in the light of my interpretation and I promise the reader that he will profit by the reading.
('63', 326, 2, 10, 665935) Many persons have written like Miss Lester before now.
('63', 326, 2, 11, 665990) The value of her conversation lies in the fact that she endeavours every moment of her life to practise what she professes and preaches in her writing.
('63', 326, 3, 12, 666142) Language is the means by which human beings misunderstand one another.
('63', 326, 3, 13, 666213) Words are inadequate as vehicles for the conveyance of spiritual truth.
('63', 326, 3, 14, 666285) Neither can men be argued into Christianity.
('63', 326, 3, 15, 666330) What was it that converted the adulteress, who a few minutes before had been doggedly facing her judges, despising them but hardening herself to accept her fate at their hands?
('63', 326, 3, 16, 666507) Her conversion was the result of Jesus’ way of looking at things.
('63', 326, 3, 17, 666573) His way of looking at people, at sinners....
('63', 326, 3, 18, 666618) Is it likely that this infectious thing, this knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ can be communicated academically?
('63', 326, 4, 19, 666756) By all means let us train the mind; let us dig deeper and ever deeper into all branches of knowledge, science and philosophy; let us bend our energies to exploring the whole realm of truth.
('63', 326, 4, 20, 666946) But let us always remember how easily knowledge can be perverted to base uses.
('63', 326, 4, 21, 667025) What mankind needs is to know how to live, what is the perennial source of joy, the peace that the world can’t give and can’t take away.
('63', 326, 4, 22, 667162) Jesus propounded His ideas in maxims such as the Beatitudes.
('63', 326, 4, 23, 667223) Then He would re clothe the same idea in a tale, knowing that thus it would stick in our minds better.
('63', 326, 4, 24, 667326) But even thus, well taught doctrines would not have moulded men’s lives, made and remade institutions and become the way of health and joy for millions, if He had not also embodied it in life, in His own life.

('63', 327, 1, 2, 667615) Following the usual rough and ready method of punishing those who have harmed us, we do not pay overmuch attention to Jesus’ clearly enunciated maxim “Love your enemies.” But we are haunted by the memory of His attitude towards His executioners and His words: “Father, they don’t understand.
('63', 327, 1, 3, 667907) Forgive them.” “He that would be great, let him be the servant of all.” In clear enough words He proclaimed this rather startling doctrine.
('63', 327, 1, 4, 668047) Throughout the centuries, its meaning has been distorted and explained away successfully enough.
('63', 327, 1, 5, 668144) But its power to make us increasingly uncomfortable and at length to thrust us out from the narrowness of our privileged, selfish lives lies in the picture that lovers of Christ have enshrined in their minds, the scene where He took a bowl of water, knelt before each of His men— workmen some of them—and performed for them the servants’ work of washing the feet.
('63', 327, 1, 6, 668508) .The Ashram set up by Verrier Elwin among Gonds has a special significance.
('63', 327, 1, 7, 668584) The inmates live and work with the people, relying on their service alone whereby to commend to them the person and the power of Jesus Christ.
('63', 327, 1, 8, 668727) I know nothing that brings me closer to reality, closer to God, than to be among a crowd of my neighbours in Bow at the end of a party, which perhaps they have organized for themselves instead of going round the corner to the Rose and Crown public house.
('63', 327, 1, 9, 668982) Compromises have so dulled the sensibilities of Christians that young people often find little or nothing to challenge them in the religion presented to them.
('63', 327, 1, 10, 669141) Their tendency is to turn either to money making, sport or the barren habit of criticizing— none of them very creative activities.
