('63', 327, 1, 20, 670330) Harijan, 30 3 1934
('63', 327, 2, 21, 670349) 365. THE TEMPLE ENTRY BILL The Hon.
('63', 327, 2, 22, 670385) Secretary, Harijan Sevak Sangh, Bombay Provincial Board, has addressed the Secretary to the Government of India, Legis 
('63', 328, 0, 1, 670505) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 329
('63', 328, 1, 2, 670549) lative Department, New Delhi, as follows:
('63', 328, 2, 3, 670591) I have the honour to communicate hereunder the views of the Bombay Provincial Board of the Harijan Sevak Sangh on the Temple entry Disabilities Removal Bill, which has been circulated for public opinion under the orders of the Legislative Assembly.
('63', 328, 2, 4, 670840) At the outset I have the honour to observe that my Board are entirely in sympathy with the aims and objects of the Bill and are of opinion that it should be passed into law at the earliest opportunity.
('63', 328, 2, 5, 671042) It is our firm belief that legislation of the type contemplated in the Bill is essential, if Government and Legislature desire to implement the pledges which have been held out, on more occasions than one, that all possible steps will be taken to remove the disabilities under which Harijans labour at present.
('63', 328, 2, 6, 671353) One of the main objections that has been taken against the proposed legislation is that it involves an element of compulsion and that it is proposed that either Government or the Legislature should not compel any individual or individuals or a religious organization to act in a manner which is opposed to so called religious customs and usages.
('63', 328, 2, 7, 671699) It is pertinent here to examine what these customs are and how they have developed in Hindu society.
('63', 328, 2, 8, 671800) At some time beyond living memory, a custom grew up of treating certain sections of the Hindu community as the excluded classes, and in the development of that custom certain rights as Hindus were denied to the members of such excluded classes.
('63', 328, 2, 9, 672045) Objection was taken if they entered the temples on the ground that they were unclean and their touch or mere shadow would pollute the devout Hindus who were visiting the temples for darshan.
('63', 328, 2, 10, 672236) Gradually, the members of the excluded classes were thus completely debarred from entering the temples.
('63', 328, 2, 11, 672340) This has, in the course of time, come to be recognized as custom and usage, and this having obtained legal sanction, the Hindu community is obliged, whatever its present views may be, to exclude the untouchables from the temples.
('63', 328, 2, 12, 672570) The real position, therefore, is that compulsion is already there in the shape of the recognition given by British Courts of Justice to the custom and usage by which members of the excluded classes have been treated as untouchables and denied the rights of temple entry.
('63', 328, 2, 13, 672841) In Madras, such custom and usage has been specifically recognized by the Madras Religious Endowments Act II of 1927, Section 40 of which accords full legal sanction to it.
('63', 328, 2, 14, 673013) With the change of times and circumstances and with ideas developing from day to day, several customs and usages have undergone material changes.
('63', 328, 2, 15, 673159) In some cases, the Government, relying on the opinion of leading Hindus, have thought fit to legislate against well established and well recognized customs and usages in face of the opposition of a majority of Hindus, with a view to bring the state of Hindu society in line with modern ideas.
('63', 328, 2, 16, 673452) In other cases, the opinion of the majority of Hindus has either thrown custom overboard, where the sanction of law was not necessary for such action, or got the Government to pass legislation to set aside such custom.
('63', 328, 2, 17, 673671) Apart from the strictly legal and technical attitude, to argue, therefore, that the Bill involves an element of compulsion, without considering what that compulsion consists of and how such compulsion is for the removal of a greater compulsion
('63', 329, 0, 1, 673915) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 329, 1, 2, 673957) which already exists, would not be correct.
('63', 329, 1, 3, 674001) The Trustees and beneficiaries are now by law compelled to exclude the Harijans from darshan at Hindu temples.
('63', 329, 1, 4, 674112) If the prevalent opinion amongst the Hindus of today is that this element of compulsion should be done away with and it be left open to the Hindus to decide for themselves as to how far the excluded classes should be allowed to be treated as members of the Hindu community and to enjoy the rights or privileges of darshan, a state of circumstances must be brought into existence which would leave the door open for necessary action in that behalf.
('63', 329, 1, 5, 674560) It does not necessarily follow that, on the passing of the Bill, a rush will be made at all the temples by the excluded classes to assert their rights of darshan.
('63', 329, 1, 6, 674723) The disqualification being removed, it will then be a matter for adjustment between Hindus and the members of the excluded classes to adjust affairs without friction and without bringing themselves under the provisions of the criminal law of the land.
('63', 329, 1, 7, 674975) The view that the passing of the Bill would upset all principles and tenets of the Hindu religion would be erroneous.
('63', 329, 1, 8, 675093) In fact, even after the passing of the Bill, the excluded classes will not be able to have darshan at the temples without the goodwill and the tacit consent of the Hindus.
('63', 329, 1, 9, 675265) That the entry of the excluded classes into the temples for darshan is not so abhorrent to the mind of the Hindus is apparent from the fact that on certain days of the year some very important temples observing the most orthodox and rigid rules are thrown open to all classes of Hindus, including the excluded classes.
('63', 329, 1, 10, 675584) At all events, going to a temple for darshan is entirely voluntary.
('63', 329, 1, 11, 675652) In certain circumstances and on certain occasions, even members of the so called high class Hindus are prohibited entry into certain parts of the temples.
('63', 329, 1, 12, 675807) In certain cases, such Hindus themselves observing certain rules refrain from going to temple, believing themselves to be in a state in which their attendance at the temples would pollute the temples as well as those attending there for darshan.
('63', 329, 1, 13, 676053) The degree of compulsion, therefore, so far as this Bill is concerned, is infinitesimal as compared to the existing compulsion, which has already been imposed by reason of the recognition granted to custom and usage which had grown under circumstances which no longer exist.
('63', 329, 1, 14, 676328) The difficulty as regards the removal of custom and usage is all the greater, because in most of the cases there are no specific Trusts.
('63', 329, 1, 15, 676465) Ordinarily, the Trustees would have the power to exercise their discretion, as prudent men of the world, in considering who should be admitted and to what right.
('63', 329, 1, 16, 676627) But here the sanction obtained by custom and usage comes in the way.
('63', 329, 1, 17, 676696) New Trusts cannot be declared.
('63', 329, 1, 18, 676727) There are no specific Trusts and reliance is placed on custom and usage to shut out the discretion of the Trustees or even the beneficiaries, meaning the Hindus.
('63', 329, 1, 19, 676889) With the passing of the Bill, the result will be that the power to exercise such discretion is restored to the Trustees and, where necessary, to the beneficiaries, who can by an express vote of majority decide how far the classes of beneficiaries should be extended and, that, too, without in any way interfering with the existing rights, so that it comes to this—that the compulsion and the consequent disability from which those in control of temples are at present suffering is sought to be removed and the door thrown open and the power of discretion restored to them to act according to the circumstances and according to the wishes of those immediately concerned.
('63', 329, 1, 20, 677559) It does not, as is apprehended in some quarters, direct the Trustees to commit breaches of Trust.
('63', 329, 1, 21, 677657) In fact, the whole difficulty is created by the absence of specific Trusts.
('63', 329, 1, 22, 677733) It only creates a situation where the Trustees, as prudent men and with the sanction of the majority,
('63', 330, 0, 1, 677835) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 331
('63', 330, 1, 2, 677879) can extend the privilege of darshan, etc., to the members of the excluded classes on such terms and under circumstances which may be acceptable to Hindus.
('63', 330, 2, 3, 678034) Under these circumstances, the element of compulsion, if any, involved in the Bill is really and substantively to eliminate the greater degree of compulsion which is at present extant.
('63', 330, 2, 4, 678219) The second objection is (as to) whether the Bill seeks to interfere with any person’s religious practice or conscience.
('63', 330, 2, 5, 678339) My Board hold the view that, having regard to the fact that the entry of members of the excluded classes on certain days of festival during the year in the most orthodox Hindu temples is not objected to by the Hindus and is not considered as interference with the religious practice or conscience of a high class Hindu, the extending of that privilege to members of the excluded classes on other days in the year cannot, in substance, amount to any interference with the religious practice or conscience of a highcaste Hindu.
('63', 330, 2, 6, 678865) Apart from this, every Hindu in going to temples submits to various customary restrictions and interference, and no pious Hindu complains, as his sole aim and object in attending the temple on any particular occasion is to have darshan and perform puja and that aim and object is not in any way interfered with by the permissive legislation now sought to be put on the Statute Book.
('63', 330, 2, 7, 679248) The statutory recognition of the existing custom and usage in this respect serves, however, as a solid obstacle or bar against any modification of the existing state of things, and this is what makes legislation necessary, not with a view to hit or counter the religious practice or conscience of Hindus but to give those in authority over Hindu temples a right to give the members of the excluded classes their due status as Hindus and thereby prevent a cleavage in the community.
('63', 330, 2, 8, 679730) In effect, therefore, it merely amounts to a variation in the practice of worship hitherto observed, but such variation cannot be regarded as interference with the inherent or vested right of persons.
('63', 330, 2, 9, 679931) In fact, the right is one which, in the ordinary course, would have been modified in the larger interests of Hindu society or in the interests of certain classes but for the legal sanction accorded to custom and usage.
('63', 330, 2, 10, 680150) Interference, therefore, as used, does not amount to or mean an objectionable tampering with the vested rights of any person or persons, but is a mere statement of fact that, in the existing conditions as compared to what is proposed to be done, there would be a variation which may technically be called interference.
('63', 330, 2, 11, 680469) Experience shows that, in spite of the willingness of the Trustees as well as the worshippers of a particular Hindu temple, it is well nigh impossible for a public Hindu temple to throw its doors open to Harijans, in view of the English Law of Trusts and the known decisions of the High Courts in India.
('63', 330, 2, 12, 680773) It is for this reason that my Board hold that the recognition of the custom and usage by the High Courts of India and the Privy Council makes legislation absolutely necessary, as the effect of the decisions of these Tribunals cannot be overcome in any other manner.
('63', 330, 2, 13, 681039) The legislation now sought to be enacted is permissive, and with the provisions of criminal law now in force, it cannot be actively enforced without the goodwill of those vitally concerned, namely, the caste Hindus.
('63', 330, 2, 14, 681255) The foregoing views are expressed purely from a legal point of view.
('63', 330, 2, 15, 681324) The question of throwing open a temple to excluded classes is one of great public and practical importance.
('63', 330, 2, 16, 681432) If a substantial majority of Hindus at a particular centre are in favour of admitting the excluded classes to the local public temples, the element of
('63', 331, 0, 1, 681583) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 331, 1, 2, 681625) compulsion mentioned above need not stand in the way of the proposed legislation, as such element of compulsion would be found in the conduct of all human affairs.
('63', 331, 1, 3, 681789) But the compulsion involved in the Bill is, as above indicated, of a type which may be described as vox populi, vox Dei, and to ask a body of people to act according to the opinion of the majority of that body cannot truly or partly be said to be compulsion.
('63', 331, 1, 4, 682048) The effect of the Bill is actually to remove the compulsion resting on the Trustees to act according to a custom or usage, even if it has received judicial recognition, if such custom or usage does not find favour with the majority of the people any longer.
('63', 331, 1, 5, 682306) The law, as it stands at present, may be utilized as an engine of oppression even by a single caste Hindu worshipper at a temple to impose his will, not only on the Trustees of that temple, but on all the other worshippers at that temple who may be willing to allow a Harijan to worship at that temple.
('63', 331, 1, 6, 682609) The real effect of the Bill is to deprive a caste Hindu of the engine of oppression which judicial decisions have provided him with.
('63', 331, 1, 7, 682742) To put it in another form, it will deprive the caste Hindu of the power given to him by judicial decisions to compel the Harijans to submit for all time to the disabilities imposed on him.
('63', 331, 1, 8, 682931) Though the proposed legislation involves compulsion in theory, in practice, if the proposed Bill becomes law, it will give liberty to the worshippers at a temple to conduct their worship in accordance with the prevailing views and wishes of the majority.
('63', 331, 1, 9, 683186) On the grounds set forth above, my Board are emphatically of opinion that not only are the aims and objects of the proposed measure unexceptionable, but the method by which it seeks to achieve them are such as to cause the minimum extent of inconvenience, hardship or social disturbances.
('63', 331, 1, 10, 683475) They, therefore, request that the Legislative Assembly will enact legislation on the lines proposed at an early date in the interest of the Hindu community as a whole, apart from the duty that Government and Legislature themselves owe to the depressed classes.
('63', 331, 1, 11, 683736) I disclose no secret when I inform the reader that this represen tation has been drawn up by an eminent lawyer of Bombay.
('63', 331, 1, 12, 683858) It is an able and dispassionate examination of the legal position.
('63', 331, 1, 13, 683925) But like all documents drawn up purely from the legal standpoint, this suffers from the usual limitations.
('63', 331, 1, 14, 684032) It was open to the Board to combine with the legal, the moral and religious argument.
('63', 331, 1, 15, 684118) For, the representation is addressed not to a court of law but to a Government and through it, to a Legislative Assembly, both of which are bound to take note, as they have done, of extra legal matters.
('63', 331, 1, 16, 684321) These often become decisive factors with bodies that are not hidebound by legal procedure and other legal limitations.
('63', 331, 1, 17, 684440) Thus, in my opinion, the Board might have embodied in their document their composition and their capacity to voice Hindu public opinion.
('63', 331, 1, 18, 684577) It might have told the Assembly that the Bill was necessary, both in fulfilment of the Yeravda Pact and of the broad policy of the Government in respect of Harijans.
('63', 331, 1, 19, 684743) The Bombay lead can be well followed by the other provincial
('63', 332, 0, 1, 684804) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 333
('63', 332, 1, 2, 684848) boards.
('63', 332, 1, 3, 684856) They may examine the question with particular reference to their provinces, taking care always to understate rather than overstate the evidence as to Hindu public opinion.
('63', 332, 1, 4, 685028) The question might be asked why during the Harijan tour I did not myself take the vote of the public on the question of the proposed legislation.
('63', 332, 1, 5, 685174) It presented itself to me in the beginning stages of the tour, and I came to the conclusion that, if I took the vote, it was highly likely that the people would give their votes because I was asking for it.
('63', 332, 1, 6, 685381) I should not mind receiving co operation of people in simple faith, where faith could be legitimately exercised.
('63', 332, 1, 7, 685494) In this instance, faith had no play.
('63', 332, 1, 8, 685531) People had to decide on a highly technical issue in which knowledge of parliamentary procedure and function would be pre sumed.
('63', 332, 1, 9, 685659) I had no time nor inclination to give that kind of training to the vast mass of mankind that appeared at meetings.
('63', 332, 1, 10, 685774) And if I had attempted any such thing, I would have strayed far away from my mission, which I had claimed to be purely spiritual.
('63', 332, 1, 11, 685904) Then, if I had begun to take votes on the propriety or otherwise of temple entry legislation, there would have been danger of my being engaged in a hot controversy with sanatanists.
('63', 332, 1, 12, 686086) This was the last thing in the world that I would do.
('63', 332, 1, 13, 686140) I, therefore, deliberately refrained from putting the question of legislation to the vote of my audiences.
('63', 332, 1, 14, 686247) Whenever, therefore, I spoke on the question, I contented myself with giving my opinion that it was the duty of every Hindu reformer to press for legislation, if the pledge given at Bombay in 1932 was to be redeemed.
('63', 332, 1, 15, 686464) But if the vote of the savarna Hindus in general was not to be taken, what was to be done?
('63', 332, 1, 16, 686555) I came to the conclusion that those only could properly have any opinion on the question who were con versant with parliamentary procedure and functions.
('63', 332, 1, 17, 686709) They could appreciate how, under certain circumstances, for the very preservation of religious neutrality and freedom of conscience, on which sanata nists very properly insist, legislation might be imperatively necessary.
('63', 332, 1, 18, 686931) Such bodies were, first of all, lawyers’ associations and, then, societies of Shastris, Harijan Sevak Boards and other representative bodies who could claim to have a say in such matters.
('63', 332, 1, 19, 687119) I hope, there fore, that all associations who are interested in the removal of untouchability and who have a right to be heard will make their opinion known to the public and the authorities concerned.
('63', 332, 1, 20, 687321) But I have no desire to force legislation upon an unwilling public.
('63', 332, 1, 21, 687389) Nevertheless, it cannot be educated nor its opinion ascertained, without reasoned public discussion and legitimate canvassing.
('63', 332, 1, 22, 687516) If in the end it is found that enlightened caste Hindu opinion is against legislation, I, for one, would not desire to see it carried by a mixed majority vote.
('63', 332, 1, 23, 687676) All that I contend is that Hindus who have faith in
('63', 333, 0, 1, 687728) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 333, 1, 2, 687770) temples have the right and owe it as a duty to enforce their opinion, wherever an overwhelming majority wants to open public Hindu temples to Harijans.
('63', 333, 1, 3, 687922) And if there is a legal hindrance, as lawyers say there is, it can only be, and therefore should be, removed by law.
('63', 333, 2, 4, 688039) Harijan, 30 3 1934

('63', 338, 4, 23, 699753) 373. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, DARBHANGA 2
('63', 338, 5, 24, 699796) March 31, 1934
('63', 338, 6, 25, 699811) Gandhiji said that he had seen sands on lands that used to smile with plenty; he had seen wells destroyed or filled with sand and rivers dried up.
('63', 338, 6, 26, 699958) None, however hard hearted he might be, can remain unmoved at the sight that he saw.
('63', 338, 6, 27, 700043) Not to speak of the palaces of the Maharajadhiraj, which were smashed to pieces, even the poor man’s dwellings had been reduced to heaps of ruins.
('63', 338, 6, 28, 700190) What could he do?
('63', 338, 6, 29, 700208) What could the whole world do?
('63', 338, 6, 30, 700239) The situation presented a hard problem.
('63', 338, 6, 31, 700279) They could get some relief; they could get money but the real thing needed was sympathy.
('63', 338, 6, 32, 700368) Monetary help was only a token of such sympathy.
('63', 338, 6, 33, 700417) Their duty at this juncture was clear.
('63', 338, 6, 34, 700456) They should
('63', 338, 7, 35, 700468) 1 About whether the civil disobedience should be withdrawn 2 Extracted from Pyarelal Nayyar’s “Weekly Letter”
('63', 339, 0, 1, 700578) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 339, 1, 2, 700620) strive for internal purity.
('63', 339, 2, 3, 700648) Gandhiji made a fervent appeal for the abolition of the bar sinister, as a measure of self purification and reform.
('63', 339, 2, 4, 700764) Referring to the allegorical story of the elephant and the alligator, he reminded the audience that the visitations of Nature were the inevitable—however long delayed they may be—consequence of our sins and were intended to rouse us from our spiritual slumber.
('63', 339, 2, 5, 701025) The elephant and the alligator, the legend goes, were in their previous birth brothers.
('63', 339, 2, 6, 701113) But, instead of loving each other like brothers, they hated each other and so were condemned to be born as natural enemies.
('63', 339, 2, 7, 701237) Still they refused to reform.
('63', 339, 2, 8, 701267) One day, when the elephant visited the lake, the alligator seized his leg and tried to drag him under water.
('63', 339, 2, 9, 701376) The deadly struggle lasted for “a thousand aeons”.
('63', 339, 2, 10, 701427) Finally, when the elephant found his strength failing and only the tip of his trunk remained above the surface of the water, he called upon God and God came to his rescue.
('63', 339, 2, 11, 701599) His delusion left him and he again loved his brother, both of them being restored to their human form through God’s grace.
('63', 339, 2, 12, 701722) Nature utters its warning to us in a voice of thunder.
('63', 339, 2, 13, 701777) It flashes it before our eyes in letters of flame.
('63', 339, 2, 14, 701828) But seeing, we see not, and hearing, we do not understand.
('63', 339, 3, 15, 701887) He warned the people that, if they failed to pay heed to Nature’s signals, Nature would exact her due with compound interest.
('63', 339, 4, 16, 702013) Harijan, 20 4 1934, and The Searchlight, 4 4 1934
('63', 339, 5, 17, 702063) 374. TALK TO RELIEF WORKERS, DARBHANGA
('63', 339, 6, 18, 702102) March 31, 1934
('63', 339, 7, 19, 702117) Gandhiji referring to the problem of middle class relief, said that he was not unaware of their distress.
('63', 339, 7, 20, 702223) He did not want them to be neglected.

('63', 339, 7, 23, 702512) Only an agency like Government with adequate resources could properly take it up.
('63', 339, 7, 24, 702594) But the question of water supply in the villages for the time being must wholly engage the attention of the Relief Committee.
('63', 339, 7, 25, 702720) That alone might take away 20 lakhs of the Committee.

('63', 340, 2, 7, 703826) 375. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MADHUBANI 1
('63', 340, 3, 8, 703869) March 31, 1934
('63', 340, 4, 9, 703884) Gandhiji expressed his deep sense of distress at the disaster and the havoc visible on all sides.
('63', 340, 4, 10, 703982) It looked as if some powerful enemy had bombed towns, villages, palaces and mud houses but no bombs could shatter the firm surface of the earth like what he saw now.
('63', 340, 4, 11, 704148) Houses had been swallowed up by yawning chasms.
('63', 340, 4, 12, 704196) It was terrible.
('63', 340, 4, 13, 704213) He observed: As I viewed the picture of ruin spread out before me at Rajnagar, I felt overwhelmed and crushed by the weight of human misery.
('63', 340, 4, 14, 704354) But then I remembered Kunti’s prayer, ‘O Lord, send me misery and misfortune always, lest I forget Thee!’ It may not be given to us to have Kunti’s Himalayan faith to utter that prayer.
('63', 340, 4, 15, 704540) But may we not at least learn from it the lesson of using our calamities as a means of self purification and turning the mind Godward?
('63', 340, 5, 16, 704675) Continuing, he said he felt the irony of the situation when man attached himself heart and soul to such ephemeral objects as had been destroyed in a few moments.
('63', 340, 5, 17, 704837) He could very well understand why rishis and munis advocated renunciation and rejected all attachment, all ease and luxury.
('63', 340, 5, 18, 704961) The episode of Gajendra Moksha came vividly to him now.
('63', 340, 5, 19, 705017) It was like the whole elephant being immersed in water drawn in by the Graha, only the tip of the trunk remaining out and enabling the struggling Gaj to invoke the aid of Lord Vishnu by presenting lotus held in that remaining portion of the trunk.
('63', 340, 5, 20, 705265) They, the sufferers, had likewise to invoke the Lord, to become humble, to look inward so that hope may dawn .
('63', 340, 6, 21, 705376) Look, there the black flagwallas are come and they are waving black umbrellas too.
('63', 340, 6, 22, 705459) Well, let them come and have their say, if they like.
('63', 340, 6, 23, 705513) I have got to speak in their presence about removal of chhuachoot (untouchability).
('63', 340, 6, 24, 705597) The demon of untouchability has got to be driven away.
('63', 340, 7, 25, 705652) 1 The meeting was attended by more than 25,000 people.

('63', 341, 0, 1, 705922) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 341, 1, 2, 705964) Gandhiji categorically reiterated his view on untouchability, which he charact erized as contrary to the teachings of the Shastras and abhorrent to the spirit of sanatana dharma, which was the most catholic and tolerant of all religions in the world.
('63', 341, 1, 3, 706215) He asked: Is it not ridiculous to regard a Dom as untouchable, when for performing the same function we honour and worship our mother?

('63', 341, 6, 11, 706710) When we know that God Himself is the mystery of mysteries, why should anything that He does perplex us?
('63', 341, 6, 12, 706814) If He acted as we would have Him do or if He acted exactly like us, we would not be His creatures and He our Creator.
('63', 341, 6, 13, 706932) The impenetrable darkness that surrounds us is not a curse but a blessing.
('63', 341, 6, 14, 707007) He has given us power to see the steps in front of us and it would be enough if Heavenly Light reveals that step to us.
('63', 341, 6, 15, 707127) We can then sing with Newman, ‘One step enough for me.’ And we may be sure from our past experience that the next step will always be in view.
('63', 341, 6, 16, 707270) In other words, the impenetrable darkness is nothing so impenetrable as we may imagine.
('63', 341, 6, 17, 707358) But it seems impenetrable when in our impatience we want to look beyond that one step.
('63', 341, 6, 18, 707445) And since God is love, we can say definitely that even the physical catastrophes that He sends now and then must be a blessing in disguise and they can be so only to those who regard them as a warning for introspection and self purification.

('63', 345, 4, 8, 713578) 382. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('63', 345, 5, 9, 713606) April 2, 1934
('63', 345, 6, 10, 713620) Question: Is it not the duty of every Congressman and particularly an inmate of the Ashram to participate in the individual satyagraha?
('63', 345, 7, 11, 713756) ANSWER: Not at all, if they do not feel it from within.
('63', 345, 8, 12, 713812) Q. Won’t you like those workers to take part in civil disobedience who have dropped out from the movement for some reason or other but are always inclined to associate themselves with it?
('63', 345, 9, 13, 714000) A. I would like them to do so if they have understood the full significance of the religion of satyagraha, and they follow the path even at the cost of their life.
('63', 345, 10, 14, 714164) Q. Would you accept like Pt. Jawaharlal that the country stands to benefit by resorting to civil disobedience for winning political independence?
('63', 345, 11, 15, 714310) A. I would certainly accept it if the civil disobedience is pure.
('63', 345, 12, 16, 714376) Q. Is it not desirable that those who have been resorting to satyagraha against the Government with a political motive rather than as a matter of dharma should continue to participate in the civil disobedience movement with the same attitude?
('63', 345, 13, 17, 714619) A. I really doubt it.

('63', 346, 4, 7, 715550) 383. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('63', 346, 5, 8, 715580) SAHARSA, April 2, 1934 This statement owes its inspiration to a personal chat with the inmates and associates of the Satyagraha Ashram who had just come out of prison and whom at Rajendrababu’s instance I had sent to Bihar.
('63', 346, 5, 9, 715804) More especially it is due to a revealing information I got in the course of conversation about a valued companion of long standing who was found reluctant to perform the full prison task and preferring his private studies to the allotted task.
('63', 346, 5, 10, 716048) This was undoubtedly contrary to the rules of satyagraha.
('63', 346, 5, 11, 716106) More than the imperfection of the friend, whom I love more than ever, it brought home to me my own im perfection.
('63', 346, 5, 12, 716220) The friend said he had thought that I was aware of his weakness.
('63', 346, 5, 13, 716285) I was blind.
('63', 346, 5, 14, 716298) Blindness in a leader is unpardonable.
('63', 346, 5, 15, 716337) I saw at once that I must for the time being remain the sole representative of civil resistance in action.
('63', 346, 5, 16, 716444) During the informal conference week at Poona in July last I had stated that while many individual civil resisters would be welcome, even one was sufficient to keep alive the message of satyagraha.
('63', 346, 5, 17, 716641) Now after much searching of the heart I have arrived at the conclusion that in the present circumstances only one, and that myself and no other, should for the time being bear the responsibility of civil resistance if it is to succeed as a means of achieving purna swaraj.
('63', 346, 5, 18, 716914) I feel that the masses have not received the full message of satyagraha owing to its adulteration in the process of transmission.
('63', 346, 5, 19, 717044) It has become clear to me that spiritual instruments suffer in their potency when their use is taught through non spiritual media.
('63', 346, 5, 20, 717175) Spiri tual messages are self propagating.
('63', 346, 5, 21, 717217) The reaction of the masses throu 
('63', 346, 6, 22, 717251) 1 This was released to the Press on April 7; vide “Statement to the Press”,
('63', 347, 0, 1, 717327) 348 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 347, 1, 2, 717369) ghout the Harijan tour has been the latest forcible illustration of what I mean.
('63', 347, 1, 3, 717450) The splendid response of the masses has been spontaneous.
('63', 347, 1, 4, 717508) The workers themselves were amazed at the attention and the fervour of vast masses whom they had never reached.
('63', 347, 1, 5, 717620) Satyagraha is a purely spiritual weapon.
('63', 347, 1, 6, 717661) It may be used for what may appear to be mundane ends and through men and women who do not understand its spirituality provided the director knows that the weapon is spiritual.
('63', 347, 1, 7, 717838) Everyone cannot use surgical instruments.
('63', 347, 1, 8, 717880) Many may use them if there is an expert behind them directing their use.
('63', 347, 1, 9, 717953) I claim to be a satyagraha expert in the making.
('63', 347, 1, 10, 718002) I have need to be far more careful than the expert surgeon who is complete master of his science.
('63', 347, 1, 11, 718100) I am still a humble searcher.
('63', 347, 1, 12, 718130) The very nature of the science of satyagraha precludes the student from seeing more than the step immediately in front of him.
('63', 347, 1, 13, 718257) The introspection prompted by the conversation with the Ashram inmates has led me to the conclusion that I must advise all Congressmen to suspend civil resistance for swaraj as distinguished from specific grievances.
('63', 347, 1, 14, 718474) They should leave it to me alone.
('63', 347, 1, 15, 718508) It should be resumed by others in my lifetime only under my direction unless one arises claiming to know the science better than I do and inspires confidence.
('63', 347, 1, 16, 718667) I give this opinion as the author and initiator of satya graha.
('63', 347, 1, 17, 718731) Henceforth, therefore, all who have been impelled to civil resis tance for swaraj under my advice directly given or indirectly inferred will please desist from civil resistance.
('63', 347, 1, 18, 718909) I am quite convinced that this is the best course in the interests of India’s fight for freedom.
('63', 347, 1, 19, 719006) I am in dead earnest about this greatest of weapons at the disposal of mankind.
('63', 347, 1, 20, 719086) It is claimed for satyagraha that it is a complete substitute for violence or war.
('63', 347, 1, 21, 719169) It is designed, therefore, to reach the hearts both of the so called “terrorists” and the rulers who seek to root out the “terrorists” by emasculating a whole nation.
('63', 347, 1, 22, 719336) But the in different civil resistance of many, grand as it has been in its results, has not touched the hearts of either the “terrorists” or the rulers as a class.
('63', 347, 1, 23, 719500) Unadulterated satyagraha must touch the hearts of both.
('63', 347, 1, 24, 719556) To test the truth of the proposition, satyagraha needs to be confined to one qualified person at a time.
('63', 347, 1, 25, 719661) The trial has never been made.
('63', 347, 1, 26, 719692) It must be made now.
('63', 347, 1, 27, 719713) Let me caution the reader against mistaking satyagraha for mere
('63', 348, 0, 1, 719777) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 349
('63', 348, 1, 2, 719821) civil resistance.
('63', 348, 1, 3, 719839) It covers much more than civil resistance.
('63', 348, 1, 4, 719882) It means relentless search for truth and the power that such a search gives to the searcher.
('63', 348, 1, 5, 719975) The search can only be pursued by strictly non violent means.
('63', 348, 2, 6, 720037) What are the civil resisters, thus freed, to do?
('63', 348, 2, 7, 720086) If they are to be ready for the call whenever it comes, they must learn the art and the beauty of self denial and voluntary poverty.
('63', 348, 2, 8, 720219) They must engage themselves in nation building activities, the spread of khaddar through personal hand spinning and hand weaving, the spread of communal unity of hearts by irreproachable personal conduct towards one an other in every walk of life, the banishing of untouchability in every shape or form in one’s own person, the spread of total abstinence from intoxicating drinks and drugs by personal contact with indivi dual addicts and generally by cultivating personal purity.
('63', 348, 2, 9, 720700) These are services which provide maintenance on a poor man’s scale.
('63', 348, 2, 10, 720768) Those for whom the poor man’s scale is not feasible should find a place in small unorganized industries of national importance which give a better wage.
('63', 348, 2, 11, 720921) Let it be understood that civil resistance is for those who know and perform the duty of voluntary obedience to law and authority.
('63', 348, 3, 12, 721052) It is hardly necessary to say that in issuing this statement I am in no way usurping the function of the Congress.
('63', 348, 3, 13, 721167) Mine is mere advice to those who look to me for guidance in matters of satyagraha.
('63', 348, 4, 14, 721250) From a copy: C.W. 9137
('63', 349, 0, 1, 721273) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 349, 1, 2, 721315) 384. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BHAGALPUR
('63', 349, 2, 3, 721356) April 2, 1934 I have been touring in Bihar for the last several days.
('63', 349, 2, 4, 721426) I have already seen the areas greatly affected by the earthquake.
('63', 349, 2, 5, 721492) This tour will be over tomorrow evening.
('63', 349, 2, 6, 721533) The scene was horrible.
('63', 349, 2, 7, 721557) I can only imagine the actual scene which you all have seen.
('63', 349, 2, 8, 721618) Palaces and big houses collapsed within a minute or two.
('63', 349, 2, 9, 721675) Water came out.
('63', 349, 2, 10, 721691) I do not know what was then the scene at Bhagalpur.
('63', 349, 2, 11, 721743) The Central Relief Committee and the Government are co operating to remove your distress but the relief is for those who have actually suffered.
('63', 349, 2, 12, 721888) The Gita says that to eat without doing work is to commit theft.
('63', 349, 2, 13, 721953) If money is to come from Government we should not sit idle.
('63', 349, 2, 14, 722013) The Government and the Relief Committee should help the deserving people.
('63', 349, 2, 15, 722087) What help can be given to the Maharaja of Dar bhanga and Deep Babu 1 for their losses?
('63', 349, 2, 16, 722174) It is also not possible to help all persons.
('63', 349, 2, 17, 722219) No matter whether help is given or not, people must do their duty.
('63', 349, 2, 18, 722286) The complaint on behalf of the middle class has been received, but there are representatives of the middle class in the Central Relief Committee.
('63', 349, 2, 19, 722432) I pray the middle class should forget their position as such and think that all are equal.
('63', 349, 2, 20, 722523) All are human beings, God is the same for all.
('63', 349, 2, 21, 722570) The Central Relief Committee has forgotten the difference but the middle class ought also to be helped.
('63', 349, 2, 22, 722674) Suppose there are men who are thirsty, hungry, who want cloth, and who want houses to live in, whom to help first?
('63', 349, 2, 23, 722789) Nobody can take the share of the thirsty.
('63', 349, 2, 24, 722831) The thirsty ought to be helped first.
('63', 349, 2, 25, 722869) Let the thirst of the men and animals be quenched first, then help the hungry, then let cloth be given an lastly the houses constructed.
('63', 349, 2, 26, 723006) We shall forget the earthquake in four months or in a year or two.
('63', 349, 2, 27, 723073) If I come again I shall be gettingmoney from you all.
('63', 349, 2, 28, 723127) Even today you give money to me.
('63', 349, 2, 29, 723160) The people of Bihpur brought money.
('63', 349, 2, 30, 723196) I told them only if they believed untouchability to be a sin of the Hindu society, should they subscribe for the funds I am raising.
('63', 349, 2, 31, 723329) They subscribed.
('63', 349, 2, 32, 723346) Even the women touched my feet and offered subscription.
('63', 349, 2, 33, 723403) Purify yourselves.
('63', 349, 2, 34, 723422) Untouchability is a social sin.
('63', 349, 2, 35, 723454) Nobody is born untouchable.
('63', 349, 2, 36, 723482) If you want to remove your distress remove untouchability.
('63', 349, 2, 37, 723541) No Viceroy’s fund, no Central Com mittee, can help you in this work.
('63', 349, 2, 38, 723610) This is all that I have to say.
('63', 349, 3, 39, 723642) History of the Freedom Movement in Bihar, Vol. II (1928 1941), pp.
('63', 349, 3, 40, 723709) 221 2 and The Indian Nation, 6 4 1934

('63', 350, 3, 4, 723870) After so many lives were lost and so many houses destroyed, God has roused us from our slumber.
('63', 350, 3, 5, 723966) All the religions say that when sin accumulates upon the earth, a total cataclysm follows.
('63', 350, 3, 6, 724057) Untoucha bility is a great sin.
('63', 350, 3, 7, 724089) Are we prepared to get rid of it or not is the great question.
('63', 350, 3, 8, 724152) Someone has said that that sin is not confined only to the fifteen millions of Biharis.
('63', 350, 4, 9, 724240) Nothing can be more absurd than to suppose that the Biharis were specially marked by nature for its attention because they are more wicked than the rest.
('63', 350, 4, 10, 724394) 4 Misfortune is not a proof of an indivi dual’s wickedness.
('63', 350, 4, 11, 724454) All the same, there is an indissoluble connection between natural calamities and man’s sin.
('63', 350, 4, 12, 724546) You cannot have an inter ruption of the moral law in one part without producing a reaction in the entire system.
('63', 350, 4, 13, 724659) When one limb is afflicted, through it the entire body is punished.
('63', 350, 4, 14, 724727) Every calamity should, therefore, lead to a thor ough cleansing of individual as well as social life.
('63', 350, 4, 15, 724829) What sin have the Muslims committed?
('63', 350, 4, 16, 724866) Shall I tell you their sin?
('63', 350, 4, 17, 724894) Their sin is that they have kept up the relationship with us in spite of the fact that we observe untouchability.
('63', 350, 4, 18, 725008) Can it be a divine law that some persons are born untouchables and remain so for generations?
('63', 350, 4, 19, 725102) Even men do not have such a law.
('63', 350, 4, 20, 725135) It does not exist anywhere in this world.
('63', 350, 4, 21, 725177) The plight of Negroes in America is very bad.
('63', 350, 4, 22, 725223) They are untou chables but they are not considered to have been born so.
('63', 350, 4, 23, 725296) Treating them as untouchables is not considered a dharma.
('63', 350, 4, 24, 725354) There are a vast number of people who treat Negroes as untouchables but such beha viour is not considered a part of religion.
('63', 350, 4, 25, 725480) It is not that Bihar has incurred this punishment because it is more wicked.
('63', 350, 4, 26, 725557) Bihar is a part of India.
('63', 350, 4, 27, 725583) It is a part of the world.
('63', 350, 4, 28, 725610) God alone knows His ways.
('63', 350, 4, 29, 725636) We only know that God is full of compassion, love and kindness, so the punish ment he metes out must have been based on justice.
('63', 350, 4, 30, 725765) It is beyond my

('63', 352, 1, 2, 727636) 387. LETTER TO DR.
('63', 352, 1, 3, 727655) M. A. ANSARI 1
('63', 352, 2, 4, 727670) April 5, 1934
('63', 352, 3, 5, 727684) DEAR DR.
('63', 352, 3, 6, 727693) ANSARI, It was good of you, Bhulabhai and Dr. Bidhan Roy to come all the way to Patna to discuss the resolutions arrived at recently at an informal meeting 2 of some Congressmen and ascertain my opinion on them.
('63', 352, 3, 7, 727905) I have no hesitation in welcoming the revival of the Swarajya Party and the decision of the meeting to take part in the forth coming elections to the Assembly, which you tell me is about to be dissolved.
('63', 352, 3, 8, 728109) My views on the utility of legislatures in the present state are well known.
('63', 352, 3, 9, 728186) They remain on the whole what they were in 1920, but I feel that it is not only right, but it is the duty of every Congressman, who for some reason or other does not want to or cannot take part in the Poona programme and who has faith in entry into the legislatures to seek entry and form combinations in order to prosecute the programme which he or they believe to be in the interest of the country.
('63', 352, 3, 10, 728587) Consistently with my view above mentioned, I shall be at the disposal of the Party at all times and render such assistance as it is in my power to give.
('63', 352, 4, 11, 728740) Yours sincerely, The Hindustan Times, 6 4 193
('63', 352, 5, 12, 728786) 1 The letter was released to the Press with the following statement by Dr. Ansari, Dr. B. C. Roy and Bhulabhai Desai: “We arrived at Patna on the morning of the 4th instant and were able to confer with Mahatma Gandhi as regards the conclusions arrived at by the Delhi Conference.
('63', 352, 5, 13, 729066) Notwithstanding the strain he had gone through, considering the importance of the matter he discussed with us for over three hours the various aspects of the revival of the Swarajya Party.
('63', 352, 5, 14, 729255) The matter was again discussed today with Mahatmaji in the morning and in the afternoon, and the result of discussions is now embodied in the following letter addressed by Mahatmaji to Dr. Ansari.
('63', 352, 5, 15, 729452) .” 2 The meeting, which was held in Delhi on March 31, 1934, was attended by Madan Mohan Malaviya, Dr. B. C. Roy, Khaliquzzaman, G. B. Pant and other Congress leaders.
('63', 352, 5, 16, 729620) The meeting decided to form a Swarajya Party and take part in the elections for the Central Assembly.
('63', 352, 5, 17, 729722) 3 For Pyarelal’s note on Gandhiji’s views on the subject, vide “Pyarelal’s note on Gandhiji’s view”.
('63', 353, 0, 1, 729823) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 353, 1, 2, 729865) 388. NOTES
('63', 353, 2, 3, 729876) HOW DO YOU PRAY?
('63', 353, 3, 4, 729893) God has blessed me with numerous friends belonging to different faiths.
('63', 353, 3, 5, 729965) Some of these are anxious to help me in the move ment against untouchability.
('63', 353, 3, 6, 730043) The question is assuming a concrete form and requires a definite answer.
('63', 353, 3, 7, 730116) My own position is very clear and precise.
('63', 353, 3, 8, 730159) I need the co operation of the whole world in this purity movement of gigantic internal reform.
('63', 353, 3, 9, 730255) I have asked for the prayers of the whole world.
('63', 353, 3, 10, 730304) But some non Hindus want to translate their prayer into action, and that they would do, if they could, in co operation with me.
('63', 353, 3, 11, 730432) I would love to have it in the closest manner possible.
('63', 353, 3, 12, 730488) But there is a limitation.
('63', 353, 3, 13, 730515) Suppose I hand a Harijan child to a Christian or a Muslim friend or institution.
('63', 353, 3, 14, 730596) What will they do?
('63', 353, 3, 15, 730615) Will they bring it up as a Hindu or in their own faith?
('63', 353, 3, 16, 730671) For me all the principal religions are equal in the sense that they are all true.
('63', 353, 3, 17, 730753) They are supplying a felt want in the spiritual progress of humanity.
('63', 353, 3, 18, 730823) Hence I have had no difficulty in bringing up Muslim, Parsi and Christian children under my care in their own faith.
('63', 353, 3, 19, 730940) Indeed, I had to study some literature for their sake when their parents wanted me to teach them particular forms of worship according to special books.
('63', 353, 3, 20, 731093) The easiest way to find out a man’s position is perhaps through his prayer.
('63', 353, 3, 21, 731169) I suggest the following two forms:
('63', 353, 5, 22, 731204) O God !
('63', 353, 5, 23, 731212) give all Thy creation wisdom, so that each may worship and follow Thee according to his light and grow in his own faith.
('63', 353, 7, 24, 731333) give Thy creation wisdom, so that each may worship and follow Thee even as I try to do.
('63', 353, 7, 25, 731421) It is clear that the first form is all inclusive and that, therefore, a person or institution that will subscribe to it can conscientiously bring up Hindu wards as Hindus, Muslim as Muslims, etc., whereas one subscribing to the second form can conscientiously take in only those who belong to his denomination, unless he takes others with the declared intention of converting them to his own denomination.
('63', 353, 7, 26, 731827) Will friends who read these lines and care write to me for my information which prayer they subscribe to and offer every day?
('63', 353, 7, 27, 731953) Harijan, 6 4 1934
('63', 354, 0, 1, 731971) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 355
('63', 354, 1, 2, 732015) 389. AN ADI DRAVIDA’S DIFFICULTIES
('63', 354, 2, 3, 732050) A correspondent writes:
('63', 354, 3, 4, 732074) (1) Are you really interested in the welfare of Harijans or are you
('63', 354, 4, 5, 732142) actuated by any ulterior motive so as to show an increase in the population of Hindus?
('63', 354, 5, 6, 732229) (2) If you really think that untouchables form a part and parcel of
('63', 354, 6, 7, 732297) Hindus, will you kindly throw light on the following shlokas of Manusmriti considered holy by the Hindus:
('63', 354, 7, 8, 732403) “If any Panchama carries on any trade which a respectable man
('63', 354, 8, 9, 732465) conducts, and then grows rich, he should be deprived of his wealth and driven out of the country.” (Manusmriti, x.
('63', 354, 9, 10, 732580) “Whosoever that affords tuition to a Shudra, will enter Hell along with
('63', 354, 10, 11, 732652) him (Shudra).
('63', 354, 10, 12, 732666) Any Shudra endeavouring to impart religious instruction to a Brahmin should be inflicted with the punishment of hot oil being poured into his mouth and ears.” (XIV.
('63', 354, 11, 13, 732831) “Any Shudra found talking with a loud voice should be branded with red hot iron bars.
('63', 354, 11, 14, 732917) Any Shudra occupying an equal seat with a Brahmin, Kshatriya and Vaishya should be burnt with a red hot iron.” (VIII.
('63', 354, 11, 15, 733035) 276, VIII.
('63', 354, 12, 16, 733046) Hindus are commanded to observe this book as holy and act according
('63', 354, 13, 17, 733114) to the injunctions contained therein.
('63', 354, 13, 18, 733152) If you consider this as unholy, why should you not declare it as such and instead issue a new decree of your own called “Gandhismriti”?
('63', 354, 14, 19, 733288) (3) Even Arya Samajists are removing this untouchability, and their
('63', 354, 15, 20, 733356) novel procedure in carrying out this task is to perform the ritual of shuddhi and then to admit the individual into the fold.
('63', 354, 15, 21, 733482) If the untouchable is really a Hindu, how does this necessity arise?
('63', 354, 15, 22, 733551) Do you agree with them in this respect?
('63', 354, 15, 23, 733591) The correspondent claims to be an Adi Dravida and, therefore,
('63', 354, 16, 24, 733653) he has every right to suspect my motive.
('63', 354, 16, 25, 733694) The best answer, therefore, I can return to his first question is that he should await my death for forming a final judgment.
('63', 354, 16, 26, 733820) Meanwhile, if he is prepared to accept my word, I would assure him that I set no value upon an increase in the number of Hindus so called.
('63', 354, 16, 27, 733959) False professors of a creed not only do no service to it but may kill it.
('63', 354, 16, 28, 734033) The only motive, therefore, that guides me in working for the Harijan cause is to see Hinduism purified of the curse of untouchability.
('63', 354, 16, 29, 734169) And if, in so becoming, it is represented only by one Hindu, I would have no repentance but real joy that it was not
('63', 355, 0, 1, 734286) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 355, 1, 2, 734328) The correspondent’s second question is very pertinent, only he would not have put that question to me if he had been a constant reader of Harijan and had, therefore, known my definition of Shastras.
('63', 355, 1, 3, 734527) I hold Manusmriti as part of the Shastras.
('63', 355, 1, 4, 734570) But that does not mean that I swear by every verse that is printed in the book described as Manusmriti.
('63', 355, 1, 5, 734674) There are so many contradictions in the printed volume that, if you accept one part, you are bound to reject those parts that are wholly inconsistent with it.
('63', 355, 1, 6, 734833) I hold Manusmriti as a reli gious book because of the lofty teachings contained in it.
('63', 355, 1, 7, 734920) The verses quoted by the correspondent are flatly contradictory to the spirit of its main theme.
('63', 355, 1, 8, 735017) The correspondent should know that nobody is in possession of the original text.
('63', 355, 1, 9, 735098) In fact, there is no evidence to prove that a rishi named Manu ever lived.
('63', 355, 1, 10, 735173) Somehow or other, the genius of Hinduism has made the writers or the givers of the grandest truths efface themselves.
('63', 355, 1, 11, 735291) Therefore I have suggested to seekers after Truth the only safe rule for their guidance in studying Shastras, namely, that they should reject whatever is contrary to truth and ahimsa, the true foundations of all religions.
('63', 355, 1, 12, 735514) The correspondent’s third question should rightly be addressed to Arya Samajists.
('63', 355, 1, 13, 735596) It is news to me that Harijans are required by the Arya Samajists to perform the ritual of shuddhi before being admitted to the Arya Samaj.
('63', 355, 1, 14, 735736) But I have seen the shuddhi ceremony performed in order to strengthen the Harijans in the due fulfilment of the vow that they take as to abstention from beef, carrion eating, drinking intoxicating liquors, etc.
('63', 355, 1, 15, 735947) The correspondent quite rightly says that, if an untouchable is really a Hindu, no shuddhi is required of him.
('63', 355, 1, 16, 736058) If any is required, it is required of the caste Hindu who has committed the sin of believing in untouchability.
('63', 355, 2, 17, 736170) Harijan, 6 4 1934

('63', 356, 13, 16, 736589) 391. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('63', 356, 14, 17, 736622) PATNA, April 6, 1934
('63', 356, 15, 18, 736643) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, It is about 2.30 a.m.

('63', 359, 7, 18, 740851) 394. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('63', 359, 8, 19, 740881) PATNA, April 6, 1934 Although I have been credited with a very vivid imagination and although, having known fair Bihar intimately, I had a good mental picture of the havoc caused by the earthquake, the reality went far beyond the imaginary picture I had formed from descriptions received from Rajendrababu.
('63', 359, 8, 20, 741188) Although Rajendrababu is a word painter, he had failed to convey an adequate impression of the ruin that has overtaken Bihar.
('63', 359, 9, 21, 741314) 1 Vide “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 6 4 1934 2 Vithalbhai Patel
('63', 360, 0, 1, 741380) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 361
('63', 360, 1, 2, 741424) I have now covered almost all areas of destruction barring Purnea.
('63', 360, 1, 3, 741491) Practically everywhere, owing to the scarcity of water, there is a real danger of famine.
('63', 360, 1, 4, 741581) The rich fields covered with sand, rows upon rows of houses in towns and villages utterly destroyed, water and sand shooting up through stone of cement floors, walls and pillars waist deep, palaces a heap of bricks, solitary walls or pillars standing as a mournful reminder of the glory that was, improvised huts every moment in danger of catching fire, old sites not capable of being built upon for fear of a subsidence during rains, cattle starving for want of fodder and some dying for want of water, add to this the very real danger of floods reaching areas hitherto untouched by them.
('63', 360, 1, 5, 742171) The middle classes have been perhaps the hardest hit.
('63', 360, 1, 6, 742225) Some of them have lost their all and are reduced to beggary.
('63', 360, 1, 7, 742286) Those, therefore, who are least able to bear the burden have been the hardest hit.
('63', 360, 1, 8, 742369) The combined efforts of the Bihar Central Relief Committee assisted by other organizations will fail to give anything like full relief to these middle class men.
('63', 360, 1, 9, 742531) Nearly twenty lakhs subscribed to the Central Relief and nearly forty lakhs subscribed to the Viceroy’s Fund are utterly inadequate for the minimum requirements.
('63', 360, 1, 10, 742693) I hope therefore that the public will realize the immensity of the task before the Government and the people and will not in any way relax their efforts to send their dona tions as liberally as they can to the Central Relief Committee.
('63', 360, 1, 11, 742929) I am unable to say how many lakhs will be required to ensure just sufficient supply of water for thirsty men and cattle, let alone the supply of food, medical necessaries and house accommodation, temporary or semi permanent.
('63', 360, 1, 12, 743154) The reclamation of devastated fields has not been altogether overlooked.
('63', 360, 1, 13, 743227) The Government are engaged in conducting a survey of the devastated area.
('63', 360, 1, 14, 743301) They have issued elaborate instructions to the peasantry to show how they can renovate their fields for the approa ching monsoons.
('63', 360, 1, 15, 743432) The latest estimate made by the Government of the area under earthquake sands is over 500,000 acres.
('63', 360, 1, 16, 743533) The average cost of reclaim ing one acre is, at the lowest estimate, calculated at twenty per acre.
('63', 360, 1, 17, 743633) That means one crore.
('63', 360, 1, 18, 743655) What relief it would be possible to give the owners of these fields is more than I can say at present.
('63', 360, 1, 19, 743758) But I think I have given what is undoubtedly an underestimate of the needs one
('63', 361, 0, 1, 743837) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 361, 1, 2, 743879) and a half crores of people living in the affected area require.
('63', 361, 1, 3, 743944) Needless to say all these are not all equally affected.
('63', 361, 1, 4, 744000) Some have escaped direct loss altogether.
('63', 361, 1, 5, 744042) But none has escaped the indirect effect of the devastation.
('63', 361, 2, 6, 744103) CORRESPONDENT: Why, you have presented such a doleful picture of the Bihar situation and asked for more money, that I should be less than human were I to treat this as an exclusive interview.
('63', 361, 2, 7, 744295) Should I do so, I shall be denying Bihar all available sources of help.
('63', 361, 3, 8, 744367) GANDHIJI: What are you driving at?
('63', 361, 4, 9, 744402) CORRESPONDENT: I propose to share this interview with all newspaper men for obvious reasons.
('63', 361, 4, 10, 744495) The Hindu, 7 4 1934
('63', 361, 5, 11, 744515) 395. OBSERVATIONS AT MEETING OF BIHAR ANTI UNTOUCHABILITY BOARD
('63', 361, 6, 12, 744579) April 5/6, 1934
('63', 361, 7, 13, 744595) Asked regarding the ways to secure entry for Harijans into temples of all India importance, such as the Vaidyanath Temple at Deoghar and Vishnupur Temple at Gaya, Gandhiji emphasized the importance of winning the heart of caste Hindus by peaceful propaganda without coercion or compulsion of any kind whatsoever.
('63', 361, 7, 14, 744908) ln that way he thought untouchability was bound to disappear in course of time.
('63', 361, 8, 15, 744988) Regarding the desirability of persuading Harijans to enter Hindu temples, Gandhiji thought that caste Hindus should throw open the temples, but it was for the Harijans to enter or not.
('63', 361, 8, 16, 745173) They should create in them a desire to lead pure lives and merely entering the temples will not lead to purity of life.
('63', 361, 9, 17, 745293) Asked regarding touchability in the matter of food and water, Gandhiji said that water and food did not necessarily become polluted by touch and it was only impure hands that caused pollution.
('63', 361, 10, 18, 745486) Asked whether secondary education alone was desirable for Harijans or whether it should be supplemented by vocational or industrial education, Gandhiji said that all kinds of education should be provided for the Harijans and arrangements should be made for vocational training.
('63', 361, 11, 19, 745764) The Bombay Chronicle, 9 4 1934

('63', 363, 3, 5, 747755) 398. INTERVIEW TO THE “HINDU”
('63', 363, 4, 6, 747785) PATNA, April 7, 1934
('63', 363, 5, 7, 747806) CORRESPONDENT: Your statement is all too brief for the general reader and is
('63', 363, 6, 8, 747883) likely to be mistaken by some as a desertion on your part of your fellow prisoners.
('63', 363, 7, 9, 747967) GANDHIJI: I knew that I laid myself open to such a charge when I deliberately decided to omit all references to them, for my decision had nothing to do with securing a release of the prisoners.
('63', 363, 7, 10, 748161) Civil resis ters do not march to the prison in order to get out of it the next day.
('63', 363, 7, 11, 748245) They will come out in their own good time.
('63', 363, 7, 12, 748288) My only aim in coming to this decision was to purge the movement of any possibility of internal decay.
('63', 363, 7, 13, 748391) Such a possibility must always be there when an imperfect man handles imperfect instru ments.
('63', 363, 7, 14, 748485) I therefore felt that the time had come for me to reduce the possibility of decay to the minimum.
('63', 363, 7, 15, 748583) That could only be secured if civil resistance was confined to one person only, that one being the most versed in the science.
('63', 363, 7, 16, 748710) In my opinion the decision will make the movement stronger than before and capable of being easily handled both by the people and by the Government.
('63', 363, 7, 17, 748859) Hence the possibility of an early discharge of prisoners is really greater now than before, especially if the Government believe in the sincerity of my decision.
('63', 363, 8, 18, 749021) Replying to the question why, having confined civil resistance to himself, he
('63', 363, 9, 19, 749099) should not go to the whole hog and suspend it altogether, Gandhiji declared: That is undoubtedly a very proper question.
('63', 363, 9, 20, 749220) All I can say in answer is that, as the author of satyagraha and as a staunch believer in its efficacy, I may not suspend it in my own person except under circumstances which will discredit the movement itself, as for instance violence by satyagrahis themselves.
('63', 364, 0, 1, 749483) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 365
('63', 364, 1, 2, 749527) Asked how far his decision was prompted by the Delhi decisions, the Mahatma
('63', 364, 2, 3, 749603) replied: Not in the slightest degree.
('63', 364, 2, 4, 749641) It was taken definitely on Easter Monday at Saharsa.
('63', 364, 2, 5, 749694) I had no knowledge that the Delhi Conference had finished its deliberations and that it had come to a definite conclusion.
('63', 364, 2, 6, 749817) I came to know on Tuesday that the Conference had con cluded its deliberations.
('63', 364, 2, 7, 749897) What is more, the decision had come to me vaguely some days before it was finally taken when I knew nothing of the Delhi proposals.
('63', 364, 2, 8, 750029) Therefore, in point of time and fact, my decision to confine civil resistance only to me had no connection whatsoever with the Delhi Conference resolutions.
('63', 364, 2, 9, 750186) Long before the Delhi Conference took a concrete form I had said in conversations and in letters to friends that it was the duty of Congressmen who believed in Council entry, and could not or would not offer civil resistance, to form a party and prosecute the Council entry programme.
('63', 364, 2, 10, 750471) Thus and only thus, in my opinion, could the situation be clarified and the paralysis of Congressmen removed.
('63', 364, 2, 11, 750581) Indeed, even when the Poona Conference was meeting I suggested to Messrs Asaf Ali and Satya murti that if they believed in the Council programme they should follow it and canvass public opinion in its favour.
('63', 364, 2, 12, 750790) The decision about civil resistance is only based on ethical grounds and, so far as I know, has no connection whatsoever with external circumstances.
('63', 364, 2, 13, 750940) I can also tell you that, in the statement as it was drafted on Easter Monday, there was a paragraph regarding Council entry for those who would not take up the constructive activi ties mentioned in my statement.
('63', 364, 2, 14, 751153) I removed that paragraph because I had, before the statement was given to the Press, seen the Delhi friends and given them the letter which is already before the public.
('63', 364, 3, 15, 751323) The Hindu, 8 4 1934
('63', 365, 0, 1, 751343) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 365, 1, 2, 751385) 399. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('63', 365, 2, 3, 751415) PATNA, April 7, 1934
('63', 365, 3, 4, 751436) Asked what would be the extent of his co operation with the Swaraj Party, Gandhiji said: Consistently with my views on Council entry I will render them all the assistance I can.
('63', 365, 4, 5, 751614) Asked if he would assist them in securing election, Gandhiji stated: I will certainly not interfere in an election, but the electors will be guided, so far as my opinion counts with them, by the knowledge that I would like them to vote for Swarajist candidates if they are otherwise qualified.
('63', 365, 5, 6, 751908) Asked as to what extent it will be the duty of Congressmen as a body to help in the elections, Gandhiji said: Those Congressmen who believe in Council entry will certainly consider it their duty to take part in the elections.
('63', 365, 6, 7, 752134) Q. What will be the position of men like Babu Rajendra Prasad, who do not believe in Council entry, but whose assistance will be necessary for success at the election?
('63', 365, 7, 8, 752302) A. If Rajendrababu does not believe in Council entry he will not seek election, but there will be nothing to prevent him from advising those Congressmen who may desire to enter the Assembly and guide them.
('63', 365, 8, 9, 752508) Asked how far his assistance would be available to the Party, Gandhiji replied: Whenever they seek assistance and I can legitimately give them, it will be always at their disposal—so long as I am out.
('63', 365, 9, 10, 752709) Asked if he would assist the Party in drawing up the Constitution and programme, Gandhiji replied: If I can spare time and can usefully advise them, 1 shall certainly do so.
('63', 365, 9, 11, 752883) But this must not on any account be interpreted as an invitation to come to me for advice on all occasions.
('63', 365, 9, 12, 752991) For one thing, I shall have no time left to me for shouldering such a burden.
('63', 365, 10, 13, 753069) The Hindu, 8 4 1934

('63', 367, 6, 12, 755164) 403. LETTER TO J. S. HOYLAND April 9, 1934
('63', 367, 7, 13, 755207) DEAR HOYLAND, I have been having your notes of affection with due regularity.
('63', 367, 7, 14, 755285) These I do not acknowledge to save time and money.
('63', 367, 7, 15, 755336) The postage is a considerable item.
('63', 367, 7, 16, 755372) At the end of the month I find that it is more than enough to conduct a village school for Harijans or any others.
('63', 367, 7, 17, 755487) It is enough to provide 1,000 meals for the famine stricken areas of India.
('63', 367, 7, 18, 755563) I am glad you have come to terms with Allen & Unwin about the translations 1. I hope you are not calling them my translations.
('63', 367, 7, 19, 755690) They are your adaptations from my translations.

('63', 377, 5, 24, 770105) 417. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, RUPSI 1
('63', 377, 6, 25, 770144) April 11, 1934 I am glad to be again in Assam after a very long period.
('63', 377, 6, 26, 770216) This time my mission is in connection with the Harijan movement.
('63', 377, 6, 27, 770281) Untouc hability is a great blot on Hinduism, and if we do not efface it in time, we shall ourselves be effaced from the face of the earth.
('63', 377, 6, 28, 770420) I congratulate you for your purse and address, for both are a promise of your deter mination to root out untouchability in your daily lives.
('63', 377, 6, 29, 770561) It is said that there is no considerable untouchability in Assam and Bengal.
('63', 377, 6, 30, 770638) But I do not think that statement squares with facts.
('63', 377, 6, 31, 770692) We are guilty of untou chability as soon as we make distinctions between man and man and have grades of high and low.
('63', 377, 6, 32, 770810) Surely there are distinctions enough in Assam.
('63', 377, 6, 33, 770857) And those against whom distinctions are drawn feel them just as keenly as any in the other parts of India.
('63', 377, 6, 34, 770964) Then you look down upon Doms, Bhangis and Chamars, who come here from other provinces, as lowest among the low.
('63', 377, 6, 35, 771076) And it is a common thing for
('63', 377, 7, 36, 771105) 1 Extracted from Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('63', 378, 0, 1, 771152) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 379
('63', 378, 1, 2, 771196) almost all castes to consider themselves superior to some other castes and to treat Mussalmans, Christians and others as untouchables in some way or other.
('63', 378, 1, 3, 771352) Removal of untouchability implies that we shall get rid of all this high and lowness and accord equal treatment to all human beings as children of one and the same God, and thus have a real brotherhood of man.
('63', 378, 1, 4, 771562) I have no hesitation in saying that there is no warrant in our Shastras for the untouchability that I have described to you and that we are practising more or less all over India.
('63', 378, 1, 5, 771742) I ask your blessings and co operation in this one of the noblest of all causes.
('63', 378, 1, 6, 771822) Harijan, 27 4 1934
('63', 378, 2, 7, 771841) 418. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, RANGIYA 1
('63', 378, 3, 8, 771882) April 12, 1934 I should not as a rule have liked to speak after the morning prayer.
('63', 378, 3, 9, 771966) But as the mission that has brought me to Assam is for me of a deeply religious character, I have no hesitation in combining the meeting with the prayer.
('63', 378, 3, 10, 772120) But before I speak on the mission, I should like to ask you all who have gathered here in such large numbers to take to the practice of rising early in the morning and commencing the day with prayer and finishing the day with prayer before retiring.
('63', 378, 3, 11, 772370) Do it with the members of your family, if you cannot get your neighbours to join, and if you cannot get the members of your family to do so, do it alone.
('63', 378, 3, 12, 772524) If you will cultivate the practice, you will find for yourselves what a peace giving thing a prayer from the heart is, and you will find that it will steady you.
('63', 378, 3, 13, 772686) And a day begun under such happy auspices will invariably end well.
('63', 378, 3, 14, 772754) One of the verses we sang this morning paraphrased means this: “O God, I desire no earthly riches, nor heaven, not even salvation.
('63', 378, 3, 15, 772885) I desire the alleviation of the sufferings of all Thy creatures.” This is not a verse of modern coinage.
('63', 378, 3, 16, 772990) It is an ancient orthodox prayer.
('63', 378, 3, 17, 773024) Do you think that you can truthfully utter that prayer from day to day and yet treat crores of fellow beings as untouchables, whose very life is crushed out of them and who are treated as less than domestic cattle?
('63', 378, 3, 18, 773239) You have, therefore, to choose between untouchability and the prayer which is enjoined upon every good Hindu.
('63', 378, 3, 19, 773349) I suggest that you choose the prayer and banish
('63', 378, 4, 20, 773397) 1 Extracted from Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('63', 378, 4, 21, 773445) Gandhiji passed Rangiya in the morning on his way from Barpeta to Tejpur.
('63', 379, 0, 1, 773519) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 379, 1, 2, 773561) untouchability from your hearts.
('63', 379, 1, 3, 773594) Regard untouchability as a heinous sin.
('63', 379, 1, 4, 773634) But whilst it is sinful to regard a single human being as an untouchable, I can introduce you to some untouchables whom you have to shun at any cost, and these are the evil thoughts which make us do all sorts of evil things from day to day.
('63', 379, 1, 5, 773875) They need to be banished.
('63', 379, 1, 6, 773901) And then in Assam, more than in any other part of India, you have the opium curse, a true untouchable.
('63', 379, 1, 7, 774004) The opium habit dulls the intellect and promotes laziness.
('63', 379, 1, 8, 774063) I do not believe that it does any good whatever.
('63', 379, 1, 9, 774112) If, therefore, you will take my advice, I would ask you every day to pray that God may give you strength to remove the untouchability of human beings from your breasts and give you the wisdom to regard every evil thought as an untouchable and to give you strength to exorcize it.
('63', 379, 1, 10, 774392) If you are an opium addict, ask God’s help to give up the habit.

('63', 379, 2, 12, 774476) 419. NOTES
('63', 379, 3, 13, 774487) LET RECEPTION COMMITTEES BEWARE
('63', 379, 4, 14, 774519) In pursuance of a circular letter addressed by Thakkar Bapa to the Provincial Harijan Sevak Sanghs, we have been receiving memoranda of expenses from the respective places visited by me during the Harijan tour in connection with the reception given to me in each place.
('63', 379, 4, 15, 774789) In a memorandum from Khandwa, where a purse of over RS.
('63', 379, 4, 16, 774845) 3,000 was presented, I find nearly Rs. 40 shown as the charges for printing the address presented to me and a certain sum for dresses for volunteers.
('63', 379, 4, 17, 774995) There are other items about which I say nothing, although they appear to me extravagant.
('63', 379, 4, 18, 775084) But to think that the expenses of the addresses, uniform for volunteers and the like should be debited against the purse makes the reception not only farcical but demoralizing.
('63', 379, 4, 19, 775261) If a reception has to be given, money for printed or illuminated addresses should be collected separately as such, and that after the purse has been collected.
('63', 379, 4, 20, 775421) A costly reception should never mar a Harijan tour.
('63', 379, 4, 21, 775473) It is wholly unnecessary.
('63', 379, 4, 22, 775499) Some kind of a demon stration, I suppose, is inevitable and necessary.
('63', 379, 4, 23, 775570) But when it is spon taneous, it ought not to cost a single pice, or if it must, every pice should be separately collected and in such a manner that it in no way affects the collection for the purse.
('63', 379, 4, 24, 775769) Caskets are unbecoming, addresses are unnecessary.
('63', 379, 4, 25, 775820) A brief report on their Harijan activities should take
('63', 380, 0, 1, 775875) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 381
('63', 380, 1, 2, 775919) the place of the addresses and it should be written in a clear hand writing and handed to me to enable me to deal with it.
('63', 380, 1, 3, 776042) This mention of the Khandwa expenses is not intended to cast any reflection upon the Reception Committee.
('63', 380, 1, 4, 776148) Probably many of the Committees have done what the Khandwa Committee has done.
('63', 380, 1, 5, 776227) They have evidently not realized the impropriety of making the Harijan purse pay for addres ses and caskets presented to one who claims to be a true servant of Harijans.
('63', 380, 2, 6, 776397) ALL ABOUT A LOST CHAIN
('63', 380, 3, 7, 776420) The reader will appreciate the following account of the discovery of a lost chain, which ultimately came to the Harijan cause, and that through the honesty of a Harijan.
('63', 380, 3, 8, 776590) R. M. Kumaraswami of Palla dam, Tamil Nad, writes:
('63', 380, 4, 9, 776641) REVERED MAHATMAJI,
('63', 380, 5, 10, 776660) On your way to Coimbatore from Tirupur during your recent visit, a
('63', 380, 6, 11, 776727) purse of Rs. 450 was given at Palladam.
('63', 380, 6, 12, 776767) There my sister’s daughter aged four
('63', 380, 7, 13, 776804) wanted to give her gold chain to you.
('63', 380, 7, 14, 776842) But my aunt did not like to give the
('63', 380, 8, 15, 776879) So she took it and kept it with her.
('63', 380, 8, 16, 776916) When you arrived at Palladam,
('63', 380, 9, 17, 776946) somehow my aunt lost the chain in the crowd.
('63', 380, 9, 18, 776991) I told her that the loss was a fine
('63', 380, 10, 19, 777027) for her refusing the child’s wish.
('63', 380, 11, 20, 777062) After two weeks we got the clue about the chain.
('63', 380, 11, 21, 777111) A Harijan boy about
('63', 380, 12, 22, 777131) 10 years old was fortunate enough to get that lost chain.
('63', 380, 12, 23, 777189) He was from a
('63', 380, 13, 24, 777203) neighbouring village.
('63', 380, 13, 25, 777225) After a fortnight, when we approached the boy’s father
('63', 380, 14, 26, 777280) who was in possession of the chain, he at first denied any knowledge of it.
('63', 380, 15, 27, 777356) was under a false fear of his being taken to task.
('63', 380, 15, 28, 777407) When I explained to him what
('63', 380, 16, 29, 777436) the object of your tour was and also that there was absolutely nothing wrong
('63', 380, 17, 30, 777513) in possessing lost property found by his son, he gladly took us into his
('63', 380, 18, 31, 777586) confidence and willingly returned the chain.
('63', 380, 18, 32, 777631) I gave him Rs. 25 as a present,
('63', 380, 19, 33, 777663) which he accepted with gratitude, and he has promised to give up his evil habit
('63', 380, 20, 34, 777743) of drinking.
('63', 380, 20, 35, 777756) He is considered to be one of the sincere and trustworthy men
('63', 380, 21, 36, 777818) among the Harijans here.
('63', 380, 22, 37, 777843) All the members of my family wish to send you this chain according to
('63', 380, 23, 38, 777913) the child’s wish.
('63', 380, 23, 39, 777931) I also wish, if you would kindly permit, to have the proceeds
('63', 380, 24, 40, 777993) of the chain earmarked for Harijan work at Palladam.
('63', 380, 24, 41, 778046) I will consider this a good
('63', 380, 25, 42, 778074) beginning for doing Harijan uplift work in these parts.
('63', 381, 0, 1, 778130) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 381, 1, 2, 778172) I have assured my correspondent that the proceeds of the chain will be earmarked as he wishes.
('63', 381, 1, 3, 778267) 1 He is, of course, wrong in thinking that lost property belongs to the finder.
('63', 381, 1, 4, 778347) It belongs to the state, if the owner cannot be traced.
