('63', 381, 2, 7, 778704) THEIR PLIGHT
('63', 381, 3, 8, 778717) P. Majmudar writes:
('63', 381, 4, 9, 778737) For want of work, or more truly speaking, because of untouchability, which debars them from avenues of employment open to the rest, Harijans were reported to be living on the undigested grains picked out from droppings of cattle.
('63', 381, 4, 10, 778967) I had the pain of recently witnessing such a disgusting scene in Gujarat.
('63', 381, 4, 11, 779041) I was visiting a village in Bhal district.
('63', 381, 4, 12, 779084) In the Bhangi quarter, I saw everywhere cattle dung spread for drying.
('63', 381, 4, 13, 779155) On enquiry into the cause of this, the Harijans residing in the quarters told me that they had so little employment that they had to maintain themselves on grains picked out from cattle dung collected by them.
('63', 381, 4, 14, 779365) After the dung was dried, they separated the undigested, halfchewed grains from the dung, washed them, dried them and ground them into powder which they eat in the form of chapatis.
('63', 381, 4, 15, 779547) I have not seen nor heard of such a practice amongst savarna Hindus anywhere.
('63', 381, 4, 16, 779625) It is impossible to question the evidence given by Sjt.
('63', 381, 4, 17, 779681) P. Majmudar of what he has seen through his own eyes.
('63', 381, 4, 18, 779735) Let caste Hindus understand what untouchability is doing to a portion of Hindu humanity.
('63', 381, 5, 19, 779824) Harijan, 13 4 1934
('63', 381, 6, 20, 779843) 1 This letter is not traceable.

('63', 382, 1, 2, 779919) 420. A REFORMER’S DIFFICULTY
('63', 382, 2, 3, 779948) A correspondent writes:
('63', 382, 3, 4, 779972) In the course of your drive against untouchability you make some remarks which seem to be inconsistent with your previous writings in the columns of Young India.
('63', 382, 3, 5, 780134) For instance, you wrote some years ago that the rule about restraint of inter dining was intended for the evolution of the soul but was no part of varnadharma.
('63', 382, 3, 6, 780294) Now, if you grant the necessity or the advisability of restraint upon inter dining for the evolution of the soul, how can you say, as you have now a days been saying, that for anyone to object to dine with an ‘untouchable’ on the ground of untouchability is a sin?
('63', 382, 3, 7, 780559) I agree with you that restraint upon inter dining is no part of varnadharma; but I do not understand why inter dining retards the evolution of the soul.
('63', 382, 3, 8, 780712) Here there is a double confusion.
('63', 382, 3, 9, 780746) In the first instance, restraint upon inter dining on the ground of untouchability is wholly different from the restraint based on the ground of the evolution of the soul.
('63', 382, 3, 10, 780918) The first restraint excludes a whole class whose very existence is challenged, the second excludes nobody on the ground of his birth in a particular class, but it may exclude those individuals who are addicted to particular habits.
('63', 382, 3, 11, 781150) Thus, restraint on the ground of untou chability will persist without reference to the person’s habits, while that on the ground of evolution of the soul will abate immediately the person excluded shedshis objectionable habits.
('63', 382, 3, 12, 781378) There is, therefore, no inconsistency between the Young India writing referred to and my present position.
('63', 382, 3, 13, 781485) Secondly, even if my opinion as expressed in Young India is indefensible, the correspondent’s doubt is solved by my showing, as I have shown, that my condemnation of objection to inter dining on the ground of untouchability has nothing to do with the restraint referred to in Young India, of which I have approved.
('63', 382, 3, 14, 781800) The correspondent further asks how I reconcile my attitude with the peremptory restrictions laid down in Vaishnavite literature.
('63', 382, 3, 15, 781929) The question is pertinent.
('63', 382, 3, 16, 781956) I must, however, confess my inability to recon cile the two positions.
('63', 382, 3, 17, 782027) Though I take pride in belonging to the Vaishn avite faith, my pride does not require my adherence to all the ceremonial observances prescribed in Vaishnavite literature.
('63', 382, 3, 18, 782198) I cling to the Vaishnavite faith because it inculcates universal love and, therefore, brotherhood; it lays the greatest emphasis on meticulous observance of truth and non violence and insists on unselfish devotion
('63', 383, 0, 1, 782412) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 383, 1, 2, 782454) to God.
('63', 383, 1, 3, 782462) In Hindu literature, religious and secular, the unadulterated condemna tion of narrowness, intolerance and bigotry by Vaishnavite saints and other writers is not to be beaten by any other writing.
('63', 383, 1, 4, 782659) I need not be disturbed, therefore, by ceremonial observances which are manifestly contrary to the spirit of Vaishnavism.
('63', 383, 1, 5, 782781) The correspondent concludes:
('63', 383, 2, 6, 782810) We cannot resolve our doubts ourselves.
('63', 383, 2, 7, 782850) We yield to your better judg ment.
('63', 383, 2, 8, 782885) But when we follow your teaching, we run the risk of being boycotted even by those who are near and dear to us.
('63', 383, 2, 9, 782997) What is to be done under such circu mstances?
('63', 383, 2, 10, 783043) This is a difficult question to answer and can only be deter mined by each one according to his or her individual ability to suffer.
('63', 383, 2, 11, 783176) Those who feel that untouchability is an evil cannot practise it in any shape or form.
('63', 383, 2, 12, 783263) In a matter of such grave importance, I should expect every reformer to have the courage of his or her convictions and the ability to brave all the social persecution that they may have to suffer.
('63', 383, 2, 13, 783460) Such has been the lot of reformers all the world over.
('63', 383, 2, 14, 783515) Harijan, 13 4 1934
('63', 383, 3, 15, 783534) 421.THE WRONG WAY
('63', 383, 4, 16, 783552) A friend who is interested in the Harijan cause sends me a collection of clippings from sanatanist writings which attribute to me all kinds of opinions and some of which even contain quotations from my writings mutilated in order to prejudice the masses against me.
('63', 383, 4, 17, 783818) He asks me to reply to this indictment.
('63', 383, 4, 18, 783858) It is not new to me.
('63', 383, 4, 19, 783879) Some of the counts in it I have answered from time to time.
('63', 383, 4, 20, 783939) Those who are prejudiced will not listen to any defence I may offer.
('63', 383, 4, 21, 784008) Those who are friendly are unaffected by charges, especially when they are wild as those in question undoubtedly are.
('63', 383, 4, 22, 784126) But, between the critics who will not be convinced and supporters who will not be seduced, there is always a middle class that would be swayed one way or the other.
('63', 383, 4, 23, 784291) The friend who has sent me the clippings probably belongs to that middle class.
('63', 383, 4, 24, 784371) His letter, therefore, is such as to demand a reply in these columns.
('63', 383, 4, 25, 784441) Some of the clippings are as follows:
('63', 383, 5, 26, 784479) 1. “The Mahabharata is a mass of rubbish from beginning to end.”
('63', 383, 6, 27, 784544) 2. “I do not regard Shri Krishna as an ‘avatar’ (incarnation) but as an ordinary man.”
('63', 383, 7, 28, 784631) 3. “I do not believe in morals.
('63', 383, 7, 29, 784663) I am a breaker of idols.”
('63', 384, 0, 1, 784689) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 385
('63', 384, 1, 2, 784733) 4. “The Dharma of Hindus is devilish, the Shastras are godless and rishis and munis are devils.” The inverted commas are in the original sanatanist writings.
('63', 384, 1, 3, 784891) There is no reference to Young India or Navajivan writings at the end of any of the quotations.
('63', 384, 1, 4, 784987) I have not the files of Young India or Nava jivan with me.
('63', 384, 1, 5, 785046) I have, therefore, to rely upon memory.
('63', 384, 1, 6, 785086) What I have said of the Mahabharata before and what I believe of it today is that it is like a rich diamond mine from which the deeper you dig the more diamonds you find.
('63', 384, 1, 7, 785257) What I have said of Krishna and what I believe of him today is that he is one of the many avatars.
('63', 384, 1, 8, 785356) I have never said that Hindu temples are brothels, but I have said and repeat now that some of them are like brothels.
('63', 384, 1, 9, 785475) I could never say ‘I do not believe in morals’, for with me religion and morality are convertible terms, as can be evidenced by all my writings.
('63', 384, 1, 10, 785620) I am, indeed, a breaker of idols, if I am also a worshipper of them.
('63', 384, 1, 11, 785689) I do not bow my head to false gods.
('63', 384, 1, 12, 785725) Quotation 4 is a blasphemy I am incapable of uttering.
('63', 384, 1, 13, 785780) If I had believed the dharma of the Hindus to be devilish, I should have said good bye to it long ago.
('63', 384, 1, 14, 785883) Sanatana Dharma can gain nothing by distortions or reckless writing in the pages of publications brought out by those who call themselves sanatanists.
('63', 384, 2, 15, 786034) Harijan, 13 4 1934
('63', 384, 3, 16, 786053) 422. SOME AMENDMENTS 1
('63', 384, 4, 17, 786076) The following three amendments have been received from the head office of the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('63', 384, 6, 18, 786175) A rider clause may be added to Rule (5), para 2:—To fulfil this desire, the 25% quota and 50% quota of the principal cities appropriated by the Central Board will also be devoted to direct welfare work only.
('63', 384, 6, 19, 786383) A sum of Rs. 25,000 now donated by Mr. Birla shall be earmarked for meeting the establishment and travelling charges of the Central Board and office.
('63', 384, 7, 20, 786533) 1 For the text of the Draft Rules to which these are amendments, vide “Opinion Invited”,2 3 1934.
('63', 385, 0, 1, 786631) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 385, 1, 2, 786673) Central Board will make special efforts to take separate collections for paying its share of administrative and propaganda expenses incurred by Provincial Boards now and hereafter.
('63', 385, 3, 3, 786854) The following be substituted for Rule (9): (9) In view of the difficulty of raising additional funds in the provinces soon after the tour, the Provincial Secretary, as also District Secretaries, should cease to be officemen, but should become necessary parts of the welfare schemes.
('63', 385, 3, 4, 787137) The charges of the provincial staff needed for supervising schemes in the districts will thus be met from the 75% quota and taken from the districts in proportion to their budgets.
('63', 385, 3, 5, 787318) This rule, however, will operate only for one year from the date when new financial relations arising out of the Purse Fund are established.
('63', 385, 5, 6, 787459) The following be added as Rule (10):
('63', 385, 6, 7, 787496) Welfare schemes must be submitted by Provincial Boards within two months after the expiry of the tour in their respective provinces.
('63', 385, 6, 8, 787629) Failing this, the grants under the old arrangement will be stopped.
('63', 385, 6, 9, 787697) Grants under the new arrangement will be paid only after the welfare scheme submitted by the province is approved of by the Central Board.
('63', 385, 6, 10, 787836) These amendments should be carefully considered by all concerned, especially Provincial Boards, and their comments sent to the head office without delay.
('63', 385, 6, 11, 787990) It will be observed that the rider to Rule (5), para 2, carried out to greater perfection the original intention that donations received for Harijan service should be as far as possible devoted solely to welfare work.
('63', 385, 6, 12, 788208) And this object can be easily fulfilled, if Provincial Boards will heartily co operate and realize that the most expeditious way of driving out untouchability is to be prepared for, and render, silent, selfless service to Harijans.
('63', 385, 6, 13, 788440) Such work serves a threefold purpose.
('63', 385, 6, 14, 788478) Requiring, as it does, purity among the workers, it constitutes the best propaganda amongst the sanatanists.
('63', 385, 6, 15, 788587) No amount of intellectual argument will ever convince those in whom a false religious belief is deeply seated.
('63', 385, 6, 16, 788698) But the purity and gentleness of the reformer will undoubtedly do so.
('63', 385, 6, 17, 788768) Secondly, selfless work amongst Harijans will not only enable the reformers to overcome some, if not all, of the bad customs and habits that are to be seen among them but
('63', 385, 7, 18, 788939) 1 The reference is to the special desire of Gandhiji that not a single rupee out of the Purse Fund should be spent on administration and propaganda but that it should be utilized for the execution of schemes for Harijan welfare work.
('63', 386, 0, 1, 789173) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 387
('63', 386, 1, 2, 789217) will also strengthen their faith in Hinduism, which they have hitherto known only as a means of their degradation.
('63', 386, 1, 3, 789332) Thirdly, the high stan dard of character required of those who render personal service to Harijans cannot but be a matter of inward joy to the workers.
('63', 386, 1, 4, 789484) The second and third amendments do not deserve any comment, except this—that the third has evidently been found necessary because of the negligence on the part of Boards of the Provinces in sending up their schemes of constructive work.
('63', 386, 1, 5, 789721) I am fully aware that, strange as it may seem, to produce a good constructive scheme and equally good workers who would faithfully carry it out is far more difficult than to collect funds.

('63', 386, 5, 10, 790083) On one side of me is Thakkar Bapa, on the other is Om and all around are sitting the rest of the party.

('63', 386, 5, 13, 790235) The rains have already set in here.

('63', 386, 5, 15, 790335) Deck journey, therefore, is bearable.
('63', 386, 5, 16, 790373) It is nine in the morning now.

('63', 386, 5, 20, 790536) My health is good.
('63', 386, 5, 21, 790555) I allow myself sufficient rest.
('63', 386, 5, 22, 790587) I don’t over strain the body.
('63', 386, 5, 23, 790617) If one were to listen to all the advice that doctors give, one would never leave one’s bed.
('63', 386, 5, 24, 790709) In the dispute between the workers and the mill owners in Ahmedabad, in my view the latter are more at fault.

('63', 386, 5, 29, 791062) The resolution was nothing but a threat.

('63', 386, 5, 31, 791208) My letter had an effect.
('63', 386, 5, 32, 791233) It may be said, rather, that differences arose among the mill owners themselves.

('63', 393, 5, 7, 801621) 432. WHY ONLY BIHAR?
('63', 393, 6, 8, 801642) A student writes.
('63', 393, 7, 9, 801660) A science student has no right to disbelieve what is beyond his comprehension.
('63', 393, 7, 10, 801739) A science student should be humble.
('63', 393, 7, 11, 801775) Instead of brushing aside whatever he hears, he must give it some thought.
('63', 393, 7, 12, 801850) There are very few things in this world which we are able to understand.
('63', 393, 7, 13, 801923) Many things are beyond our understanding.
('63', 393, 7, 14, 801965) That is exactly why the learned become more humble as they acquire more knowledge, for the knowledge of the learned man consists in realizing his immense ignorance.
('63', 393, 7, 15, 802130) The deeper he goes, the more he realizes that he knows nothing.
('63', 393, 7, 16, 802194) Moreover, most of what he knows is just surmise.
('63', 393, 7, 17, 802243) I have no intention of running down science by writing this.
('63', 393, 7, 18, 802304) Though infini tesimal, the knowledge we acquire has its uses.
('63', 393, 7, 19, 802366) But compared to what remains to be acquired, what is already acquired is less than a drop in the ocean.
('63', 393, 7, 20, 802470) All life in this world originates from the same root.
('63', 393, 7, 21, 802524) Hence all are fundamentally one.
('63', 393, 7, 22, 802557) These include all things from vegetable life to human life.
('63', 393, 7, 23, 802617) For one who understands, the misery of one living crea ture is the misery of all, and the happiness of one is the happiness of all.
('63', 393, 7, 24, 802749) Hence it is sacrifice that has always contained and still contains true happiness.
('63', 393, 7, 25, 802832) We see this rule working in a family.
('63', 393, 7, 26, 802870) Everyone is unhappy if the father is unhappy.
('63', 393, 7, 27, 802916) And everyone is affected by his sinful ways.
('63', 393, 7, 28, 802961) Hence, if this student accepts the oneness of all living creatures, everyone would be included in the punishment of Bihar.
('63', 393, 7, 29, 803084) Those who have not felt the earthquake have not remained untouched.
('63', 393, 7, 30, 803152) If they do not directly experience, they should be considered ignorant to that extent.
('63', 393, 7, 31, 803239) So, the science student would probably agree that there
('63', 393, 8, 32, 803295) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('63', 393, 8, 33, 803332) The correspondent, a science student, could not accept Gandhiji’s view that untouchability was one of the causes of the Bihar earthquake.
('63', 394, 0, 1, 803470) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 395
('63', 394, 1, 2, 803514) is not much sense in asking: “Why only Bihar?” Why only Bihar and no other province?
('63', 394, 1, 3, 803599) Who are we to put this question to God?
('63', 394, 1, 4, 803639) His ways are inscrutable.
('63', 394, 1, 5, 803665) Hence, where reason cannot function, it is faith that works.
('63', 394, 1, 6, 803726) We can prove with the help of several illustrations that physical events are related to things spiritual.
('63', 394, 1, 7, 803832) Physical things originate from the same source of energy as spiritual, and so there is no impassable gulf between physical and spiritual things.
('63', 394, 1, 8, 803977) Rain is a physical phenomenon; it is no doubt related to human happiness and unhappiness; if so, how could it fail to be related to his good and bad deeds?
('63', 394, 1, 9, 804133) We know of no period in world history when countless people have not related events like earthquakes to sinful deeds of man.
('63', 394, 1, 10, 804258) Even today, religious minded people everywhere believe in such a relationship.
('63', 394, 1, 11, 804337) It can never be known for which sins of ours such calamities overtake us.
('63', 394, 1, 12, 804411) The golden rule is for each one of us to regard them as punishment for one’s individual and social sins.
('63', 394, 1, 13, 804516) It is pride and ignorance if one says, ‘This happened because of your sins’; but it is humility, it is wisdom, if one says, ‘It happened because of my sins.’ I have never tried to convince those who do not consider untouchability a sin that the earthquake is the result 1 of it.
('63', 394, 1, 14, 804795) They may well believe that it is the result of my sin.
('63', 394, 1, 15, 804850) Imperfect man can never finally determine what is right and what is wrong in such matters.
('63', 394, 1, 16, 804941) My job is over if I could convince the reader that the earthquake is the result of our sins.
('63', 394, 1, 17, 805034) Then the people who regard untouchability as a great sin are bound to connect it with the earthquake and endeavour to expiate and wipe out the blot as soon as possible.
('63', 394, 2, 18, 805203) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 15 4 1934

('63', 397, 5, 6, 809425) 438. LETTER TO K. M. MUNSHI
('63', 397, 6, 7, 809453) JORHAT, April 16, 1934
('63', 397, 7, 8, 809476) BHAI MUNSHI, I have your letter.
('63', 397, 7, 9, 809509) It has helped me.
('63', 397, 7, 10, 809527) Your criticism of the defi nition is correct.
('63', 397, 7, 11, 809573) You have shown how the certificates which I have been receiving for the draft are superficial.
('63', 397, 7, 12, 809668) At present I am working in such a hurry that I get no time for second thoughts.
('63', 397, 7, 13, 809748) The mistake which you have discovered should have been evident to me.
('63', 397, 7, 14, 809818) I am returning the draft to you so that it may help you in further scrutiny, and I am also sending a copy of the revised draft.
('63', 397, 7, 15, 809946) If you notice any mistake in that too, do point it out.
('63', 397, 7, 16, 810002) If Lilavati can devote herself blindly to small industries without thinking about other things, the venture may succeed, otherwise they will be going round and round like the bullock at the oilpress.
('63', 397, 7, 17, 810202) The only difference will be that there is an observant oilman following the blind bullock and so some oil is extracted.
('63', 397, 7, 18, 810322) But in this case the oil press of swadeshi will go on working and there will be no result at the end.
('63', 397, 7, 19, 810424) Mill cloth, sugar mills, etc., are excluded from my definition, and khadi, jaggery, etc., are protected.
('63', 397, 7, 20, 810529) We can, and should, manage only these.
('63', 397, 7, 21, 810568) It is not a small field.
('63', 397, 7, 22, 810593) Small industries would be crushed if mixed up with big ones.
('63', 397, 7, 23, 810654) Some change in the definition occurred to me even as I was writing this.
('63', 397, 7, 24, 810727) I have made it by adding an adjective, intended to exclude intoxicating substances.
('63', 397, 7, 25, 810811) I do not know whether or not you smoke.
('63', 397, 7, 26, 810851) My son Harilal does.
('63', 397, 7, 27, 810872) One day when the matter came up for discussion, he said: “I smoke Madras cheroots, not foreign cigars.” In spite of his generous encouragement, the Madras cheroot would be excluded from my definition.
('63', 397, 7, 28, 811073) The cheroot will find its way out, as today it is doing.
('63', 397, 7, 29, 811130) I too entertain the fear which you do regarding Council entry.
('63', 397, 7, 30, 811193) I have other fears too.
('63', 397, 7, 31, 811217) But I think that the thing has come to stay.
('63', 397, 7, 32, 811262) The Congress will always have in it a party favouring it.
('63', 397, 7, 33, 811320) I have come to
('63', 398, 0, 1, 811335) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 399
('63', 398, 1, 2, 811379) believe that it would be impossible and improper to ignore it.
('63', 398, 1, 3, 811442) I, therefore, have made up my mind to give all possible help in strengthening it.
('63', 398, 1, 4, 811524) But this will not go well with civil disobedience.
('63', 398, 1, 5, 811575) From prison, I can give little direct help.
('63', 398, 1, 6, 811619) The strength which it may receive from the fact of my imprisonment itself will be another matter.
('63', 398, 1, 7, 811717) My hopes are pinned on you and Bhulabhai.
('63', 398, 1, 8, 811759) I do not know who else might go.
('63', 398, 1, 9, 811792) I don’t feel inclined to press anybody.
('63', 398, 1, 10, 811832) Hence, Rajagopala chari, Rajendrababu, Jairamdas, etc., will probably stay out.
('63', 398, 1, 11, 811912) I have not discussed the subject with anyone.
('63', 398, 1, 12, 811958) As a result of my decision regarding civil disobedience, they are free for the time being to do as they like.
('63', 398, 1, 13, 812068) Possibly Jawaharlal also may be tempted.
('63', 398, 1, 14, 812109) If firm minded, capable, selfless and devoted workers join, Council entry may do some good.
('63', 398, 1, 15, 812201) But most of such people would not be interested in the goings on of legislatures.
('63', 398, 1, 16, 812283) The democracy of my conception is a different thing altogether.
('63', 398, 1, 17, 812347) It can be moulded outside, not inside the legislatures.
('63', 398, 1, 18, 812403) The latter will take the right shape when such democracy has come into existence outside them.
('63', 398, 1, 19, 812498) Today everywhere democracy waits on legislatures and nothing is done.
('63', 398, 1, 20, 812568) I want to have legislatures that will follow the wishes of the people.
('63', 398, 1, 21, 812639) I do not see at present the right atmosphere for such legislatures.
('63', 398, 1, 22, 812707) I think that it is being created.
('63', 398, 1, 23, 812741) Civil disobedience has succeeded in no small measure.
('63', 398, 1, 24, 812795) I do not regret a single step taken in connection with it.
('63', 398, 1, 25, 812854) Every step has been taken at the right time for it is my firm conviction that it was not I that took the decision every time but that it was Satyanarayana 1 who prompted my decisions.
('63', 398, 1, 26, 813038) I let myself be led by Him.
('63', 398, 1, 27, 813066) Council entry will remain a permanent feature of the Congress like civil disobedience and constructive work.
('63', 398, 1, 28, 813175) It will not receive step motherly treatment.
('63', 398, 1, 29, 813220) But I do not know just now how far I shall be able to interest myself in it.
('63', 398, 1, 30, 813297) Constructive work has already become part of civil disobedience.
('63', 398, 1, 31, 813362) I can see my way clearly in that sphere.
('63', 398, 1, 32, 813403) But it is the love of friends and circumstances that has dragged me into the Council entry programme.
('63', 398, 1, 33, 813505) I regard myself qualified for the first two.
('63', 398, 1, 34, 813550) Not for this.
('63', 398, 1, 35, 813564) Let us see what happens.
('63', 398, 2, 36, 813589) Blessings from

('63', 409, 2, 9, 832657) 454. INTERVIEW TO AMERICAN MISSIONARY 1
('63', 409, 3, 10, 832697) JORHAT, [April 18, 1934] 2
('63', 409, 4, 11, 832724) Gandhiji had an interesting talk with an American missionary who asked for his views about conversion.
('63', 409, 4, 12, 832827) He repeated the opinion he has often given that he did not believe in conversion by human agency.
('63', 409, 4, 13, 832925) Seekers after Truth were in the same position as the blind men in the Indian parable who went to see an elephant, or rather in a worse position.
('63', 409, 4, 14, 833070) For, if the physically blind lacked in sight, they were compensa ted for it to some extent by the enhanced power of other organs of sense.
('63', 409, 4, 15, 833209) But seekers after Truth could only see as through a glass, darkly, so far as inward sight was concerned.
('63', 409, 4, 16, 833314) It would, therefore, be sheer presumption on their part to seek to “con vert” others to their own faith.
('63', 409, 4, 17, 833419) God had as many ways of approaching Him as there were human beings.
('63', 409, 5, 18, 833487) Upon the missionary friend attempting a comparison between Jesus and other men revered by humanity, Gandhiji said that such comparison was fruitless.
('63', 409, 5, 19, 833637) Jesus of history was not the same as the Jesus whom Christians adored.
('63', 409, 5, 20, 833708) For them He was the living God of their conception.
('63', 409, 5, 21, 833760) Similarly he himself believed in the Krishna of his own imagination, who was identical with God and had not much to do with the historic Krishna about whom there was a mass of conflicting evidence.
('63', 409, 5, 22, 833958) Historical persons were dead.
('63', 409, 5, 23, 833988) The mystical incarnations were living ideas—more real than earthly existences.
('63', 409, 5, 24, 834067) Religion could never be based on history, for, if it was so based, faith would be undermined.
('63', 409, 5, 25, 834161) Tulsidas therefore clinched the point by saying that nama (the name) was greater than Rama.
('63', 409, 5, 26, 834253) Harijan, 4 5 1934

('63', 410, 1, 2, 834523) 455. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS April 18, 1934
('63', 410, 2, 3, 834566) That there can be, and should be, co operation with the Government in the legislatures was the opinion expressed by Mr. Gandhi in an interview today.
('63', 410, 3, 4, 834716) Asked whether, in giving his blessing to the formation of the Swaraj Party, he meant that Congressmen should enter the legislatures for the specific purpose of getting “repressive” laws repealed and the White Paper Constitution rejected, Mr. Gandhi said that he could not define the policy of Congress parliamentarians just as he did not define the policy followed by Pandit Malaviya and the late Mr. C. R. Das although he was instrumental in handing the reins of the Congress to the Swaraj Party.
('63', 410, 3, 5, 835214) If the Swaraj Party was revived and they asked him for advice as to their line of action in the legislatures, he would advise them according to the circumstances that might present themselves at the time his advice was asked for.
('63', 410, 4, 6, 835444) Asked whether he did not think that there could be occasions for cooperation with the Government in the legislatures, Mr. Gandhi replied: Certainly I can conceive many instances in which there can be, and should be, co operation.
('63', 410, 5, 7, 835674) Asked whether members of the old Swaraj Party now in the legislatures, Provincial and Central, should be allowed to rejoin the new Swaraj Party, Mr. Gandhi said: They will be members for the asking.
('63', 410, 6, 8, 835873) Replying to further questions he said: I am sure the fact that they did not resign their seats in obedi ence to the Lahore resolution will make no difference.
('63', 410, 6, 9, 836032) Anyone that adopts the policy of the Swaraj Party will be entitled to membership no matter what his past views may have been.
('63', 410, 6, 10, 836158) Suppose I become a Congressman now and adopt the programme of the Swaraj Party, I should be entitled to membership.
('63', 410, 7, 11, 836274) In reply to another question Mr. Gandhi said: If the All India Congress Committee endorse the revival of the Swaraj Party, the party will occupy the same place that it did when a resolution was adopted at Patna just after Mr. C. R. Das’s death.
('63', 410, 8, 12, 836519) Q. It would seem from your Patna statement 1 that the suspension of civil disobedience is only temporary.
('63', 410, 8, 13, 836625) Do you mean that it will have to be resorted to at least by those who are sufficiently skilled in it in the near or distant future?

('63', 411, 3, 8, 837686) With regard to the passage: “Physical non violence combined with boycott and disobedience is only a mask for spiritual violence and, in depriving it of its outlet and condemning it to use ethical language, it intensified the inward passion of hate” in The Statesman’s editorial on the Patna statement, Mr. Gandhi observed: If the writer of the editorial had used the expression, “might only be a mask for spiritual violence” instead of saying “is only a mask for spiritual violence”, I should have taken no exception to it.

('63', 411, 3, 10, 838386) We never had any hate for a single Briton, not even those like General Dyer who in our opinion had done grave wrong to thousands of innocent men and women.

('63', 415, 2, 3, 844536) DIBRUGARH, April 19, 1934
('63', 415, 3, 4, 844562) Interviewed this morning by the Associated Press regarding the Home Member’s statement 1 in the Assembly, Mr. Gandhi, who is staying at Gosala Ashram, Dibrugarh said: I have no views on the Home Member’s statement because, being continuously travelling, I have not been able to see it.
('63', 415, 3, 5, 844848) It has just come to me, but I have not yet read it.
('63', 415, 3, 6, 844900) It is, therefore, impossible for me to pronounce an opinion as to whether the statement is cautious or halting or magnanimous.
('63', 415, 4, 7, 845027) He added that it was doubtful whether he could make any comment on the statement while he would be touring, having the whole of his mind concentrated upon Harijan work.
('63', 415, 5, 8, 845196) Replying to a question whether he suggested that Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru should be allowed to participate in the deliberations of the Ranchi Conference, Mr. Gandhi said: I can only say that any conclusions that any conference may arrive at can only be inconclusive without the presence of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.

('63', 416, 5, 26, 847895) 464. A HARIJAN’S QUESTIONS ANSWERED
('63', 416, 6, 27, 847931) A Harijan sends the following questions for me to answer.
('63', 416, 7, 28, 847989) 1. Mahatmaji, why are you so much interested in our cause?
('63', 416, 8, 29, 848048) 2. If all religions are one in your consideration, are the Christians not entitled to combat untouchability?
('63', 417, 0, 1, 848157) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 417, 1, 2, 848199) 3. In what way will our people be benefited if untouchability is removed?
('63', 417, 2, 3, 848273) 4. Why should we enter Hindu temples?
('63', 417, 3, 4, 848311) 5. Did not the Hindu deities that were incarnated oppress us?
('63', 417, 4, 5, 848373) 6. Arya and un Arya are the divisions created for us.
('63', 417, 4, 6, 848427) What harm is there if we remain separated?
('63', 417, 5, 7, 848470) 7. Even in untouchables there are many sub castes.
('63', 417, 5, 8, 848521) What do you propose to do with this problem?
('63', 417, 6, 9, 848566) 8. Once you said that swaraj can be attained the day untouchability is removed.
('63', 417, 6, 10, 848646) Is this present propaganda directed to that end?
('63', 417, 7, 11, 848695) 9. If so, are you going to give equivalent rights with other Hindus to our crores of untouchables?
('63', 417, 8, 12, 848794) 10. Instead of opening temples and eradicating untouchability, suffice
('63', 417, 9, 13, 848865) it if you make provision for our livelihood.
('63', 417, 9, 14, 848910) They are good questions.
('63', 417, 9, 15, 848935) My answers are: 1. I am interested in the Harijan cause for the sake of purifying myself of the taint of untouchability and doing penance for the sin; and, being jealous of the reputation of the faith I profess, I am anxious that fellow members of the faith should also purge themselves of the same.
('63', 417, 9, 16, 849235) 2. Not only are the Christians entitled, but it is their duty, to combat untouchability in their own midst.
('63', 417, 9, 17, 849343) But if the question is that Christians should combat untouchability in Hinduism, my answer is that they simply cannot do it, because untouchables of Hinduism should not be untouchables to Christians.
('63', 417, 9, 18, 849543) The antiuntouchability movement means weaning Hindus from their error.
('63', 417, 9, 19, 849614) This cannot be effectively done by non Hindus, even as Hindus cannot bring about religious reform among Christians or Mussalmans.
('63', 417, 9, 20, 849744) If the question means that Christians should combat untouchability among Hindus by converting untouchables to Christianity, they do not advance the cause in any shape or form, the cause being reformation among caste Hindus.
('63', 417, 9, 21, 849968) If the latter repented of their sin, the Harijans would be delivered from the yoke of untouchability in a moment.
('63', 417, 9, 22, 850082) Conversion can never do it.
('63', 417, 9, 23, 850110) It can only add to the prevailing bitterness and intro duce a disturbing factor in a situation which is already bad but which, owing to the work of the Harijan Sevak Sanghs and other movements of internal reform in Hinduism, is steadily improving, untouchability being daily undermined.
('63', 418, 0, 1, 850397) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 419
('63', 418, 1, 2, 850441) 3. In many ways.
('63', 418, 1, 3, 850458) I enumerate some below: (i) Caste Hindus will be purified by their repentance.
('63', 418, 1, 4, 850537) (ii) The economic, moral, social and political status of Harijans will be improved at a bound by the removal of an artificial barrier which has been stunting their growth all along.
('63', 418, 1, 5, 850719) (iii) Untouchability that is imposed on untouchables is such a poison that it has overtaken those living within its zone.
('63', 418, 1, 6, 850841) And therefore, Hindus, Christians, Mussalmans and others have become untouchables to one another.
('63', 418, 1, 7, 850939) Real removal of untouchability must bring us all together and thus promote a heart unity of the different communities of India.
('63', 418, 1, 8, 851067) (iv) Removal of untouchability with all its implications must mean a great contribution to the promotion of universal brotherhood.
('63', 418, 1, 9, 851198) 4. Harijans need not enter Hindu temples, if they do not wish it.
('63', 418, 1, 10, 851264) But they should, if they have faith in them.
('63', 418, 1, 11, 851309) The temple entry movement has for its object, not the entering by Harijans into Hindu temples, but the opening of these temples to all those Harijans who wish to enter them for worship.
('63', 418, 1, 12, 851495) In other words, it is a movement of repentance and change of heart in caste Hindus.
('63', 418, 1, 13, 851579) 5. I should be sorry if I found that the Hindu deities oppressed Harijans, and if they did, they were certainly not beneficent deities, but evil ones to be shunned.
('63', 418, 1, 14, 851744) 6. He would be a bold man who is able to say today with any degree of success who is Arya and who is un Arya.
('63', 418, 1, 15, 851854) Historians tell us that a blending of the two took place centuries ago.
('63', 418, 1, 16, 851926) If now a sharp division is attempted, it will harm not only Hindus, both caste and outcaste, but it will harm the whole of India and, by implication, the whole of humanity.
('63', 418, 1, 17, 852099) 7. When untouchability practised by caste Hindus is radically removed, its offshoot among untouchables will automatically wither.
('63', 418, 1, 18, 852229) 8. I should assert the statement again.
('63', 418, 1, 19, 852269) But the present propa ganda is directed only to the purification of caste Hindus and, there fore, of Hindus.
('63', 418, 1, 20, 852378) And when that purification is demonstrably attained, not only swaraj but many other desirable results will follow, as day follows night.
('63', 418, 1, 21, 852515) The word “swaraj” as here used does not mean a mere legal status but something far better and more lasting.
('63', 418, 1, 22, 852623) I would call it an organic status evolved from within.
('63', 418, 1, 23, 852678) 9. Whatever meaning may be given to the word “swaraj”, re 
('63', 419, 0, 1, 852737) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 419, 1, 2, 852779) moval of untouchability will be a fraud if it does not carry with it the enjoyment by the freed Hindus of precisely the same rights as the other Hindus and all other communities may enjoy under it.
('63', 419, 1, 3, 852977) 10. It is beyond me, a single, poor mortal, to make provision for the livelihood of millions.
('63', 419, 1, 4, 853071) That can only be achieved by their whole effort and God’s grace.
('63', 419, 1, 5, 853136) But, if temples are flung open to Harijans and untouchability is eradicated, the dead weight that is grinding them down will have lifted, and they will have an equal opportunity with the rest of their fellow men for earning an honest livelihood.
('63', 419, 2, 6, 853382) Harijan, 20 4 1934
('63', 419, 3, 7, 853401) 465. HOW THEY SHOULD ACT
('63', 419, 4, 8, 853426) The reader is aware that I have dissuaded Harijans from pressing for representation on Harijan boards, for the very simple and complete reason that these boards are meant to be composed of savarna Hindus who regard untouchability as a sin and who would do reparation to Harijans for past wrongs done to them.
('63', 419, 4, 9, 853735) Savarna Hindus are, therefore, debtors and Harijans creditors.
('63', 419, 4, 10, 853798) When debtors consider the ways and means of discharging their obligations, it is they alone who have to frame their proposals for the acceptance of creditors, who have their own boards which consider such proposals and accept or reject them or advise amendments before acceptance.
('63', 419, 4, 11, 854079) I have, there fore, suggested the formation of advisory committees of Harijans to assist Harijan Seva Sangh boards.
('63', 419, 4, 12, 854195) Writing on my suggestion, a Harijan correspondent says:
('63', 419, 5, 13, 854251) If you will kindly paint a picture of an ideal Harijan advisory commit tee, what it should do, how it should act and how it should assert itself, I shall certainly be able to have a clear cut idea of what it should be.
('63', 419, 5, 14, 854470) I feel also this to be essential, in view of the necessity of establishing such committees.
('63', 419, 5, 15, 854562) These are pertinent questions.
('63', 419, 5, 16, 854593) I should suggest the formation of compact, small representative committees who would truly represent the opinion of local Harijans.
('63', 419, 5, 17, 854725) They would frame rules for the conduct of their proceedings and formulate their expectations of savarna Hindus and generally watch the proceedings of Harijan boards.
('63', 419, 5, 18, 854891) These advisory committees, wherever they are formed, would advise Harijan boards of their existence and show their preparedness to help the latter.
('63', 419, 5, 19, 855039) If the boards are sincere in their desire to discharge their debt, that is, to serve Harijans, they will establish the friendliest contact with
('63', 420, 0, 1, 855183) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 421
('63', 420, 1, 2, 855227) the advisory committees, and perfect co operation and harmony will prevail.
('63', 420, 1, 3, 855303) There may be friction in the beginning because of mutual sus picion.
('63', 420, 1, 4, 855372) Harijan boards, being naturally better organized and better off in every respect, will have to exercise tact in handling what may appear to be extravagant demands.
('63', 420, 1, 5, 855536) Advisory committees would en deavour to be considerate.
('63', 420, 1, 6, 855592) The more considerate they are, the better able they will be to help themselves.
('63', 420, 1, 7, 855672) From their ability to conduct themselves in a dignified manner, they will learn the art of asserting themselves if the occasion ever arises.
('63', 420, 1, 8, 855813) For they should know that savarna Hindus will never be able to discharge their debt except with the co operation of Harijans.
('63', 420, 1, 9, 855939) But the question of asserting themselves does not arise just yet, because the vast mass of Harijans have been rendered so completely helpless that they have no power of resisting injustice, even if they wanted to.
('63', 420, 1, 10, 856153) Let me explain what I mean.
('63', 420, 1, 11, 856181) Harijan boards have three functions, to raise the economic, social and religious status of Harijans, or to put it in another way, to remove the difficulties that savarna Hindus have for centuries put in the way of Harijans raising their heads in any department of life.
('63', 420, 1, 12, 856451) Thus the Harijan boards have to provide wells, scholarships, boarding houses, schools and social amenities, wherever the need arises.
('63', 420, 1, 13, 856585) In all these, the general body of Harijans simply take the help wherever it is offered.
('63', 420, 1, 14, 856673) Advisory committees can, therefore, help the cause and themselves by making useful suggestions to the boards and also rendering such help as they themselves can to those whom they represent.
('63', 420, 1, 15, 856864) Thus only will they acquire the power of asserting themselves.
('63', 420, 1, 16, 856927) In short, advisory com mittees will best help the cause by taking up internal reform and causing an awakening among the Harijan masses, so that they may begin to realize that they are men and women entitled to the same rights as are enjoyed by the other members of the society to which they belong.
('63', 420, 1, 17, 857226) Harijan, 20 4 1934

('63', 422, 6, 12, 859776) 469. STATEMENT TO ASSOCIATED PRESS 1
('63', 422, 7, 13, 859813) TINSUKHIA, April 20, 1934 I have not noticed any active opposition from conservative upper classes as you call it and I have certainly had considerable active support in the shape of money, as also promises of constructive work.
('63', 422, 7, 14, 860042) Strange as it may appear, even in Assam, whilst the Harijans have naturally laid stress upon the necessity of educational and econo mic betterment, they have bitterly complained of social dis abilities and bar against entry into temples and Namghars (places of worship).
('63', 422, 7, 15, 860313) They feel the sting of inferiority underlying the social and religious restrictions.
('63', 422, 7, 16, 860398) I believe, however, that these are fast melting away and public opinion is gathering in favour of the removal of such restric tions.
('63', 422, 7, 17, 860531) I said the problem in Assam was complex, because indigenous Harijans and coolies from provinces are all regarded as Harijans, whether they were so regarded in the provinces or not.
('63', 422, 7, 18, 860712) Theirs is, therefore, not an enviable lot.
('63', 422, 7, 19, 860755) They present a problem of peculiar difficulty, because they are settlers in Assam, holding land in their own right and if they are not well looked after, they must present increasingly greater difficulties; but I am hoping that the Assam leaders, as a result of the anti untouchability campaign, will seriously
('63', 422, 8, 20, 861066) 1 The statement was made in answer to questions from an Associated Press correspondent.
('63', 423, 0, 1, 861154) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 423, 1, 2, 861196) deal with the problem and help these coolies to become honourable citizens.

('63', 423, 2, 4, 861293) 470. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TINSUKHIA 1

('63', 423, 4, 6, 861351) Alluding to the incident 2, Gandhiji said that if anybody had insulted these friends, it was wrong.

('63', 423, 5, 11, 861883) He wanted money only if he could carry with it the hearts of the donors.
('63', 423, 5, 12, 861956) If a single donor gave him one crore of rupees, he could not abolish untouchability; but he could undertake the task without a single pie, if he could carry with him the hearts of one crore of caste Hindus.
('63', 423, 5, 13, 862163) Let them know what he meant by the removal of untouchability.

('63', 423, 5, 16, 862496) The root cause was the distinction of high and low, i.e., untouchability.

('63', 423, 5, 18, 862671) No human being could be unclean by birth.

('63', 436, 3, 7, 887255) 489. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 2
('63', 436, 4, 8, 887285) April 25, 1934 It grieves me to have to state that sanatanist friends have given up all sense of self restraint whether in language or in action.
('63', 436, 4, 9, 887431) This morning when I alighted at a quarter past two at Jashidih, black flags were being waved prominently with all kinds of shouts.
('63', 436, 4, 10, 887562) It was with difficulty that I was taken to a car.
('63', 436, 4, 11, 887612) Lathis rained upon the hood of the car.
('63', 436, 4, 12, 887652) One lathi or stone, I cannot definitely say which—Shashibabu, who was occupying the same car, is positive that it was a stone—was aimed at the pane at the back of the car.
('63', 436, 4, 13, 887824) Fortunately I was the only occupant in the back seat and was sitting in a corner when the pane fell just on my side.
('63', 436, 4, 14, 887941) I would certainly have been seriously hurt if I had been sitting in the centre.
('63', 436, 4, 15, 888021) And if there had been more occupants, one of us would have been hurt without doubt.
('63', 436, 4, 16, 888105) That the hood was not broken to pieces was no fault of those who wielded heavy lathis.
('63', 436, 4, 17, 888192) I was not prepared for this wild demonstration.
('63', 436, 4, 18, 888240) I would like to appeal to the best minds among sanatanists and suggest that sanatana dharma will be ill served by vulgarity and violence.
('63', 436, 4, 19, 888378) In Buxar, though there was a boisterous demonstration, nothing happened to cars but there was a row between sanatanists and reformers.
('63', 436, 4, 20, 888513) As soon as I saw three broken heads and one injured arm among reformist volunteers and on learning that sanatanists were also hurt, I sent Thakkar Bapa to see how they were and went to hospital myself where injuries were being examined.
('63', 436, 4, 21, 888750) There were broken heads among them also.
('63', 436, 4, 22, 888791) I am investigating the Buxar incident and if I find that the reformer volunteers were guilty, I should most decidedly do such penance as lies within my power, for in a struggle essentially

('63', 437, 1, 3, 889298) The pity of it all, however, is that demonstration on the part of sanatanists should be at all neces sary.
('63', 437, 1, 4, 889405) They must know that I have no violence in me and I want no compulsion in any shape or form.

('63', 437, 2, 12, 890208) 490. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, DEOGHAR 1
('63', 437, 3, 13, 890249) April 26, 1934 It is a matter of great pleasure to me to have been able to revisit this holy place.
('63', 437, 3, 14, 890349) My ancestors had visited it.
('63', 437, 3, 15, 890378) But I admit that I was not fired with the same kind of motive that they had.
('63', 437, 3, 16, 890455) You may not also know that this was one of the places where, on my return from South Africa to India in 1915, I was invited to open the Ashram.
('63', 437, 3, 17, 890599) During my last visit, practically all the Pandas (priests) were volunteers, lavishing their affectionate services on me and my party.
('63', 437, 3, 18, 890733) They knew that I had the same convictions about untouchability that I have today.
('63', 437, 3, 19, 890815) They knew, too, that there was hardly a meeting at which I did not speak on untouchability in those days.
('63', 437, 3, 20, 890921) But, alas!
('63', 437, 3, 21, 890932) on this occasion they are divi ded into two camps; one serving me and my party and the other, be it ever so small, resisting me.
('63', 437, 3, 22, 891061) I know that it is not given to man to retain the affection of all men for all time.
('63', 437, 3, 23, 891145) I know of myself that such a possibility has existed for me, a very imperfect man, only in imagina tion.
('63', 437, 3, 24, 891250) It is, therefore, neither a matter for surprise nor sorrow that some of my old friends, the Pandas, I find in the opposite camp.
('63', 437, 3, 25, 891379) But the manner of resistance is a matter for deep grief to me.
('63', 437, 3, 26, 891442) I suppose they
('63', 437, 4, 27, 891457) 1Gandhiji spoke in Hindi.

('63', 438, 0, 1, 891543) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 439
('63', 438, 1, 2, 891587) are responsible for the circulation of leaflets full of untruths and half truths about myself designed to wean the people from me.
('63', 438, 1, 3, 891718) Decency of language has been thrown to the winds.
('63', 438, 1, 4, 891768) One of the leaflets is supposed to have been issued under the instructions of the Maharaja Saheb of Gidhaur.
('63', 438, 1, 5, 891877) But unless I had authentic proof, I should refuse to believe that he had lent his name to it.
('63', 438, 1, 6, 891971) Black flag demonstrations took place also at some places during my tour in the South.
('63', 438, 1, 7, 892057) But they were carried out gracefully.
('63', 438, 1, 8, 892095) It was merely a demonstration that those who held the black flags were opposed to the movement.
('63', 438, 1, 9, 892191) Many of them were urchins who did not hesitate to return my greetings, which invariably went to the black flaggers as to the others, and even to take part in the shouts of joy.
('63', 438, 1, 10, 892368) And I have little doubt that they should have said with their distinguished ancestors, Drona and Bhishma, that they were doing it for the sake of their bellies.
('63', 438, 1, 11, 892529) Here, alas!
('63', 438, 1, 12, 892541) not only has decency of language been thrown away, they have resorted to violence.
('63', 438, 1, 13, 892624) Early in the morning, at half past two, when I alighted at Jashidih, they filled the air with yells of denunciation.
('63', 438, 1, 14, 892741) They even became violent.
('63', 438, 1, 15, 892767) If they could have done so, they would certainly have smashed the hood of the car to pieces.
('63', 438, 1, 16, 892860) Heavy blows descended on it.
('63', 438, 1, 17, 892889) The pane at the back was smashed and I had a providential escape from being seriously hurt.
('63', 438, 1, 18, 892981) I believe that they do not want to do me bodily injury, and by landing lathi blows on the hood and breaking the pane, they had intended merely to make a demonstration of their anger against me.
('63', 438, 1, 19, 893175) But whatever their intention, their action was undoubtedly violent.
('63', 438, 1, 20, 893243) It might have ended in a manner which they would themselves have deplored.
('63', 438, 1, 21, 893318) I should like to contrast the behaviour of [some people] this morning with the very correct behaviour of the Zamorin of Calicut I went to Guruvayur.
('63', 438, 1, 22, 893467) The Zamorin had certainly some cause for indignation when the battle was raging round that famous temple of the South, and yet he had prohibited any demonstration even the black flags, against me, and he received me with marked cordiality in his palace.
('63', 438, 1, 23, 893721) He frankly recognized that on each side it was a battle of principle against principle.
('63', 438, 1, 24, 893809) The Pandas of Deoghar and the local Varnashram Swaraj Sangh have not had even a pretext, which the Zamorin would have had, for making a demonstration against me.
('63', 438, 1, 25, 893971) And what is this opposition for and why this arrogation of possession of sanatana truth by the self styled sanatanists?
('63', 438, 1, 26, 894091) I have put forth the same claim that they have of trying to follow sanatana dharma.
('63', 438, 1, 27, 894175) They have as much or as little right as I have to the exclusive interpretation
('63', 439, 0, 1, 894254) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 439, 1, 2, 894296) of what it is.
('63', 439, 1, 3, 894311) I swear by the same Shastras that they do.
('63', 439, 1, 4, 894354) There undoubtedly is a difference between them and me.
('63', 439, 1, 5, 894409) But that is purely in the matter of interpretation.
('63', 439, 1, 6, 894461) Such differences there always will be.
('63', 439, 1, 7, 894500) Surely they should be satisfied with the assurance that I do not seek to impose my views on anybody.
('63', 439, 1, 8, 894601) I utterly disbelieve in methods of compulsion.
('63', 439, 1, 9, 894648) I seek to bring people round to my view of truth by an appeal to their reason and to their hearts.
('63', 439, 1, 10, 894747) Take, for instance, the temple entry question.
('63', 439, 1, 11, 894794) In the course of my tour, I have had the privilege of declaring open many temples amidst the acclamations of thousands of people, practically without a dissentient voice.
('63', 439, 1, 12, 894965) In the single instance where there was an appreciable minority against the opening, I refused to open the temple till the minority was won over or it had at least ample time to act upon the majority.
('63', 439, 1, 13, 895165) If I discovered that a single temple was opened without such consent or by compulsion in any form, I should move heaven and earth to have the temple re closed to Harijans.
('63', 439, 1, 14, 895337) Then, take the Temple entry Bill.
('63', 439, 1, 15, 895371) I do believe that it is the bounden duty of every caste Hindu to adopt every legitimate means to redeem the pledge given to Harijans in Bombay during my fast in 1932. That pledge included resort to legislation when it was necessary.
('63', 439, 1, 16, 895604) I may be allowed to say that the Temple entry Bill or an equivalent is absolutely neces sary if the will of the majority is to prevail.
('63', 439, 1, 17, 895740) Today, according to legal opinion, even one dissentient voice is enough to keep a temple closed to Harijans.
('63', 439, 1, 18, 895849) But I would be no party even to such enabling legislation being passed, if there is not a clear majority of caste Hindus in favour of it.
('63', 439, 1, 19, 895987) What, therefore, the sanatanist opposition means is that I must not even cultivate public opinion in favour of such legislation under self imposed restriction, which several of my friends and co workers consider to be ludicrous.
('63', 439, 1, 20, 896216) For I do not even take the votes at public meetings.
('63', 439, 1, 21, 896269) Though I know that the majority will vote in favour of such legislation, I refrain, because I believe that it will be wrong to take the votes of the general body of people in technical matters.
('63', 439, 1, 22, 896463) The question of necessity or advisability of such a law as the Temple entry Bill is one to be decided by technical experts, that is, in this instance, lawyers.
('63', 439, 1, 23, 896623) I have said repeatedly that the votes of only caste Hindus should count in the matter of opening temples.
('63', 439, 1, 24, 896729) For, if they are unwilling to open their temples to Harijans, it shows that they have not cleansed themselves of untouchatility.
('63', 439, 1, 25, 896858) And it would be of little avail to me if all the temples were opened but caste Hindus were against such opening.
('63', 439, 1, 26, 896971) There is no such thing as bringing about purity by compulsion.
('63', 440, 0, 1, 897034) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 441
('63', 440, 1, 2, 897078) tried, therefore, to discover the cause of the opposition, and I have failed unless it be that public opinion is fast changing and untou chability is on its last lap and that, therefore, by hook or by crook my tour should be brought to a standstill, no matter how scru pulously fair my means may be of converting Hindu opinion.
('63', 440, 1, 3, 897406) I have, therefore, no hesitation in saying that by this morning’s behaviour the sanatanists lowered the sanatanist flag in this sacred place, even as the great Yudhishthira lowered it by uttering a half truth.
('63', 440, 1, 4, 897616) For, has not the reputed author of the Mahabharata told us that, when Yudhishthira uttered the fateful half truth, the wheel of his chariot sank some feet into the ground and that he had to make amends even after death?
('63', 440, 1, 5, 897836) I, therefore, implore the sanatanist friends to repent of their behaviour in the sanctuary of their hearts and resolve never to repeat the violence of this morning.
('63', 440, 1, 6, 898001) To the reformers I say, you are in an overwhelming majority.
('63', 440, 1, 7, 898062) Those who are organizing the opposition are to be counted on one’s fingers.
('63', 440, 1, 8, 898138) You should try to win them over by your patience, gentleness and personal purity.
('63', 440, 1, 9, 898220) This movement is one of self purification, and only the pure of heart can have place in it.
('63', 440, 1, 10, 898312) There ought to be no interference with the demons trators.
('63', 440, 1, 11, 898371) They have every right to express their resentment by carrying flags, if they like, so that I may know how many are opposed to this movement.
('63', 440, 1, 12, 898512) The difficulty comes in only when they obstruct my passage or show their resentment by resorting to other species of violence.
('63', 440, 1, 13, 898639) In any case you must, especially as you are in an over whel ming majority, be gentle and patient with the sanatanist friends, seek to win them over by persuasion and trust that, even if persuasion fails, time will bring them round to the truth if you are really representing it.
('63', 440, 1, 14, 898918) There should be no retaliation on the part of reformers.
('63', 440, 1, 15, 898975) You should know that in this movement of self purification any violence done by the reformers may involve serious penance on my part.
('63', 440, 1, 16, 899109) Now, a word to the audience.
('63', 440, 1, 17, 899138) I understand that there are several lakhs of Santhals, who call themselves Hindus, observe Hindu customs and manners, worship the Hindu deities and yet are regarded as untouchables to all intents and purposes.
('63', 440, 1, 18, 899348) Those of them who do not call themselves Hindus are not regarded by you as untouchables; but those who do call themselves Hindus are almost punished for doing so.
('63', 440, 1, 19, 899511) What is the wrong they have done?
('63', 440, 1, 20, 899545) They have given up intoxica ting liquors.
('63', 440, 1, 21, 899587) They worship the cow as you do and I do or should do.
('63', 440, 1, 22, 899641) They have even adopted vegetarianism.
('63', 440, 1, 23, 899679) They utter Ramanama with perhaps greater zest and certainly greater faith than you or I do.
('63', 441, 0, 1, 899771) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 441, 1, 2, 899813) utilize their idle hours by spinning and weaving and thus add to the wealth of the country.
('63', 441, 1, 3, 899905) They deserve to be treated with affectionate consideration, instead of as pariahs of society.
('63', 441, 1, 4, 899999) There is no warrant in the Shastras for regarding them as untouchables.
('63', 441, 1, 5, 900071) If there is, the sooner we perish the better it will be for us and the world.
('63', 441, 1, 6, 900149) And to the Santhals I would say, “If you have faith in Ramanama you will have it in spite of your being rejected by your fellows.
('63', 441, 1, 7, 900279) That sacred name, and not they, will save you and give you peace and joy, of which no one can rob you.”
('63', 441, 2, 8, 900383) Harijan, 4 5 1934
('63', 441, 3, 9, 900401) 491. WHOSE OPINION CAN COUNT?
('63', 441, 4, 10, 900431) A sanatanist pandit complained to me the other day that in the matter of the untouchability Bills the opinion of non Hindus, Arya Samajists, Sikhs and others who did not believe in temples and idol worship was being taken by magistrates in Benares.
('63', 441, 4, 11, 900680) If that is so, it is surprising.
('63', 441, 4, 12, 900713) I have always held the view, and have expressed it in these columns, that, if opinion must be taken, that of non Hindus, nay even of Hindu Harijans, cannot count either way.
('63', 441, 4, 13, 900887) For, untouchability is a doctrine with which the caste Hindus alone are concerned, and the Bills have been designed to reflect their opinion.
('63', 441, 4, 14, 901029) To hold otherwise would be to introduce coercion of caste Hindus by non caste Hindus and others.
('63', 441, 4, 15, 901126) The anti untouchability movement is a movement of internal reform among caste Hindus.
('63', 441, 4, 16, 901212) It is one of repentance and self purification.
('63', 441, 4, 17, 901259) These cannot be imposed from without.
('63', 441, 4, 18, 901297) If, therefore, I had any influence with the Government and if the sanatanist pandit had given me correct information, I should advise the Government to revise their instructions so as to confine the taking of opinion to caste Hindus only on the question of approval of the Bills.
('63', 441, 4, 19, 901577) My fear, however, is not that the Bills are likely to be passed by reason of non Hindu opinion being given in their favour.
('63', 441, 4, 20, 901701) My belief is that the so called sanatanist opinion is not truly representative.
('63', 441, 4, 21, 901781) For, so far as I am aware, caste Hindu opinion is overwhelmingly in favour of the temples being thrown open to Harijans.
('63', 441, 4, 22, 901902) As to the advisability of passing the Bills in question, the masses, I hold, are incapable of pronouncing judgment.
('63', 441, 4, 23, 902018) It is purely a question of law to be decided by lawyers.
('63', 441, 4, 24, 902075) If caste Hindu opinion is overwhelmingly in favour of the opening of temples to Harijans, they have to be opened, notwithstan 
('63', 442, 0, 1, 902202) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 443
('63', 442, 1, 2, 902246) ding the opposition of pandits, however eminent they might be.
('63', 442, 1, 3, 902309) If the existing law is powerless to give effect to that opinion, as lawyers say it is, the legislature ought to correct the existing practice so as to enable caste Hindu opinion to operate freely.
('63', 442, 1, 4, 902506) Indeed, viewed in the light here suggested, the Bills should never have been circulated for opinion.
('63', 442, 1, 5, 902607) They cannot themselves throw open a single temple to Harijans.
('63', 442, 1, 6, 902670) They are enabling Bills.
('63', 442, 1, 7, 902695) The opposi tionists hold that, even if there is one caste Hindu against the opening of a single Hindu temple, indeed, even if no one is against the open ing, no temple can be opened.
('63', 442, 1, 8, 902878) The position is no doubt absurd, but such in theory is the opinion held and expressed by those who claim to speak for sanatana dharma.
('63', 442, 1, 9, 903013) I hold that it is the duty of the Govern ment to hold the scales even and remove the admitted legal obstacle in the way of reform.
('63', 442, 1, 10, 903144) The Bills are designed to do that and no more.
('63', 442, 1, 11, 903191) The opening of temples would depend wholly on the will of caste Hindus who are entitled to worship in the existing temples.
('63', 442, 1, 12, 903315) Harijan, 27 4 1934
('63', 442, 2, 13, 903334) 492. NOTES
('63', 442, 3, 14, 903345) SHAMEFUL, IF TRUE
('63', 442, 4, 15, 903363) The same pandit who complained to me about the taking of opinion by magistrates in Benares on the anti untouchability Bills also complained that some temples had been forcibly opened at the instance of reformers.
('63', 442, 4, 16, 903576) If that is so, it is certainly shameful and contrary to the wishes of those who, like me, view the movement from the purely religious standpoint and regard it as one of self puri fication.
('63', 442, 4, 17, 903765) Even if all the temples could be compulsorily opened to Harijans, I should not regard it as a welcome event in Hinduism.
('63', 442, 4, 18, 903886) It would contribute nothing to the promotion of the spirit of brother hood of man at which the movement aims.
('63', 442, 4, 19, 903996) Indeed, the compulsory opening of even a single temple to Harijans can only retard the move ment in that it must accentuate opposition, instead of weakening it.
('63', 442, 4, 20, 904157) A change of heart is possible only in a free atmosphere.
('63', 442, 4, 21, 904214) The pandit produced no proof in support of his allegation that certain two temples [sic] in the North were forcibly opened.
('63', 442, 4, 22, 904338) I have asked for proof and referred the allegation to friends for verification.
('63', 442, 4, 23, 904418) I thought, however, that I should not wait for verification before referring to the subject.
('63', 442, 4, 24, 904511) If it is true, the sooner the mischief is mended
('63', 443, 0, 1, 904560) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 443, 1, 2, 904602) the better it is for the cause itself.
('63', 443, 1, 3, 904641) Such temples should be closed to Harijans till a better day dawns.
('63', 443, 1, 4, 904708) If the allegation proves to be false or exaggerated nothing will have been lost by the superfluous warning given by me.
('63', 443, 1, 5, 904828) Harijan, 27 4 1934
('63', 443, 2, 6, 904847) 493. HARIJANS’ HANDICAP
('63', 443, 3, 7, 904871) One of the addresses presented to me at Gauhati by the Harijans has the following recital of their grievances:
('63', 443, 4, 8, 904982) 1. We are not allowed entrance into the great Hajo temple and many other devalayas for purposes of worship, nor are we allowed admission into namghars belonging to Mahapurushiya or Damodhoria sects;
('63', 443, 5, 9, 905181) 2. We are subjected to persecution by the higher castes, if we want to make use of elephants and dolas in marriages;
('63', 443, 6, 10, 905298) 3. At the time of giving diksha, we have to be satisfied with touching the footprints of our Dharma Gurus, but are never allowed to touch their feet;
('63', 443, 7, 11, 905448) 4. In some places, people of higher castes prevent us from using public wells, although the local authorities themselves maintain no discriminatory rules regarding them;
('63', 443, 8, 12, 905618) 5. No Pujari Brahmin would touch us to put sacrificial tilak on our foreheads, and the idols made by us are considered polluted;
('63', 443, 9, 13, 905747) 6. Oftentimes we cannot perform shraddha for want of priests; and some Brahmins would not perform any pooja for us even in their own houses;
('63', 443, 10, 14, 905888) 7. In villages the higher caste Hindus would be polluted if they happen to touch us after their daily bath;
('63', 443, 11, 15, 905996) 8. Excepting in the Gauhati College hostels, we are not allowed into the common dining room.
('63', 443, 11, 16, 906089) In spite of the galling social persecution, the signatory was able to say on behalf of those whom he represented:
('63', 443, 12, 17, 906203) From the enumeration of grievances you must not think that we do this with a view to spite, or out of ill will towards, our more fortunate brethren of the higher castes.
('63', 443, 12, 18, 906373) We venture to assure you that we have tried to realize the significance of your great doctrine of nonviolence and that we believe that in course of time the more advanced sections of the Hindu community will embrace us as their fellow brethren.
('63', 443, 12, 19, 906618) In Assam I noticed no settled conviction about untouchability even among those who might be considered orthodox.
('63', 443, 12, 20, 906731) A little hard work put in by cultured men and women of purity can bring about a
('63', 444, 0, 1, 906811) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 445
('63', 444, 1, 2, 906855) healthy and silent revolution in the unholy custom of untouchability.
('63', 444, 1, 3, 906925) I would like to complete the list of the grievances enumerated above by adding those of the so called ‘coolie’ population imported from the other provinces.
('63', 444, 1, 4, 907082) The scavengers of Assam are mostly drawn from the neighbouring provinces.
('63', 444, 1, 5, 907156) These are consigned to ghettos where they have, as they complained, no lights and most inadequate sanitary conveniences.
('63', 444, 1, 6, 907277) Their plight in the rains must be infinitely worse than I found it to be when everything was comparatively dry.
('63', 444, 1, 7, 907389) With but a little consideration and very little expense, the grievous defects can be immediately remedied.
('63', 444, 1, 8, 907496) Harijan, 27 4 1934
('63', 444, 2, 9, 907515) 494. SPINNING AND WEAVING FOR HARIJANS
('63', 444, 3, 10, 907554) During my peregrinations I have observed that spinning and weaving are among the industries that are supporting thousands of Harijans and, if properly organized, can support many more.
('63', 444, 3, 11, 907739) Indeed, in some places, there are to be found weavers who are classed as untouchables on account of their occupation.
('63', 444, 3, 12, 907857) They are mostly weavers of coarsest khadi without any pattern.
('63', 444, 3, 13, 907920) This class was fast dying out when khadi came to the rescue and there was created a demand for their coarse manufacture.
('63', 444, 3, 14, 908041) It was then discovered that there were numerous Harijan families that even subsisted on spinning.
('63', 444, 3, 15, 908139) Thus khadi is doubly the poor man’s staff of life.
('63', 444, 3, 16, 908190) It helps the poorest, including the Harijans, who are the most helpless among the poorest.
('63', 444, 3, 17, 908281) They are so because many occupations which are available to the others are not available to the Harijans.
('63', 444, 3, 18, 908387) Apart from its great value from the Harijan standpoint, I have not omitted, to the extent I have been able during the Harijan tour, to study the whole problem of khadi.
('63', 444, 3, 19, 908556) And I have found that the time has come for khadi workers to emphasize more than ever before the necessity of greater concentration on the observance of the laws of khadi economics.
('63', 444, 3, 20, 908738) Some of them are essentially different from those that govern the general economics.
('63', 444, 3, 21, 908823) Thus as a rule, articles manufac tured in one place are sent or attempted to be sent to all parts of the world.
('63', 444, 3, 22, 908935) Those who manufacture the articles need not use them at all.
('63', 444, 3, 23, 908996) Not so with khadi.
('63', 444, 3, 24, 909015) Its peculiarity is that it has to be used where it is produced and preferably by the spinners and weavers themselves.
('63', 444, 3, 25, 909133) Thus, the demand for khadi when thus used is automatically assured.
('63', 444, 3, 26, 909201) No doubt this ideal will never be reached.
('63', 444, 3, 27, 909244) But the worth of khadi will
('63', 445, 0, 1, 909272) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 445, 1, 2, 909314) always be measured by the extent to which the ideal is reached.
('63', 445, 1, 3, 909378) Khadi is a cottage industry in this special sense in which no other industry is or can be, except agriculture in a restricted sense, if agriculture may be regarded as an industry.
('63', 445, 1, 4, 909558) Therefore it is necessary to educate the spinners and weavers to appreciate the simple economics of khadi.
('63', 445, 1, 5, 909665) Where cloth is spun and woven by the spinners and weavers for their own use, it is naturally cheapest for them.
('63', 445, 1, 6, 909777) It follows that we must not seek to send khadi for sale far away from its place of manufacture.
('63', 445, 1, 7, 909873) The surplus khadi should be sold in the village where it is manufactured.
('63', 445, 1, 8, 909947) If there is still a surplus, it should be sold in the district of its manufacture.
('63', 445, 1, 9, 910030) Special varieties will no doubt continue to be manufactured by those families which have woven artistic patterns from time immemorial.
('63', 445, 1, 10, 910165) That sort of khadi will live, no matter what befalls the villagers’ khadi, which is meant as a perennial source of labour and income for them.
('63', 445, 1, 11, 910308) The foregoing does not mean a revolution in the immediate administration of the A.I.S.A. Its depots will go on as usual.
('63', 445, 1, 12, 910429) But it does mean a revolution in the thought world.
('63', 445, 1, 13, 910481) The best mind of khadi workers will concentrate itself upon the village khadi, upon its style and durability, to suit the taste of the villagers.
('63', 445, 1, 14, 910627) There will thus have to be a better and more real bond between ginners, carders, spinners and weavers, on the one hand, and the khadi workers on the other.
('63', 445, 1, 15, 910783) There will be no feverish anxiety to increase the sales in towns.
('63', 445, 1, 16, 910849) These sales will be regulated according to the demand of town dwellers and the propaganda conducted by khadi lovers who will not or cannot directly reach the villagers but who will not be satisfied till they have sold some khadi on behalf of the poor spinners and weavers.
('63', 445, 1, 17, 911122) Let this be borne in mind that khadi can be permanent only when it has obtained a permanent footing as village wear.
('63', 445, 1, 18, 911239) Harijan, 27 4 1934

('63', 448, 1, 2, 915425) 498. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, GUMIA 1
('63', 448, 2, 3, 915464) [April 28, 1934] 2
('63', 448, 3, 4, 915483) Gandhiji said that it gave him great joy to meet them 3. Referring to the groups of spinners, he said it was a fine thing that they should be producing yarn in large quantities and wearing the cloth woven from it.
('63', 448, 3, 5, 915697) But this did not fully satisfy him.
('63', 448, 3, 6, 915733) He wanted all the Santhals to take to it.
('63', 448, 3, 7, 915775) If they all span, wove and wore their own cloth, they would fulfil the great ideal of khadi and they would be infinitely the better off themselves.
('63', 448, 3, 8, 915923) What mothers or sisters are there who would think of giving up making their rotis at home and getting them from the bazaar?
('63', 448, 3, 9, 916047) Just as we eat our home made chapatis, so should we wear our homespun cloth.
('63', 448, 3, 10, 916124) And remember this, too, that our mothers and sisters, who make our chapatis in the home, take care not to give us badly mixed and under baked bread.
('63', 448, 3, 11, 916273) They know that, for the good of the family, the bread must be well made.
('63', 448, 3, 12, 916346) That is exactly how we must regard khadi.
('63', 448, 3, 13, 916388) We must not be satisfied till we can card, spin and weave well, thus producing good, lasting cloth for the home.
('63', 448, 3, 14, 916501) I must confess that the quality of carding and spinning is not half good enough to satisfy me.
('63', 448, 3, 15, 916596) Your implements are also unwieldy, but could easily be improved if you had the technical knowledge.
('63', 448, 3, 16, 916696) The rough quality of your khadi and the slowness of your production are simply due to want of knowledge.
('63', 448, 3, 17, 916801) It is clear that those who have been working amongst you to serve and help you have not been able to impart the full skill of khadi production because they themselves are perhaps not in possession of the art.
('63', 448, 3, 18, 917010) It is necessary for an instructor to have full mastery over the technique himself.
('63', 448, 4, 19, 917093) Gandhiji then went on to explain to them how, if their instruments were improved, they would be able to get the same output as at present in half the time each day.
('63', 448, 4, 20, 917258) That would give them leisure for other things, or if they needed more cloth, they would produce double the quantity.
('63', 448, 5, 21, 917375) Gandhiji then spoke of the curse of drink, describing its awful effect on man’s
('63', 448, 6, 22, 917455) morality, and urged those of them who were addicted to the habit of drinking this
('63', 448, 7, 23, 917537) poison to abjure it henceforth.
('63', 448, 8, 24, 917569) He then referred to the complaint that they had voiced in their welcome address
('63', 448, 9, 25, 917649) 1 Extracted from Mirabehn’s report “Gandhiji with Nature’s Children” .

('63', 449, 1, 2, 917853) about the hardships they were suffering from.

('63', 449, 1, 4, 918019) That spare time which you will gain when you improve your spinning methods can be devoted to the study of the Ramayana and other religious books, to improving your Hindi, to learning Bengali or anything else you like of that kind.
('63', 449, 1, 5, 918250) If you gain purity and knowledge in this way, your hardships will melt.
('63', 449, 2, 6, 918322) Gandhiji then spoke to them of the beauty and power of the name of God: You must learn to take the name of Rama with full devotion and faith.
('63', 449, 2, 7, 918464) When you study the Ramayana, you will learn from Tulsidas the divine power of that blessed name.
('63', 449, 2, 8, 918561) You might ask me why I tell you to use the word Rama and not one of the many other names of the Creator.
('63', 449, 2, 9, 918666) True, His names are as many as and more than the leaves on a tree, and I might, for instance, ask you to use the word God.

('63', 449, 2, 14, 919295) You know the story of Ahalya?
('63', 449, 2, 15, 919325) No, I see you don’t.

('63', 449, 2, 17, 919496) You must learn to repeat the blessed name of Rama with such sweetness and such devo tion that the birds will pause in their singing to listen to you—that the very trees will bend their leaves towards you, stirred by the divine melody of that Name.
