('63', 461, 6, 24, 944336) 507. THREE UNHAPPY INCIDENTS On the 25th April I commenced the Harijan tour in South Bihar.
('63', 461, 6, 25, 944428) The first place to be visited was Arrah.
('63', 461, 6, 26, 944469) On the way I had to motor to visit the temple of a zamindar, who had opened it to Harijans, and to receive a purse from him.
('63', 461, 6, 27, 944594) As the Reception Committee had feared obstruction by black flag sanatanists, they suggested that I should go in a lorry, in the hope that it might escape molestation, the sanatanists not suspecting that I would be thus stolen away.
('63', 461, 6, 28, 944826) But, unfortunately for the members and for me, the black flaggers had anticipated the ruse, and as soon as the lorry entered the dense crowd which contained them, they made a dash for it.
('63', 461, 6, 29, 945014) They were but a drop in the ocean and were soon overpowered and torn away bodily from the lorry wheels to which they were clinging.
('63', 461, 6, 30, 945146) I could not bear the sight.
('63', 461, 6, 31, 945174) That nobody was
('63', 461, 7, 32, 945190) 1 Chhotubhai Purani, pioneer of physical culture activities in Gujarat 2 Ravishankar Vyas, popularly known as Ravishankar Maharaj 3 Dadabhai Naoroji’s granddaughter
('63', 462, 0, 1, 945355) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 463
('63', 462, 1, 2, 945399) seriously hurt was mere good luck.
('63', 462, 1, 3, 945434) The crowd was certainly in no mood to tolerate the obstruction.
('63', 462, 1, 4, 945498) Terrific shouts of “ ” (seize, seize)” filled the air.
('63', 462, 1, 5, 945553) The handling was none too gentle.
('63', 462, 1, 6, 945587) The black flaggers were determined to court injury, as the leader had assured me even when his party had begun the plan of obstruction.
('63', 462, 1, 7, 945723) They were, therefore, resisting the seizure of their persons.
('63', 462, 1, 8, 945785) I was the helpless onlooker of the wretched scene.
('63', 462, 1, 9, 945836) I had no present method of dealing with the situation, unless I was to turn back from my mission.
('63', 462, 1, 10, 945934) I had, therefore, to allow the black flaggers to be bodily removed.
('63', 462, 1, 11, 946002) The police were on the spot and they, too, were trying to remove the obstructionists without hurting them.
('63', 462, 1, 12, 946109) But though there was no serious hurt caused to anybody, the sight was enough to move me to the marrow.
('63', 462, 1, 13, 946212) An indescribable sensation crept over me and I felt like swooning.
('63', 462, 1, 14, 946279) I began the conscious recital of Ramanama, which unconsciously goes on continually in me.
('63', 462, 1, 15, 946369) It steadied me.
('63', 462, 1, 16, 946385) I was able to go through the day’s work without anybody knowing what had happened to me or what was going on in my heart.
('63', 462, 1, 17, 946507) We reached the temple, received the purse and motored to Arrah to attend its meeting which, owing to the din and noise, it was impossible to address beyond saying a few words in response to the address and the purse.
('63', 462, 1, 18, 946724) From Arrah we took the train for Buxar, which we reached at noon.
('63', 462, 1, 19, 946790) There was a black flag demonstration at Buxar.
('63', 462, 1, 20, 946837) My car passed safely, but Mirabehn came in for a lathi blow on the hood of her car.
('63', 462, 1, 21, 946921) Within 15 minutes of my arrival, I heard that there was a scuffle between the reception volunteers and the black flaggers, who must have numbered not more than thirty in a vast crowd.
('63', 462, 1, 22, 947105) This news was followed by three volunteers walking in, two with broken heads.
('63', 462, 1, 23, 947183) The third had a swollen arm.
('63', 462, 1, 24, 947212) They told me that they were injured while they were averting the blows of the sanatanists and pacifying the infuriated crowd, which was angry over the boisterous behaviour of the demonstrators.
('63', 462, 1, 25, 947406) They told me also that some sanatanists were undoubtedly injured.
('63', 462, 1, 26, 947472) The time for attending the public meeting was approaching.
('63', 462, 1, 27, 947531) I was ill at ease.
('63', 462, 1, 28, 947550) The Arrah incident was still fresh in my mind.
('63', 462, 1, 29, 947597) In consultation with Thakkar Bapa and Vindhyababu, I decided to walk to the meeting.
('63', 462, 1, 30, 947682) I felt that the car was a red rag to the bull and that my walking would perhaps disarm the black flaggers’ anger and sober the crowd of sympathizers and admirers.
('63', 462, 1, 31, 947845) Vindhyababu went in ad vance to tell the crowds that I proposed to walk to the meeting and that they should neither shout, nor attempt to touch my feet, nor molest the black flaggers if they wished to demonstrate.
('63', 462, 1, 32, 948059) The whole route, less than a mile, was lined on either side by a dense row of people, leaving a clear broad passage for me.
('63', 462, 1, 33, 948183) The walk for me was a
('63', 463, 0, 1, 948205) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 463, 1, 2, 948247) pilgrimage.
('63', 463, 1, 3, 948259) Thakkar Bapa and Vindhyababu had accompanied me.
('63', 463, 1, 4, 948308) The meeting was most successful.
('63', 463, 1, 5, 948341) The enormous crowd listened to me in perfect silence.
('63', 463, 1, 6, 948395) I described what I had heard and seen and said that my apology was due to the demonstrators if any injury was done to them by the reception volunteers, and gave my assurance that I would inquire further into the happenings.
('63', 463, 1, 7, 948619) The meeting over, I walked back to the residence.
('63', 463, 1, 8, 948669) Immediately on my reaching there, I found a sanatanist volunteer, who showed an injury in his head and told me that there were others hurt, of whom one would surely die.
('63', 463, 1, 9, 948839) They were all at the hospital.
('63', 463, 1, 10, 948870) I sent Thakkar Bapa to the hospital, whilst I was preparing for going to the station.
('63', 463, 1, 11, 948956) On finishing the preparation, I followed him to the hospital and saw the injured men.
('63', 463, 1, 12, 949042) I saw four in all, of whom the one who was reported to be dying was certainly not in any such condition.
('63', 463, 1, 13, 949147) He was injured in the head.
('63', 463, 1, 14, 949175) He was awaiting examination.
('63', 463, 1, 15, 949204) He was able to carry on a sustained conversation with me and was quite in his senses.
('63', 463, 1, 16, 949290) I should not describe his injuries as serious.
('63', 463, 1, 17, 949337) The medical officer entertained no fear about his condition.
('63', 463, 1, 18, 949398) The other three were not much hurt.
('63', 463, 1, 19, 949434) All said they could recognize one of their assailants who had the reception committee ribbon.
('63', 463, 1, 20, 949528) As I was unable to make a detailed enquiry, I asked them to send me the names or description of their assailant and a full account of what had happened.
('63', 463, 1, 21, 949681) I told them what the injured volunteers had told me and assured them that I would do such penance as was possible for me if I found that the volunteers had assaulted them or had incited others to do so, and that for me they were just as dear as the volunteers.
('63', 463, 1, 22, 949942) It was a hurried visit to the hospital.
('63', 463, 1, 23, 949982) I had to hasten to the station to catch the train for Jashidih, the junction for Deoghar, which I was to reach at 2.10 a.m.
('63', 463, 1, 24, 950106) the next day, i.e., 26th.
('63', 463, 1, 25, 950132) The night was disturbed by Pandit Lalnath and his party, who were travelling with us, getting out at every station and vigorously singing out “We shall not let him proceed on his mission” and other slogans.
('63', 463, 1, 26, 950339) To my knowledge, they were in no way molested whilst they were going through the performance.
('63', 463, 1, 27, 950433) Indeed, the crowds who had come to greet me, as they did practically at every station, remained still whilst the sanatanists were trying to provoke me into stopping the tour or the public into seriously molesting him and his party.
('63', 463, 1, 28, 950665) Thus we reached Jashidih which was a seething mass of humanity.
('63', 463, 1, 29, 950729) The station was ill lighted.
('63', 463, 1, 30, 950758) I therefore could not see faces.
('63', 463, 1, 31, 950791) The police were certainly there.
('63', 463, 1, 32, 950824) They took part side by side with the volunteers in escorting me.
('63', 463, 1, 33, 950889) After we had arrived with difficulty at the station gate where tickets were collected, we passed through a suffocating crowd inter 
('63', 464, 0, 1, 951021) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 465
('63', 464, 1, 2, 951065) spersed with numerous black flag demonstrators.
('63', 464, 1, 3, 951113) With the greatest difficulty the police officials and the volunteers showed me into the car.
('63', 464, 1, 4, 951206) Thakkar Bapa, who was to have got into it with me, simply could not do so, and it was considered dangerous to detain the car for him.
('63', 464, 1, 5, 951340) So the car proceeded, making its way very slowly through the crowd.
('63', 464, 1, 6, 951408) Heavy blows descended on the hood of the car.
('63', 464, 1, 7, 951454) I momentarily expected it to break to pieces.
('63', 464, 1, 8, 951500) Meanwhile came a blow on the pane at the back of the hood.
('63', 464, 1, 9, 951559) The broken bits fell at my side.

('63', 464, 3, 16, 952012) 508. LETTER TO CHANDULAL DESAI 2
('63', 464, 4, 17, 952045) RANCHI, May 4, 1934 It is undoubtedly true that the temporary suspension of civil disobedience raises in an acute form the problem of the cultivators who have suffered and lost their farms and homes.
('63', 464, 4, 18, 952245) Nor is there any doubt that it is the duty of every Gujarati to give whatever help he can to enable those cultivators to stand on their feet again.
('63', 464, 4, 19, 952393) But it is necessary to remember that in giving them help we do not make them permanently dependent.
('63', 464, 4, 20, 952493) Great battles have never been fought, and will never be fought, without some individuals suffering.
('63', 464, 4, 21, 952593) Please also remember that there is no question of compensating the cultivators for their losses.
('63', 464, 4, 22, 952690) It is a question of rehabilitating them.
('63', 464, 4, 23, 952731) Those who have lost their lands should have faith that, if not they themselves in their lifetime, their heirs will surely get back one day the lands which they have lost.
('63', 464, 4, 24, 952902) According to me, this is only one sign, and that too a small one, that we shall get swaraj.

('63', 465, 1, 2, 953347) 509. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, JAMSHEDPUR 1
('63', 465, 2, 3, 953391) May 4, 1934
('63', 465, 3, 4, 953403) Gandhiji said .
('63', 465, 3, 5, 953419) that in a newly built city like Jamshedpur, taking its name after one of the greatest and the wisest philanthropists of his age, it was a pity that the hovels occupied by its Harijans were not changed into decent tenements.
('63', 465, 3, 6, 953643) He added that in that cosmopolitan city it was hardly creditable to its population that there had to be separate Harijan bastis at all.
('63', 465, 3, 7, 953779) It was essentially a labourers’ city.
('63', 465, 3, 8, 953817) Labour at least should be free from the taint of untouchability.
('63', 465, 4, 9, 953882) The speech also dealt with the drink evil which, he had learnt at Jharia, was on the increase.
('63', 465, 4, 10, 953977) Claiming himself to be a labourer by choice, Gandhiji warned his fellow labourers that their greatest enemy was not capital but drink and other bad habits.
('63', 465, 4, 11, 954133) If they did not give up drink, it might finally prove their undoing.
('63', 465, 5, 12, 954202) Gandhiji also adverted to goondaism, which was reported to be growing in their midst.
('63', 465, 5, 13, 954288) It was a disgrace that barbarous methods were employed, no matter by whom.
('63', 465, 5, 14, 954363) He had heard that ex labourers were employed in this nefarious traffic.
('63', 465, 5, 15, 954435) It was a shame if such was the case.
('63', 465, 6, 16, 954472) Gandhiji deplored the fact that the labourers could not trust themselves to part with their money 2 for sacred causes when once the cash came into their hands.
('63', 465, 6, 17, 954632) He, therefore, asked the labourers and their advisers to arrange for payment of their donations on the next pay day.
('63', 465, 6, 18, 954749) He did not mind how small the donation was, but he wanted to feel that labour was solidly for the removal of untouchability.
('63', 465, 6, 19, 954874) He cited the example of labour in all the other labour areas he had visited—the last being Chakradharpur—that very day.
('63', 465, 6, 20, 954994) Labourers there had paid their own quota.
('63', 465, 6, 21, 955036) Harijan, 11 5 1934

('63', 467, 3, 8, 957050) 514. A FRAGRANT FLOWER
('63', 467, 4, 9, 957073) Fulchand Bapuji Shah was a lovely flower in the garden of Gujarat.
('63', 467, 4, 10, 957140) It has dropped but left its fragrance behind.
('63', 467, 4, 11, 957186) I had come in intimate contact with Bhai Fulchand at the time of the Kheda Satyagraha.
('63', 467, 4, 12, 957273) Ever since I knew him as a silent worker, he was always ready to serve in whatever way the call came to him.
('63', 467, 4, 13, 957382) Being an honest servant of the Harijans, he had become a Harijan himself.
('63', 467, 4, 14, 957456) He was a brave man.
('63', 467, 4, 15, 957476) I have not known of any occasion when he hesitated to make a sacrifice.
('63', 467, 4, 16, 957548) God has granted him a death worthy of a brave worker.
('63', 467, 4, 17, 957602) He took this great journey without accepting any service from others.
('63', 467, 4, 18, 957672) We shall not grieve over his death.
('63', 467, 4, 19, 957708) Let not the members of his family grieve.
('63', 467, 4, 20, 957750) Fulchand had a large family.
('63', 467, 4, 21, 957779) He considered all of us as the members of his family.
('63', 467, 4, 22, 957833) To emulate his silent service is the true memorial for such a servant.
('63', 467, 4, 23, 957904) At this moment of selfpurification, let us remember Fulchand and cleanse ourselves of all impurities.
('63', 467, 4, 24, 958006) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 6 5 1934

('63', 468, 2, 10, 959084) 516. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ANGULI 1
('63', 468, 3, 11, 959124) May 6, 1934 I am very glad to see you all.
('63', 468, 3, 12, 959167) You all know that I never came to this part of Orissa.
('63', 468, 3, 13, 959222) Railway communication to this place is not sufficient.
('63', 468, 3, 14, 959277) For this and for other reasons I had not come to this place.
('63', 468, 3, 15, 959338) It is a good thing that I get an opportunity of speaking about removal of untouchability here as I do elsewhere.
('63', 468, 3, 16, 959451) I wish to say that untouchability as we observe it nowadays has no mention in our religious Shastras.
('63', 468, 3, 17, 959553) The Dharmashastras do not mention the names of people whom we call untouchables.
('63', 468, 3, 18, 959634) We cannot show any reason why we call them untouchables.
('63', 468, 3, 19, 959691) In matters of religion which concerns crores of people such ignorance is unpardonable.
('63', 468, 3, 20, 959778) It is a pity that for so long we have been taking darkness for light and ignorance for knowledge.
('63', 468, 3, 21, 959876) So I ask you all—the old, the young, male and female, who have assembled here— to save yourselves from the darkness of ignorance.
('63', 468, 3, 22, 960006) If we do not save ourselves from this ignorance, we are sure to lose our existence and our dharma will be wiped out.
('63', 468, 3, 23, 960123) We are all sons of one Father.
('63', 468, 3, 24, 960154) God makes no distinction among His own sons.
('63', 468, 3, 25, 960199) Ordinary parents do not make any distinction among their children and so in the case of God difference is not possible.
('63', 468, 3, 26, 960319) We should wash off the idea of untouchability.
('63', 468, 3, 27, 960366) It is not desirable to treat anyone as untouchable.
('63', 468, 3, 28, 960418) We should have self purification by forgetting considerations of great and
('63', 468, 4, 29, 960493) 1 Gandhiji spoke in Hindi and the speech was translated into Oriya.
('63', 469, 0, 1, 960561) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 469, 1, 2, 960603) small and high and low.
('63', 469, 1, 3, 960627) There have been divisions high and low even among the savarna Hindus.
('63', 469, 1, 4, 960697) This is the consequence of untouchability.
('63', 469, 1, 5, 960740) It is also a sin to find differences among the untouchables as high class and low class.
('63', 469, 1, 6, 960829) Parents teach us that there is no difference between a Brahmin and a Chandala and that they can serve each other.
('63', 469, 1, 7, 960943) I cannot find any difference between them.
('63', 469, 1, 8, 960986) The Shastras never teach that illiterate people should be shunned.
('63', 469, 1, 9, 961053) It is our duty to impart knowledge to the ignorant.
('63', 469, 1, 10, 961105) To cure the diseased is a good service.
('63', 469, 1, 11, 961145) Ignorance is a sort of disease.
('63', 469, 1, 12, 961177) We are establishing schools at places to remove ignorance of people.
('63', 469, 1, 13, 961246) When we go to school we never think that we are low and the teachers are high.
('63', 469, 1, 14, 961325) One who thinks himself high and his pupils low is not fit to be a teacher.
('63', 469, 1, 15, 961400) You should learn from this that to think anyone low is meanness and sin.
('63', 469, 1, 16, 961473) There is a kind of untouchability in the world; it is evil thought.
('63', 469, 1, 17, 961541) Removal of real untouchability consists in dismissing all the evil thoughts from our minds.
('63', 469, 1, 18, 961633) We should all pray to God in the morning daily that He will give us strength to overcome all the evil thoughts that come to our mind.
('63', 469, 1, 19, 961767) Another kind of untouchability is drinking liquor.
('63', 469, 1, 20, 961818) Wine is the great untouchability.
('63', 469, 1, 21, 961852) Those who drink wine should give it up believing that it is a sin.
('63', 469, 1, 22, 961919) Idleness is an untouchability.
('63', 469, 1, 23, 961950) It is our great enemy.
('63', 469, 1, 24, 961973) I know Orissa occupies a prominent place in idleness.
('63', 469, 1, 25, 962027) It has various reasons and I am not going to make an exposition of them.
('63', 469, 1, 26, 962100) But I say that whatever be the reason all should give up idleness.
('63', 469, 1, 27, 962167) We cannot be industrious throughout the year by taking recourse to cultivation only.
('63', 469, 1, 28, 962252) My advice to Orissa people is that when they have no work in hand they should pick cotton, spin and weave khaddar for their own use.
('63', 469, 1, 29, 962385) This will not only make you self dependent but crores of rupees will be saved.
('63', 469, 1, 30, 962464) Instruction on spinning wheel is the best instruction that can be given to our boys.
('63', 469, 1, 31, 962549) They will learn to earn their livelihood by means of spinning wheel.
('63', 469, 1, 32, 962618) I know that thousands of Harijans of Orissa do not get any work in the year.
('63', 469, 1, 33, 962695) If we want to make the Harijans our own we should train them in cotton cultivation, picking cotton, spinning thread and weaving cloth.
('63', 469, 1, 34, 962830) If you realize that it is necessary to remove untouchability then you can contribute a pice or two or whatever you can.
('63', 469, 1, 35, 962950) Those who contribute and those who do not, should all be peaceful.

('63', 470, 9, 21, 964102) 519. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('63', 470, 10, 22, 964132) PURI, May 8, 1934 The idea is growing on me that I should finish the balance of the Harijan tour by walking as far as it may be possible.
('63', 470, 10, 23, 964270) When the Tamil Nadu tour was being settled by Mr. Thakkar, and pressure was being put upon him and Dr. Rajan to include places which could not
('63', 470, 11, 24, 964413) 1 The statement was issued through the United Press.
('63', 470, 11, 25, 964466) It was also published in Harijan, 11 5 1934, under the title “Shall it be on Foot?”
('63', 471, 0, 1, 964550) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 471, 1, 2, 964592) possibly be done during the time allotted to Tamil Nadu, I suggested to Mr. Thakkar that if he could share my faith, I would gladly cancel the elaborate programme that was then being drawn up and finish the tour by walking from village to village.
('63', 471, 1, 3, 964840) Latterly, the idea has been revised and it has gripped me especially after the Deoghar incident.
('63', 471, 1, 4, 964937) I know that those who are resorting to the violent method are to be counted on one’s finger’s ends.
('63', 471, 1, 5, 965037) But even the fewest can disturb meetings.
('63', 471, 1, 6, 965079) I would love to demonstrate to them in every way I can that the movement is essentially religious in conception and execution.
('63', 471, 1, 7, 965206) If the motive is religious, so is the end sought.
('63', 471, 1, 8, 965256) I am anxious too to show that it does not depend for its spread upon swift locomotion.
('63', 471, 1, 9, 965343) A suggestion that I should use the aeroplane was dismissed as soon as it was made.
('63', 471, 1, 10, 965426) Nor need anyone run away with the idea that the tour has been undertaken for the sole purpose of collecting funds.
('63', 471, 1, 11, 965541) I am sure that both the men, women and money that may be necessary for the cause will be forthcoming even though I may be walking.
('63', 471, 1, 12, 965672) It is likely that if my message comes from the heart, it will travel faster on foot than by rail or motor.
('63', 471, 1, 13, 965779) And then I am tired of the terrific noises.
('63', 471, 1, 14, 965823) Though they are an expression of people’s affection and joy at seeing me, they jar on my nerves which have now become too weak to bear them.
('63', 471, 1, 15, 965964) I am equally tired of the hustling that has become my daily lot.
('63', 471, 1, 16, 966029) The pressing towards me of vast crowds and the frantic efforts of volunteers to protect me from these crowds are proving too much for my weak body and I see no use in these shouts and this pressure.
('63', 471, 1, 17, 966228) The mania for touching my feet is a source of danger to my body.
('63', 471, 1, 18, 966293) Hardly a day passes when I do not get light scratches from the nails of the merit seekers.
('63', 471, 1, 19, 966384) I have made little lasting impression in spite of having strongly disapproved of the shouts, the pressings and the touching of feet.
('63', 471, 1, 20, 966517) I do produce a local impression when I succeed in being heard.
('63', 471, 1, 21, 966580) This opportunity cannot occur to me often when I have to rush through space as I have been doing and have to take, during the day, three places far apart from one another.
('63', 471, 1, 22, 966752) For the essential truth of the message to soak into the people, it has to be delivered to silent and listening crowds.
('63', 471, 1, 23, 966871) Religious truth, or for that matter any truth, requires a calm and meditative atmosphere for its percolation.
('63', 471, 1, 24, 966981) I have therefore three suggestions to make to my co workers for the balance of the tour.
('63', 471, 1, 25, 967070) I give them in their order of merit: (1) I should begin the tour on foot wherever I may be on the day the resolution is made, interrupting it for attending the A.I.C.C. meeting at Patna or the like and returning for resumption to the point where the interruption may take place, or choosing a fresh start after interruption.
('63', 471, 1, 26, 967395) (2) Choosing a new province after finishing Orissa and finish 
('63', 472, 0, 1, 967458) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 473
('63', 472, 1, 2, 967502) ing the tour in that province or taking as many provinces as possible on foot.
('63', 472, 1, 3, 967581) (3) Drawing up a new programme to cover not all as arranged at present but as many provinces as possible and using the railway for going from province to province.
('63', 472, 1, 4, 967745) I am sure that if the workers have faith in the spiritual nature of the message, they will not hesitate to adopt the first suggestion.
('63', 472, 1, 5, 967880) In no case may the workers come to a mechanical decision.
('63', 472, 1, 6, 967938) Theirs must not be a borrowed faith.
('63', 472, 1, 7, 967975) If none of my suggestions appeals to their hearts, they must reject them summarily and I shall go through the balance of the tour in the best manner I can.
('63', 472, 1, 8, 968131) The question may be asked if I am sure of my ground why I do not act independently of the co workers as I have been known to have done before.
('63', 472, 1, 9, 968274) The question is appropriate.
('63', 472, 1, 10, 968303) I do not so act because my own faith is not quite as strong as I would like it to be.
('63', 472, 1, 11, 968389) I perceive the truth of it but dimly.
('63', 472, 1, 12, 968427) Then the tour is not of my seeking.
('63', 472, 1, 13, 968463) It was suggested by Mr. Thakkar and Sheth Ghanshyamdas Birla.
('63', 472, 1, 14, 968525) It was planned too by them.
('63', 472, 1, 15, 968553) I have not mooted my suggestion to the latter.
('63', 472, 1, 16, 968600) The former is not enthusiastic about it.
('63', 472, 1, 17, 968641) He dreads what he thinks might be a breach of promise to the provinces and in no case will he act without the consent of the provinces concerned.
('63', 472, 1, 18, 968787) Of course he is right after his own manner.
('63', 472, 1, 19, 968831) Will the Chairmen or Secretaries of the remaining provinces after consultation with their co workers wire briefly their views to me?
('63', 472, 1, 20, 968964) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 8 5 1934

('63', 473, 5, 12, 969977) 522. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, PURI 1
('63', 473, 6, 13, 970015) May 8, 1934
('63', 473, 7, 14, 970027) Gandhiji gave the citizens an idea of the new dispensation.
('63', 473, 7, 15, 970087) He was glad that his walking tour 2 would commence from Jagannathpuri, the Eastern shrine par excellence, where all Hindus received the prasad of the Lord of the Universe on a footing of perfect equality.
('63', 473, 7, 16, 970292) The walking pilgrimage emphasized the spiritual nature of the Harijan movement.
('63', 473, 7, 17, 970372) His own experience, fortified by a study of history, had convinced him that all conveyances, even bullock carts, not only did not help but hampered the free operation of spiritual forces.
('63', 473, 7, 18, 970560) The work before them was so arduous, and the canker of untouchability had taken such a deep root in their body politic, that all the renunciation and tapas that they were capable of were required for its removal.
('63', 473, 7, 19, 970773) Hence did the idea grow upon him from day to day that he must give up railway trains and motor cars and content himself with what he could do on foot, so far as the delivery of the message was concerned.
('63', 473, 7, 20, 970977) But at Vaidyanath the idea simply gripped him.
('63', 473, 7, 21, 971024) He had long realized that his body must ever be resigned to the tender mercies of the people, and he also felt that, if God still intended his body as an instrument of service, His arm was long enough to defend it against all designs upon it.
('63', 473, 7, 22, 971267) It would be painful to him if he had to have resort to conveyances in order to save his skin.
('63', 473, 7, 23, 971361) Whilst the police did their duty, he could not help feeling ashamed that they had to defend him against possible mischief.
('63', 473, 7, 24, 971484) All these considerations had weighed with him in coming to the present decision.
('63', 473, 7, 25, 971565) If there was vital truth in the message he was delivering, it should be self luminous and selfpropagating and reach millions by the sheer force of thought.
('63', 473, 7, 26, 971721) If, therefore, the results were not what he expected, he would
('63', 473, 8, 27, 971784) 1 Extracted from Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('63', 473, 8, 28, 971832) Gandhiji walked to the place of the meeting.
('63', 473, 8, 29, 971877) Before the speech Gandhiji unveiled a bust of Gopabandhu Das.
('63', 473, 8, 30, 971939) 2 From here onwards Gandhiji renounced the use of conveyances for the duration of the Orissa tour.

('63', 474, 1, 2, 972082) question his own worthiness for the mission, rather than question the truth of the mission.
('63', 474, 1, 3, 972174) He would start for the villages on the Puri Cuttack road the next day, and he asked them to bless the effort.
('63', 474, 2, 4, 972284) To the sanatani oppositionists he would give the assurance in sight of the great temple that, so far as he could help it, temples would be thrown open to Harijans only with the consent of the temple goers and never by force.
('63', 474, 3, 5, 972509) People were welcome to join him in his pilgrimage, but they must not try to touch his feet or crowd round him.
('63', 474, 3, 6, 972620) They must walk behind the pilgrims, never ahead or abreast of them, and obey their instructions.
('63', 474, 3, 7, 972717) They must not make noises, but march in peace, and they must make their own arrangements for food and shelter.
('63', 474, 3, 8, 972828) There must not be any burden to the villagers.

('63', 476, 1, 2, 975253) 526. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS May 9, 1934 I am glad to be able to say that when I discussed the proposal 1
('63', 476, 2, 3, 975358) this morning with Utkal workers they readily accepted it and realized the spiritual significance of the proposed step.
('63', 476, 2, 4, 975477) Of course, they had difficulties about the severe disappointment that would be caused to local workers and people in general in places to be omitted but I suggested to them that the disappointment would turn to joy when they would see that the reality of the message dawned upon them more quickly than now.
('63', 476, 2, 5, 975784) I hope that co workers will spread the news in villages and instruct villagers about the solemnity of the mission.
('63', 476, 2, 6, 975899) All cries should be abandoned.
('63', 476, 2, 7, 975930) No hustling should take place, and whenever meetings are held people should be prepared to receive my message in perfect silence.
('63', 476, 2, 8, 976060) The habit of touching my feet should be discountenanced.
('63', 476, 2, 9, 976117) It would be most embarrassing to me if whilst I was walking people insisted on touching my feet.
('63', 476, 2, 10, 976214) To workers in places that were to be visited I would suggest that they should bring their purses if they are so inclined to any of the villages I would visit.
('63', 476, 2, 11, 976373) Indeed, if the full significance of the pilgrimage is realized I should expect purses from all parts of Orissa if not India.
('63', 476, 2, 12, 976498) If provincial workers have understood the significance of this step they would absolve me from having to travel in their provinces and let me take the tour as it has come to me in Orissa itself after finishing the A.I.C.C. meeting at Patna.
('63', 476, 2, 13, 976739) I feel that my touring in Orissa is equal to touring in the whole of India.
('63', 476, 2, 14, 976815) The effect of the pilgrimage will be marred by constant interruptions.
('63', 476, 2, 15, 976886) I am quite clear in my mind that continuous walking is far more effective than frequent interruptions followed by a few days’ tour on foot in the remaining provinces.
('63', 476, 2, 16, 977053) Workers should give up the idea for the sake of the mission itself of having me in their midst.
('63', 476, 2, 17, 977149) I would like workers in the provinces to consider my proposal and wire their opinion as early as they can.
('63', 476, 3, 18, 977256) The Bombay Chronicle, 11 5 1934
('63', 476, 4, 19, 977288) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 8 5 1934.
('63', 477, 0, 1, 977331) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 477, 1, 2, 977373) 527. SPEECH AT HAREKRISHNAPUR May 9, 1934 Today is a very auspicious day.
('63', 477, 1, 3, 977447) Up till now the Harijan movement was being carried on by going in motors and vehicles.
('63', 477, 1, 4, 977534) Thus I had travelled thousands and thousands of miles.
('63', 477, 1, 5, 977589) Still I am not satisfied with the movement.
('63', 477, 1, 6, 977633) With much deliberation and thought I have decided to walk on foot and deliver my message as was formerly done by our rishis.
('63', 477, 1, 7, 977758) This method I have had recourse to consequent upon some medieval [sic] developments.
('63', 477, 1, 8, 977843) Through experience I have learnt that an atmosphere created by going in motors and vehicles is quite different from the atmosphere made by going on foot.
('63', 477, 1, 9, 977997) I see that Brahmins and higher caste Hindus live separately from the Harijans.
('63', 477, 1, 10, 978076) I also see here distinctions of high and low.
('63', 477, 1, 11, 978122) It has wounded my feelings.
('63', 477, 1, 12, 978150) The Brahmins have a pride and they feel that their lineage is the foremost of all the Hindus.
('63', 477, 1, 13, 978244) It is our duty to look to cleaning of their houses.
('63', 477, 1, 14, 978296) I have come here for service of the Harijans which we had long neglected.
('63', 477, 1, 15, 978370) If you have thoroughly understood my teachings, go over to them, call them your brothers and devote yourselves to the service of the Harijans.
('63', 477, 1, 16, 978513) As Hindi is our lingua franca, try to learn Hindi as much as possible.
('63', 477, 1, 17, 978584) It has many advantages.
('63', 477, 1, 18, 978608) As some of your time is wasted without labour you should take to some other callings, be it hand spinning, carding and ginning cotton or weaving.
('63', 477, 1, 19, 978754) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 9 5 1934

('63', 480, 7, 13, 984138) 533. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL May 10, 1934
('63', 480, 8, 14, 984184) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, I left the bed at one in the morning and feel quite fresh.
('63', 480, 8, 15, 984261) Please do not get alarmed or angry or start worrying.
('63', 480, 8, 16, 984315) This is simply God’s greatness.
('63', 480, 8, 17, 984347) I am sitting on a bed of straw spread on the ground in a small village.
('63', 480, 8, 18, 984419) On one side are sleeping Mira and others, and on the other Thakkar Bapa and other men.
('63', 480, 8, 19, 984506) This is a village named Chandanpur.
('63', 480, 8, 20, 984542) Today is the third day since we started walking.
('63', 480, 8, 21, 984591) We are ten miles from Puri.
('63', 480, 8, 22, 984619) Or it may be eight.
('63', 480, 8, 23, 984639) We started from Puri yesterday in the morning.
('63', 480, 8, 24, 984686) Thakkar Bapa has planned this march as you had planned the Dandi March.
('63', 480, 8, 25, 984758) I got thoroughly upset in Puri.
('63', 480, 8, 26, 984790) I was tired of travelling by rail and car.
('63', 480, 8, 27, 984833) I put my difficulties before Bapa and other companions.

('63', 481, 1, 3, 985114) I went to the Puri meeting on foot.
('63', 481, 1, 4, 985150) The sanatanists seemed subdued and there was less of noise and other disturbances at the meeting.
('63', 481, 1, 5, 985248) When we started yesterday in the morning, the news had not spread, but in the first village where we halted more and more people came as the day advanced.
('63', 481, 1, 6, 985403) When we walked to Chandanpur in the afternoon, the road overflowed with people and the meeting which was held immediately on arrival here was attended by crowds which had poured in from all sides.
('63', 481, 1, 7, 985600) We are camping in the open air on the outskirts of the village.

('63', 482, 1, 2, 987309) 534. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA May 10, 1934
('63', 482, 2, 3, 987349) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, I am writing this letter from the village Chandanpur, some ten miles from Puri.
('63', 482, 2, 4, 987448) I am sure you will like the idea of my walking tour.
('63', 482, 2, 5, 987501) I had had it in mind for a long time but the feeling was never so strong as now.
('63', 482, 2, 6, 987582) Buxar and Deoghar would appear to have contributed much towards it.
('63', 482, 2, 7, 987650) There is no doubt that a scholar like Panchanan Tarkaratna was also involved in the Deoghar incident.
('63', 482, 2, 8, 987752) How can such darkness be dispelled by travelling by train?
('63', 482, 2, 9, 987811) The very idea of collecting funds has left my mind.
('63', 482, 2, 10, 987863) This work can hardly be accomplished by money.
('63', 482, 2, 11, 987910) I find that the change of heart can be brought about more by touring on foot.
('63', 482, 2, 12, 987988) Now I would like to confine my tour to Utkal if I can persuade the co workers in other provinces to accept it.
('63', 482, 2, 13, 988099) I would not like to go even to Patna.
('63', 482, 2, 14, 988137) You must have agreed with my opinion about “National Call”.
('63', 482, 2, 15, 988197) Sahni has addressed a long letter to Rajendrababu assuring that he would act in accordance with the wishes of the latter or of myself.
('63', 482, 2, 16, 988332) You will have received Rajendrababu’s letter.
('63', 482, 2, 17, 988378) Ansari too fully concurred.
('63', 482, 2, 18, 988406) I have gone through your prosperity plan.
('63', 482, 2, 19, 988448) The idea is good.
('63', 482, 2, 20, 988466) But I do not find it as attractive as your other schemes.
('63', 482, 2, 21, 988524) It contains much material on the necessity of a plan but it is not a plan.
('63', 482, 2, 22, 988599) A plan should be so devised that it can be put into effect by the Government and the people right from today.
('63', 482, 2, 23, 988709) That they may not implement it is another matter.
('63', 482, 2, 24, 988759) Such a plan is not beyond you.
('63', 482, 2, 25, 988790) Think it over and if possible do something on these lines.
('63', 482, 2, 26, 988849) In my view charkha should be at the centre of it.
('63', 482, 2, 27, 988899) If you do not think so, you should produce the arguments against.
('63', 482, 2, 28, 988965) It should not be left hanging in mid air.
('63', 482, 2, 29, 989007) Crores of rupees will be saved at one stroke if Government, i.e., State aid, is forthcoming.
('63', 482, 2, 30, 989100) It is not necessary that all planning should be on the Western pattern.
('63', 482, 2, 31, 989172) You know that I hold strong views on the subject.
('63', 482, 2, 32, 989222) These have become strengthened.
('63', 482, 2, 33, 989254) You can see that people are becoming lethargic in the absence of the charkha.
('63', 482, 2, 34, 989332) Our cattle have become a liability owing to our ignorance of animal husbandry.
('63', 482, 2, 35, 989411) India can beat any other country in prosperity by the study and practice of the charkha and animal husbandry and by solving the problem of small holdings.
('63', 482, 2, 36, 989566) We shall discuss this when we meet.

('63', 483, 3, 5, 989842) 535. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('63', 483, 4, 6, 989877) KADUA, May 10, 1934 This attempt at the murder of Sir John Anderson 1 is undoubt edly most deplorable.
('63', 483, 4, 7, 989980) Every minute of life’s experience further confirms me in the belief which I hold that non violence is the only remedy for all the ills of life to deal with which violence is practised today.
('63', 483, 4, 8, 990171) It is a great tragedy that some young men will not see that there is no short cut to deliverance from evils.
('63', 483, 4, 9, 990280) I am not thinking of non violence as a mere passive state.
('63', 483, 4, 10, 990339) I do not know a more active force than the force released by the vital adoption of non violence.

('63', 483, 5, 12, 990468) 536. SPEECH AT SHIVALICHAK
('63', 483, 6, 13, 990495) [May 10, 1934] 2
('63', 483, 7, 14, 990512) Why do I use the expression “Harijan”?
('63', 483, 7, 15, 990551) Whom man disowns God owns.
('63', 483, 7, 16, 990578) All religious books teach us this.
('63', 483, 7, 17, 990613) Mother Gita tells us the same thing.
('63', 483, 7, 18, 990650) Ahalya was changed into a stone.
('63', 483, 7, 19, 990683) Society had repudiated her.
('63', 483, 7, 20, 990711) Rama touched the stone and she revived and found refuge in Him.
('63', 483, 7, 21, 990775) Caste Hindus have disowned Harijans.
('63', 483, 7, 22, 990812) God has therefore taken them under His protection.
('63', 483, 7, 23, 990863) For this reason they are Harijans, Hari’s people.
('63', 483, 7, 24, 990913) It is only after we have willingly taken the untouchables to our hearts that we shall all become Hari’s people.
('63', 483, 7, 25, 991025) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 3 6 1934

('63', 484, 1, 2, 991336) 537. SPEECH AT VIRPURUSHOTTAMPUR 1
('63', 484, 2, 3, 991371) May 10, 1934
('63', 484, 3, 4, 991384) Gandhiji said that, according to the Shastras, Brahmins 2 were expected to spend themselves in the service of religion by tapas, social service and the quest of Brahma or truth.
('63', 484, 3, 5, 991562) It was a pity that modern Brahmins not only paid no attention to the duties which had been laid upon them and did not serve religion, but followed all manner of professions to enrich themselves.
('63', 484, 3, 6, 991757) A true Brahmin should be the very image of humility, and not be proud of his knowledge or wisdom.
('63', 484, 3, 7, 991855) A Brahmin would cease to be a Brahmin if he considered himself superior to others, as it was his duty to teach people to look upon a Brahmin and a Bhangi with an equal eye.
('63', 484, 3, 8, 992028) Again, a Brahmin was hardly worth the name if he did not have the courage of his own convictions.
('63', 484, 3, 9, 992126) We must fear the Lord and none else.
('63', 484, 3, 10, 992163) Cowardice was incompatible with divine wisdom.
('63', 484, 4, 11, 992210) It would not do to say that sinful people could not be allowed to enter temples.
('63', 484, 4, 12, 992291) Temples were like spiritual hospitals, and the sinful, who were spiritually diseased, had the first right to be ministered unto by them.
('63', 484, 4, 13, 992428) Temples were for sinners, not for saints.
('63', 484, 4, 14, 992470) And who was to judge where no man was without sin?
('63', 484, 4, 15, 992521) They declared every day
('63', 484, 5, 16, 992545) in their prayers: (I am sinful, I am a doer of sinful deeds).
('63', 484, 5, 17, 992607) So, if the temples were intended only for the sinless, they would have to bar their doors in the face of all mankind.
('63', 484, 5, 18, 992725) Harijan, 18 5 1934

('63', 484, 9, 23, 993124) 3 Certainly there is not the least foundation of truth in the statement that I had lent my name to it in any way.
('63', 484, 10, 24, 993238) This is to make my position perfectly clear, and, without troubling to have to let you know my individual views as regards the proposed Temple entry Bill, I must share with you in expressing regret at the spread of untruths as well as the unseemly demonstrations at Deoghar.

('63', 489, 1, 2, 1000083) 547. MESSAGE TO PEOPLE OF GANJAM 1
('63', 489, 2, 3, 1000118) [Before May 12, 1934] 2
('63', 489, 3, 4, 1000142) I know that the workers and villagers in the place which I was expected to visit will be disappointed by the step that I have taken of carrying on the balance of the Harijan tour on foot.
('63', 489, 3, 5, 1000330) That naturally ruled out all places which could only be reached by rail or road.
('63', 489, 3, 6, 1000411) In order to demonstrate as far as it was possible the religious character of the mission I felt the peremptory necessity of adopting the ancient simple method of walking.
('63', 489, 3, 7, 1000582) There were several other reasons which precipitated the decision.
('63', 489, 3, 8, 1000648) I would like you to appreciate this ancient method and feel that by walking to the few villages I shall be walking spiritually to all the villages of Orissa.
('63', 489, 3, 9, 1000806) Such mental performance was necessary even while I was covering long distances by means of rail or motor.
('63', 489, 3, 10, 1000912) But speed is most probably inimical to spiritual progress.
('63', 489, 3, 11, 1000971) Spiritual messages are better delivered through the natural methods of locomotion.
('63', 489, 3, 12, 1001054) The mental attitude that I have suggested is therefore more easily attainable when a person is walking than when he is speeding through space at the rate of 50 miles per hour.
('63', 489, 3, 13, 1001230) I am convinced that if I receive the hearty co operation of the workers and the villagers throughout this province we will see results through this pilgrimage on foot which could not have been attained through the carrying out of the original programme.
('63', 489, 3, 14, 1001484) I would, therefore, ask you to regard this pilgrimage as a greater fulfilment of the programme than its literal carrying out.
('63', 489, 3, 15, 1001610) Some of the co workers who came from their respective places pressed upon me to alter the decision and to resume the original programme but their argument was wholly unconvincing and the decision taken after incessant prayer and consultation with workers who were available at Puri could not be given up.
('63', 489, 3, 16, 1001915) After all you will not want me to conduct this tour mechanically as I would have been doing after the conviction came clear to me that I should finish this tour on foot.
('63', 489, 3, 17, 1002085) The co operation that all can give during these precious seven days will be by doing concrete work in Harijan bastis in the way of cleaning up tanks, wells, roads, etc., by inducing the different Municipalities to perform their
('63', 489, 4, 18, 1002313) 1 Sent through Jayamangala Rath, Secretary of the Ganjam Gandhi Reception Committee.
('63', 489, 4, 19, 1002398) 2 The report in the source is dated May 12.
('63', 490, 0, 1, 1002442) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 491
('63', 490, 1, 2, 1002486) duties by Harijans, by awakening savarna conscience to a sense of its duty towards Harijans; by opening temples to Harijans where there is a practically unanimous wish on the part of bona fide temple goers, by making collections of coppers and silver and sending them to me.
('63', 490, 1, 3, 1002761) I know that monies have been collected in anticipation of my visit to particular places.
('63', 490, 1, 4, 1002850) If the donors want to recall the gifts because I shall not be visiting their places the donations should be refunded and if any monies have been legitimately spent in connection with the tour out of the funds collected and if they desire them to be refunded they will be refunded on receipt of authenticated accounts if the expenses incurred are found to be legitimate.
('63', 490, 1, 5, 1003220) But I do hope that the necessity of the step taken will be recognized by all and that therefore not only will the donations not be recalled but that during the pilgrimage substantial additions will be made.
('63', 490, 1, 6, 1003427) The Hindu, 14 5 1934
('63', 490, 2, 7, 1003448) 548. LETTER TO F. MARY BARR
('63', 490, 3, 8, 1003476) AS AT PATNA, May 12, 1934
('63', 490, 4, 9, 1003502) MARY, I have your letter.
('63', 490, 4, 10, 1003528) I have been always thinking of you and Duncan all the time.
('63', 490, 4, 11, 1003588) But I have had no time at all to write to you.
('63', 490, 4, 12, 1003635) I wish I had the time to write to you about the swift and momentous changes that have taken place during the last few days.
('63', 490, 4, 13, 1003759) Each one has given me the keenest satisfaction, and the experience I am daily gaining as a result of these changes proves the correctness of the changes.
('63', 490, 4, 14, 1003913) I hope that you are following whatever I am able to write about them.
('63', 490, 4, 15, 1003983) This walking pilgrimage, if you had been with me, you would have thoroughly enjoyed.
('63', 490, 4, 16, 1004068) I am dictating this after the last march at night.
('63', 490, 4, 17, 1004119) Every time immediately on reaching the village there is a meeting.
('63', 490, 4, 18, 1004186) These meetings are a perfect study—no noise, no stir and every word spoken is certainly heard by the audience.
('63', 490, 4, 19, 1004297) Whether the audience assimilates it or not remains to be seen.
('63', 490, 4, 20, 1004360) The instance you quote of the Hindu widow nursing a Mussal man sister is certainly very touching.
('63', 490, 4, 21, 1004458) We need have no doubt that they are not only not rare occurrences, but they are frequent in many a place in India.
('63', 490, 4, 22, 1004573) Personal affection overrides all barriers.
('63', 490, 4, 23, 1004616) You should persistently try to get the weavers to weave the yarn that is spun under your aegis.
('63', 490, 4, 24, 1004712) I am glad the experiment in growing

('63', 491, 1, 2, 1004790) bhaji is proving successful.
('63', 491, 1, 3, 1004819) I do not mind your having wasted a few annas or even more on getting seeds.

('63', 498, 5, 12, 1018288) 561. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('63', 498, 6, 13, 1018323) BALIANTA, UTKAL, May 15, 1934 I hope you have not been alarmed by the changes in my life.
('63', 498, 6, 14, 1018413) They are not the result of my impatience, but are the natural outcome of my quest for Truth.
('63', 498, 6, 15, 1018506) A tour on foot is an old aspiration of mine.
('63', 498, 6, 16, 1018551) I would even like to give up completely travelling by rail or car.
('63', 498, 6, 17, 1018618) That time has not come yet, but my mind is working in that direction.
('63', 498, 6, 18, 1018688) I, therefore, have often declared that I regard railway trains, cars, etc., only as a necessary evil.
('63', 498, 6, 19, 1018790) I have never taken pleasure in travelling by them.
('63', 498, 6, 20, 1018841) Dharma does not use even a bullock cart.
('63', 498, 6, 21, 1018882) He may only limp, but ever goes forward in his journey.
('63', 498, 6, 22, 1018938) The experience of even these seven days has been wonderful.
('63', 498, 6, 23, 1018998) It is only now that I see villages and can see untouchability as it really is.
('63', 498, 6, 24, 1019077) This will also mollify the wrath of the sanatanists, but even if does not I can retain peace of mind.
('63', 498, 6, 25, 1019179) When travelling by car, I am always afraid that it might get crushed.

('63', 499, 9, 15, 1019963) 564. SPEECH AT OPENING OF TEMPLE 1
('63', 499, 10, 16, 1019998) BALIANTA, May 15, 1934
('63', 499, 11, 17, 1020021) Temples, Gandhiji said, were a reflection of the state of the society for whose use they were built.
('63', 499, 11, 18, 1020122) Temples of yore were reported to have had such a moral atmosphere round them that the worshippers felt elevated and, for the time being, shed all their evil thoughts.
('63', 499, 11, 19, 1020289) Then, one found on the temple ground primary schools for boys and girls.
('63', 499, 11, 20, 1020362) They had pandits attached to them who imparted Sanskrit learning
('63', 499, 12, 21, 1020427) 1 Extracted from Valji Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('63', 499, 12, 22, 1020475) The temple was intended for all Hindus, including untouchables
('63', 500, 0, 1, 1020538) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 501
('63', 500, 1, 2, 1020582) to seekers.
('63', 500, 1, 3, 1020594) They were an abode of refuge for the poor who would always be sure of finding shelter for the night, and they had commodious rooms or open spaces for the assembly of elders.
('63', 500, 1, 4, 1020768) That was the ideal surrounding ancient temples.
('63', 500, 1, 5, 1020816) In his wanderings, he had seen temples where one or more of the institutions he had described were to be found.
('63', 500, 1, 6, 1020928) There was no difficulty about carrying out the programme he had suggested if the trustees put forth their best effort for the realization of the simple ideal.
('63', 500, 1, 7, 1021087) Nor was there a question of large funds.
('63', 500, 1, 8, 1021128) The school might be a palm grove, the assembly hall might consist of mother earth below and open sky above.
('63', 500, 1, 9, 1021236) The question, therefore, was one of will and sufficient men of purity and strength of character.
('63', 500, 1, 10, 1021333) He hoped that such men would be forthcoming.

('63', 501, 5, 11, 1023045) May 16, 1934
('63', 501, 6, 12, 1023058) In replying to the address, Gandhiji said that, if this were true of him, 2 it would be a matter, not of praise but of reproach.
('63', 501, 6, 13, 1023187) He was a follower of Advaita or the theory of oneness of all.
('63', 501, 6, 14, 1023249) East and West, South and North were all one to him.
('63', 501, 6, 15, 1023301) How could he, sworn opponent of untouchability in every shape and form, dare to make an untouchable of the West?
('63', 501, 6, 16, 1023414) What he had really said was that it would be suicidal for them to imitate Western, or properly speaking, modern civilization, which they called Western because it came from the West.
('63', 501, 6, 17, 1023597) Modern civilization stood for indulgence, while ancient or Eastern civilization attached great importance to self denial and self restraint.
('63', 501, 6, 18, 1023738) It was, therefore, a conflict, not of East and West, but of two widely divergent philosophies of life.
('63', 501, 6, 19, 1023841) Untouchability was the worst form of exclusiveness.
('63', 501, 6, 20, 1023893) The Harijan movement was really only the first step in his programme of breaking down all barriers whatever which divided man from man.

('63', 504, 1, 2, 1028725) 572. APPEAL TO WORKERS
('63', 504, 2, 3, 1028748) The day on which I am writing this is the sixth day of the walk ing pilgrimage.
('63', 504, 2, 4, 1028828) 1 By train and motor I would have covered probably seven hundred and fifty miles and would have nominally seen 1,50,000 people at least.
('63', 504, 2, 5, 1028965) On foot I have covered not more than 40 miles, the sixth day being my silence day, and come in touch with not less than 20,000 men and women.
('63', 504, 2, 6, 1029107) My innermost feeling is that the work done is in inverse ratio to that between the artificial locomotion and the natural.
('63', 504, 2, 7, 1029229) The contact during the past five days has been more real between the villagers and myself.
('63', 504, 2, 8, 1029320) But, of these experiences, perhaps, some other time.
('63', 504, 2, 9, 1029373) The purpose of this note is to invite the co operation of the whole of India.
('63', 504, 2, 10, 1029451) It was no small thing for the Utkal leaders all of a sudden to disturb the programme, which they had prepared with elaborate care and from the fulfilment of which they had expected to realize nothing less than Rs. 30,000 even from this the poorest province in all India.
('63', 504, 2, 11, 1029722) I had certainly set my heart on Rs. 50,000. But they had no hesitation, when the truth burst upon them, in sacrificing the pecuniary gain and risking the wrath of their lieutenants.
('63', 504, 2, 12, 1029904) Nor, when I approached Dr. B. C. Roy, had he any difficulty in sacrificing the Bengal programme practically altogether.
('63', 504, 2, 13, 1030024) I expect no difficulty from the other provinces.
('63', 504, 2, 14, 1030073) I must refuse to believe that they will fail to see the superior beauty of the walking tour over that of the train and motor travel.
('63', 504, 2, 15, 1030206) But I ask for and expect much more than mere passive co ope ration.
('63', 504, 2, 16, 1030274) I invite the active co operation of all India.
('63', 504, 2, 17, 1030321) I expect the all India workers to arrange simultaneous walking tours in their own provinces for the purpose of delivering the messsage and even collecting coppers and silver pieces from the people by way of purses to be sent to me, as they would have given if I had gone to them.
('63', 504, 2, 18, 1030601) There should be more intimate touch established between the workers and the Harijans and friendlier approach to the sanatanists.
('63', 504, 2, 19, 1030730) There should be a more real appreciation of the difficulties and disa bilities of the Harijans in the villages visited.
('63', 504, 2, 20, 1030850) There should be more temples opened, more Harijan children brought to public schools.
('63', 504, 2, 21, 1030936) Let the workers and the villagers believe that, in as much as I am walking to the Utkal villages, I am walking to theirs also.
('63', 504, 2, 22, 1031063) If mine is a spiritual act, it should have that value, the people should
('63', 504, 3, 23, 1031136) 1 Gandhiji renounced the use of conveyances at Puri on May 8, 1934, and on the following day walked to Hastinapur.
('63', 504, 3, 24, 1031251) Vide also “Statement to the Press”, 8 5 1934.

('63', 506, 1, 11, 1034405) I would not hesitate even to wipe myself out, if I were convinced that the step would lead to an advance in the progress of India onwards her goal.
('63', 506, 1, 12, 1034553) My conviction on the contrary is that India will not win swaraj by depriving a single individual of his freedom of action.
('63', 506, 1, 13, 1034676) A speaker has said, I claim to bring swaraj by my single action when he says “swaraj won by one man is no good to the nation”.
('63', 506, 1, 14, 1034803) He only quotes from my own words.

('63', 506, 1, 19, 1035300) Legislative work cannot rouse the masses.

('63', 506, 1, 22, 1035472) I have no power but that of gentle persuasion.

('63', 508, 1, 2, 1038661) resolution 1 passed by the Working Committee on the eve of the Dandi March in 1930, and the preamble to that resolution contains the same thing as I have said in this statement.

A. Ansari to form a Board with Dr. M. A. Ansari as president, called the Congress Parliamentary Board, consisting of not more than 25 Congressmen.

('63', 511, 2, 6, 1046462) 577. SPEECH AT A.I.C.C. MEETING, PATNA—II 1
('63', 511, 3, 7, 1046506) May 19, 1934 It is in the fitness of things that I have been asked to move this resolution 2, for the idea of boycott of legislatures, so far as I know, had originated with me.
('63', 511, 3, 8, 1046683) I fought for years with some of my most valued comrades in the Congress for a rigid observance of that boycott, but an influential minority always thought it to be a mistake.
('63', 511, 3, 9, 1046858) When, therefore, we met in an informal conference 3 at Poona in July last year and Messrs Satyamurti and Asaf Ali came to me to lift the council entry boycott, I suggested their forming a council entry party of Congressmen.
('63', 511, 3, 10, 1047082) Let us trace the history of the boycott.
('63', 511, 3, 11, 1047123) The country accepted it in 1920, and it gave the country a new life.
('63', 511, 3, 12, 1047192) No one could miss seeing that wonderful manifestation.
('63', 511, 3, 13, 1047247) But when in 1922, civil resistance was suspended, council entry programme came and crystallized itself in the formation of the Swaraj Party which first received Congress recognition, and in 1926, took charge of the Congress organization.
('63', 511, 3, 14, 1047485) In 1929, at the instance of Pandit Motilal Nehru, leader of the Congress Party in the Assembly, the boycott of legislatures was resumed.
('63', 511, 3, 15, 1047622) But even then, there remained a body of Congressmen who did not like the resumption of boycott.
('63', 511, 3, 16, 1047718) And now that there is a virtual suspension of civil resistance, the demand for return to legislatures has resulted in the revival of the Swaraj Party under the leadership of no less a veteran ‘No changer’ than Dr. Ansari.
('63', 511, 3, 17, 1047940) I regard myself as a practical idealist.
('63', 511, 3, 18, 1047981) I shall retain my disbelief in legislatures as an instrument for obtaining swaraj in terms of masses.
('63', 511, 3, 19, 1048083) But I see that I have failed to wean some of the Congressmen
('63', 511, 4, 20, 1048144) 1 Gandhiji spoke in Hindi.
('63', 511, 4, 21, 1048171) 2 Vide the preceding item.
('63', 511, 4, 22, 1048198) 3 Vide “Speech at Leaders Conference, Poona—I”, 12 7 1933 and“Speech at Leaderonference, Poona—II”, 14 7 1933.

('63', 512, 1, 2, 1048353) from their faith in council entry.
('63', 512, 1, 3, 1048388) The question therefore is whether they should or should not enforce their desire to enter legislature as Congress representatives.
('63', 512, 1, 4, 1048519) I have no doubt that they must have the recognition they want.
('63', 512, 1, 5, 1048582) Not to give it, will be to refuse to make use of the talents we possess.
('63', 512, 1, 6, 1048655) These patriots, every whit as staunch as any of us, were idle and discontented for want of political work, strictly so called.
('63', 512, 1, 7, 1048782) Their discontent affected others, and there was a general paralysis.
('63', 512, 1, 8, 1048851) For Congressmen, as a whole, have never taken kindly to purely constructive work, such as the spinning wheel.
('63', 512, 1, 9, 1048961) I could not look at this state of things with indifference.
('63', 512, 1, 10, 1049021) When therefore Dr. Ansari wrote to me I had no hesitation in encouraging him to form a Parliamentary Party of Congressmen.
('63', 512, 1, 11, 1049144) Now that by Government sufferance we have met as lawful body, it is but meet that we give recognition to Dr. Ansari’s effort.
('63', 512, 1, 12, 1049270) Hence the resolution is before you.
('63', 512, 1, 13, 1049306) The virtual suspension of civil resistance makes the resolution doubly necessary.
('63', 512, 1, 14, 1049388) I call it virtual, because it is now strictly restricted to one individual.
('63', 512, 1, 15, 1049464) By this resolution, we create a Board which will be entrusted with the carrying on of the work inside legislatures.
('63', 512, 1, 16, 1049580) It will be an autonomous body like the All India Spinners’ Association with one difference.
('63', 512, 1, 17, 1049672) The All India Spinners’ Association is subject to no interference from the All India Congress Committee or the Congress, whilst the Parliamentary Party will be subject to the discipline of the All India Congress Committee because the latter would, from time to time, have to express its opinion on political questions cropping up in the country.
('63', 512, 1, 18, 1050018) The All India Congress Committee naturally wants its political opinion reflected through the Parliamentary Board in legislatures, and would, therefore, expect Congressmen in legislatures to voice its opinion.
('63', 512, 1, 19, 1050227) In all other respects, it will be an autonomous body.Some of the Provincial Congress Committees have expressed the view that the All India Congress Committee, instead of creating a separate Board, should itself undertake council work.
('63', 512, 1, 20, 1050462) The Working Committee considered the suggestion, and rejected it as unworkable.
('63', 512, 1, 21, 1050542) I have cherished the hope that all Congressmen do not want to enter legislatures and that all of us do not have the faith in the councils that the parliamentary minded section has.
('63', 512, 1, 22, 1050723) I have tried so far to put before you the view of the council goers.
('63', 512, 1, 23, 1050792) They hope to reap limited benefit for the nation through the councils.
('63', 512, 1, 24, 1050863) There is no doubt in my mind that the benefit would be insignificant, when compared to the energy that must be spent on it.
('63', 512, 1, 25, 1050987) The All India Congress Committee must not be an exclusively parliamentary body.
('63', 512, 1, 26, 1051067) It must represent and regulate all the national activities of the Congressmen.
('63', 512, 1, 27, 1051146) It must interest itself in the great constructive programme of 1920

('63', 513, 1, 2, 1051256) including khadi, Hindu Muslim unity, untouchability, prohibition, national education, organization of villages, village industries, and industrial labour and the like.
('63', 513, 1, 3, 1051424) The parliamentary work must be left to those who are so inclined.
('63', 513, 1, 4, 1051490) I hope that the majority will always remain untouched by the glamour of council work.
('63', 513, 1, 5, 1051576) In its own place, it will be useful.
('63', 513, 1, 6, 1051613) But the Congress will commit suicide if its attention is solely devoted to legislative work.

('63', 513, 1, 11, 1052021) I said I had no such fear.
('63', 513, 1, 12, 1052048) The ‘No changer’ must be weak of faith, if he could not survive the competition of the glittering council programme.

('63', 513, 1, 14, 1052239) The Swarajist resolution 1 at Ranchi had to be self contained, and therefore full.

('63', 513, 1, 17, 1052533) The All India Congress Committee does not need to reiterate what the Ranchi resolution was bound to do.
('63', 513, 1, 18, 1052637) The question has been asked why two members have been authorized to appoint other members.
('63', 513, 1, 19, 1052728) I have always seen that in a well regulated democracy, those who are invested with power are trusted to use that power judiciously.
('63', 513, 1, 20, 1052860) If you believe in the integrity of the two gentlemen named in the resolution, you must also have trust in them that they will appoint fully competent men on the Board.
('63', 513, 1, 21, 1053028) It would be wrong to thrust upon them members who may not co operate with them to the extent they desire.
('63', 513, 1, 22, 1053134) When we give the reins of a particular administration into the hands of somone, he should be left free to choose his own colleagues.
('63', 513, 1, 23, 1053267) The Congrees, following my advice, has made of it a convention.
('63', 513, 1, 24, 1053331) Regarding the Working Committee, I had not the courage to incorporate the rule into the Constitution, but we have learnt by experience that the convention has worked well.
('63', 513, 1, 25, 1053503) The President chooses his own colleagues.
('63', 513, 1, 26, 1053545) Your sanction to the choice has become a formal affair.
('63', 513, 1, 27, 1053601) When the Bihar Earthquake Committee met, I went a step
