('63', 515, 1, 2, 1055330) APPENDICES
('63', 515, 2, 3, 1055341) APPENDIX I RABINDRANATH TAGORE’S STATEMENT 1
('63', 515, 3, 4, 1055386) It has caused me painful surprise to find Mahatma Gandhi accusing those who blindly follow their own social custom of untouchability of having brought down God’s vengeance upon certain parts of Bihar, evidently specially selected for His desolating displeasure.
('63', 515, 3, 5, 1055648) It is all the more unfortunate because this kind of unscientific view of things is too readily accepted by a large section of our countrymen.
('63', 515, 3, 6, 1055790) I keenly feel the indignity of it when I am compelled to utter a truism in asserting that physical catastrophes have their inevitable and exclusive origin in certain combination of physical facts.
('63', 515, 3, 7, 1055987) Unless we believe in the inexorableness of the universal law in the working of which God Himself never interferes, we find it impossible to justify His ways on occasions like the one which has sorely stricken us in an overwhelming manner and scale.
('63', 515, 3, 8, 1056236) If we associate ethical principles with cosmic phenomena, we shall have to admit that human nature is morally superior to Providence that preaches its lessons in good behaviour in orgies of the worst behaviour possible.
('63', 515, 3, 9, 1056456) For we can never imagine any civilized ruler of men making indiscriminate examples of casual victims, including children and members of the untouchable community, in order to impress others dwelling at a safe distance who possibly deserve severer condemnation.
('63', 515, 3, 10, 1056717) Though we cannot point out any period of human history that is free from iniquities of the darkest kind, we still find citadels of malevolence yet remain unshaken, that the factories, that cruelly thrive upon abject poverty and the ignorace of the famished cultivators, or prison houses in all parts of the world where a penal system is pursued which, most often, is a special form of licensed criminality, still stand firm.
('63', 515, 3, 11, 1057142) It only shows that the law of gravitation does not in the least respond to the stupendous load of callousness that accumulates till the moral foundation of our society begins to show dangerous cracks and civilizations are undermined.
('63', 515, 3, 12, 1057376) What is truly tragic about it is the fact that the kind of argument that Mahatmaji used by exploiting an event of cosmic disturbance far better suits the psychology of his opponents than his own, and it would not have surprised me at all if they had taken this opportunity of holding him and his followers responsible for the visitation of Divine anger.
('63', 515, 3, 13, 1057730) As for us, we feel perfectly secure in the faith that our own sins and errors, however enormous, have not enough force to drag down the structure of creation to ruins.
('63', 515, 3, 14, 1057898) We can depend upon it, sinners and saints, bigots and breakers of conventions.
('63', 515, 3, 15, 1057977) We, who are immensely grateful to Mahatmaji for inducing, by his wonder working inspiration, freedom from fear and feebleness in the minds of his countrymen, feel profoundly hurt when any words from his mouth may emphasize the elements of unreason in those very minds— unreason, which is a fundamental source of all the blind powers that drive us against freedom and self respect.
('63', 515, 3, 16, 1058358) Harijan, 16 2 1934
('63', 515, 4, 17, 1058377) 1 Vide “Letter to Rabindranath Tagore”, 2 2 1934 and “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 13 2 1934.
('63', 516, 0, 1, 1058472) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 517
('63', 516, 1, 2, 1058516) APPENDIX II
('63', 516, 2, 3, 1058528) BACKGROUND TO “LETTER TO SIR SAMUEL HOARE” WITH EXTRACTS FROM AN INRODUCTION BY HORACE ALEXANDER 1
('63', 516, 3, 4, 1058627) When Mr. Gandhi was returning to India at the end of the Second Round Table Conference in December 1931, he visited Rome.
('63', 516, 3, 5, 1058749) It may be recalled that, just as he was leaving Italy for India, he was reported by The Times correspondent in Rome to have given a sensational interview to the Giornale d’Italia.
('63', 516, 3, 6, 1058929) Denials and counter denials followed, Mr. Gandhi was soon afterwards imprisoned, and the public were left to draw their own conclusions.
('63', 516, 4, 7, 1059066) In view of all that has happened since, this affair may seem trivial today .
('63', 516, 4, 8, 1059143) But it wrought great mischief at the time, and such mischief may subconsciously continue to affect judgments.
('63', 516, 4, 9, 1059253) Accordingly it seems necessary that now at last .
('63', 516, 4, 10, 1059303) an exact statement of the truth should be made available.
('63', 516, 5, 11, 1059361) In republishing the statements from The Times together with Mr. Gandhi’s recent letter on the subject to Sir Samuel Hoare, it has seemed desirable to prefix a statement on the circumstances under which Mr. Gandhi left England.
('63', 516, 5, 12, 1059588) For the Rome interview gained credence in England largely because it seemed to fit in with some of the things Mr. Gandhi had said just at the close of the Conference in London.
('63', 516, 5, 13, 1059765) After listening to the Prime Minister’s declaration of policy, Mr. Gandhi had questioned whether a new “parting of the ways” had been reached; he had also spoken of the “hidden meanings” in the Prime Minister’s statement.
('63', 516, 5, 14, 1059987) What did these phrases indicate?
('63', 516, 5, 15, 1060020) Did the Rome interview provide the answer?
('63', 516, 5, 16, 1060063) (Those who were in Mr. Gandhi’s confidence during the last days of his stay in London know that there was no such connection, for certain decisive private conversations had intervened.)
('63', 516, 6, 17, 1060249) There were in fact two matters that were specially occupying Mr. Gandhi’s mind during the last days of the Conference: the question of India’s public debt, and the fresh measures just taken by the Govt.
('63', 516, 6, 18, 1060452) of India for destroying terrorism in Bengal.
('63', 516, 7, 19, 1060497) However, before he left England he had conversations with the Prime Minister and with Sir Samuel Hoare.
('63', 516, 7, 20, 1060601) These conversations reassured him.
('63', 516, 7, 21, 1060636) He understood that if he accepted membership of the small representative working committee to be appointed in India, he could raise the question of India’s public debt there.
('63', 516, 7, 22, 1060811) As to Bengal, the Govt.
('63', 516, 7, 23, 1060835) of India was free to decide with whom they would discuss their administrative measures.
('63', 516, 7, 24, 1060923) The India Office was not closing either door.
('63', 516, 8, 25, 1060969) Finally, on the eve of his departure from England, Mr. Gandhi solemnly assured his friends that he would do all he could to keep the door of negotiation open.
('63', 516, 8, 26, 1061128) Though he admitted that for him the Conference in London had been, indeed, a “long and slow agony” he still hoped to find a peaceful solution of the outstanding problems.
('63', 516, 9, 27, 1061299) 1 Vide “Letter to Hiralal Sharma”, 6 3 1934.
('63', 517, 0, 1, 1061344) 518 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 517, 2, 2, 1061386) THE INTERVIEW
('63', 517, 3, 3, 1061400) ‘A NEW TRADE BOYCOTT’
('63', 517, 4, 4, 1061422) The Rome correspondent of The Times writes on December 15, 1931: Mr. Gandhi, who had refused to make any statements to the many journalists, both Italian and foreign, who had been invited to meet him, has now made a long statement to Signor Gayda of the Giornale d’Italia.
('63', 517, 4, 5, 1061695) Mr. Gandhi said that the Round Table Conference, which “marked the definite rupture of relations between the Indian nation and the British Government” had been for Indians a long and slow agony.
('63', 517, 4, 6, 1061890) It had, however, served to make quite clear to the British authorities the spirit of the Indian nation and its leaders and to test the true intentions of England.
('63', 517, 4, 7, 1062053) He was returning to India in order to restart at once his struggle against England, which was to take the form of passive resistance and the boycott of British goods.
('63', 517, 4, 8, 1062220) He considered that the boycott would now prove a powerful means of rendering more acute the British crisis, already difficult through the devaluation of the currency and unemployment.
('63', 517, 4, 9, 1062404) The closing of the Indian market to all British products would signify substantially a reduction of English industrial activity, an increase of unemployment, and a new depreciation of the pound.
('63', 517, 4, 10, 1062599) Mr. Gandhi concluded his remarks by lamenting that few European countries had hitherto shown interest in the Indian problem.
('63', 517, 4, 11, 1062724) That was a pity, since an independent and prosperous India would mean a richer market for the products of other nations and Indian freedom would be manifested through commercial and intellectual exchanges with all countries.
('63', 517, 5, 12, 1062949) GANDHIJI REFUTES
('63', 517, 6, 13, 1062966) The Times of December 18, 1931, publishes the following: Mr. Gandhi has authorized a complete denial of the authenticity of an inter view which he was alleged to have given to the Giornale d’Italia during his brief stay in Rome, and which was summarized in The Times of December 15. The statement attributed to him went so much farther in respect of the prospect of restarting civil disobedience in India than any previous utterance that it was felt necessary to ascertain precisely what he said.
('63', 517, 6, 14, 1063463) Accordingly a telegram was sent from an authori tative quarter to Mr. Gandhi on board the Italian liner Pilsna in the Mediterranean in the following terms: Press reports state that on embarkment, you issued to Giornale d’Italia a statement which contained expressions such as following: (1) Round Table Conference marked a definite rupture of relations between Indian nation and British Government.
('63', 517, 6, 15, 1063862) (2) You are returning to India in order to restart at once struggle against England.
('63', 517, 6, 16, 1063947) (3) Boycott would now prove powerful means of rendering more acute British crisis.
('63', 517, 6, 17, 1064030) (4) We will not pay taxes, we will not work for England in any way, we will
('63', 518, 0, 1, 1064106) VOL. 63 : 18 JANUARY, 1934 19 MAY, 1934 519
('63', 518, 1, 2, 1064150) completely isolate British authorities, their politics and their institutions, and we will totally boycott all British goods.
('63', 518, 1, 3, 1064276) Some of your friends here think you must have been misreported, and, if so, denial desirable.
('63', 518, 1, 4, 1064370) GANDHIJI’S REPLY
('63', 518, 2, 5, 1064387) The following telegraphic reply was received from Mr. Gandhi yesterday: “Giornale d’Italia statement is wholly false.
('63', 518, 2, 6, 1064505) I never gave any interview to Pressmen at Rome.
('63', 518, 2, 7, 1064553) Last interview I gave was to Reuter at Villeneuve in Switzerland, where I asked the people of India not to come to hasty decision but to await my statement.
('63', 518, 2, 8, 1064710) I shall take no precipitate action but shall make ample previous entreaty to the authorities should direct action become unfortunately necessary.
('63', 518, 2, 9, 1064856) Please give this statement the widest publicity possible.” SIGNOR GAYDA’S REAFFIRMATION
('63', 518, 3, 10, 1064944) The following appears in The Times of December 21, 1931: Signor Gayda has resolutely refused to accept Mr. Gandhi’s denial of the statements attributed to him in the Giornale d’Italia.
('63', 518, 3, 11, 1065129) In a laconic note Signor Gayda has declared that the words attributed by him to the Mahatma were written in his presence as he spoke them and in the presence of other witnesses.
('63', 518, 3, 12, 1065307) So far as I understood the facts of the case, the “demanti” of Mr. Gandhi may be correct in so far as Signor Gayda did not request a formal “interview”, and no such “interview” was granted.
('63', 518, 3, 13, 1065497) According to information given to me, Signor Gayda was introduced to the Mahatma in a private house, and it was made perfectly clear to Mr. Gandhi who Signor Gayda was.
('63', 518, 3, 14, 1065666) When Mr. Gandhi began to make the remarkable statements attributed to him Signor Gayda, realizing their interest and anxious to make no mistake, asked for a pencil and paper, which were given to him.
('63', 518, 3, 15, 1065866) Signor Gayda then wrote down the statements of Mr. Gandhi there and then in his presence and in that of a follower, without any word being spoken by either of them that the remarks were not for publication.
('63', 518, 3, 16, 1066073) It would appear, therefore, from the version I have received that so far as the substance of the remarks is concerned Signor Gayda, who, as I personally can testify, understands English quite well, took down the utterance of the Mahatma with particular care.
('63', 518, 3, 17, 1066332) MIRABEHN’S RECOLLECTION
('63', 518, 4, 18, 1066356) My recollection of the occasion, which occurred now two years and three months ago, is as follows: Gandhiji with his companions was invited to an informal gathering at the house of an Italian Countess in Rome, friend of the Italian Consul, Bombay (then in Rome).
('63', 518, 4, 19, 1066619) It was a long visit consisting of a drawing room talk followed by light refreshments and further general conversation.
('63', 518, 4, 20, 1066738) During the beginning of the visit I was the only member of our party with Gandhiji, the others dropping in later one after another.
('63', 518, 4, 21, 1066870) I was with Gandhiji during the whole visit except for 15 or 20 minutes near the end of the time when I went into the dining room to prepare some fruits, etc., for Gandhiji and to take some refreshment myself.
('63', 519, 0, 1, 1067079) 520 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 519, 1, 2, 1067121) During the talk as far as I can now remember, the conversation was, to begin with, somewhat social and varied.
('63', 519, 1, 3, 1067232) The Countess was busy introducing people to Gandhiji and leading off conversations on various topics.
('63', 519, 1, 4, 1067334) As the talk warmed up two or three gentlemen from amongst the group became conspicuous by their persistent questioning on the political and economic situation, and I remember one of them asking for a pencil and paper and beginning to make notes.
('63', 519, 1, 5, 1067580) After a little while the rest of our company began to turn up and we soon moved into a bigger room next to the dining room.
('63', 519, 1, 6, 1067704) Here the conversation again became general except for a little serious talk of Gandhiji with someone, the particulars of which I cannot now remember.
('63', 519, 1, 7, 1067854) I heard every word that Gandhiji uttered except for the few minutes I had gone out.
('63', 519, 1, 8, 1067938) He was giving his usual replies to political and economic questions with rather extra force and plainness of language because of the difficulty the Italian gentlemen felt in understanding English and because of the persistence of the questioners.
('63', 519, 1, 9, 1068185) If Gandhiji had said some of the things attributed to him by The Times correspondent I should have been dumbfounded.
('63', 519, 1, 10, 1068302) It would have meant that he had thrown his ideals and beliefs to the winds, and I could no longer have looked to him as my guide and father.

('63', 519, 3, 12, 1068475) APPENDIX III
('63', 519, 4, 13, 1068488) PYARELAL’S NOTE ON GANDHIJI’S VIEWS 1
('63', 519, 5, 14, 1068526) [On or after April 4, 1934]2
('63', 519, 6, 15, 1068555) The present step is a logical corollary of the Poona decision.
('63', 519, 6, 16, 1068618) When mass civil disobedience was suspended in August last under the Poona resolution it was expected that all those who could should offer individual resistance.
('63', 519, 6, 17, 1068780) The idea was that they should keep the spark of satyagraha alive till under favourable circumstances the movement could again develop white heat.
('63', 519, 6, 18, 1068926) It was assumed that those who took to it were capable of developing independent inspiration and could go on indefinitely without any outside direction or guidance and in such an ideal manner what was lost in numbers would be more than made up by gain in quality.
('63', 519, 6, 19, 1069189) Experience, however, has shown that the assumption made was unwarranted.
('63', 519, 6, 20, 1069262) Those who went in had not assimilated the spirit of satyagraha fully.
('63', 519, 6, 21, 1069332) Almost to a man the individual civil resisters who were in the field were fighting because they felt that they ought to, not because they must.
('63', 519, 6, 22, 1069476) Those who came out showed no impatience to rush back.
('63', 519, 6, 23, 1069530) Instead they hesitated and faltered.
('63', 519, 6, 24, 1069567) Even the best ones instead of feeling spiritually exhilarated had experienced mental anguish in prison.
('63', 519, 6, 25, 1069671) No good can come out of sacrifice that is forced instead of being spontaneous and natural.
('63', 519, 6, 26, 1069762) Under the circumstances Bapu felt that the continuation of individual civil resistance would only result in internal decay.
('63', 519, 6, 27, 1069886) For coercive effect it was too insignificant; for spiritual effect too cumbersome and heterogeneous.

('63', 520, 1, 2, 1070289) proved inadequate for producing immediate political results it failed to satisfy the patriotic instinct of the terrorist, and because its quality was indifferent it failed to touch the spirit of his idealism which craved for intenser and intenser forms of self expression and self sacrifice.
('63', 520, 1, 3, 1070581) The present step is an essay on Bapu’s part, to purify and intensify the ideal of satyagraha to the last degree.
('63', 520, 1, 4, 1070694) There was danger of indifferent numbers smothering the flame of his individual satyagraha when it should burn the brightest and of diluting its potency.
('63', 520, 1, 5, 1070847) Unadulterated by numbers it should prove more efficacious.
('63', 520, 1, 6, 1070906) Even as it is, Bapu feels that it would be possible to put thousands of civil resisters in the field, if not today, in the very near future.
('63', 520, 1, 7, 1071047) Of that his experience of the present Harijan tour has left him in no doubt.
('63', 520, 1, 8, 1071124) But now he has discovered that for a successful fight the plan of civil disobedience as it has been practised so far would have to be radically modified and extended.
('63', 520, 1, 9, 1071291) In what way he cannot say at present.
('63', 520, 1, 10, 1071329) We have not succeeded in harnessing the classes to our cause.
('63', 520, 1, 11, 1071391) They have uniformly failed to rise to the occasion and unsupported by the classes the masses have been overwhelmed.
('63', 520, 1, 12, 1071507) In other words Bapu has suddenly discovered that we were advancing into a blind alley.
('63', 520, 1, 13, 1071594) It was absolutely essential to retrace the steps.
('63', 520, 1, 14, 1071644) Even if all had gone well with the mass movement this reorientation of the strategy should have been inevitable sooner or later.
('63', 520, 1, 15, 1071773) That being so, Bapu is anxious to save to the utmost the remnants of his disorganized force and give the country time to reorganize, rest and recuperate.
('63', 520, 1, 16, 1071927) He remained the ideal satyagrahi.
('63', 520, 1, 17, 1071961) Because the next fight, as Bapu conceives, must be planned on a different pattern.
('63', 520, 1, 18, 1072044) Bapu would not like even a perfect satyagrahi today to go on.
('63', 520, 1, 19, 1072106) To do so would be wasteful.
('63', 520, 1, 20, 1072134) It would be, to use his own simile, like cashing a good cheque at the wrong bank, at the wrong time.
('63', 520, 1, 21, 1072235) As far back as August 1933 the feeling had come upon him that there was something internally wrong in the movement somewhere.
('63', 520, 1, 22, 1072361) But at that time, first owing to the quick succession of his fasts and then owing to the Harijan tour, he could not analyse that feeling further.
('63', 520, 1, 23, 1072507) “The step I have taken today ought to have been taken after the Poona Pact.
('63', 520, 1, 24, 1072583) That was the right time for it,” he remarked the other day.
('63', 520, 1, 25, 1072643) “The arrest of every worker since then has jarred upon me.
('63', 520, 1, 26, 1072702) But I have ignorantly allowed things to drift like an improvident speculator who fails to pull himself up when every fresh deal would make the chance of his ultimate solvency more and more remote.” On another occasion he said, “by allowing my best men to go now I would only be bargaining for the survival of the unfittest.
('63', 520, 1, 27, 1073026) The fittest would be reduced to utter wrecks for want of a proper grounding, leaving the field a barren waste after I am gone”.
('63', 520, 1, 28, 1073154) Instead, therefore, of making a holocaust of his old guard he has chosen to release the civil disobedience forces that were lying locked up owing to the present stalemate to combat in whatever ways it might be possible the fresh rivets that are being sought to be fastened upon the country.
('63', 520, 1, 29, 1073445) In the mean time he himself would be active in his laboratory making fresh researches in satyagraha.
('63', 520, 1, 30, 1073546) And given time and God’s grace he expects to discover a weapon that would give us what we have lacked so far.
('63', 520, 1, 31, 1073656) Let it be noted here that what Gandhiji has said about the imperfection of satyagrahis in connection with individual civil resistance does not apply to all that has taken place before the Poona resolution.
('63', 520, 1, 32, 1073862) Perfect satyagraha was essential for individual resistance, not for mass resistance.
('63', 520, 1, 33, 1073947) The mistake lay in sanctioning
('63', 521, 0, 1, 1073978) 522 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('63', 521, 1, 2, 1074020) individual civil resistance when perfect satyagrahis were not forthcoming.
('63', 521, 1, 3, 1074095) If the mass civil disobedience had to be started tomorrow we would not have to wait for perfect satyagrahis.
('63', 521, 1, 4, 1074204) There is therefore no cause to feel despondent about the future of mass satyagraha; because perfection is not a sine qua non of mass civil disobedience.
('63', 521, 2, 5, 1074357) The freedom to offer civil resistance for specific purposes is there.
('63', 521, 2, 6, 1074427) But an early or extensive exercise of it is not envisaged.
('63', 521, 2, 7, 1074486) The country has to pass through a period of darkness, depression and reaction.
('63', 521, 2, 8, 1074565) But Bapu has faith that there is sufficient vitality in the nation to enable it to pull itself through the morass.
('63', 521, 2, 9, 1074680) The length of the period of recuperation can be curtailed by the civil resisters of today deporting themselves as ideal constructive workers and using all the energy set free from the civil resistance to free the country from the paralysis that has overtaken it, instead of allowing it to be dissipated by despondency or self indulgence.
('63', 521, 2, 10, 1075018) Here I may add that just now Bapu’s mind is teeming with fresh constructive projects.
('63', 521, 2, 11, 1075104) He contemplates covering [the country] with new institutions and organizations that would be based not on ideals adulterated with heavy doses of compromise as was the case with our old institutions but would be erected on pure unwatered principles.
('63', 521, 2, 12, 1075353) The old institutions were good enough for their time but institutions that we now need to carry us over the remaining stage of our journey need to be differently patterned.
('63', 521, 2, 13, 1075526) It is good therefore in a way that old institutions have disappeared leaving the ground clear for the rise of new ones.
('63', 521, 3, 14, 1075646) Lastly it should be remembered that the fight for independence has not been given up.
('63', 521, 3, 15, 1075732) Civil disobedience has not been suspended.
('63', 521, 3, 16, 1075775) It remains the official programme of the Congress.
('63', 521, 3, 17, 1075826) If the Government will not tolerate the sanction of civil disobedience by the Congress even when it was confined to Bapu alone and foreclosed to everyone else, it would be best for the Congress to remain under suspension.
('63', 521, 3, 18, 1076048) Dr. Ansari, Bhulabhai and Dr. Roy have agreed that the Congress must not repudiate Bapu’s civil resistance, come what may.
('63', 521, 3, 19, 1076171) For to do so would spell death to the Congress.
('63', 521, 3, 20, 1076219) If, however, the Government recognizes civil disobedience as a legitimate political weapon by restoring the Congress unconditionally after Bapu’s latest statement, it would be open to the Congress to adopt the Council programme while recognizing civil disobedience as an alternative weapon.
('63', 521, 4, 21, 1076510) The conditions about the resumption of civil disobedience during Gandhiji’s lifetime for the attainment of swaraj should not worry an intelligent satyagrahi.
('63', 521, 4, 22, 1076668) It should be realized that owing to the self imposed restrictions by Gandhiji during the year of grace several things had to be left unsaid in his statement.
('63', 521, 4, 23, 1076826) There is nothing whatever in that statement to prevent the nation from launching upon individual civil resistance of the direct and the most extensive type to secure Gandhiji’s release, for instance, if the authorities should choose to indefinitely incarcerate him.
('63', 521, 4, 24, 1077092) Even in 1930 mass fight had that for culminating point.
